eg \paren {p \lor 
eg p}|1|7}} {{DoubleNegElimination |9||p \lor 
eg p|8}} {{EndTableau}} {{Qed}}

statement: If two [[Definition:Square Matrix|square matrices of order $n > 1$]] over a [[Definition:Ring with Unity|ring with unity]] $R$ are [[Definition:Matrix Equivalence|equivalent]], they are not necessarily [[Definition:Matrix Similarity|similar]].
rationale: As a counterexample, let $\mathbf A = \mathbf I_n$ be the [[Definition:Unit Matrix|unit matrix]] of order $n > 1$. Let $\mathbf B$ be any [[Definition:Invertible Matrix|invertible matrix]] over $R$ of order $n$ that is different from the [[Definition:Unit Matrix|unit matrix]]. Then [[Definition:Matrix Equivalence|$\mathbf A \equiv \mathbf B$]], as: :$\mathbf I_n^{-1} \mathbf A \mathbf B = \mathbf I_n^{-1} \mathbf I_n \mathbf B = \mathbf B$. If $\mathbf P$ is an invertible [[Definition:Square Matrix|square matrix]] of order $n$, then: :$\mathbf P^{-1} \mathbf A \mathbf P = \mathbf P^{-1} \mathbf P = \mathbf I_n \ne \mathbf B$ Hence, $\mathbf A$ is not [[Definition:Matrix Similarity|similar]] to $\mathbf B$. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\R\) be the [[Definition:Real Number|real numbers]] with the [[Definition:Usual Ordering|usual ordering]]. Let \(n \in \N_{>0}\). Let \(f: \R \to \R\) be defined by: :\(\map f x = x^n\) Then \(f\) is [[Definition:Unbounded Above Real-Valued Function|unbounded above]].
rationale: If \(n = 1\), then \(f\) is the [[Definition:Identity Mapping|identity function]]. By the [[Archimedean Principle]], the [[Definition:Real Number|real numbers]] are [[Definition:Unbounded Above Subset of Real Numbers|unbounded above]]. Thus by definition of the [[Definition:Identity Mapping|identity function]]: \(f\) is [[Definition:Unbounded Above Real-Valued Function|unbounded above]]. {{qed|lemma}} Let \(n \ge 2\). {{AimForCont}} that \(f\) is [[Definition:Bounded Above Subset of Real Numbers|bounded above]] by \(b \in \R\). {{WLOG}} suppose that \(b > 0\). Then by the definition of an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Subset of Real Numbers|upper bound]]: :\(\forall x \in \R: x^n \le b\) Let \(x > b\). Then: :\(\dfrac {x^n - b} {x - b} \le 0\) By the [[Mean Value Theorem]], there exists a point \(p\) between \(b\) and \(x\) such that: :\(\map {f'} p = \dfrac {x^n - b} {x - b}\) By [[Power Rule for Derivatives/Natural Number Index|Derivative of Power]]: :\(\map {f'} p = n p^{n - 1}\) Therefore \(n p^{n - 1} \le 0\). By [[Power of Strictly Positive Real Number is Strictly Positive/Positive Integer|Power of Strictly Positive Real Number is Positive]] and [[Positive Real Numbers Closed under Multiplication]] it follows that: :\(p > 0 \implies n p^{n - 1} > 0\) But this is impossible because it was previously established that \(p \ge b > 0\). From this [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that there can be no such \(b\). Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {R, +, \circ, \le}\) be a [[Definition:Totally Ordered Ring|totally ordered ring]] without [[Definition:Proper Zero Divisor|proper zero divisors]] whose [[Definition:Ring Zero|zero]] is \(0_R\). Let \(x, y \in R\) be [[Definition:Positive|positive]], that is, \(0_R \le x, y\). Then \(x \le y \iff x \circ x \le y \circ y\). That is, the [[Definition:Square Mapping|square mapping]] is an [[Definition:Order Embedding|order embedding]] of \(\struct {R_{\ge 0}, \le}\) into itself. When \(R\) is one of the standard [[Definition:Number|sets of numbers]] \(\Z, \Q, \R\), then this translates into: :If \(x, y\) are [[Definition:Positive Number|positive]], then \(x \le y \iff x^2 \le y^2\).

$
eg \left({p \land q}ight) \vdash

statement: The corresponding proof::[[File:Area Equal.jpg]] Refer to the figure. Construct a [[Definition:Circle|circle]] with [[Definition:Radius of Circle|radius]] r and [[Definition:Circumference of Circle|circumference]] $c$, where its [[Definition:Area|area]] is denoted by $C$. Construct a [[Definition:Triangle (Geometry)|triangle]] with [[Definition:Altitude of Triangle|height]] r and [[Definition:Base of Triangle|base]] $c$, where its area is denoted by $T$.
rationale: === Lemma 1: $T = \pi r^2$ === {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = T       | r = \frac {r c} 2       | c = [[Area of Triangle in Terms of Side and Altitude]] }} {{eqn | r = \frac {r 2 \pi r} 2       | c = [[Perimeter of Circle]] }} {{eqn | r = \pi r^2 }} {{end-eqn}} {{qed|lemma}} === Lemma 2: $T \ge C$ === :[[File:Area Smaller.jpg]] {{AimForCont}} $T < C$. It should be possible to construct a [[Definition:Regular Polygon|regular polygon]] with area $P$, where $T < P < C$. For any given regular polygon: :$P = \dfrac {h q} 2$ where: :$q$ is the [[Definition:Perimeter|perimeter]] of the polygon :$h$ is the height of any given triangular part of it :$P$ is the area.   On one hand: :$P > T \implies \dfrac {h q} 2 > \dfrac {r c} 2$ On the other hand: :$0 < h < r \land 0 < q < c \implies \dfrac {h q} 2 < \dfrac {r c} 2$ Hence a contradiction is obtained. Hence $\neg T < C$. Hence $T \ge C$. {{qed|lemma}} === Lemma 3: $T \le C$ === :[[File:Area Greater.jpg]] {{AimForCont}} $T > C$. It should be possible to construct a [[Definition:Regular Polygon|regular polygon]] with area $P$, where $C < P < T$. From [[Area of Polygon by Inradius and Perimeter]]: :$P = \dfrac {h q} 2$ where: :$q$ is the [[Definition:Perimeter|perimeter]] of the [[Definition:Regular Polygon|regular polygon]] :$h$ is the [[Definition:Inradius of Polygon|inradius]] of the [[Definition:Regular Polygon|regular polygon]] :$P$ is the [[Definition:Area|area]]. as each triangle has the base $B = \dfrac q n$ and area $A = \dfrac {h q} {2 n}$ and with $n$ triangles we get $P = \dfrac {h q} 2$ {{improve|Better to link to the result which demonstrates this. The redlink [[Area of Polygon by Inradius and Perimeter]] opens up the result which is to be linked to. Note that first it needs to be established that a polygon can indeed be divided into $n$ congruent isosceles triangles, as far as I know this has not yet been done.}} On one hand: :$P < T \implies \dfrac {h q} 2 < \dfrac {r c} 2$ On the other hand: :$0 < h = r \land 0 < c < q \implies \dfrac {h q} 2 > \dfrac {r c} 2$ Hence a contradiction is obtained. Hence $\neg T > C$. Hence $T \le C$. {{qed|lemma}} === Final Proof === :$T \ge C$ (from Lemma 2) :$T \le C$ (from Lemma 3) :$\therefore T \mathop = C$ :$\therefore C \mathop = T \mathop = \pi r^2$ (from Lemma 1) {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {X, \preceq, \tau}\) be a [[Definition:Linearly Ordered Space|linearly ordered space]]. Then \(X\) is [[Definition:Dedekind Complete|Dedekind complete]] {{iff}} every closed, bounded subset of \(X\) is [[Definition:Compact Subspace|compact]].
rationale: The forward implication follows from [[Heine-Borel Theorem/Dedekind-Complete Space|Heine-Borel Theorem: Dedekind-Complete Space]]. Suppose that \(X\) is not Dedekind complete. Then \(X\) has a non-empty subset \(S\) with an upper bound \(b\) in \(X\) but no supremum in \(X\). Let \(a \in S\) and let \(Y = {\bar \downarrow} S \cap {\bar \uparrow} a\). \(Y\) is nonempty and bounded below by \(a\) and above by \(b\). === \(Y\) is closed in \(X\) === Let \(x \in X \setminus Y\). Then \(x \prec a\) or \(x\) strictly succeeds every element of \(S\). If \(x \prec a\), then \(x \in {\downarrow} a \subseteq X \setminus Y\). If \(x\) strictly succeeds each element of \(S\), then it is an upper bound of \(S\). Since \(S\) has no supremum in \(X\), it has an upper bound \(p \prec x\). Then \(x \in {\uparrow p} \subseteq X \setminus Y\). {{explain|What does {\downarrow} a and {\uparrow p} mean?}} ===  \(Y\) is not compact === Let \(\AA = \set { {\downarrow} s: s \in  S}\). Then \(\AA\) is an open cover of \(Y\) with no finite subcover. {{qed}} [[Category:Order Topology]] [[Category:Compact Spaces]] 2ze14h1qxh81mb7rrsz45wixi8rqibh

statement: Let \land denote the [[Definition:Conjunction|conjunction operation]] of [[Definition:Propositional Logic|propositional logic]]. Then there exists no [[Definition:Binary Logical Connective|binary logical connective]] \circ such that: :(1): \quad \forall p, q \in \left\{{T, F}\right\}: \left({p \land q}\right) \circ q = p
rationale: This will be [[Proof by Contradiction|proven by contradiction]]. Let such an operation \circ exist. Let f^\circ: \mathbb B^2 \to \mathbb B be the associated [[Definition:Truth Function|truth function]]. Suppose now that q = F, while p remains unspecified. Then: :p \land q = f^\land \left({p, F}\right) = F where f^\land is the [[Definition:Truth Function|truth function]] of [[Definition:Conjunction|conjunction]]. It does not matter what p is, for: :f^\land \left({T, F}\right) = f^\land \left({F, F}\right) = F Hence, for \left({p \land q}\right) \circ q = p to hold, f^\circ must satisfy: :f^\circ \left({F, F}\right) = p However, because p could still be either T or F, this identity cannot always hold. Therefore, \circ cannot exist. {{qed}} [[Category:Conjunction]] iz8xrrjo16at5wz9wiqbjhnuzh6k4nl

statement: Let \(\struct {S, \preceq}\) be an [[Definition:Ordered Set|ordered set]]. Suppose that there is no [[Definition:Infinite Sequence|infinite sequence]] \(\sequence {a_n}\) of [[Definition:Element|elements]] of \(S\) such that \(\forall n \in \N: a_{n + 1} \prec a_n\). Then \(\struct {S, \preceq}\) is [[Definition:Well-Founded|well-founded]].
rationale: Suppose \(\struct {S, \preceq}\) is not [[Definition:Well-Founded|well-founded]]. So by definition there exists a [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] \(T\) of \(S\) which has no [[Definition:Minimal Element|minimal element]]. Let \(a \in T\). Since \(a\) is not minimal in \(T\), we can find \(b \in T: b \prec a\). Since this holds for all \(a \in T\), \(\prec \restriction_{T \times T}\), the [[Definition:Restriction of Relation|restriction]] of \(\prec\) to \(T \times T\), is a [[Definition:Right-Total Relation|right-total]] [[Definition:Endorelation|endorelation]] on \(T\). So, by the [[Axiom:Axiom of Dependent Choice/Right-Total|Axiom of Dependent Choice]], it follows that there is an [[Definition:Sequence|infinite sequence]] \(\sequence {a_n}\) in \(T\) such that \(\forall n \in \N: a_{n + 1} \prec a_n\). {{qed|lemma}}

statement: Let \(\struct {S, \preceq}\) be an [[Definition:Ordered Set|ordered set]]. Suppose that there is no [[Definition:Infinite Sequence|infinite sequence]] \(\sequence {a_n}\) of [[Definition:Element|elements]] of \(S\) such that: :\(\forall n \in \N: a_{n + 1} \prec a_n\) Then \(\struct {S, \preceq}\) is [[Definition:Well-Founded|well-founded]].
rationale: Suppose \(\struct {S, \preceq}\) is not [[Definition:Well-Founded|well-founded]]. Let \(T \subseteq S\) have no [[Definition:Minimal Element|minimal element]]. Let \(a_0 \in T\). We have that \(a_0\) is not [[Definition:Minimal Element|minimal]] in \(T\). So: :\(\exists a_1 \in T: a_1 \prec a_0\) Similarly, \(a_1\) is not [[Definition:Minimal Element|minimal]] in \(T\). So: :\(\exists a_2 \in T: a_2 \prec a_1\) Let \(a_{k + 1}\) be an arbitrary element for which \(a_{k + 1} \prec a_k\). In order to allow this to be possible in the infinite case, it is necessary to invoke the [[Axiom:Axiom of Dependent Choice/Right-Total|Axiom of Dependent Choice]] as follows: Let \(a_k \in T\). Then as \(a_k\) is not [[Definition:Minimal Element|minimal]] in \(T\): :\(\exists a_{k + 1} \in T: a_{k + 1} \prec a_k\) Hence by definition \(\prec\) is a [[Definition:Right-Total Relation|right-total relation]]. So, by the [[Axiom:Axiom of Dependent Choice/Right-Total|Axiom of Dependent Choice]], it follows that: :\(\forall n \in \N: \exists a_n \in T: a_{n + 1} \prec a_n\) Thus we have been able to construct an [[Definition:Sequence|infinite sequence]] \(\sequence {a_n}\) in \(T\) such that: :\(\forall n \in \N: a_{n + 1} \prec a_n\). It follows by the [[Rule of Transposition]] that if there is no [[Definition:Infinite Sequence|infinite sequence]] \(\sequence {a_n}\) of [[Definition:Element|elements]] of \(S\) such that: :\(\forall n \in \N: a_{n + 1} \prec a_n\) then \(\struct {S, \preceq}\) is [[Definition:Well-Founded|well-founded]]. {{qed|lemma}}

statement: Let \(\struct {S, \preceq_1}\) be a [[Definition:Totally Ordered Set|totally ordered set]] and let \(\struct {T, \preceq_2}\) be an [[Definition:Ordered Set|ordered set]]. Let \(\phi: S \to T\) be a [[Definition:Strictly Increasing Mapping|strictly increasing mapping]]. Then \(\phi\) is an [[Definition:Order Embedding|order embedding]].
rationale: Let \(\phi\) be [[Definition:Strictly Increasing Mapping|strictly increasing]]. Let \(\map \phi x \preceq_2 \map \phi y\). As \(\struct {S, \prec_1}\) is a [[Definition:Strictly Totally Ordered Set|strictly totally ordered set]]: :Either \(y \prec_1 x\), \(y = x\), or \(x \prec_1 y\). {{AimForCont}} that \(y \prec_1 x\). By the definition of a strictly increasing mapping: :\(\map \phi y \prec_2 \map \phi x\) which [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the fact that \(\map \phi x \preceq_2 \map \phi y\). Therefore \(y \nprec_1 x\). Thus \(y = x\), or \(x \prec_1 y\), so \(x \preceq_1 y\). Hence: :\(\map \phi x \preceq_2 \map \phi y \iff x \preceq_1 y\) and \(\phi\) has been proved to be an [[Definition:Order Embedding|order embedding]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\FF\) be an [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set|ultrafilter]] on \(Y\). For \(S \in \FF\), let \(\map f S = \inf S\). Let \(p = \sup \map f \FF\). {{improve|perhaps directly use \(p :{{=}} \ds \sup_{S \mathop \in \FF} \inf S\)?}} Then \(\FF\) converges to \(p\):
rationale: === Upward rays === Let \(a \in X\) with \(a \prec p\). Since \(\FF\) is an [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set|ultrafilter]], either \(Y \cap {\uparrow} a \in \FF\) or \(Y \cap {\bar \downarrow} a \in \FF\). {{AimForCont}} that \(Y \cap {\bar \downarrow} a \in \FF\). For each \(S \in \FF\): :\(S \cap {\bar \downarrow} a \in \FF\) because an ultrafilter is a [[Definition:Filter on Set|filter]]. {{explain|Mention that \(S \cap (Y \cap {\bar \downarrow} a) {{=}} S \cap {\bar \downarrow} a\) is used}} :\(S \cap {\bar \downarrow} a \ne \O\) because a filter on a set is proper. By applying the definition of [[Definition:Supremum of Set|supremum]] to \(p\), it follows that there exists an \(S \in \FF\) such that \(a \prec \inf S\). By the definition of [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]]: :\(S \cap {\bar \downarrow} a = \O\) which is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Thus \(Y \cap {\uparrow} a \in \FF\). === Downward rays === Let \(b \in X\) with \(p \prec b\). Either \(Y \cap {\downarrow} b \in \FF\) or \(Y \cap {\bar \uparrow} b \in \FF\). {{AimForCont}} that \(Y \cap {\bar \uparrow} b \in \FF\). Let \(b' = \map \inf {Y \cap {\bar \uparrow} b}\). We have that \(b\) is a [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]] of \(Y \cap {\bar \uparrow} b\) So by the definition of [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]]: :\(b \preceq b'\) Since \(p \prec b\) and \(b \preceq b'\), \(p \prec b'\) by [[Extended Transitivity]]. By the definition of \(b'\) and the definition of \(f\): :\(b' \in \map f \FF\) But this contradicts the fact that \(p\) is the [[Definition:Supremum of Set|supremum]], and hence an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]], of \(\map f \FF\). {{qed|lemma}} By the definition of the [[Definition:Order Topology|order topology]], the upward and downward rays containing each point form a [[Definition:Neighborhood Sub-Basis|neighborhood sub-basis]] for that point. {{wtd|an invocation of "Sub-Basis is Nbhd Sub-Basis" would be appropriate}} Thus by the [[Neighborhood Sub-Basis Criterion for Filter Convergence]], \(\FF\) converges. Since every [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set|ultrafilter]] on \(Y\) converges, \(Y\) is [[Definition:Compact Space|compact]] by [[Equivalent Definitions of Compactness]].

statement: Let \(\left({S, \preceq}\right)\) be an [[Definition:Ordered Set|ordered set]]. Let \(L\) be a [[Definition:Lower Set|lower set]]. Then \(S \setminus L\) is an [[Definition:Upper Set|upper set]].
rationale: Let \(u \in S \setminus L\). Let \(s \in S\) such that \(u \preceq s\). Suppose for the sake of contradiction that \(s \notin S \setminus L\). Then \(s \in L\). By the definition of [[Definition:Lower Set|lower set]], \(u \in L\), a contradiction. Hence \(s \in S \setminus L\). Since this holds for all such \(u\) and \(s\), \(S \setminus L\) is an [[Definition:Upper Set|upper set]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Countable Complement Topology|countable complement topology]] on an [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable set]] $S$. Then $T$ is not a [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countable space]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} some $x \in S$ has a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Local Basis|local basis]]. That means: :there exists a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Set of Sets|set of sets]] $\BB_x \subseteq \tau$ such that: :$\forall B \in \BB_x: x \in B$ and such that: :every [[Definition:Open Neighborhood|open neighborhood]] of $x$ contains some $B \in \BB_x$. So: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \bigcap \BB_x       | r = \set x       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = S \setminus \set x       | r = S \setminus \bigcap \BB_x       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \bigcup_{B \mathop \in \BB_x} \paren {S \setminus B}       | c = [[De Morgan's Laws (Set Theory)/Set Difference/General Case/Difference with Intersection|De Morgan's Laws: Difference with Intersection]] }} {{end-eqn}} By definition, each of $S \setminus B$ is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. From [[Countable Union of Countable Sets is Countable]] it follows that $\displaystyle \bigcup_{B \mathop \in \BB_x} \paren {S \setminus B}$ is also [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. So $S \setminus \set x$ and therefore $S$ is also [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] (as we have specified that $S$ is [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable]]) it follows that our assumption that $x \in S$ has a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Local Basis|local basis]] must be false. Hence by definition $T$ can not be [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countable]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Countable Complement Topology|countable complement topology]] on an [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable set]] $S$. Then $T$ is not a [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact space]].
rationale: Consider $U \in \tau$. By definition of [[Definition:Countable Complement Topology|countable complement topology]], $\relcomp S U$ is [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite]]. Then for each $x \in \relcomp S U$, $\relcomp S U \setminus \set x$ is [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite]]. Then for each $x \in \relcomp S U$, $\relcomp S {\relcomp S U \setminus \set x} = U \cup \set x$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]. Hence $\set {U \cup \set x: x \in \relcomp S U}$ is an [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]]. This [[Definition:Cover of Set|cover]] is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] because it is [[Definition:Set Equivalence|equivalent]] to $\relcomp S U$. {{AimForCont}} $T$ is a [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact space]]. Then by definition there exists a [[Definition:Finite Subcover|finite subcover]] $\set {U \cup \set {x_1}, \ldots, U \cup \set {x_n} }$ of $T$. Then: :$(U \cup \set {x_1}) \cup \dotsb \cup (U \cup \set {x_n}) = U \cup \set {x_1, \ldots, x_n}$ Since $\relcomp S U$ is not [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]], it follows that $U \cup \set {x_1, \ldots, x_n} \ne S$. Thus there is no [[Definition:Finite Subcover|finite subcover]] of $T$. It follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]] that $T$ cannot be a [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact space]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Countable Complement Topology|countable complement topology]] on an [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable set]] $S$. Then the [[Definition:Compact Topological Subspace|compact sets]] of $T$ are exactly the [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]] [[Definition:Subset|subsets]] of $S$.
rationale: From [[Finite Topological Space is Compact]], any [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$ is [[Definition:Compact Topological Subspace|compact]]. {{AimForCont}} $H \subseteq S$ is an [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite]] [[Definition:Compact Topological Subspace|compact set]]. Take a [[Definition:Infinite Sequence|(countably) infinite sequence]] $\sequence {a_n}_{n \mathop \ge 0}$ of [[Definition:Distinct Elements|distinct elements]] of $H$. Consider the [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]]: :$V_m := S \setminus \set {a_{m + n} }_{n \mathop \ge 0} $ for $m \ge 0$, which satisfy $V_{m_1} \subset V_{m_2}$ if $m_1 < m_2$. Then: :$H \subseteq \bigcup_{m \mathop \ge 0} V_m$ is an [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] of $H$. Since $H$ is [[Definition:Compact Topological Subspace|compact]], it has a [[Definition:Finite Subcover|finite open subcover]], say: :$\displaystyle H \subseteq \bigcup_{i \mathop = 0}^N V_{m_i}$ with $m_0 < m_1 < \cdots < m_N$. But then: :$\displaystyle \bigcup_{i \mathop = 0}^N V_{m_i} = V_{m_N}$  and so: :$a_{m_N + 1}, a_{m_N + 2}, \ldots \notin V_{m_N} = \bigcup_{i \mathop = 0}^N V_{m_i}$ which implies $a_{m_N + 1}, a_{m_N + 2}, \ldots \notin H $, a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Hence the result by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Countable Finite Complement Topology|countable finite complement topology]]. Then $T$ is not [[Definition:Locally Path-Connected|locally path-connected]].
rationale: Let $\BB$ be a [[Definition:Basis (Topology)|basis]] for $T$. Let $B \in \BB$. {{AimForCont}} $f: \closedint 0 1 \to B$ is a [[Definition:Path (Topology)|path]] on $T$. Then $f$ is by definition [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]]. Now consider the set: :$F = \set {\map {f^{-1} } x: x \in S}$ From [[Continuity Defined from Closed Sets]], each of the [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $F$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. Also, from [[Mapping Induces Partition on Domain]], the [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $F$ are [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]]. From [[Basis of Countable Finite Complement Topology consists of Countably Infinite Sets]], $B$ is a [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite set]]. Hence $F$ is also [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite]] by nature of $f$ being a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]]. Furthermore, we have $\displaystyle \bigcup F = \closedint 0 1$. Hence $F$ is a [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite set]] of [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]] [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed sets]] whose [[Definition:Set Union|union]] is $\closedint 0 1$. From [[Closed Unit Interval is not Countably Infinite Union of Disjoint Closed Sets]], this is impossible. From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], $f$ cannot be [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]], and so cannot be a [[Definition:Path (Topology)|path]] on $B$. So $B$ cannot be [[Definition:Path-Connected Set (Topology)|path-connected]]. So, by definition, $T$ is not [[Definition:Locally Path-Connected Space|locally path-connected]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Countable Finite Complement Topology|countable finite complement topology]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} $f: \closedint 0 1 \to S$ is a [[Definition:Path (Topology)|path]] on $T$. Then $f$ is by definition [[Definition:Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]]. For all $x \in S$, the set $\set x$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. Now consider the set: :$F = \set {\map {f^{-1} } x: x \in S}$ From [[Continuity Defined from Closed Sets]], each of the [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $F$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. Also, from [[Mapping Induces Partition on Domain]], the [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $F$ are [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]]. As $T$ is a [[Definition:Countable Finite Complement Topology|countable finite complement topology]], its [[Definition:Underlying Set of Topological Space|underlying set]] $S$ is a [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite set]]. Hence $F$ is also [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite]] by nature of $f$ being a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]]. Furthermore, we have $\displaystyle \bigcup F = \closedint 0 1$. Hence $F$ is a [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite set]] of [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]] [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed sets]] whose [[Definition:Set Union|union]] is $\closedint 0 1$. From [[Closed Unit Interval is not Countably Infinite Union of Disjoint Closed Sets]], this is impossible. From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], $f$ cannot be [[Definition:Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]], and so cannot be a [[Definition:Path (Topology)|path]] on $T$. So $T$ cannot be [[Definition:Path-Connected Space|path-connected]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] which is [[Definition:Irreducible]
rationale: Suppose $T$ has at least two points $x, y \in S$. Because $T$ is [[Definition:Irreducible Space|irreducible]], there are no t in one and $y$ is in the other. This contradicts the fact that $T$ is [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff]]. Thus $T$ has only one point.

rationale: Let $T = \struct {S, 	au}$ be a [[Definition:Uncountable Finite Complement Topology|finite complement topology]] on an [[Defi]]. But we also have that an [[Uncountable Finite Complement Space is not First-Countable]]. Hence the result, by [[Proof by Counterexample]].

statement: Let $T$ be a [[Definition:Complete Theory|complete $\mathcal{L}$-theory]] whose [[Definition:Logical Language|language]] $\mathcal{L}$ is $\omega$-stable, then $T$ is [[Definition:Kappa-Stable Theory|$\kappa$-stable]] for all [[Definition:Infinite Cardinal|infinite $\kappa$]].
rationale:
We prove the [[Definition:Contrapositive Statement|contrapositive]]. Let $\kappa$ be an [[Definition:Infinite Cardinal|infinite cardinal]], and suppose that $T$ is not $\kappa$-stable. Then there exists some $\mathcal{M} \models T$ and $A \subseteq \mathcal{M}$ with $|A| = \kappa$ such that: :$|S_n^\mathcal{M}(A)| > \kappa$. Our goal will be to find a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable set]] $B$ in $\mathcal{M}$ such that: :$|S_n^\mathcal{M}(B)| > \omega$, which contradicts the $\omega$-stability of $T$. We will do this by constructing a tree of $\mathcal{L}_A$-formulas where distinct simple paths from the root of the tree out to infinity correspond to distinct types over $B$. Suppose $|[{\phi}]| > \kappa$. We argue that we can select some $\mathcal{L}_A$-formula $\psi$ such that both $|[{\phi \land \psi}]| > \kappa$ and $|[{\phi \land 
eg \psi}]| > \kappa$.=== Proof of Lemma ===The argument is a proof by contradiction. Assume that for every $\mathcal{L}_A$-formula $\psi$, either $|[{\phi \land \psi}]| \leq \kappa$ or $|[{\phi \land 
eg \psi}]| \leq \kappa$. Then the union of all sets $[{\phi \land \psi}]$ and $[{\phi \land 
eg \psi}]$ would have cardinality at most $\kappa$, contradicting the assumption that $|[{\phi}]| > \kappa$. Thus, there must exist a formula $\psi$ such that both $|[{\phi \land \psi}]| > \kappa$ and $|[{\phi \land 
eg \psi}]| > \kappa$. By the compactness theorem, this means that both ${\phi \land \psi} \cup Th_A(\mathcal{M})$ and ${\phi \land 
eg \psi} \cup Th_A(\mathcal{M})$ are satisfiable. Therefore, we can extend $p$ to include either $\psi$ or $
eg \psi$, without changing the fact that $|[{\phi}]| > \kappa$.Now we build the tree. This amounts to recursively defining formulas $\phi_\sigma$ for each finite sequence $\sigma$ of $0$s and $1$s. Initially, let $\phi_{()}$ be any formula for which $|[{\phi_{()}}]| > \kappa$. Suppose $\phi_\sigma$ has been defined and satisfies $|[{\phi_\sigma}]| > \kappa$. By the lemma above, we can choose an $\mathcal{L}_A$-formula $\psi$ such that both $|[{\phi_\sigma \land \psi}]| > \kappa$ and $|[{\phi_\sigma \land 
eg \psi}]| > \kappa$. Define $\phi_{\sigma^ rown 0} = \phi_\sigma \land \psi$ and $\phi_{\sigma^ rown 1} = \phi_\sigma \land 
eg \psi$. Let $B$ be the set of elements of $A$ occurring as constant symbols in any of the $\phi_\sigma$. Since only countably many $\phi_\sigma$ are used, $B$ is countable. Each infinite path through the tree corresponds to a type in $S_n^\mathcal{M}(B)$. Because the tree has $2^{\aleph_0}$ branches, it follows that $|S_n^\mathcal{M}(B)| \geq 2^{\aleph_0} > \omega$. Hence, $T$ is not $\omega$-stable. The theorem now follows by the rule of transposition. {{qed}} [[Category:Model Theory]].

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $T^*_{\bar p} = \struct {S^*_p, \tau^*_p}$ be a [[Definition:Separable Space|separable space]] {{iff}} $T$ is.
rationale: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Separable Space|separable space]]. Then there exists a [[Definition:Countable Subset|countable subset]] $H \subseteq S$ which is [[Definition:Everywhere Dense|everywhere dense]] in $T$. That is, $H^- = S$ where $H^-$ is the [[Definition:Closure (Topology)|closure]] of $H$ in $S$. So in $T_{\bar p}^*$, by [[Definition:Topological Closure is Closed]], we deduce that $H^-$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] in $T_{\bar p}^*$. From the definition of closed sets in $T_{\bar p}^*$, these are $S^*_p \setminus U$ where $U \in \tau$. Because $\set {p} \notin \tau$, $S$ is not closed. Therefore, there is a countable subset $H \subseteq S^*_p$ which is everywhere dense in $T^*_{\bar p}$. Assume for a contradiction that $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ is not separable. Let $V \subseteq S^*_p$ be a countable subset in $T^*_{\bar p}$. If $V \subseteq S$, then $V^- = S$ in $T$, but this cannot be since $T$ is not separable. By the same argument as above, we have that $V^-$ is closed in $T_{\bar p}^*$. From the definition of [[Definition:Open Extension Space|open extension space]], closed sets contain the point $p$. So $V \cup \set {p} = V^-$. From [[Set Closure is Smallest Closed Set in Topological Space]], $V$ is dense in $S$, so $V$ is countable. Thus $T$ is separable, which is a contradiction. Finally, our assumption must be false.

statement: Let $\closedint a b $ be a [[Definition:Closed Interval|closed interval]] in $\R$. Let $\JJ$ be a set of two or more [[Definition:Closed Interval|closed intervals]] contained in \$\closedint a b\$. The intervals of \$\JJ\$ are not [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]].
rationale: Aim for a contradiction that the intervals of $\JJ$ are pairwise disjoint. Let $I = \closedint c d$ be an interval in $\JJ$ such that $a \in I$. Let $J = \closedint r s\$ be the unique interval of \$\JJ\$ different from \$I\$ since \$\JJ\$ has at least two elements, and they are supposed to be disjoint. If \$d < r\$ then there is some real number with \$d < \alpha < r\$. Therefore $\alpha \notin I$. Since $J$ contains points greater than $r$, there is a $\beta \in J$ with $\beta > \alpha$. But we also have that $\alpha < r \leq \beta$ for all $\beta \in J$, a contradiction. Thus the intervals of $\JJ$ are not pairwise disjoint. {{qed}} [[Category:Measure Theory]]

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] which is [[Definition:Totally Separated Space|totally separated]].
rationale: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a totally separated space. Then for every $x, y \in S$ with $x \neq y$, there exist disjoint open sets $U, V \in \tau$ such that $x \in U, y \in V$. Suppose $T$ were not [[Definition:Totally Disconnected Space|totally disconnected]]. Then there would exist a connected subset $H \subseteq S$ containing both $x$ and $y$. However, since $H$ is connected, there can be no partition $U \mid V$ of $T$ such that $x \in U$ and $y \in V$. This contradicts the total separation property. Hence, $T$ must be totally disconnected.

statement: Let $T_A = \struct {X_A, \tau_A}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] which is [[Definition:Paracompact Space|paracompact]]. Let $\phi: T_A \to T_B$ be a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] which is both [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|everywhere continuous]] and [[Definition:Open Mapping|open]]. If $T_B = \struct {X_B, \tau_B}$ is [[Definition:Countably Metacompact Space|countably metacompact]], then it is paracompact.
rationale: Let $T_X = \struct {X, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Countable Discrete Topology|countable discrete space]]. Let $T_Y = \struct {Y, \tau_0}$ be a [[Definition:Sierpiński Space|Sierpiński space]]. Let $T = T_X \times T_Y$ be the product space of $T_X$ and $T_Y$ whose [[Definition:Product Topology|product topology]] is defined accordingly. From [[Countable Discrete Space with Sierpiński Space is Paracompact]], $T$ is paracompact. Let $T_B = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a [[Definition:Countable Particular Point Topology|countable particular point topology]]. From [[Infinite Particular Point Space is not Countably Metacompact]], $T_B$ is not countably metacompact. Let $\phi: T_A \to T_B$ be a mapping defined as $\phi(x, y) = \begin{cases} x & : y = 0 \\ p & : y = 1 \end{cases}$. Then $\phi$ is open and everywhere continuous. Let $V$ be an open set in $T_B$ such that $V \neq \O$. Then $p \in V$. Let $F = \phi^{-1}[V]$. As $p \in V$, $F$ is of the form $A \times B$ where $A$ is open in $T_X$. Thus, $\phi$ maps from open sets to open sets and is continuous. {{qed|lemma}} We have constructed a continuous mapping from a paracompact space to a non-countably metacompact space, leading to a contradiction.

statement: Let $\phi$ be a sentence in the language $\LL_r = \set {0, 1, +, -, \cdot}$ for rings, where $0, 1$ are constants, and $+, -, \cdot$ are binary operations. Let the following statements be equivalent: :$(1): \quad \phi$ is true in all algebraically closed fields of characteristic $0$. :$(2): \quad \phi$ is true in some algebraically closed field of characteristic $0$. :$(3): \quad \phi$ is true in algebraically closed fields of characteristic $p$ for sufficiently large primes $p$. :$(4): \quad \phi$ is true in algebraically closed fields of characteristic $p$ for arbitrarily large primes $p$. Note in particular that $(4)$ implies $(2)$ being true in the field $\C$.
rationale: === $(1)$ iff $(2)$ === From [[Theory of Algebraically Closed Fields of Characteristic p is Complete]], the theory of algebraically closed fields of characteristic $p$ is complete. That is, all such fields satisfy the exact same $\LL_r$ sentences. {{qed|lemma}} === $(2)$ implies $(4)$ === By the [[Compactness Theorem]] and the finiteness of proofs, it follows that there is a finite subset $\Delta$ of $ACF_0$ such that $\Delta \models \phi$. Hence, as long as $p$ is selected sufficiently large, an algebraically closed field of characteristic $p$ will satisfy $\phi$. {{qed|lemma}} === $(3)$ implies $(2)$ === We prove this by [[Proof by Contrapositive]]. If $\phi$ is false in algebraically closed fields of characteristic $0$, then since $ACF_0$ is complete, this means that there is a finite subset $\Delta$ of $ACF_0$ such that $\Delta \models \neg \phi$. But then, for all sufficiently large $p$, we have that $\phi$ is false in algebraically closed fields of characteristic $p$. By [[Rule of Transposition]], $\phi$ is true in algebraically closed fields for arbitrarily large primes $p$ implies that $\phi$ is true in algebraically closed fields of characteristic $0$. {{Namedfor|Solomon Lefschetz|name2 = Robert Lawson Vaught|cat = Lefschetz|cat2 = Vaught}} [[Category:Algebraic Geometry]] [[Category:Field Theory]] [[Category:Model Theory]]

statement: Let $S$ be a [[Definition:Set|set]] and let $\mathcal P \left({S}\right)$ be the [[Definition:Power Set|power set]] of $S$. it is not necessarily the case that $S_1 = S_2$.
rationale: Proof by counterexample: Let $S = \left\{{1, 2, 3}\right\}$. Let $T = \left\{{3}\right\}$. Let $S_1 = \left\{{1, 3} ut $S_1 \ne S_2$. {{qed}} [[Category:Set Intersection]] b1v80uc46x69qbuvlgkeqgah7bdxw6a

statement: Let $\RR \subseteq S \times T$ be a [[Definition:Relation|relation]] on $S \times T$. Let $\RR \circ \RR^{-1}$ be the [rse]]. Let $I_T$ be the [[Definition:Identity Mapping|identity mapping]] on $T$. Then: :$\RR \circ \RR^{-1} = I_T$ {{iff}}: :$\RR$ is [[Detal]].

Given a number $x \in \hointr 0 1$, there exists a unique representation of $x$ as a sum of the form: :$\displaystyle x = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{a_n}{p^n}$, where each $a_n$ satisfies $0 \leq a_n < p$. Specifically, there exists a [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] $\sequence {a_n}$ such that: :$0 \le a_n < p$, and :the series terminates (that is, $a_n = 0$ for all sufficiently large $n$), then this representation is unique. If $\sequence {a_n}$ does terminate, it satisfies the criteria of the theorem.
rationale: === Existence of Representation === Define: :$\displaystyle a_j = \floor{\paren{x - \sum_{i=1}^{j-1} \frac{a_i}{p^i}} p^j}$. This recursive definition allows for all $a_n$ to be computed. :''Lemma'': This will always be less than $p$: Suppose for contradiction that $a_n = \floor{\paren{x - \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \frac{a_i}{p^i}} p^n} \ge p$. Then we can pull out the final term of the sum, giving us $\paren{x - \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \frac{a_i}{p^i}} p^n \ge p^n$, which simplifies to $x - \sum_{i=1}^{n-1} \frac{a_i}{p^i} \ge 1$. But since $x < 1$ and $\forall i \in \N: a_i, p^{-i} > 0$, this sequence of partial sums is increasing but bounded above by $x$. Thus, at every point in the series, we add precisely as many $p^{-n-1}$ as will fit in $x-s_n$ without exceeding $x$. :''Lemma'': $\forall n \in \N$, if $s_j < x$ for some $j$, then $s_{j+1} \leq x$. Now suppose we have instead $s_j = x$. Again we have: :$s_{j+1} - s_j = a_{j+1} p^{-1-j}$. But now: ::$a_{j+1} p^{-1-j} = \floor{\paren{x - \sum_{i=1}^{j} \frac{a_i}{p^i}} p^{j+1}} p^{-1-j} \leq p^{-1-j}$. Since the induction proof shows that the series never overshoots $x$, we conclude that $\sequence{s_k} \to x$. {{qed|lemma}} It remains to be shown that this series converges to $x$. Observe that in the sum $\displaystyle s_{k-1} + \frac{a_k}{p^k}$, we count how many $p^{-k}$ will fit in $x-s_{k-1}$. We could never have $x - s_k \ge p^{-k}$ because then $s_{k+1}$ would exceed $x$. Set $z = -\log_p \epsilon$. Then: :$N > z \implies x - s_N < p^{-N} < \epsilon$. Since $\sequence{s_k}$ gets arbitrarily close to $x$, we have $\sequence{s_n} \to x$. {{qed|lemma}} === Uniqueness of Representation === Let $\sequence{a_n}$ be the sequence from the #Theorem|theorem]]. Let $\sequence{b_n}$ be another sequence of integers $0 \le b_n < p$ such that $\sequence{t_n} \to x$. Assume to the contrary that there are terms which do not agree and let $b_m$ be the first term that differs from $a_m$. Consider two cases: :If $b_m > a_m$, then since $\sequence{t_n}$ is increasing, it can never converge to $x$. :If $b_m = a_m - 1$, then for convergence, every subsequent term must be $p-1$. So, this is the only case where a different series can converge to $x$. Now suppose that $x = q p^{-k}$ for some $k \in \N$. We wish to show that there are only two series which converge to $x$: :the series defined by $\sequence{a_n}$, and :another series we describe now. Consider the sequence $\sequence{a_n}$ when $x = q p^{-k}$. Define: :$b_n = \begin{cases} a_n & : n < k \\ a_k - 1 & : n = k \\ p-1 & : n > k \end{cases}$. Then: :$\displaystyle x = \sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{b_j}{p^j} = \paren{\sum_{j=1}^{k-1} \frac{b_j}{p^j}} + \paren{a_k - 1} p^{-k} + \sum_{j=k+1}^\infty \paren{p-1} p^{-j}$. Simplifying this expression shows that it equals $x$. {{qed|lemma}}

statement: Let $f: \R \to \R$ be the [[Definition:Absolute Value|absolute value function]]: :$\forall x \in \R: \map f x = \size x$. Then $f$ is not a [[Definition:Many-to-One Relation|many-to-one relation]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} To prove that $f$ is not a many-to-one relation, we aim for a contradiction. Suppose $f$ were many-to-one. Then there exist $y_1, y_2 \in \R$ such that $y_1 \ne y_2$ and $\map f {y_1} = \map f {y_2}$. There are two possibilities: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = y_1 \ge 0       | o = \land       | r = y_2 \ge 0       | c = }} {{eqn | l = y_1 = \map f {y_1}       | r = \map f {y_2} = y_2 }} {{end-eqn}} That is: :$y_2 = y_1$. Suppose $y_1 < 0$. {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = y_1 = \map f {y_1}       | r = -y_1 }} {{eqn | l = y_2 = \map f {y_2}       | r = -y_2 }} {{end-eqn}} That is: :$y_2 = -y_1$. So by [[Proof by Cases]], we have that $y_1 = y_2$ whatever $y_1$ may be. This contradicts our assumption that $f$ is many-to-one. {{Qed}}

statement: Let $f: S \to T$ be a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]]. Let $f^{-1}$ be the [[Definition:Inverse of Mapping|inverse]] of $f$. Then $f^{-1} \paren t$ is [[Definition:Empty Set|empty]] for no $t \in T$ {{iff}} $f$ is a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]].
rationale:
=== Necessary Condition === We use a [[Proof by Contraposition]]. To that end, suppose $f$ is not a surjection. Then by definition: :$\exists t \in T: 
eg \exists s \in S: \map f s = t$. Therefore, $f^{-1} \paren t = \O$. From the [[Rule of Transposition]], it follows that if $f$ is a surjection, then $
eg \exists t \in T: f^{-1} \paren t = \O$. {{Qed}} === Sufficient Condition === Conversely, suppose $
eg \exists t \in T: f^{-1} \paren t = \O$. Then for every $t \in T$, there exists an $s \in S$ such that $\map f s = t$. Hence, $f$ is a surjection. {{Qed}}

statement: Let $\struct {\Omega, \Sigma, \Pr}$ be a [[Definition:Probability Space|probability space]]. Let $X$ and $Y$ be [[Definition:Independent Random Variables|independent random variables]] on $\struct {\Omega, \Sigma, \Pr}$. Let $\expect X$ denote the [[Definition:Expectation|expectation]] of $X$. Then $X$ and $Y$ are independent if and only if: :$\expect {\map g X \map h Y} = \expect {\map g X} \expect {\map h Y}$ for all [[Definition:Real Function|functions]] $g, h: \R \to \R$ for which the latter two expectations exist.
rationale: === Sufficient Condition === Suppose that $X$ and $Y$ were not [[Definition:Independent Random Variables|independent]]. Then there exist functions $g, h: \R \to \R$ such that: :$\expect {\map g X \map h Y} \ne \expect {\map g X} \expect {\map h Y}$. Define $g$ and $h$ as indicator functions for some $a, b \in \R$. Then: :$\expect {\map g X \map h Y} = \map \Pr {X = a, Y = b}$. And: :$\expect {\map g X} \expect {\map h Y} = \map \Pr {X = a} \map \Pr {Y = b}$. If $X$ and $Y$ are not independent, then: :$\map \Pr {X = a, Y = b} \ne \map \Pr {X = a} \map \Pr {Y = b}$. This contradicts our supposition. {{Qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === Suppose $X$ and $Y$ are [[Definition:Independent Random Variables|independent]]. Let $g, h: \R \to \R$ be arbitrary functions for which the expectations $\expect {\map g X}$ and $\expect {\map h Y}$ exist. By definition of independence: :$\expect {\map g X \map h Y} = \expect {\map g X} \expect {\map h Y}$. Thus proving the necessary condition. {{Qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {X, \preceq}, X \ne \O\) be a [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Ordered Set|ordered set]] such that every [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Chain (Set Theory)|chain]] in \(X\) has an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] in \(X\). Then \(X\) has at least one [[Definition:Maximal Element|maximal element]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} that for each \(x \in X\) there is a \(y \in X\) such that \(x \prec y\). By the [[Axiom:Axiom of Choice|Axiom of Choice]], there is a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] \(f: X \to X\) such that: :\(\forall x \in X: x \prec \map f x\) Let \(\mathcal C\) be the [[Definition:Set|set]] of all [[Definition:Chain (Set Theory)|chains]] in \(X\). By the premise, each element of \(\mathcal C\) has an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] in \(X\). Thus by the [[Axiom:Axiom of Choice|Axiom of Choice]], there is a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] \(g: \mathcal C \to X\) such that for each \(C \in \mathcal C\), \(\map g C\) is an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] of \(C\). Let \(p\) be an arbitrary element of \(X\). Define a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] \(h: \operatorname {Ord} \to X\) by [[Transfinite Recursion|transfinite recursion]] thus: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \map h 0       | r = p }} {{eqn | l = \map h {\alpha^+}       | r = \map f {\map h \alpha } }} {{eqn | l = \map h \lambda       | r = \map f {\map g {f \sqbrk \lambda} }       | c = if \(\lambda\) is a [[Definition:Limit Ordinal|limit ordinal]] }} {{end-eqn}} {{explain|The notation \(f \sqbrk \lambda\) needs to be defined.}} Then \(h\) is [[Definition:Strictly Increasing|strictly increasing]], and thus [[Definition:Injection|injective]]. {{explain|The above statement needs to be justified.}} Let \(h'\) be the [[Definition:Restriction|restriction]] of \(h\) to \(\operatorname {On} \times \map h {\operatorname{On} }\). Then \({h'}^{-1}\) is a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]] from \(\map h {\operatorname{On} } \subseteq X\) onto \(\operatorname{On}\). By the [[Axiom:Axiom of Replacement|Axiom of Replacement]], \(\operatorname{On}\) is a [[Definition:Set|set]]. By [[Burali-Forti Paradox]], this is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Thus we conclude that some element of \(X\) has no [[Definition:Strict Successor|strict successor]], and is thus [[Definition:Maximal Element|maximal]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $a \in \Z$. Let $p$ be an [[Definition:Odd Prime|odd prime]]. Let $b = a^{\\frac {\\paren {p - 1} } 2}$. Then one of the following cases holds: :$b \\bmod p = 0$ which happens exactly when $a \\equiv 0 \\pmod p$, or: :$b \\bmod p = 1$ or: :$b \\bmod p = p - 1$ where: :$b \\bmod p$ denotes the [[Definition:Modulo Operation|modulo operation]] :$x \\equiv y \\pmod p$ denotes that $x$ is [[Definition:Congruence (Number Theory)|congruent modulo $p$]] to $y$.
rationale: By definition of [[Definition:Congruence (Number Theory)|congruence modulo $p$]]: :$\\forall x, y \\in \\R: x \\equiv y \\pmod p \\iff x \\bmod p = y \\bmod p$  We have that: :$b = a^{\\frac{\\paren {p - 1} } 2}$ and so: :$b^2 = a^{p - 1}$ Let $a \\equiv 0 \\pmod p$. Then by definition of [[Definition:Congruence (Number Theory)|congruence modulo $p$]]: :$p \\divides a$ and so: :$p \\divides a^{\\frac{\\paren {p - 1} } 2}$ where $\\divides$ denotes [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisibility]]. Thus by definition of [[Definition:Congruence (Number Theory)|congruence modulo $p$]]: :$b \\equiv 0 \\pmod p$ and so: :$b \\bmod p = 0$ {{qed|lemma}} Otherwise, from [[Fermat's Little Theorem]]: :$b^2 \\equiv 1 \\pmod p$ That is: :$b^2 - 1 \\equiv 0 \\pmod p$ From [[Difference of Two Squares]]: :$b^2 - 1 = \\paren {b + 1} \\paren {b - 1}$ So either: :$p \\divides b + 1$ or: :$p \\divides b - 1$ {{AimForCont}} both $p \\divides b + 1$ and $p \\divides b - 1$. Then by [[Modulo Subtraction is Well-Defined]]: :$p \\divides \\paren {b + 1} - \\paren {b - 1} = 2$ But $p$ is an [[Definition:Odd Prime|odd prime]]. So it cannot be the case that $p \\divides 2$. From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that  Note that $p$ cannot [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divide]] both $b + 1$ and $b - 1$. So either: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \\paren {b - 1}       | o = \\equiv       | r = 0       | rr= \\pmod p       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \\leadsto       | l = b       | o = \\equiv       | r = 1       | rr= \\pmod p       | c = [[Modulo Addition is Well-Defined]] }} {{end-eqn}} or: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \\paren {b + 1}       | o = \\equiv       | r = 0       | rr= \\pmod p       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \\leadsto       | l = b       | o = \\equiv       | r = -1       | rr= \\pmod p       | c = [[Modulo Subtraction is Well-Defined]] }} {{eqn | o = \\equiv       | r = p - 1       | rr= \\pmod p       | c = [[Negative Number is Congruent to Modulus minus Number]] }} {{end-eqn}} Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Define a [[Definition:Topology|topology]] on the [[Definition:Integer|integers]] $\Z$ by declaring a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] $U \subseteq \Z$ to be an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] {{iff}} it is either: :the [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]] $\O$ or: :a [[Definition:Set Union|union]] of [[Definition:Sequence|sequences]] $\map S {a, b}$, where: ::$\map S {a, b} = \set {a n + b: n \in \Z} = a \Z + b$ In other words, $U$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] {{iff}} every $x \in U$ admits some non-[[Definition:Zero (Number)|zero]] [[Definition:Integer|integer]] $a$ such that $\map S {a, x} \subseteq U$. The [[Definition:Open Set Axioms|open set axioms]] are verified as follows: $(O1): \quad$ All [[Definition:Set Union|unions]] of [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]] are [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]: For any [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]] $U_i$ and $x$ in their [[Definition:Set Union|union]] $U$, any of the numbers $a_i$ for which $\map S {a_i, x} \subseteq U_i$ also shows that $\map S {a_i, x} \subseteq U$. $(O2): \quad$ The [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]] of two (and hence [[Definition:Finite Set|finitely many]]) [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]] is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]: Let $U_1$ and $U_2$ be [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]]. Let $x \in U_1 \cap U_2$ (with [[Definition:Integer|integers]] $a_1$ and $a_2$ establishing membership). Set $a$ to be the [[Definition:Lowest Common Multiple of Integers|lowest common multiple]] of $a_1$ and $a_2$. Then: :$\map S {a, x} \subseteq \map S {a_i, x} \subseteq U_1 \cap U_2$ $(O3): \quad$ By definition, $\O$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]: $\Z$ is just the [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] $\map S {1, 0}$, and so is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] as well. The topology is quite different from the usual Euclidean one, and has two notable properties: :$(1): \quad$ Since any non-empty [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] contains an infinite sequence, no finite set can be [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]. Put another way, the [[Definition:Set Complement|complement]] of a finite set cannot be a [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed set]]. :$(2): \quad$ The basis sets $\map S {a, b}$ are [[Definition:Clopen Set|both open and closed]]: they are [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] by definition, and we can write $\map S {a, b}$ as the [[Definition:Relative Complement|complement]] of an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] as follows: :$\displaystyle \map S {a, b} = \Z \setminus \bigcup_{j \mathop = 1}^{a - 1} \map S {a, b + j}$ The only [[Definition:Integer|integers]] that are not integer multiples of [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]] are $-1$ and $+1$, that is: :$\displaystyle \Z \setminus \set {-1, + 1} = \bigcup_{\text {$p$ prime} } \map S {p, 0}$ By the first property, the [[Definition:Set|set]] on the {{LHS}} cannot be [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. On the other hand, by the second property, the sets $\map S {p, 0}$ are [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. So, if there were only [[Definition:Finite Set|finitely many]] [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]], then the [[Definition:Set|set]] on the {{RHS}} would be a [[Definition:Finite Union|finite union]] of [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed sets]], and hence [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. Therefore by [[Proof by Contradiction]], there must be infinitely many [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]]. {{qed}}
rationale: The corresponding proof:Define a [[Definition:Topology|topology]] on the [[Definition:Integer|integers]] $\Z$ by declaring a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] $U \subseteq \Z$ to be an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] {{iff}} it is either: :the [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]] $\O$ or: :a [[Definition:Set Union|union]] of [[Definition:Sequence|sequences]] $\map S {a, b}$, where: ::$\map S {a, b} = \set {a n + b: n \in \Z} = a \Z + b$ In other words, $U$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] {{iff}} every $x \in U$ admits some non-[[Definition:Zero (Number)|zero]] [[Definition:Integer|integer]] $a$ such that $\map S {a, x} \subseteq U$. The [[Definition:Open Set Axioms|open set axioms]] are verified as follows: $(O1): \quad$ All [[Definition:Set Union|unions]] of [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]] are [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]: For any [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]] $U_i$ and $x$ in their [[Definition:Set Union|union]] $U$, any of the numbers $a_i$ for which $\map S {a_i, x} \subseteq U_i$ also shows that $\map S {a_i, x} \subseteq U$. $(O2): \quad$ The [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]] of two (and hence [[Definition:Finite Set|finitely many]]) [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]] is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]: Let $U_1$ and $U_2$ be [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]]. Let $x \in U_1 \cap U_2$ (with [[Definition:Integer|integers]] $a_1$ and $a_2$ establishing membership). Set $a$ to be the [[Definition:Lowest Common Multiple of Integers|lowest common multiple]] of $a_1$ and $a_2$. Then: :$\map S {a, x} \subseteq \map S {a_i, x} \subseteq U_1 \cap U_2$ $(O3): \quad$ By definition, $\O$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]: $\Z$ is just the [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] $\map S {1, 0}$, and so is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] as well. The topology is quite different from the usual Euclidean one, and has two notable properties: :$(1): \quad$ Since any non-empty [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] contains an infinite sequence, no finite set can be [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]. Put another way, the [[Definition:Set Complement|complement]] of a finite set cannot be a [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed set]]. :$(2): \quad$ The basis sets $\map S {a, b}$ are [[Definition:Clopen Set|both open and closed]]: they are [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] by definition, and we can write $\map S {a, b}$ as the [[Definition:Relative Complement|complement]] of an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] as follows: :$\displaystyle \map S {a, b} = \Z \setminus \bigcup_{j \mathop = 1}^{a - 1} \map S {a, b + j}$ The only [[Definition:Integer|integers]] that are not integer multiples of [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]] are $-1$ and $+1$, that is: :$\displaystyle \Z \setminus \set {-1, + 1} = \bigcup_{\text {$p$ prime} } \map S {p, 0}$ By the first property, the [[Definition:Set|set]] on the {{LHS}} cannot be [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. On the other hand, by the second property, the sets $\map S {p, 0}$ are [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. So, if there were only [[Definition:Finite Set|finitely many]] [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]], then the [[Definition:Set|set]] on the {{RHS}} would be a [[Definition:Finite Union|finite union]] of [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed sets]], and hence [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. Therefore by [[Proof by Contradiction]], there must be infinitely many [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]]. {{qed}}

statement: Just because all the [[Definition:Event|events]] in a [[Definition:Indexed Family of Sets|family]] of [[Definition:Event|events]] in a [[Definition:Probability Space|probability space]] are [[Definition:Pairwise Independent|pairwise independent]], it does not mean that the [[Definition:Indexed Family of Sets|family]] is [[Definition:Independent Events/General Definition|independent]].
rationale: Consider throwing a fair four-sided [[Definition:Die|die]]. This gives us an [[Definition:Event Space|event space]] $\Omega = \set {1, 2, 3, 4}$, with each \omega \in \Omega equally likely to occur: :$\forall \omega \in \Omega: \map \Pr \omega = \dfrac 1 4$ Consider the set of [[Definition:Event|events]]: :$\SS = \set {A, B, C}$ where: :$A = \set {1, 2}, B = \set {1, 3}, C = \set {1, 4}$ We have that: :$\map \Pr A = \map \Pr B = \map \Pr C = \dfrac 1 2$ We also have that: :$\map \Pr {A \cap B} = \map \Pr {A \cap C} = \map \Pr {B \cap C} = \map \Pr {\set 1} = \dfrac 1 4$ Thus: :$\map \Pr A \map \Pr B = \map \Pr {A \cap B}$ :$\map \Pr A \map \Pr C = \map \Pr {A \cap C}$ :$\map \Pr B \map \Pr C = \map \Pr {B \cap C}$ Thus the events $A, B, C$ are [[Definition:Pairwise Independent|pairwise independent]]. Now, consider: :$\map \Pr {A \cap B \cap C} = \map \Pr {\set 1} = \dfrac 1 4$ But: :$\map \Pr A \map \Pr B \map \Pr C = \dfrac 1 8 \ne \map \Pr {A \cap B \cap C}$ So, although $\SS$ is [[Definition:Pairwise Independent|pairwise independent]], it is not [[Definition:Independent Events/General Definition|independent]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {\Omega, \Sigma, \Pr}\) be a [[Definition:Probability Space|probability space]]. Let \(X\) and \(Y\) be [[Definition:Discrete Random Variable|discrete random variables]] on \(\struct {\Omega, \Sigma, \Pr}\). Let \(\expect X\) denote the [[Definition:Expectation|expectation]] of \(X\). Then \(X\) and \(Y\) are [[Definition:Independent Random Variables|independent]] {{iff}}: :\(\expect {\map g x \map h y} = \expect {\map g x} \expect {\map h y}\) for all [[Definition:Real Function|functions]] \(g, h: \R \to \R\) for which the latter two expectations exist.

The corresponding proof: Suppose the opposite, and let [[Definition:Circle|circle]] $ABC$ cut the [[Definition:Circle|circle]] $DEF$ at more points than two, that is at $B, G, F, H$. :[[File:Euclid-III-10.png|400px]]
rationale: Clearly, in the diagram, [[Definition:Circle|circle]] $DEF$ is not actually a [[Definition:Circle|circle]]. For the sake of demonstrating a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], we suppose that it is. [[Axiom:Euclid's First Postulate|Join]] $BH$ and $BG$, and [[Bisection of Straight Line|bisect]] them at $K$ and $L$. From $K$ and $L$, [[Construction of Perpendicular Line|draw perpendiculars]] to $BH$ and $BG$, through to $A$ and $E$. Since $AC$ cuts $BH$ into two equal parts at [[Definition:Right Angle|right angles]], from [[Finding Center of Circle/Porism|the porism to Finding Center of Circle]], the [[Definition:Center of Circle|center of circle $ABC$]] is on $AC$. For the same reason, the [[Definition:Center of Circle|center of circle $ABC$]] is also on $NO$. But as the only point on both $AC$ and $NO$ is $P$, it follows that $P$ is the [[Definition:Center of Circle|center of circle $ABC$]]. Similarly, we can show that $P$ is also the [[Definition:Center of Circle|center of circle $DEF$]]. So we have two [[Definition:Circle|circles]] that [[Definition:Intersection (Geometry)|intersect]] which have the same [[Definition:Center of Circle|center]]. From [[Intersecting Circles have Different Centers]], this statement is contradictory. Hence such a pair of [[Definition:Circle|circles]], i.e. those that intersect at more points than two, can not exist. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|10|III}}

statement: Let two [[Definition:Circle|circles]] touch internally. Then the [[Definition:Straight Line|straight line]] joining their [[Definition:Center of Circle|centers]] passes through the [[Definition:Point|point]] where they touch. {{:Euclid:Proposition/III/11}}
rationale: Let the [[Definition:Circle|circles]] $ABC$ and $ADE$ touch internally at $A$. Let $F$ be the [[Definition:Center of Circle|center of $ABC$]] and let $G$ be the [[Definition:Center of Circle|center of $ADE$]]. We are to show that the [[Definition:Straight Line|straight line]] joining $F$ to $G$ passes through $A$. :[[File:Euclid-III-11.png|400px]] Suppose, as in the diagram above, that it does not. Let $FG$ fall on $H$ instead. It will also pass through $D$ on its way, which lies on [[Definition:Circle|circle]] $ADE$. [[Axiom:Euclid's First Postulate|Join]] $AF$ and $AG$. From [[Sum of Two Sides of Triangle Greater than Third Side]] $AG + GF$ is greater than $AF$. Therefore $AG + GF$ is greater than $FH$ as $F$ is the [[Definition:Center of Circle|center]] and both $AF$ and $FH$ are [[Definition:Radius of Circle|radii]]. So, subtract $FG$ from both $AG + GF$ and $FH$. It follows that $AG$ is greater than $GH$, and hence also greater than $GD$. But as $G$ is the [[Definition:Center of Circle|center of $ADE$]], it follows that $AG$ is supposed to be equal to $GD$. So the $AG + GF$ can not be greater than $AF$ and so must be coincident with it. Hence the result. {{Qed}} {{Euclid Note|11|III}}

statement: The corresponding proof: Let the circles $ABC$ and $ADE$ touch externally at $A$. Let $F$ be the center of $ABC$ and let $G$ be the center of $ADE$. We are to show that the straight line joining $F$ to $G$ passes through $A$.
rationale: Suppose, as in the diagram above, that it does not, and that it were possible for it to pass through $C$ and $D$, as $FCDG$. (It is clear that the diagram does ''not'' have $F$ and $G$ as the ''actual'' centers of these circles - it is the point of this proof to demonstrate that this would ''not'' be possible.) Join $AF$ and $AG$. We have that: * Since $F$ is the center of $ABC$, then $FA$ and $FC$ are both radii of $ABC$, and so $FA = FC$. * Since $G$ is the center of $ADE$, then $GA$ and $GD$ are both radii of $ADE$, and so $GA = GD$. So $FA + AG = FC + GD$. So all of $FCDG$ is greater than $FA + AG$. But from Sum of Two Sides of Triangle Greater than Third Side $FA + AG$ is greater than $FCDG$. Hence we have a contradiction, and so $FG$ has to go through point $A$, the point of contact of the two circles. Hence the result. Qed Euclid Note 12 III

statement: Let $f: S \to T$ be a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]]. Let $f^{-1}$ be the [[Definition:Inverse of Mapping|inverse]] of $f$. Let $f^{-1} \paren t$ be the [[Definition:Preimage of Element under Mapping|preimage]] of $t \in T$. Then $f^{-1} \paren t$ is [[Definition:Empty Set|empty]] for no $t \in T$ {{iff}} $f$ is a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]].
rationale:
=== Necessary Condition === We use a [[Proof by Contraposition]]. To that end, suppose: :$\exists t \in T: f^{-1} \paren t = \O$ That is: :$
eg \paren { orall t \in T: \exists s \in S: f \paren s = t}$ So, by definition, $f: S 	o T$ is not a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]]. From [[Rule of Transposition]] it follows that if $f$ is a surjection: $
eg \exists t \in T: f^{-1} \paren t = \O$ {{qed|lemma}} === Sufficient Condition === We again use a [[Proof by Contraposition]]. To that end, suppose $f$ is not a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]]. Then by definition: :$\exists t \in T: 
eg \paren {\exists s \in S: f \paren s = t}$ That is: :$\exists t \in T: f^{-1} \paren t = \O$ From [[Rule of Transposition]] it follows that if $
eg \exists t \in T: f^{-1} \paren t = \O$, then $f$ is a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]]. {{Qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {P, s, 0}\) be a [[Definition:Peano Structure|Peano structure]]. Then: :\(P \setminus s \sqbrk P\) is a [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]] where: :\(\setminus\) denotes [[Definition:Set Difference|set difference]] :\(s \sqbrk P\) denotes the [[Definition:Image of Mapping|image]] of the [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] \(s\). It follows that the [[Definition:Non-Successor Element|non-successor element]] \(0\) is the only element of \(P\) with this property.
rationale:
Let \(T = P \setminus s \sqbrk P\). From [[Axiom:Peano's Axioms|Axiom $(	ext P 4)$]] we know that \(T 
e \O\). Now suppose that \(t_1 \in T\) and \(t_2 \in T\). Aiming for a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose that \(t_1 
e t_2\). Define \(A = P \setminus \set {t_2}\). Thus \(t_1 \in A 
e P\). Moreover, by the nature of \(t_2\): :\(x \in A \implies \map s x \in A\) Thus, by the [[Axiom:Peano's Axioms|induction axiom $(	ext P 5)$]], \(A = P\). From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that \(P \setminus s \sqbrk P\) cannot contain two different elements. {{qed}}

statement: {{TFAE|def = Order of Group Element}} Let $G$ be a [[Definition:Group|group]] whose [[Definition:Identity Element|identity]] is $e$. Let $x \in G$.
rationale: Let $k$ be the order of $x$ in $G$ according to [[Definition:Order of Group Element/Definition 1|Definition 1]]. Let $l$ be the order of $x$ in $G$ according to [[Definition:Order of Group Element/Definition 3|Definition 3]]. === Definition $1$ is equivalent to Definition $3$ === {{AimForCont}} $k \ne l$. Then from [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]] either $k < l$ or $k > l$. According to [[Definition:Order of Group Element/Definition 3|Definition 3]]: :$\forall i, j \in \Z: 0 \le i < j < l \implies x^i \ne x^j$ If $k < l$, then letting $i = 0$ and $j = k$ yields a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] by [[Element to Power of Zero is Identity]]. If $k > l$, then: :$\exists i,j \in \Z: 0 \le i < j < k: x^i = x^j$ But then $x^{j - i} = e$ and $j - i < k$, [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicting]] the fact that $k \in \Z_{> 0}$ is the smallest such that $x^k = e$. Therefore $k = l$. {{qed|lemma}} === Definition $1$ is equivalent to Definition $2$ === It follows straight away from [[List of Elements in Finite Cyclic Group]] that $\order {\gen a} = k$: :$\gen a = \set {a^0, a^1, a^2, \ldots, a^{k - 1} }$ {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\RR \subseteq S \times T\) be a [[Definition:Relation|relation]] on \(S \times T\). Let \(\RR \circ \RR^{-1}\) be the [[Definition:Composition of Relations|composite]] of \(\RR\) with its [[Definition:Inverse Relation|inverse]]. Let \(I_T\) be the [[Definition:Identity Mapping|identity mapping]] on \(T\). Then: :\(\RR \circ \RR^{-1} = I_T\) {{iff}}: :\(\RR\) is [[Definition:Many-to-One Relation|many-to-one]] and: :\(\RR\) is [[Definition:Right-Total Relation|right-total]].

{{TFAE|def = Independent Subgroups}} Let $G$ be a [[Definition:Group|group]] whose [[Definition:Identity Element|identity]] is $e$. Let \\(\left \langle {H_n} \right \rangle\\) be a [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] of [[Definition:Independent Subgroups|independent subgroups]] of $G$.
rationale: === Definition 1 implies Definition 2 === Let $H_1, H_2, \\ldots, H_n$ be [[Definition:Independent Subgroups/Definition 1|independent by definition 1]]: :\\(\\displaystyle \\prod_{k \\mathop = 1}^n h_k = e \\iff \\forall k \\in \\left[{1 \\,.\,.\, n}\\right]: h_k = e\\) where $h_k \\in H_k$ for all $k \\in \\left[{1 \\,.\,.\, n}\\right]$. Let \\(\\displaystyle u \\in \\left({\\prod_{j \\mathop = 1}^{k-1} H_j}\\right) \\cap H_k\\). Then: : \\(\\displaystyle \\exists x_1, x_2, \\ldots, x_{k-1} \\in H_1, \\ldots, H_{k-1}: u = \\prod_{j \\mathop = 1}^{k-1} x_j\\) We have that $u \\in H_k$ and $H_k$ is a [[Definition:Group|group]]. Therefore let $x_k = u^{-1}$, the [[Definition:Inverse Element|inverse]] of $u$. For each $j \\in \\left\\{{k+1, k+2, \\ldots, n}\\right\\}$ let $x_j = e$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \\prod_{j \\mathop = 1}^n x_j       | r = \\left({\\prod_{j \\mathop = 1}^{k-1} x_j}\\right) u^{-1} \\left({\\prod_{j \\mathop = k+1}^{n} x_j}\\right)       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \\left({\\prod_{j \\mathop = 1}^{k-1} x_j}\\right) u^{-1}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = e       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} Thus by hypothesis $u^{-1} = e$ and hence $u = e$. Hence $H_1, H_2, \\ldots, H_n$ are [[Definition:Independent Subgroups/Definition 2|independent by definition 2]]: :\\(\\displaystyle \\forall k \\in \\left\\{{2, 3, \\ldots, n}\\right\\}: \\left({\\prod_{j \\mathop = 1}^{k-1} H_j}\\right) \\cap H_k = \\left\\{{e}\\right\\}\\) === Definition 2 implies Definition 1 === Let $H_1, H_2, \\ldots, H_n$ be [[Definition:Independent Subgroups/Definition 2|independent by definition 2]]: :\\(\\displaystyle \\forall k \\in \\left\\{{2, 3, \\ldots, n}\\right\\}: \\left({\\prod_{j \\mathop = 1}^{k-1} H_j}\\right) \\cap H_k = \\left\\{{e}\\right\\}\\) Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose that: : \\(\\displaystyle x_1, x_2, \\ldots, x_n \\in H_1, H_2, \\ldots, H_n: \\prod_{i \\mathop = 1}^n x_i = e\\) but that $x_j \\ne e$ for some $j \\in \\left\\{{1, 2, \\ldots, n}\\right\\}$. There is bound to be more than one of them, because otherwise that would mean: : \\(\\displaystyle \\prod_{i \\mathop = 1}^n x_i = x_j e = e \\implies x_j = e\\) So let $m$ be the largest of the $j$ such that $x_j \\ne e$. Then $m > 1$, and: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = e       | r = x_1 \\cdots x_n       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = x_1 \\cdots x_m       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \\left({x_1 \\cdots x_{m-1} }\\right) x_m       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} Thus: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = x_m^{-1}       | r = x_1 \\cdots x_{m-1}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = H_1 \\cdots H_{m-1}       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} So: : $x_m^{-1} \\in H_m$ Therefore [[Definition:By Hypothesis|by hypothesis]]: : $x_m^{-1} = e$ and therefore: : $x_m = e$ But $m$ was defined to be the largest of the $j$ such that $x_j \\ne e$. Thus by [[Proof by Contradiction]] it follows that there can be no such $j$ so that: : \\(\\displaystyle x_1, x_2, \\ldots, x_n \\in H_1, H_2, \\ldots, H_n: \\prod_{i \\mathop = 1}^n x_i = e\\) but that $x_j \\ne e$ for some $j \\in \\left\\{{1, 2, \\ldots, n}\\right\\}$. Hence $H_1, H_2, \\ldots, H_n$ are [[Definition:Independent Subgroups/Definition 1|independent by definition 1]]: :\\(\\displaystyle \\prod_{k \\mathop = 1}^n h_k = e \\iff \\forall k \\in \\left[{1 \\,.\,.\, n}\\right]: h_k = e\\) where $h_k \\in H_k$ for all $k \\in \\left[{1 \\,.\,.\, n}\\right]$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$ and $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ be [[Definition:Ordered Set|ordered sets]]. Let $\phi: \struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1} \to \struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ be an [[Definition:Order Isomorphism|order isomorphism]]. Then $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$ is a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]] {{iff}} $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ is also a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]].
rationale:
Let $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$ be a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]]. Then by definition $\preccurlyeq_1$ is a [[Definition:Well-Ordering|well-ordering]]. By [[Well-Ordering is Total Ordering]], $\preccurlyeq_1$ is a [[Definition:Total Ordering|total ordering]]. From [[Order Isomorphism on Totally Ordered Set preserves Total Ordering]], it follows that $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ is a [[Definition:Totally Ordered Set|totally ordered set]]. All that remains is to show that $\preccurlyeq$ is [[Definition:Well-Founded|well-founded]]. Let $T_1 \subseteq S_1$. As $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$ is a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]]: :$\exists m_1 \in T_1:  orall t \in T_1: t = m_1 \lor 
eg \paren {t \preccurlyeq_1 m_1}$ Now consider the [[Definition:Image of Element under Mapping|image]] $m_2$ of $m_1$ in $S_2$: :$m_2 = \map \phi {m_1}$ Suppose $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ is not a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]]. Let there exist $T_2 \subseteq S_2$ such that: :$\exists x \in T_2: x 
e m_2, x \preccurlyeq_2 m_2$ By [[Inverse of Order Isomorphism is Order Isomorphism]], if $\phi$ is an [[Definition:Order Isomorphism|order isomorphism]] then so is $\phi^{-1}$. Hence: :$\map {\phi^{-1} } x 
e \map {\phi^{-1} } {m_2}, \map {\phi^{-1} } x \preccurlyeq_2 \map {\phi^{-1} } {m_2}$ But this contradicts the fact that $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$ is [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered]]. Hence $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ must be a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]]. The same technique is used to show that if $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ is a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]] then so is $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $S$ be a [[Definition:Set|set]] and let \(\mathcal P \left({S}\right)\) be the [[Definition:Power Set|power set]] of $S$. Let $S_1, S_2, T \in \mathcal P \left({S}\right)$. Suppose that $S_1 \cap T = S_2 \cap T$. Then it is not necessarily the case that $S_1 = S_2$.
rationale: Proof by counterexample: Let $S = \left\{{1, 2, 3}\right\}$. Let $T = \left\{{3}\right\}. Let $S_1 = \left\{{1, 3}\right\}, S_2 = \left\{{2, 3}\right\}$ Then $S_1 \cap T = S_2 \cap T = \left\{{3}\right\}$ but $S_1 \ne S_2$. {{qed}} [[Category:Set Intersection]] b1v80uc46x69qbuvlgkeqgah7bdxw6a

statement: Let $A$ be a [[Definition:Commutative and Unitary Ring|commutative ring with unity]]. Let $A^	imes$ be the [[Definition:Group of Units of Ring|group of units]] of $A$. Let \(\map {\operatorname {Jac} } A\) be the [[Definition:Jacobson Radical|Jacobson radical]] of $A$. Then: :\(\map {\operatorname {Jac} } A = \set {a \in A: 1_A - a x \in A^\times \text{ for all } x \in A}\) where \(1_A\) is the [[Definition:Unity of Ring|unity]] of $A$.
rationale:
Recall the definition of [[Definition:Jacobson Radical|Jacobson radical]] of $A$: :\(\map {\operatorname {Jac} } A\) is the [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]] of all [[Definition:Maximal Ideal of Ring|maximal ideals]] of $R$. === \(\subset\) Direction === {{AimForCont}} that $x \in \map {\operatorname {Jac} } A$ such that there exists $y \in A$ such that $1_A - x y 
otin A^	imes$.  By definition $x$ is contained in all [[Definition:Maximal Ideal of Ring|maximal ideals]] of $A$. Let $\mathfrak m \subseteq A$ be one particular such [[Definition:Maximal Ideal of Ring|maximal ideal]] of $A$. Then $x \in \map {\operatorname {Jac} } A \subseteq \mathfrak m$ implies that $xy \in \mathfrak m$ and therefore $1_A \in \mathfrak m$. But if $1_A \in \mathfrak m$ then from [[Ideal of Unit is Whole Ring/Corollary|Ideal of Unit is Whole Ring: Corollary]]: :$\mathfrak m = R$ This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the definition of $\mathfrak m$ as a [[Definition:Maximal Ideal of Ring|maximal ideal]] of $A$. Hence by [[Proof by Contradiction]]: :\(\map {\operatorname {Jac} } A \subseteq \set {a \in A: 1_A - a x \in A^	imes 	ext{ for all } x \in A}\) {{qed|lemma}} === \(\supset\) Direction === Now suppose that $x 
otin \map {\operatorname {Jac} } A$. Then $x 
otin \mathfrak m$ for some [[Definition:Maximal Ideal of Ring|maximal ideal]] $\mathfrak m$ of $A$. Because $\mathfrak m$ is [[Definition:Maximal Ideal of Ring|maximal]], $x$ and $\mathfrak m$ [[Definition:Generator of Ring|generate]] $A$. Therefore there exist $w \in \mathfrak m$ and $y \in A$ such that $w + x y = 1_A$. Thus $1_A - x y \in \mathfrak m$, and $1_A - x y 
otin A^	imes$. Hence: :\(\map {\operatorname {Jac} } A \supseteq \set {a \in A: 1_A - a x \in A^	imes 	ext{ for all } x \in A}\) {{qed|lemma}} The result follows by definition of [[Definition:Set Equality|set equality]]. {{qed}} [[Category:Commutative Algebra]]

statement: Let \(\struct {D, +, \times}\) be an [[Definition:Integral Domain|integral domain]] whose [[Definition:Unity of Ring|unity]] is \(1_D\) and whose [[Definition:Order of Structure|order]] is [[Definition:Finite Order (Structure)|finite]]. Then \(D\) cannot be an [[Definition:Ordered Integral Domain|ordered integral domain]].
rationale: Let \(\struct {D, +, \times}\) be an [[Definition:Integral Domain|integral domain]] whose [[Definition:Order of Structure|order]] is \(n\). {{AimForCont}} there exists a [[Definition:Strict Positivity Property|(strict) positivity property]] \(P\) on \(\struct {D, +, \times}\). From [[Unity of Ordered Integral Domain is Strictly Positive]], we have that \(\map P {1_D}\). Let \(\struct {D, +}\) be the [[Definition:Additive Group of Ring|additive group]] of \(\struct {D, +, \times}\). From [[Order of Element Divides Order of Finite Group]], the [[Definition:Order of Group Element|order of \(1_D\)]] is also [[Definition:Finite Order Element|finite]]. So: :\(\exists m \in \N: m \cdot 1_D = 0_D\) where \(0_D\) is the [[Definition:Ring Zero|zero]] of \(D\). But then from the [[General Positivity Rule in Ordered Integral Domain]] that would mean \(\map P {0_D}\) which contradicts the [[Definition:Trichotomy Law (Integral Domain)|trichotomy law of the positivity property]]. Further, note that from [[Inverse Element is Power of Order Less 1]] we have that \(-1_D = \paren {m - 1} \cdot 1_D\). But from the [[General Positivity Rule in Ordered Integral Domain]] \(\map P {\paren {m - 1} \cdot 1_D}\) and so \(\map P {-1_D}\) which is an even more dramatic way of showing that the [[Definition:Trichotomy Law (Integral Domain)|trichotomy law of the positivity property]] is contradicted. Hence an [[Definition:Integral Domain|integral domain]] whose [[Definition:Order of Structure|order]] is [[Definition:Finite Order (Structure)|finite]] can not be [[Definition:Ordered Integral Domain|ordered]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $\struct {D, +, \times, \le}$ be a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Integral Domain|well-ordered integral domain]]. Let $0$ and $1$ be the [[Definition:Ring Zero|zero]] and [[Definition:Unity of Ring|unity]] respectively of $D$. Then $0$ is the [[Definition:Immediate Predecessor Element|immediate predecessor]] of $1$: :$0 < 1$ :$\neg \exists a \in D: 0 < a < 1$
rationale: {{AimForCont}} there exists an [[Definition:Element|element]] $a \in D$ such that $0 < a < 1$. Let us create the [[Definition:Set|set]] $S$ of all such [[Definition:Element|elements]]: :$S = \set {x \in D: 0 < x < 1}$ We know $S$ is not [[Definition:Empty Set|empty]] because it has already been asserted that $a$ is in it. And all the [[Definition:Element|elements]] in $S$ are [[Definition:Strictly Positive|strictly positive]] by definition. Because $D$ is [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered]] it follows that $S$ has a [[Definition:Minimal Element|minimal element]], which we will call $m$. Thus we have $0 < m < 1$. Then from [[Square of Element Less than Unity in Ordered Integral Domain]] we have: :$0 < m \times m < m$ Thus $m \times m \in S$ is an [[Definition:Element|element]] of $S$ which is smaller than $m$. But $m$ was supposed to be the [[Definition:Minimal Element|minimal element]] of $S$. From this contradiction we deduce that there can be no such [[Definition:Element|element]] $a$ such that $0 < a < 1$. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2}\) denote the [[Definition:Set|set]]: :\(\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2} := \set {a + b \sqrt 2: a, b \in \Z}\) that is, all [[Definition:Real Number|(real) numbers]] of the form \(a + b \sqrt 2\) where \(a\) and \(b\) are [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. Then the [[Definition:Algebraic Structure|algebraic structure]]: :\(\struct {\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2}, +, \times}\) where \(+\) and \(\times\) are [[Definition:Real Addition|addition]] and [[Definition:Real Multiplication|multiplication]] on [[Definition:Real Number|real numbers]], is '''not''' a [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]].
rationale: We start from the result [[Numbers of Type Integer a plus b root 2 form Subdomain of Reals]]. We have from that result that 1 + 0 \sqrt 2 is the [[Definition:Unity of Ring|unity]]. Now consider a representative element \(a + b \sqrt 2 \in \Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2}\). From [[Difference of Two Squares]] we have: :\(\paren {a + b \sqrt 2} \paren {a - b \sqrt 2} = a^2 - 2 b^2\) which leads to: :\(\paren {a + b \sqrt 2} \paren {\dfrac {a - b \sqrt 2} {a^2 - 2 b^2} } = 1\) so demonstrating that the [[Definition:Product Inverse|product inverse]] of \(\paren {a + b \sqrt 2}\) is \(\dfrac a {a^2 - 2b^2} + \dfrac {b \sqrt 2} {a^2 - 2 b^2}\). But for any two given integers \(a\) and \(b\), the values \(\dfrac a {a^2 - 2 b^2}\) and \(\dfrac b {a^2 - 2 b^2}\) are not in general [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. For instance, when \(a = 3\) and \(b = 4\) we get: :\(\dfrac a {a^2 - 2 b^2} = \dfrac 3 {23}\) and \(\dfrac b {a^2 - 2 b^2} = \dfrac 4 {23}\) (unless I've got my sums wrong).
