So not every element of \(\struct {\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2}, +, \times}\) has a [[Definition:Product Inverse|product inverse]], demonstrating that \(\struct {\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2}, +, \times}\) is not a [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]]. {{qed}}

statement: The characteristic of any subfield of the field of complex numbers is $0$.
rationale: Suppose to the contrary. Let $K$ be a subfield of $\C$ such that $\Char K = n$ where $n \in \N, n > 0$. Then: :$\exists a \in K: n \cdot a = 0$ But as $K$ is a subfield of $\C$ it follows that $K \subseteq \C$ which means: :$\exists a \in \C: n \cdot a = 0$ Thus, by definition of characteristic: :$0 < \Char \C \le n$ But $\C$ is infinite and so $\Char \C = 0$. From that contradiction follows the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {F, +, \circ}\) be a [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]] whose [[Definition:Field Zero|zero]] is \(0_F\) and whose [[Definition:Unity of Field|unity]] is \(1_F\). Let \(F \sqbrk X\) be the [[Definition:Ring of Polynomial Forms|ring of polynomial forms]] in an [[Definition:Indeterminate (Polynomial Theory)|indeterminate]] \(X\) over \(F\). Then the [[Definition:Unit of Ring|units]] of \(F \sqbrk X\) are all the elements of \(F \sqbrk X\) whose [[Definition:Degree (Polynomial)|degree]] is \(0\).
rationale: An element of \(F \sqbrk X\) whose [[Definition:Degree (Polynomial)|degree]] is \(0\) is merely an element of \(F\). But note that \(0_F\), considered as an element of \(F \sqbrk X\), has a [[Definition:Degree (Polynomial)|degree]] which is not defined, so the [[Definition:Null Polynomial over Ring|null polynomial]] is seen to be excluded. Any element \(a\) of \(F\) has an [[Definition:Inverse Element|inverse]] \(1_F / a\). So all the elements of \(F \sqbrk X\) whose [[Definition:Degree (Polynomial)|degree]] is \(0\) are [[Definition:Unit of Ring|units]] of \(F\) and hence of \(F \sqbrk X\). Now suppose \(\map a X \in F \sqbrk X\) is a [[Definition:Unit of Ring|unit]] of \(F \sqbrk X\). Then \(\map a X \, \map q X = 1_F\) for some \(\map q X \in F \sqbrk X\). Neither \(\map a X\) nor \(\map q X\) can be [[Definition:Null Polynomial over Ring|null]]. So by [[Properties of Degree]] \(\map \deg {\map a X} + \map \deg {\map q X} = 0\). So \(\map \deg {\map a X} = 0\). {{qed}}

statement: Let $T_A = \struct {S_A, \tau_A}$ and $T_B = \struct {S_B, \tau_B}$ be [[Definition:Topological Space|topological spaces]]. Let \phi: T_A \to T_B$ be a [[Definition:Closed Mapping|closed]] [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]]. If $T_A$ is a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]], then so is $T_B$.
rationale:
Let $T_A$ be a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]]. By [[Bijection is Open iff Closed]], $\phi$ is an [[Definition:Open Mapping|open]] [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]]. By [[Bijection is Open iff Inverse is Continuous]], it follows that $\phi^{-1}$ is [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]]. By definition:  :$ orall x, y \in S_A$, either: ::$\exists U \in 	au_A: x \in U, y 
otin U$ :or: ::$\exists U \in 	au_A: y \in U, x 
otin U$ Suppose that: :$\exists x, y \in S_B:  orall V \in 	au_B: x, y \in V \lor x, y 
otin V$ That is: :$\exists x, y \in S_B:  orall V \in 	au_B: \set {x, y} \subseteq V \lor \set {x, y} \cap V = \O$ From [[Image of Subset under Relation is Subset of Image/Corollary 3|Image of Subset under Relation is Subset of Image: Corollary 3]] it follows that: :$ orall V \in 	au_B: \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {\set {x, y} } \subseteq \phi^{-1} \sqbrk V \lor \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {\set {x, y} } \cap \phi^{-1} \sqbrk V = \O$ that is: :$ orall V \in 	au_B: \map {\phi^{-1} } x, \map {\phi^{-1} } y \in \phi^{-1} \sqbrk V \lor \map {\phi^{-1} } x, \map {\phi^{-1} } y 
otin \phi^{-1} \sqbrk V$ But by definition of [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous mapping]], $U = \phi^{-1} \sqbrk V$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] in $T_A$ {{iff}} $V$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] in $T_B$. Thus: :$ orall U \in 	au_A: \map {\phi^{-1} } x, \map {\phi^{-1} } y \in U \lor \map {\phi^{-1} } x, \map {\phi^{-1} } y 
otin U$ This contradicts the condition that $T_A$ is a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]]. It follows that $T_B$ must also be a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T_A = \struct {S_A, \tau_A}$ and $T_B = \struct {S_B, \tau_B}$ be [[Definition:Topological Space|topological spaces]]. Let $\phi: T_A \to T_B$ be a [[Definition:Closed Mapping|closed]] [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]]. If $T_A$ is a [[Definition:Completely Hausdorff Space|$T_{2 \frac 1 2}$ (completely Hausdorff) space]], then so is $T_B$.
rationale:
Let $T_A$ be a [[Definition:Completely Hausdorff Space|$T_{2  rac 1 2}$ (completely Hausdorff) space]]. Then: :$ orall x, y \in S_A, x 
e y: \exists U_A, V_A \in 	au_A: x \in U_A, y \in V_A: U_A^- \cap V_A^- = \O$ where $U_A^-$ signifies the [[Definition:Closure (Topology)|closure]] of $U_A$. Suppose that $T_B$ is not [[Definition:Completely Hausdorff Space|completely Hausdorff]]. Then: :$\exists a, b \in S_B: a 
e b:  orall U_B, V_B \in 	au_B: a \in U_B, b \in V_B \implies U_B^- \cap V_B^- 
e \O$ That is, there exists at least one pair of points $a$ and $b$ for which the [[Definition:Closure (Topology)|closures]] of all the [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]] containing $a$ and $b$ are not [[Definition:Disjoint Sets|disjoint]]. From [[Topological Closure is Closed]], both $U_B^-$ and $V_B^-$ are [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. From [[Topology Defined by Closed Sets]], it follows that $W_B = U_B^- \cap V_B^-$ is also a [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed set]]. From [[Preimage of Intersection under Mapping]], we have: :$\phi^{-1} \sqbrk {U_B^- \cap V_B^-} = \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {U_B^-} \cap \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {V_B^-}$ Let $H_A = \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {U_B^-}, K_A = \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {V_B^-}, W_A = \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {W_B}$. Then we have: :$H_A \cap K_A = W_A 
e \O$ By [[Bijection is Open iff Closed]], $\phi$ is an [[Definition:Open Mapping|open]] [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]]. By [[Bijection is Open iff Inverse is Continuous]], it follows that $\phi^{-1}$ is [[Definition:Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]]. From [[Continuity Defined from Closed Sets]], we have that $H_A$, $K_A$ and $W_A$ are all [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. Also, let $U_A = \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {U_B}$ and $V_A = \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {V_B}$. From [[Continuity Defined by Closure]], we have that: :$\phi^{-1} \sqbrk {U_B^-} \subseteq \paren {\phi^{-1} \sqbrk {U_B} }^-$ :$\phi^{-1} \sqbrk {V_B^-} \subseteq \paren {\phi^{-1} \sqbrk {V_B} }^-$ that is: :$H_A \subseteq U_A^-$ :$K_A \subseteq V_A^-$ As $H_A \cap K_A 
e \O$ it follows that $U_A^- \cap V_A^- 
e \O$. From the [[Definition:Bijection|bijective]] nature of $\phi$, we have that: :$a \in U_B \implies \map {\phi^{-1} } a \in U_A$ :$b \in V_B \implies \map {\phi^{-1} } b \in V_A$ Let $x = \map {\phi^{-1} } a, y = \map {\phi^{-1} } b$. Thus we have that: :$\exists x, y \in X_A: x 
e y:  orall U_A, V_A \in 	au_A: x \in U_A, y \in V_A \implies U_A^- \cap V_A^- 
e \O$ contradicting the fact that $T_A$ is a [[Definition:Completely Hausdorff Space|$T_{2  rac 1 2}$ (completely Hausdorff) space]]. Hence $T_B$ must after all be a [[Definition:Completely Hausdorff Space|$T_{2  rac 1 2}$ (completely Hausdorff) space]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T_A = \struct {S_A, \tau_A}$ and $T_B = \struct {S_B, \tau_B}$ be [[Definition:Topological Space|topological spaces]]. Let $\phi: T_A \to T_B$ be a [[Definition:Closed Mapping|closed]] [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]]. If $T_A$ is a [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|$T_2$ (Hausdorff) space]], then so is $T_B$.
rationale:
Let $T_A$ be a [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|$T_2$ (Hausdorff) space]]. Then: :$ orall x, y \in S_A, x 
e y: \exists U_A, V_A \in 	au_A: x \in U_A, y \in V_A: U_A \cap V_A = \O$ Suppose that $T_B$ is not [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff]]. Then: :$\exists a, b \in S_B: a 
e b:  orall U_B, V_B \in 	au_B: a \in U_B, b \in V_B \implies U_B \cap V_B 
e \O$ That is, there exists at least one pair of points $a$ and $b$ for which all the [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]] containing $a$ and $b$ are not [[Definition:Disjoint Sets|disjoint]]. As $	au_B$ is a [[Definition:Topology|topology]], it follows that $W_B = U_B \cap V_B$ is also an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]]. Let $U_A = \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {U_B}, V_A = \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {V_B}, W_A = \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {W_B}$. From [[Preimage of Intersection under Mapping]], we have: :$\phi^{-1} \sqbrk {U_B \cap V_B} = \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {U_B} \cap \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {V_B}$ that is: :$U_A \cap V_A = W_A$ By [[Bijection is Open iff Closed]], $\phi$ is an [[Definition:Open Mapping|open]] [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]]. By [[Bijection is Open iff Inverse is Continuous]], it follows that $\phi^{-1}$ is [[Definition:Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]]. As $\phi$ is [[Definition:Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]], all of $U_A, V_A, W_A$ are [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open in $T_A$]]. From the [[Definition:Bijection|bijective]] nature of $\phi$, we have that: :$a \in U_B \implies \map {\phi^{-1} } a \in U_A$ :$b \in V_B \implies \map {\phi^{-1} } b \in V_A$ Let $x = \map {\phi^{-1} } a, y = \map {\phi^{-1} } b$. Thus we have that: :$\exists x, y \in S_A: x 
e y:  orall U_A, V_A \in 	au_A: x \in U_A, y \in V_A \implies U_A \cap V_A 
e \O$ contradicting the fact that $T_A$ is a [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|$T_2$ (Hausdorff) space]]. Hence $T_B$ must after all be a [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|$T_2$ (Hausdorff) space]]. {{qed}}

statement: The corresponding proof: Let every [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] of $S$ have a [[Definition:Finite Subcover|finite subcover]].
rationale: Let $\AA$ be any [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] [[Definition:Subset|subsets]] of $S$ satisfying $\displaystyle \bigcap \AA = \O$. We define the [[Definition:Set|set]]: :$\VV := \set {S \setminus A : A \in \AA}$ which is trivially an [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] of $S$. From [[De Morgan's Laws (Set Theory)/Set Difference/General Case/Difference with Union|De Morgan's Laws: Difference with Union]]: :$\displaystyle S \setminus \bigcup \VV = \bigcap \set {S \setminus V : V \in \VV} = \bigcap \set {A : A \in \AA} = \O$ and therefore: :$S = \displaystyle \bigcup \VV$ By definition, there exists a [[Definition:Finite Subcover|finite subcover]] $\tilde \VV \subseteq \VV$. We define: :$\tilde \AA := \set {S \setminus V : V \in \tilde \VV}$ then $\tilde \AA \subseteq \AA$ by definition of $\VV$. Because $\tilde \VV$ covers $S$, it follows directly that: :$\displaystyle \bigcap \tilde \AA = \bigcap \set {S \setminus V : V \in \tilde \VV} = S \setminus \bigcup \tilde \VV = \O$ Thus, in every [[Definition:Set|set]] $\AA$ of [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] [[Definition:Subset|subsets]] of $S$ satisfying $\displaystyle \bigcap \AA = \O$ exists a [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] $\tilde \AA$ such that $\displaystyle \bigcap \tilde \AA = \O$. That is, $S$ satisfies the [[Definition:Finite Intersection Axiom|Finite Intersection Axiom]]. {{qed|lemma}} The converse works exactly as the previous, but with the roles of the [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] and $\AA$ reversed. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Normal Space|normal space]]. Then $T$ is [[Definition:Pseudocompact Space|pseudocompact]] {{iff}} $T$ is [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact]].
rationale: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Normal Space|normal space]]. By [[Countably Compact Space is Pseudocompact]] we already have that if $T$ is [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact]] then $T$ is [[Definition:Pseudocompact Space|pseudocompact]]. It remains to prove that if $T$ is [[Definition:Pseudocompact Space|pseudocompact]] then $T$ is [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact]]. {{AimForCont}} $T$ is not [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact]]. By definition of [[Definition:Countably Compact Space/Definition 5|countably compact space]], $S$ contains an [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] $H = \set {x_n}$ with no [[Definition:Omega-Accumulation Point|$\omega$-accumulation point]] in $T$. Since, by definition of [[Definition:Normal Space|normal]], $S$ is a [[Definition:T1 Space|$T_1$ space]], $H$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] and [[Definition:Discrete Space|discrete]] in the [[Definition:Topological Subspace|subspace topology]]. {{Explain|$H$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] and [[Definition:Discrete Space|discrete]] in the [[Definition:Topological Subspace|subspace topology]].}} By definition, $T$ is [[Definition:Pseudocompact Space|pseudocompact]] {{iff}} every [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]] [[Definition:Real-Valued Function|real-valued function]] on $S$ is [[Definition:Bounded Real-Valued Function|bounded]]. By definition of [[Definition:Normal Space|normal]], we have that $S$ is a [[Definition:T4 Space|$T_4$ space]]. Hence the [[Tietze Extension Theorem]] guarantees a [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]] [[Definition:Extension of Mapping|extension]] to $S$ of the [[Definition:Unbounded Mapping|unbounded]] [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous mapping]] $f: H \to \R$ defined by $\map f {x_n} = n$. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] our hypothesis that $S$ is [[Definition:Pseudocompact Space|pseudocompact]]. It follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]] that $T$ is [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\zeta\) be the [[Definition:Riemann Zeta Function|Riemann zeta function]]. Then for all \(t \in \R\), \(\zeta(1 + it) \neq 0\)
rationale: Throughout, the complex variable \(s\) is \(s = \sigma + it\). We have, for \(\sigma > 1\), {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn|l= -\frac{\zeta'(s)}{\zeta(s)} |r= \sum_{n\geq 1} \Lambda(n) n^{-s} |c= By [[Logarithmic Derivative of Riemann Zeta Function]] }} {{eqn|l= |r=\sum_{n\geq 1} \Lambda(n) n^{-\sigma} \exp\left( -it\log n\right) |c=Where \(s = \sigma + it\) }} {{eqn|l= |r=\sum_{n\geq 1} \Lambda(n) n^{-\sigma} \left( \cos(t\log n) - i \sin(t\log n) \right) |c=By [[Euler's Formula]] }} {{end-eqn}} Therefore, :\(-\Re\left( \frac{\zeta'(s)}{\zeta(s)} \right) = \sum_{n\geq 1} \Lambda(n) n^{-\sigma} \cos(t\log n) \qquad (1)\) Now observe that :\(3 + 4\cos\theta + \cos(2\theta) = 2(1+ \cos\theta)^2 \geq 0\) Because for all \(n \geq 1\) we have \(\Lambda(n)n^{-\sigma} \geq 0\), we have {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn|l=0 |r=\sum_{n\geq 1} \Lambda(n) n^{-\sigma} \left\{ 3 + 4\cos(t\log n) + \cos(2t\log n) \right\} |c= |o=\leq }} {{eqn|l= |r=-\Re\left( 3\frac{\zeta'(\sigma)}{\zeta(\sigma)} + 4\frac{\zeta'(\sigma + it)}{\zeta(\sigma + it)} + \frac{\zeta'(\sigma + 2it)}{\zeta(\sigma + 2it)} \right) |c=By $(1)$ }} {{end-eqn}} Now let :\(\eta(s) = \zeta(s)^3\cdot \zeta(s+it)^4\cdot \zeta(s+2it)\) Then the above computation has shown that :\(\displaystyle\Re\left( \frac{\eta'(s)}{\eta(s)} \right) \leq 0\) By [[Poles of Riemann Zeta Function]] we know that \(\zeta\) has a [[Definition:Simple Pole|simple pole]] at \(s=1\) with [[Definition:Residue (Complex Analysis)|residue]] \(1\). Suppose that \(1+it\) is a zero of \(\zeta\) of [[Definition:Order of a Zero|order]] \(d \geq 1\). Therefore, at \(s = 1\), \(\eta\) has a zero of order \(4d - 3 \geq 0\), that is, :\(\displaystyle \eta(s) \sim (s-1)^{4d -3}\) as \(s \to 1^+\), where \(\sim\) indicates asymptotic equality, and superscript \(+\) denotes a limit from the right along the real line. Therefore :\(\displaystyle \frac{\eta'(s)}{\eta(s)} \sim \frac{4d -3}{s-1}\) as \(s \to 1^+\). Since \(\displaystyle \Re\left( \frac{4d -3}{s-1}\right) \to + \infty\) as \(s \to 1^+\), it follows that :\(\displaystyle \Re\left(\frac{\eta'(s)}{\eta(s)}\right) \to \infty\) as \(s \to 1^+\). But we have already shown that :\(\displaystyle\Re\left( \frac{\eta'(s)}{\eta(s)} \right) \leq 0\) a contradiction. {{qed}} [[Category:Riemann Zeta Function]] fo6o84yn30601r2nq1x3org4ioua0l4

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Fully T4 Space|fully $T_4$ space]]. Then $T$ is a [[Definition:T4 Space|$T_4$ space]].
rationale:
Recall that $\struct {S, 	au}$ is a [[Definition:T4 Space|$T_4$ space]] {{iff}}: :$ orall A, B \in \map \complement 	au, A \cap B = \O: \exists U, V \in 	au: A \subseteq U, B \subseteq V, U \cap V = \O$ That is, for any two [[Definition:Disjoint Sets|disjoint]] [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed sets]] $A, B \subseteq X$ there exist [[Definition:Disjoint Sets|disjoint]] [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]] $U, V \in 	au$ containing $A$ and $B$ respectively. Consider the [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] $\UU = \set {\map \complement A, \map \complement B}$. Since $T$ is [[Definition:Fully T4 Space|fully $T_4$]], there exists a [[Definition:Star Refinement|star refinement]] $\VV$ of $\UU$. Define $\VV_A$ and $\VV_B$ by: :$\VV_A := \set {V \in \VV: A \cap V 
e \O}$ :$\VV_B := \set {V \in \VV: B \cap V 
e \O}$ and subsequently $U_A$ and $U_B$ by: :$U_A :=  igcup \VV_A$ :$U_B :=  igcup \VV_B$ Now given $a \in A$, since $\VV$ is a [[Definition:Open Cover|cover]], there exists $V \in \VV$ such that $a \in V$. But then $V \in \VV_A$, so that: :$a \in U_A$ Hence $A \subseteq U_A$, and similarly $B \subseteq U_B$. {{AimForCont}} that $x \in U_A \cap U_B$. Then there exist $V_A \in \VV_A, V_B \in \VV_B$ such that: :$x \in V_A, x \in V_B$ By definition of $\VV_A$ and $\VV_B$, there exist: :$a \in A \cap V_A$ :$b \in B \cap V_B$ Now recall the definition of the [[Definition:Star (Topology)|star]] $x^*$ of $x$: :$x^* :=  igcup \set {V \in \VV: x \in V}$ Since $T$ is [[Definition:Fully T4 Space|fully $T_4$]], either $x^* \subseteq \map \complement A$ or $x^* \subseteq \map \complement B$. But $a \in V_A \subseteq x^*$, so $x^* 
subseteq \map \complement A$. Similarly $b \in V_B \subseteq x^*$, so $x^* 
subseteq \map \complement B$. From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] it is inferred that $x \in U_A \cap U_B$ cannot exist. That is: :$U_A \cap U_B = \O$ and it follows that $T$ is a [[Definition:T4 Space|$T_4$ space]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Separable Space|separable topological space]] which is also [[Definition:Metacompact Space|metacompact]]. Then $T$ is a [[Definition:Lindelöf Space|Lindelöf space]].
rationale: $T$ is [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]] {{iff}} there exists a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$ which is [[Definition:Everywhere Dense|everywhere dense]]. $T$ is [[Definition:Metacompact Space|metacompact]] {{iff}} every [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] of $S$ has an [[Definition:Open Refinement|open refinement]] which is [[Definition:Point Finite|point finite]]. $T$ is a [[Definition:Lindelöf Space|Lindelöf space]] if every [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] of $S$ has a [[Definition:Countable Subcover|countable subcover]]. Having established the definitions, we proceed. Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]] and [[Definition:Metacompact Space|metacompact]]. {{AimForCont}} there exists an [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] $\UU$ of $S$ which has no [[Definition:Countable Subcover|countable subcover]]. As $T$ is [[Definition:Metacompact Space|metacompact]], $\UU$ has an [[Definition:Open Refinement|open refinement]] $\VV$ which is [[Definition:Point Finite|point finite]]. By nature of $\UU$, which has no [[Definition:Countable Subcover|countable subcover]], $\VV$ is [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable]]. {{explain|How would $\VV$ being countable lead to a countable subcover of $\UU$? ACC is helpful for this.}} [[Definition:By Hypothesis|By hypothesis]], $T$ is [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]]. Let $\SS$ be a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$ which is [[Definition:Everywhere Dense|everywhere dense]]. Then each $V \in \VV$ contains some $s \in \SS$. {{explain|why? Also, this is not true if $\VV$ contains the empty set.}} So some $s \in \SS$ is contained in an [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable]] number of elements of $\VV$. Thus, by definition, $\VV$ is not [[Definition:Point Finite|point finite]]. Thus no [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable]] [[Definition:Open Refinement|open refinement]] $\VV$ of $\UU$ exists which is [[Definition:Point Finite|point finite]]. It follows that $\VV$ must be [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. Thus $\UU$ has a [[Definition:Countable Subcover|countable subcover]]. That is, by definition, $T$ is a [[Definition:Lindelöf Space|Lindelöf space]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\psi\) be a [[Definition:Dirichlet Character#Trivial Character|non-trivial Dirichlet charater]] modulo \(q\). Let \(\map L {s, \chi}\) be the [[Definition:Dirichlet L-function|Dirichlet \(L\)-function associated to \(\chi\)]]. Then \(\map L {1, \chi} \ne 0\).
rationale: Let \(G^*\) be the [[Definition:Group|group]] of characters modulo \(q\). {{explain|"[[Definition:Group|group]] of characters modulo \(q\)" - we have the definition for character, and we have (somewhere) the definition of the ring of integers modulo \(q\), but not this entity.}} Let \(\displaystyle \map {\zeta_q} s = \prod_{\chi \mathop \in G^*} \map L {s, \chi} R\). Among the factors of \(\zeta_q\) is the the \(L\)-function associated to the trivial character, which by [[Analytic Continuation of Dirichlet L-Function]] we know to have a [[Definition:Simple Pole|simple pole]] at \(s = 1\). {{AimForCont}} \(\map L {1, \psi} = 0\).  Then the zero of this factor kills the [[Definition:Pole (Complex Analysis)|pole]] of the principal \(L\)-function. So by [[Analytic Continuation of Dirichlet L-Function]] \(\zeta_q\) is analytic on \(\map \Re s > 0\). For \(\map \Re s > 1\) we have: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \map {\zeta_q} s       | r = \prod_{\chi \mathop \in G^*} \prod_p \frac 1 {1 - \map \chi p p^{-s} }       | c = [[Euler Product]], where \(p\) ranges over the [[Definition:Prime Number|primes]] }} {{eqn | r = \prod_{p \mathop \nmid q} \prod_{\chi \mathop \in G^*}  \frac 1 {1 - \map \chi p p^{-s} }       | c = because the [[Euler Product]] is [[Definition:Absolutely Convergent Series|absolutely convergent]] }} {{end-eqn}} For any prime \(p\), let \(f_p\) be the order of \(p\) mod \(q\). {{explain|order}} Then: :\(\map \chi p^{f_p} = \map \chi {p^{f_p} } = \map \chi 1 = 1\) So \(\map \chi p\) is an \(f_p\)th root of unity. Moreover by the [[Orthogonality Relations for Characters]] each distinct such root occurs \(\map \phi q / f_p\) times among the numbers \(\map \chi p\) where \(\chi \in G^*\). Also, letting \(\xi\) be a primitive \(f_p\)th root of unity we find that for any \(u \in \C\): :\(\displaystyle \prod_{i \mathop = 0}^{f_p} \paren {1 - \xi^i u} = 1 - u^\xi\) Putting these facts together: :\(\displaystyle \prod_{\chi \mathop \in G^*} \frac 1 {1 - \map \chi p p^{-s} } = \paren {\frac 1 {1 - p^{-f_p s} } }^{\map \phi q / f_p}\) Therefore: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \map {\zeta_q} s       | r = \prod_{p \mathop \divides q} \paren {\frac 1 {1 - p^{-f_p s} } }^{\map \phi q / f_p}       | c = }} {{eqn | r = \prod_{p \mathop \divides q} \paren {1 + p^{-f_p s} + p^{-2 f_p s} + \cdots}^{\map \phi q / f_p}       | c = }} {{end-eqn}} Also, if \(\chi_0\) is the trivial character modulo \(q\), by [[Euler Product]] we have: :\(\displaystyle \map L {\map \phi q s, \chi_0} = \prod_{p \mathop \nmid q} \paren {1 + p^{-\map \phi q s} + p^{-2 \map \phi q s} + \cdots}\) from which we see that for \(s \in \R_{\ge 0}\): :\(\map {\zeta_q} s \ge \map L {\map \phi q s, \chi_0}\) However, by [[Analytic Continuation of Dirichlet L-Function]], \(\map L {\map \phi q s, \chi_0}\) diverges for \(s = \map \phi q^{-1}\), and therefore so does \(\map {\zeta_q} s\). But we showed above that \(\map {\zeta_q} s\) converges for \(\map \Re s > 0\), a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. {{qed}} [[Category:Analytic Number Theory]] 9xcwrmj6yiktscec0jn9tgxixhzz0vh

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff space]] which is [[Definition:Compact Topological Space|compact]]. Then $\tau$ is the [[Definition:Minimal Set|minimal]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of the [[Definition:Power Set|power set]] $\powerset S$ such that $T$ is a [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff space]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} there exists a [[Definition:Topology|topology]] $\\tau'$ on $S$ such that: :$\\tau' \\subseteq \\tau$ but $\\tau' \\ne \\tau$ :$\\tau'$ is a [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff space]]. From [[Equivalence of Definitions of Finer Topology]]: :the [[Definition:Identity Mapping|identity mapping]] $I_S: \\struct {S, \\tau} \\to \\struct {S, \\tau'}$ is [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]]. Let $A \\in \\tau$. Then $S \\setminus A \\subseteq S$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] in $\\struct {S, \\tau}$. By [[Closed Subspace of Compact Space is Compact]], $S \\setminus A$ is [[Definition:Compact Topological Space|compact]] in $\\struct {S, \\tau}$. From [[Continuous Image of Compact Space is Compact]]: :$I_S \\sqbrk {S \\setminus A}$ is also [[Definition:Compact Topological Space|compact]]. [[Definition:By Hypothesis|By hypothesis]], $\\struct {S, \\tau'}$ is a [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff space]]. From [[Compact Subspace of Hausdorff Space is Closed]]: :$I_S \\sqbrk {S \\setminus A}$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] in $\\struct {S, \\tau'}$. Hence: :$A = S \\setminus I_S \\sqbrk {S \\setminus A} \\in \\tau'$ By definition of [[Definition:Subset|subset]]: :$\\tau \\subseteq \\tau'$ Thus we have that $\\tau \\subseteq \\tau'$ and $\\tau' \\subseteq \\tau$. Hence by definition of [[Definition:Equality of Sets|set equality]]: :$\\tau' = \\tau$ But this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] our hypothesis that $\\tau' \\ne \\tau$. By [[Proof by Contradiction]], it follows that no [[Definition:Topology|topology]] which is [[Definition:Strictly Coarser Topology|strictly coarser]] than $\\tau$ can be [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff space]] which is [[Definition:Compact Topological Space|compact]]. Then $\tau$ is [[Definition:Maximal Set|maximally]] [[Definition:Compact Topological Space|compact]].
rationale: Let $\tau'$ be a [[Definition:Topology|topology]] on $S$ such that $\tau \subseteq \tau'$ but that $\tau \ne \tau'$. Consider the [[Definition:Identity Mapping|identity mapping]] $I_S: \struct {S, \tau'} \to \struct {S, \tau}$. From [[Separation Properties Preserved in Subspace]], $I_S$ is a [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]] [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]] from a [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff space]] to a [[Definition:Compact Topological Space|compact]] [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff space]]. {{AimForCont}} $\struct {S, \tau'}$ is [[Definition:Compact Topological Space|compact]]. Then $I_S$ is also [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]], and so $\tau' \subseteq \tau$. {{explain|Why does the fact that $\struct {S, \tau'}$ is compact mean $I_S$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]?}} Thus we have that $\tau \subseteq \tau'$ and $\tau' \subseteq \tau$. Hence by definition of [[Definition:Equality of Sets|set equality]]: :$\tau' = \tau$ But this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] our hypothesis that $\tau' \ne \tau$. By [[Proof by Contradiction]], it follows that no [[Definition:Topology|topology]] which is [[Definition:Finer Topology|strictly finer]] than $\tau$ can be [[Definition:Compact Topological Space|compact]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $H \subseteq S$ be [[Definition:Clopen Set|both closed and open]] in $T$. Then $H$ contains the [[Definition:Component (Topology)|components]] of all of its points.
rationale: Let $H$ be a [[Definition:Clopen Set|clopen set]] in $T$. By definition, $H$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] and so $H \in \tau$. But as $H$ is also [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]], by definition $\relcomp S H \in \tau$ where $\complement_S$ denotes [[Definition:Relative Complement|complement relative to $S$]]. Thus $H$ and $\relcomp S H$ are both [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] such that: :$H \cap \relcomp S H = \O$ from [[Intersection with Relative Complement is Empty]] :$H \cup \relcomp S H = S$ from [[Union with Relative Complement]] and so forming a [[Definition:Partition (Topology)|partition]] of $T$. As $H$ and $\relcomp S H$ are both [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]], it follows from [[Closed Set Equals its Closure]] that: :$H \cap \paren {\relcomp S H}^- = \O = H^- \cap \relcomp S H$ and so by definition $H$ and $\relcomp S H$ are [[Definition:Separated Sets|separated]]. {{AimForCont}} that $H$ does not contain the [[Definition:Component (Topology)|components]] of all of its points. That is: :$\exists x \in H: \map {\operatorname {Comp}_x} T \nsubseteq H$ where $\map {\operatorname {Comp}_x} T$ is the [[Definition:Component (Topology)|component]] of $x$ in $T$. Then: :$\exists z \in \map {\operatorname {Comp}_x} T: z \in H \cup \relcomp S H$ This means that $H \cup \relcomp S H$ is [[Definition:Connected Set (Topology)|connected]]. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the fact that $H$ and $\relcomp S H$ are [[Definition:Separated Sets|separated]]. The result follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] which is [[Definition:Ultraconnected Space|ultraconnected]]. If $S$ has more than one [[Definition:Element|element]], then $T$ is not a [[Definition:Fréchet Space (Topology)|$T_1$ (Fréchet) space]]. That is, if $T$ is a [[Definition:Fréchet Space (Topology)|$T_1$ (Fréchet) space]] with more than one [[Definition:Element|element]], it is not [[Definition:Ultraconnected Space|ultraconnected]].
rationale: $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be [[Definition:Ultraconnected Space|ultraconnected]]. Thus by definition: :$(1): \quad \forall x, y \in S: \set x^- \cap \set y^- \ne \O$ Let $a, b \in S$ such that $a \ne b$. {{AimForCont}} $T$ is a [[Definition:Fréchet Space (Topology)|$T_1$ (Fréchet) space]]. By definition of [[Definition:Fréchet Space (Topology)/Definition 2|$T_1$ Space]], $\set a$ and $\set b$ are [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. From [[Closed Set Equals its Closure]] we have that $\set a^- = \set a$ and $\set b^- = \set b$. It immediately follows that: :$\set a^- \cap \set b^- = \O$ But that [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] $(1)$ above.  The result follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be [[Definition:Totally Separated Space/Definition 1|'''totally separated''' by definition 1]]: :For every $x, y \in S: x \ne y$ there exists a [[Definition:Separation (Topology)|separation]] $U \mid V$ of $T$ such that $x \in U, y \in V$.
rationale: {{AimForCont}} there exist $x, y \in S$ such that $x \ne y$ such that $x$ and $y$ are in the same [[Definition:Quasicomponent|quasicomponent]] of $T$. Then, by definition of [[Definition:Quasicomponent|quasicomponent]], every [[Definition:Separation (Topology)|separation]] of $T$ includes a single [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] $U \in \tau$ which contains both $x$ and $y$. But this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] our stipulation that there exists a [[Definition:Separation (Topology)|separation]] $U \mid V$ of $T$ such that $x \in U, y \in V$. So there exists no [[Definition:Quasicomponent|quasicomponent]] of $T$ with more than one [[Definition:Element|element]]. That is, $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ is [[Definition:Totally Separated Space/Definition 2|'''totally separated''' by definition 2]]. {{qed|lemma}} Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be [[Definition:Totally Separated Space/Definition 2|'''totally separated''' by definition 2]]: :Each of its [[Definition:Quasicomponent|quasicomponents]] is a [[Definition:Singleton|singleton set]]. {{AimForCont}} there exist $x, y$ such that there exists no [[Definition:Separation (Topology)|separation]] $U \mid V$ of $T$ such that $x \in U, y \in V$. That is, each [[Definition:Separation (Topology)|separation]] of $T$ contains an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] $U \in \tau$ which contains both $x$ and $y$. That is, there exists a [[Definition:Quasicomponent|quasicomponent]] which contains both $x$ and $y$. But this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] our stipulation that every [[Definition:Quasicomponent|quasicomponent]] of $T$ is a [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]. So for every $x, y \in S: x \ne y$ there exists a [[Definition:Separation (Topology)|separation]] $U \mid V$ of $T$ such that $x \in U, y \in V$. That is, $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ is [[Definition:Totally Separated Space/Definition 1|'''totally separated''' by definition 1]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Fréchet Space (Topology)|$T_1$ (Fréchet) topological space]]. Let $H \subseteq S$ be [[Definition:Connected Set (Topology)|connected]] in $T$. If $H$ has more than one element, then $H$ is [[Definition:Dense-in-itself|dense-in-itself]].
rationale:
{{AimForCont}} $H$ is not [[Definition:Dense-in-itself|dense-in-itself]]. Then $\exists x \in H$ such that $x$ is [[Definition:Isolated Point of Subset|isolated]] in $H$. That is, $\exists U \in 	au: U \cap H = \set x$. Since $H$ has more than one element, we can find $y \in H$ with $y 
e x$. Since $T$ is [[Definition:Fréchet Space (Topology)|$T_1$]]: :$ orall y \in H: y 
e x \implies \paren {\exists V_y \in 	au: y \in V_y, x 
otin V_y}$ Define $V = \displaystyle  igcup_{y \in H\ y 
e x} V_y$. Then $ orall z \in H$: :$z = x \implies z \in U$ :$z 
e x \implies z \in V_z \subseteq V$ Showing that $H \subseteq U \cup V$. This also shows that both $U \cap H$ and $V \cap H$ are non-empty. Since $x 
otin V_y$ for any $y \in H$,  we have $x 
otin V$.  This implies $\set x \cap V = \O$ So $H \cap U \cap V = \O$. Thus we have: :$H \subseteq U \cup V$ :$H \cap U \cap V = \O$ :$U \cap H 
e \O$ :$V \cap H 
e \O$ Showing that $H$ is [[Definition:Disconnected Set (Topology)|disconnected]]. This is a contradiction. Hence we must have $H$ is [[Definition:Dense-in-itself|dense-in-itself]].  {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Scattered Space|scattered topological space]]. Then $T$ is also a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]].
rationale: Suppose $T$ is not a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]]. From [[Equivalence of Definitions of T0 Space|Equivalence of Definitions of $T_0$ Space]], there exist $x, y \in S$ such that $x$ and $y$ are both [[Definition:Limit Point of Point|limit points]] of each other. So by definition of [[Definition:Isolated Point (Topology)/Subset/Definition 2|isolated point]], neither $x$ nor $y$ are [[Definition:Isolated Point of Subset|isolated in $\set {x, y}$]]. Thus we have found a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] $\set {x, y} \subseteq T$ such that $\set {x, y}$ is by definition [[Definition:Dense-in-itself|dense-in-itself]]. So $T$ is not [[Definition:Scattered Space|scattered]]. Hence the result by [[Rule of Transposition]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $H \subseteq S$ be a [[Definition:Connected Set (Topology)|connected set]] in $T$. Let $p \in H$ be a [[Definition:Dispersion Point|dispersion point]] of $H$. Then $H$ is [[Definition:Biconnected Set|biconnected]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} $H$ is not [[Definition:Biconnected Set|biconnected]]. Then by definition there exist [[Definition:Disjoint Sets|disjoint]] [[Definition:Non-Degenerate Connected Set|non-degenerate connected sets]] $U, V$ such that $H = U \cup V$. {{WLOG}}, let $p \in U$. Then $V \subset H \setminus \set p$. As $p$ is a [[Definition:Dispersion Point|dispersion point]] of $H$, $H \setminus \set p$ is [[Definition:Totally Disconnected Space|totally disconnected]]. Thus, by definition, $H \setminus \set p$ contains no [[Definition:Non-Degenerate Connected Set|non-degenerate connected sets]]. But this contradicts our definition of $V$, as $V \subset H \setminus \set p$. It follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]] that $H$ is [[Definition:Biconnected Set|biconnected]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a [[Definition:Metric Space|metric space]] which is [[Definition:Compact Metric Space|compact]]. Then $M$ is [[Definition:Totally Bounded Metric Space|totally bounded]].

Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be an [[Definition:Infinite Particular Point Topology|infinite particular point space]]. Let $U \in \tau_p$ be a [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite]] [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] of $T$. Let the [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $U$ be arranged into a [[Definition:Sequence of Distinct Terms|sequence $\sequence {a_i}$ of distinct terms]] in $T$. Then while every [[Definition:Element|element]] $x$ of $U$ such that $x \ne p$ is a [[Definition:Limit Point of Set|limit point]] of $U$, there exists no $x \in U$ such that $x$ is an [[Definition:Accumulation Point of Sequence|accumulation point]] of $\sequence {a_i}$.
rationale: We note from [[Limit Points in Particular Point Space]] that every $x \in U$ such that $x \ne p$ is a [[Definition:Limit Point of Set|limit point]] of $U$. Let $\sequence {a_i}$ be the [[Definition:Infinite Sequence|(infinite) sequence]] in $T$ whose [[Definition:Term of Sequence|terms]] are the [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $U$. {{AimForCont}} $\beta \in S$ is an [[Definition:Accumulation Point of Sequence|accumulation point]] of $\sequence {a_i}$. Then from [[Accumulation Points for Sequence in Particular Point Space]], $\beta$ is such that an [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite number]] of [[Definition:Term of Sequence|terms]] of $\sequence {a_i}$ are equal either to $\beta$ or to $p$. But this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the assertion that $\sequence {a_i}$ is a [[Definition:Sequence of Distinct Terms|sequence of distinct terms]]. Hence no [[Definition:Element|element]] of $U$ is an [[Definition:Accumulation Point of Sequence|accumulation point]] of $\sequence {a_i}$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T$ be a satisfiable $\mathcal L$-theory with no finite models. Let $T$ be $\kappa$-categorical for some infinite cardinal $\kappa \ge \left|{\mathcal L}\right|$. Then $T$ is complete.
Let $F$ be an [[Definition:Algebraically Closed Field|algebraically closed field]]. Then $F$ is [[Definition:Infinite Field|infinite]].
rationale: We prove the [[Definition:Contrapositive Statement|contrapositive]]: that a [[Definition:Galois Field|Galois field]] cannot be [[Definition:Algebraically Closed Field|algebraically closed]]. Let $F$ be [[Definition:Galois Field|Galois]]. Define the [[Definition:Polynomial (Abstract Algebra)|polynomial]]: :$\displaystyle \\map f x = 1 + \\prod_{a \\mathop \\in F} \\paren {x - a}$ By definition, a [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]] is a [[Definition:Ring (Abstract Algebra)|ring]]. Thus by [[Ring Product with Zero]]: :$\displaystyle \\forall x \\in F: \\prod_{a \\mathop \\in F} \\paren {x - a} = 0$ But: :$\\forall a \\in F: \\map f a = 1 + 0 \\ne 0$ Therefore $\\map f x$ cannot have a [[Definition:Root of Polynomial|root]] in $F$. Thus $F$ is not [[Definition:Algebraically Closed Field|algebraically closed]]. The result follows by the [[Rule of Transposition]]. {{qed}} [[Category:Field Theory]] dxwe85ej6e1gfs3xfgm4kzqok4lswql

statement: Let \(\phi\) be a sentence in the language \(\LL_r = \set {0, 1, +, -, \cdot}\) for rings, where \(0, 1\) are constants and \(+, -, \cdot\) are binary functions. {{TFAE}} :$(1): \quad \phi$ is true in every algebraically closed field of characteristic $0$. :$(2): \quad \phi$ is true in some algebraically closed field of characteristic $0$. :$(3): \quad \phi$ is true in algebraically closed fields of characteristic $p$ for arbitrarily large primes $p$. :$(4): \quad \phi$ is true in algebraically closed fields of characteristic $p$ for sufficiently large primes $p$. Note in particular that since \(\C\) is an algebraically closed field of characteristic $0$, these are equivalent to \(\phi\) being true in the field \(\C\).
rationale: === $(1)$ iff $(2)$ === From [[Theory of Algebraically Closed Fields of Characteristic p is Complete|Theory of Algebraically Closed Fields of Characteristic $p$ is Complete]]: the theory $ACF_p$ of algebraically closed fields of characteristic $p$ is complete. That is, all such fields satisfy the exact same \(\LL_r\) sentences. {{qed|lemma}} === $(2)$ implies $(4)$ === Let \(\phi\) be true in some such field. Then: :$ACF_0 \models \phi$ By [[Gödel's Completeness Theorem]] and the finiteness of proofs, it follows that there is a finite subset \(\Delta\) of \(ACF_0\) such that \(\Delta \models \phi\). Such a \(\Delta\) can only make finitely many assertions about the character of its models. Hence, as long as \(p\) is selected sufficiently large, an algebraically closed field of characteristic \(p\) will satisfy \(\phi\). {{qed|lemma}} === $(4)$ implies $(3)$ === We have that all sufficiently large \(p\) work. Hence it follows that it is always possible to find arbitrarily large \(p\) that work. {{qed|lemma}} === $(3)$ implies $(2)$ === We prove this by [[Proof by Contraposition|contraposition]]. Suppose there is no algebraically closed field of characteristic $0$ where \(\phi\) is true. Then \(\phi\) is false in algebraically closed fields of characteristic $0$ Since \(ACF_0\) is complete, this means that \(ACF_0 \models \neg \phi\). Similarly to the case of $(2)$ implies $(4)$, there must then be a finite subset \(\Delta\) of \(ACF_0\) such that \(\Delta \models \neg \phi\). But then, for all sufficiently large \(p\), we have that \(\phi\) is false in the algebraically closed fields of characteristic \(p\). Hence, it cannot be true for arbitrarily large \(p\). By [[Rule of Transposition]], \(\phi\) is true in algebraically closed fields for arbitrarily large primes \(p\) implies there exists an algebraically closed field of characteristic $0$ where \(\phi\) is true. {{qed}} {{Namedfor|Solomon Lefschetz|cat = Lefschetz}} [[Category:Algebraic Geometry]] [[Category:Field Theory]] [[Category:Model Theory]] [[Category:Mathematical Logic]] [[Category:Proofs by Contraposition]] 2ztr54llb9zkvlktqc9933kmxbwp44x

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] which is [[Definition:Totally Separated Space|totally separated]]. Then $T$ is [[Definition:Totally Disconnected Space|totally disconnected]].
rationale: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Totally Separated Space|totally separated space]]. Then for every $x, y \in S: x \ne y$ there exists a [[Definition:Partition (Topology)|partition]] $U \mid V$ of $T$ such that $x \in U, y \in V$. Suppose $T$ were not [[Definition:Totally Disconnected Space|totally disconnected]]. Then $\exists H \subseteq S: x, y \in U$ such that $H$ is [[Definition:Connected Set (Topology)|connected]]. But by definition of [[Definition:Connected Set (Topology)|connected]], there can be no [[Definition:Partition (Topology)|partition]] $U \mid V$ of $T$ such that $x \in U, y \in V$. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\closedint a b\) be a [[Definition:Closed Interval|closed interval]] in \(\R\). {{explain|Title mentions only "interval"; this does not affect truth of statement so may "closed" above line be removed as superfluous?}} Let \(\JJ\) be a [[Definition:Set|set]] of two or more [[Definition:Closed Interval|closed intervals]] contained in \(\closedint a b\) such that \(\displaystyle \bigcup \JJ = \closedint a b\). Then the intervals in \(\JJ\) are not [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]].
rationale:
{{AimForCont}} that the intervals of \(\JJ\) are [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]]. Let \(I = \closedint p q\) be the [[Definition:Unique|unique]] [[Definition:Closed Interval|interval]] of \(\JJ\) such that \(a \in I\). Let \(J = \closedint r s\) be the [[Definition:Unique|unique]] [[Definition:Closed Interval|interval]] of \(\JJ\) containing the least [[Definition:Real Number|real number]] not in \(I\). These choices are possible since \(\JJ\) has at least two elements, and they are supposed [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|disjoint]]. If \(q = r\) then \(I \cap J 
e \O\), a contradiction. If \(r < q\) then \(I \cap J 
e \O\), a contradiction. If \(r > q\) then there is some [[Definition:Real Number|real number]] with \(q < \alpha < r\). Therefore \(\alpha 
otin I\). Since \(J\) contains the least [[Definition:Real Number|real number]] not in \(I\) it follows that there is \( eta \in J\) with \( eta < \alpha\). But we also have that \(\alpha < r \le  eta\) for all \( eta \in J\), a contradiction. This exhausts all the possibilities, and we conclude that the intervals of \(\JJ\) are not [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]]. {{qed}} [[Category:Measure Theory]] 9wda0ujr5f54g8ssj2kpco4umgx8h92

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $T^*_{\bar p} = \struct {S^*_p, \tau^*_{\bar p} }$ be the [[Definition:Open Extension Space|open extension space]] of $T$. Then $T^*_{\bar p}$ is a [[Definition:Separable Space|separable space]] {{iff}} $T$ is.
rationale: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Separable Space|separable space]]. Then there exists a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] $H \subseteq S$ which is [[Definition:Everywhere Dense|everywhere dense]] in $T$. That is, $H^- = S$ where $H^-$ is the [[Definition:Closure (Topology)|closure]] of $H$ in $S$. So in $T_{\bar p}^*$, $S\subseteq H^-=S^-\subseteq S^*_p$. Hence $H^- = S$ or $H^- = S \cup \set p = S^*_p$. From [[Topological Closure is Closed]] we deduce that $H^-$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] in $T_{\bar p}^*$. From the definition of [[Definition:Open Extension Topology|open extension topology]], the [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed sets]] of $T_{\bar p}^*$ are $S^*_p \setminus U$ where $U \in \tau$. Because $\set p \notin \tau$, $S$ is not [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. Thus it must be that $H^- = S^*_p$. Hence $H$ is a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] $H \subseteq S^*_p$ which is [[Definition:Everywhere Dense|everywhere dense]] in $T^*_{\bar p}$. {{qed|lemma}} {{AimForCont}} $T^*_{\bar p} = \struct {S^*_p, \tau}$ is [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]], but that $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ is not [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]]. Let $H \subseteq S^*_p$ be a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] which is [[Definition:Everywhere Dense|dense]] in $T^*_{\bar p}$. If $H \subseteq S$, then $H^- = S$ in $T$, but this cannot be since $T$ is not [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]]. Then $p \in H$. Consider the subset $V = H \setminus \set p$. From [[Topological Closure is Closed]] we have that $V^-$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] in $T_{\bar p}^*$. From the definition of [[Definition:Open Extension Space|open extension space]], all [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed sets]] contain the point $p$. So $V \cup \set p = H \subseteq V^-$.  From [[Set Closure is Smallest Closed Set in Topological Space]], $S^*_p = H^- \subseteq V^- \implies V$ is dense in $T_{\bar p}^*$. But because $V \subseteq S$, $V$ is [[Definition:Everywhere Dense|dense]] in $S$ also. From [[Subset of Countably Infinite Set is Countable]], $V$ is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] as it is a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable set]]. Thus $T$ is [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]], which is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Finally, our assumption is false: $T$ is indeed [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Uncountable Finite Complement Topology|finite complement topology]] on an [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable set]] $S$. Then $T$ is not [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countable]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} some $x \in S$ has a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Local Basis|local basis]]. That means: :there exists a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Set of Sets|set]] $\\BB_x \\subseteq \\tau$ such that: :$\\forall B \\in \\BB_x: x \\in B$ and such that: :every [[Definition:Open Neighborhood|open neighborhood]] of $x$ contains some $B \\in \\BB_x$. Let $y \\in S$ with $y \\ne x$. Because its [[Definition:Relative Complement|complement relative to $S$]] is [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]], we have that $S \\setminus \\set y$ is an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] containing $x$. Because  $\\BB_x$ is a [[Definition:Neighborhood Basis|neighborhood basis]] at $x$, there exists some $B \\in \\BB_x$ such that: :$B \\subseteq S \\setminus \\set y$ whence $y \\notin B$. So: :$y \\notin \\bigcap \\BB_x$ So: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \\bigcap \\BB_x       | r = \\set x       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \\leadsto       | l = S \\setminus \\set x       | r = S \\setminus \\bigcap \\BB_x       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \\bigcup_{B \\mathop \\in \\BB_x} \\paren {S \\setminus B}       | c = [[De Morgan's Laws (Set Theory)/Set Difference/General Case/Difference with Intersection|De Morgan's Laws: Difference with Intersection]] }} {{end-eqn}} By definition, each of $S \\setminus B$ is [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]]. From [[Countable Union of Countable Sets is Countable]] it follows that $\\displaystyle \\bigcup_{B \\mathop \\in \\BB_x} \\paren {S \\setminus B}$ is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. So $S \\setminus \\set x$ and therefore $S$ is also [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] (as we have specified that $S$ is [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable]]) it follows that our assumption that $x \\in S$ has a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Local Basis|local basis]] must be false. Hence by definition $T$ can not be [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countable]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] which is [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]]. Then $T$ does not necessarily have to be [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countable]].
rationale: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Uncountable Finite Complement Topology|finite complement topology]] on an [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable]] set $S$. We have that a [[Finite Complement Topology is Separable]]. But we also have that an [[Uncountable Finite Complement Space is not First-Countable]]. Hence the result, by [[Proof by Counterexample]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Finite Complement Topology|finite complement topology]] on an [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite set]] $S$. Let $H \subseteq S$ be an [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$. Then the [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]] of $H$ with any [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] of $T$ is [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite]].
rationale: Let $U \in \tau$ be any [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] of $T$. Then $\relcomp S U$ is [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]]. We have that: :$H = H \cap \paren {U \cup \relcomp S U} = \paren {H \cap U} \cup \paren {H \cap \relcomp S U}$ {{AimForCont}} $H \cap U$ is [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]]. Since $H \cap \relcomp S U \subseteq \relcomp S U$, $H \cap \relcomp S U$ is also [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]]. $H = \paren {H \cap U} \cup \paren {H \cap \relcomp S U}$ is the [[Definition:Set Union|union]] of two [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]] sets, and so it is [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]]. It is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] that $H$ is [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite]] and [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]] at the same time, so $H \cap U$ must be [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] which is [[Definition:Irreducible Space|irreducible]] and [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff]]. Then $T$ contains only one point.
rationale: Suppose $T$ has at least two points $x, y \in S$. Because $T$ is [[Definition:Irreducible Space|irreducible]], there are no two [[Definition:Disjoint Sets|disjoint]] [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]] such that $x$ is in one and $y$ is in the other. This contradicts the fact that $T$ is [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff]]. Thus $T$ has only one point. {{qed}} [[Category:Irreducible Spaces]] [[Category:Hausdorff Spaces]] 77maej8b2acclyq5geemvmi4h4g2vae

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Countable Finite Complement Topology|countable finite complement topology]]. Then $T$ is not [[Definition:Path-Connected Space|path-connected]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} $f: \closedint 0 1 \to S$ is a [[Definition:Path (Topology)|path]] on $T$. Then $f$ is by definition [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]]. By definition of the [[Definition:Finite Complement Topology|finite complement topology]], for all $x \in S$, the set $\set x$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. Now consider the set: :$F = \set {\map {f^{-1} } x: x \in S}$ From [[Continuity Defined from Closed Sets]], each of the [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $F$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. Also, from [[Mapping Induces Partition on Domain]], the [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $F$ are [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]]. As $T$ is a [[Definition:Countable Finite Complement Topology|countable finite complement topology]], its [[Definition:Underlying Set of Topological Space|underlying set]] $S$ is [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite]] by definition. Hence $F$ is also [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite]] by nature of $f$ being a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]]. Furthermore, we have $\displaystyle \bigcup F = \closedint 0 1$. Hence $F$ is a [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite set]] of [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]] [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed sets]] whose [[Definition:Set Union|union]] is $\closedint 0 1$. From [[Closed Unit Interval is not Countably Infinite Union of Disjoint Closed Sets]], this is impossible. From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], $f$ cannot be [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]], and so cannot be a [[Definition:Path (Topology)|path]] on $T$. So $T$ cannot be [[Definition:Path-Connected Space|path-connected]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Countable Finite Complement Topology|countable finite complement topology]]. Then $T$ is not [[Definition:Locally Path-Connected|locally path-connected]].
rationale: Let $\BB$ be a [[Definition:Basis (Topology)|basis]] for $T$. Let $B \in \BB$. {{AimForCont}} $f: \closedint 0 1 \to B$ is a [[Definition:Path (Topology)|path]] on $T$. Then $f$ is by definition [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]]. Now consider the set: :$F = \set {\map {f^{-1} } x: x \in S}$ From [[Continuity Defined from Closed Sets]], each of the [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $F$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. Also, from [[Mapping Induces Partition on Domain]], the [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $F$ are [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]]. From [[Basis of Countable Finite Complement Topology consists of Countably Infinite Sets]], $B$ is a [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite set]]. Hence $F$ is also [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite]] by nature of $f$ being a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]]. Furthermore, we have $\displaystyle \bigcup F = \closedint 0 1$. Hence $F$ is a [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite set]] of [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]] [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed sets]] whose [[Definition:Set Union|union]] is $\closedint 0 1$. From [[Closed Unit Interval is not Countably Infinite Union of Disjoint Closed Sets]], this is impossible. From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], $f$ cannot be [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous]], and so cannot be a [[Definition:Path (Topology)|path]] on $B$. So $B$ cannot be [[Definition:Path-Connected Set (Topology)|path-connected]]. So, by definition, $T$ is not [[Definition:Locally Path-Connected Space|locally path-connected]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Countable Complement Topology|countable complement topology]] on an [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable set]] $S$. Then the [[Definition:Compact Topological Subspace|compact sets]] of $T$ are exactly the [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]] [[Definition:Subset|subsets]] of $S$.
rationale: From [[Finite Topological Space is Compact]], any [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$ is [[Definition:Compact Topological Subspace|compact]]. {{AimForCont}} $H \\subseteq S$ is an [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite]] [[Definition:Compact Topological Subspace|compact set]]. Take a [[Definition:Infinite Sequence|(countably) infinite sequence]] \\sequence {a_n}_{n \\mathop \\ge 0}$ of [[Definition:Distinct Elements|distinct elements]] of $H$. Consider the [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]]: :$V_m := S \\setminus \\set {a_{m + n} }_{n \\mathop \\ge 0}$ for $m \\ge 0$, which satisfy $V_{m_1} \\subset V_{m_2}$ if $m_1 < m_2$. Then: :$\\displaystyle H \\subseteq \\bigcup_{m \\mathop \\ge 0} V_m$ is an [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] of $H$. Since $H$ is [[Definition:Compact Topological Subspace|compact]], it has a [[Definition:Finite Subcover|finite open subcover]], say: :$\\displaystyle H \\subseteq \\bigcup_{i \\mathop = 0}^N V_{m_i}$ with $m_0 < m_1 < \\cdots < m_N$. But then: :$\\displaystyle \\bigcup_{i \\mathop = 0}^N V_{m_i} = V_{m_N}$  and so: :$\\displaystyle a_{m_N + 1}, a_{m_N + 2}, \\ldots \\notin V_{m_N} = \\bigcup_{i \\mathop = 0}^N V_{m_i}$ which implies $a_{m_N + 1}, a_{m_N + 2}, \\ldots \\notin H$, a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Hence the result by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Countable Complement Topology|countable complement topology]] on an [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable set]] $S$. Then $T$ is not a [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact space]].
rationale: Consider $U \in \tau$. By definition of [[Definition:Countable Complement Topology|countable complement topology]], $\relcomp S U$ is [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite]]. Then for each $x \in \relcomp S U$, $\relcomp S U \setminus \set x$ is [[Definition:Countably Infinite Set|countably infinite]]. Then for each $x \in \relcomp S U$, $\relcomp S {\relcomp S U \setminus \set x} = U \cup \set x$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]. Hence $\set {U \cup \set x: x \in \relcomp S U}$ is an [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]]. This [[Definition:Cover of Set|cover]] is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] because it is [[Definition:Set Equivalence|equivalent]] to $\relcomp S U$. {{AimForCont}} $T$ is a [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact space]]. Then by definition there exists a [[Definition:Finite Subcover|finite subcover]] $\set {U \cup \set {x_1}, \ldots, U \cup \set {x_n} }$ of $T$. Then: :$\paren {U \cup \set {x_1} } \cup \dotsb \cup \paren {U \cup \set {x_n} } = U \cup \set {x_1, \ldots, x_n}$ Since $\relcomp S U$ is not [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]], it follows that $U \cup \set {x_1, \ldots, x_n} \ne S$. Thus there is no [[Definition:Finite Subcover|finite subcover]] of $T$. It follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]] that $T$ cannot be a [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact space]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Countable Complement Topology|countable complement topology]] on an [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable set]] $S$. Then $T$ is not a [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countable space]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} some $x \in S$ has a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Local Basis|local basis]]. That means: :there exists a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Set of Sets|set of sets]] $\BB_x \subseteq \tau$  such that: :$\forall B \in \BB_x: x \in B$ and such that: :every [[Definition:Open Neighborhood|open neighborhood]] of $x$ contains some $B \in \BB_x$. So: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \bigcap \BB_x       | r = \set x       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = S \setminus \set x       | r = S \setminus \bigcap \BB_x       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \bigcup_{B \mathop \in \BB_x} \paren {S \setminus B}       | c = [[De Morgan's Laws (Set Theory)/Set Difference/General Case/Difference with Intersection|De Morgan's Laws: Difference with Intersection]] }} {{end-eqn}} By definition, each of $S \setminus B$ is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. From [[Countable Union of Countable Sets is Countable]] it follows that $\displaystyle \bigcup_{B \mathop \in \BB_x} \paren {S \setminus B}$ is also [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. So $S \setminus \set x$ and therefore $S$ is also [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] (as we have specified that $S$ is [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable]]) it follows that our assumption that $x \in S$ has a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Local Basis|local basis]] must be false. Hence by definition $T$ can not be [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countable]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\left({S, \preceq}\right)\) be an [[Definition:Ordered Set|ordered set]]. Let \(\preceq^\leftrightarrow\) be the [[Definition:Symmetric Closure|symmetric closure]] of \(\preceq\). Then it is not necessarily the case that \(\preceq^\leftrightarrow\) is [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]].
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let \(S = \left\{{a, b, c}\right\}\) where \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) are [[Definition:Distinct|distinct]]. Let: : \({\preceq} = \left\{{\left({a, a}\right), \left({b, b}\right), \left({c, c}\right), \left({a, c}\right), \left({b, c}\right)}\right\}\): Then \(\preceq\) is an [[Definition:Ordering|ordering]], but \(\preceq^\leftrightarrow\) is not [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]], as follows: \(\preceq\) is [[Definition:Reflexive Relation|reflexive]] because it [[Definition:Subset|contains]] the [[Definition:Diagonal Relation|diagonal relation]] on \(S\). That \(\preceq\) is [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]] and [[Definition:Antisymmetric Relation|antisymmetric]] can be verified by inspecting all [[Definition:Ordered Pair|ordered pairs]] of its [[Definition:Element|elements]]. Thus \(\preceq\) is an [[Definition:Ordering|ordering]]. Now consider \(\preceq^\leftrightarrow\), the [[Definition:Symmetric Closure|symmetric closure]] of \(\preceq\): : \({\preceq^\leftrightarrow} = {\preceq} \cup {\preceq}^{-1} = \left\{{\left({a, a}\right), \left({b, b}\right), \left({c, c}\right), \left({a, c}\right), \left({c, a}\right), \left({b, c}\right), \left({c, b}\right)}\right\}\) by inspection. Now \(\left({a, c}\right) \in {\preceq^\leftrightarrow}\) and \(\left({c, b}\right) \in {\preceq^\leftrightarrow}\), but \(\left({a, b}\right) \notin {\preceq^\leftrightarrow}\). Thus \(\preceq^\leftrightarrow\) is not [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]]. {{qed}} [[Category:Closure Operators]] e6yrejzm7xnk4pm1f0q9c2yo0ztm679

statement: Let \(\struct {D, +, \circ}\) be a [[Definition:Principal Ideal Domain|principal ideal domain]]. Let \(p\) be an [[Definition:Irreducible Element of Ring|irreducible element]] of \(D\). Let \(\ideal p\) be the [[Definition:Principal Ideal of Ring|principal ideal of \(D\) generated by \(p\)]]. Then \(\ideal p\) is a [[Definition:Maximal Ideal of Ring|maximal ideal]] of \(D\).
rationale:
Let \(p\) be [[Definition:Irreducible Element of Ring|irreducible]] in \(D\). Let \(U_D\) be the [[Definition:Group of Units of Ring|group of units]] of \(D\). By definition, an [[Definition:Irreducible Element of Ring|irreducible element]] is not a [[Definition:Unit of Ring|unit]]. So from [[Principal Ideals in Integral Domain]]: :\(\ideal p \subset D\) Suppose the [[Definition:Principal Ideal of Ring|principal ideal]] \(\ideal p\) is not [[Definition:Maximal Ideal of Ring|maximal]]. Then there exists an [[Definition:Ideal of Ring|ideal]] \(K\) of \(D\) such that: :\(\ideal p \subset K \subset R\) Because \(D\) is a [[Definition:Principal Ideal Domain|principal ideal domain]]: :\(\exists x \in R: K = \ideal x\) Thus: :\(\ideal p \subset \ideal x \subset D\) Because \(\ideal p \subset \ideal x\): :\(x \divides p\) by [[Principal Ideals in Integral Domain]]. That is: :\(\exists t \in D: p = t \circ x\) But \(p\) is [[Definition:Irreducible Element of Ring|irreducible]] in \(D\), so \(x \in U_D\) or \(t \in U_D\). That is, either \(x\) is a [[Definition:Unit of Ring|unit]] or \(x\) is an [[Definition:Associate in Integral Domain|associate]] of \(p\). But since \(K \subset D\): :\(\ideal x 
e D\) so \(x 
otin U_D\) by [[Principal Ideals in Integral Domain]]. Also, since \(\ideal p \subset \ideal x\): :\(\ideal p 
e \ideal x\) so \(x\) is not an [[Definition:Associate in Integral Domain|associate]] of \(p\), by [[Principal Ideals in Integral Domain]]. This contradiction shows that \(\ideal p\) is a [[Definition:Maximal Ideal of Ring|maximal ideal]] of \(D\). {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {\R, \tau}\) denote the [[Definition:Real Number Line with Euclidean Topology|real number line with the usual (Euclidean) topology]]. Let \(\Q\) be the [[Definition:Rational Number|rational numbers]]. Let \(\mathbb I\) be the [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational numbers]]. Then \(\set {\Q, \mathbb I}\) is a [[Definition:Partition (Set Theory)|partition]] of \(\R\). Let \(\sim\) be the [[Definition:Equivalence Relation|equivalence relation]] [[Definition:Relation Induced by Partition|induced]] on \(\R\) by \(\set {\Q, \mathbb I}\). Let \(T_\sim := \struct {\R / {\sim}, \tau_\sim} \) be the [[Definition:Quotient Space (Topology)|quotient space]] of \(\R\) by \(\sim\). Then \(T_\sim\) is an [[Definition:Indiscrete Space|indiscrete space]].
rationale: Let \(\phi: \R \to \R/{\sim}\) be the [[Definition:Quotient Mapping|quotient mapping]]. Then: :\(\forall x \in \Q: \map \phi x = \Q\) :\(\forall x \in \mathbb I: \map \phi x = \mathbb I\) {{AimForCont}} \(\set {\mathbb I} \in \tau_\sim\). Then by the definition of the [[Definition:Quotient Topology|quotient topology]]: :\(\O \subsetneqq \mathbb I = \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {\set {\mathbb I} } \in \tau\) Thus by [[Rationals are Everywhere Dense in Topological Space of Reals]], \(\mathbb I\) contains a [[Definition:Rational Number|rational number]]. This is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. {{AimForCont}} \(\set \Q \in \tau_\sim\). Then: :\(\O \subsetneqq \Q = \phi^{-1} \sqbrk {\set \Q} \in \tau\) Thus by [[Irrationals are Everywhere Dense in Topological Space of Reals]], \(\Q\) contains a [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational number]]. This is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. As \(\R / {\sim}\) has exactly two elements, its only [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Proper Subset|proper subsets]] are \(\set \Q\) and \(\set {\mathbb I}\). As neither of these sets is \(\tau_\sim\)-open, \(\struct {\R / {\sim}, \tau_\sim}\) is [[Definition:Indiscrete Space|indiscrete]]. {{qed}} [[Category:Quotient Spaces]] [[Category:Real Number Line with Euclidean Topology]] 7xylwfsreu0d6btn0gh71xdhpx4qwml

statement: Let $f$ be a [[Definition:Polynomial Form|polynomial form]] in the [[Definition:Indeterminate (Polynomial Theory)|indeterminates]] $\set {X_j: j \in J}$ such that $f: \mathbf X^k \mapsto a_k$. For $r \in \R$, $\mathbf X^k \in M$, let $r \mathbf X^k$ denote the [[Definition:Polynomial Form|polynomial form]] that takes the value $r$ on $\mathbf X^k$ and zero on all other [[Definition:Monomial|monomials]]. Let $Z$ denote the set of all [[Definition:Multiindex|multiindices]] indexed by $J$. Then the sum representation: :$\ds \hat f = \sum_{k \mathop \in Z} a_k \mathbf X^k$ has only [[Definition:Finite|finitely many]] non-zero [[Definition:Term of Polynomial|terms]]. Moreover it is everywhere equal to $f$, and is the unique such sum.
rationale:
Suppose that the sum has infinitely many non-zero terms. Then infinitely many $a_k$ are non-zero, which contradicts the definition of a polynomial. Therefore the sum consists of finitely many non-zero terms. Let $\mathbf X^m \in M$ be arbitrary. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \map {\hat f} {\mathbf X^m}       | r = \paren {\sum_{k \mathop \in Z} a_k \mathbf X^k} \paren {\mathbf X^m} }} {{eqn | r = \paren {a_m \mathbf X^m} \paren {\mathbf X^m} + \sum_{k \mathop 
e m \mathop \in Z} \paren {a_k \mathbf X^k} \paren {\mathbf X^m} }} {{eqn | r = a_m }} {{end-eqn}} So $\hat f = f$. Finally suppose that: :$\ds 	ilde f = \sum_{k \mathop \in Z} b_k \mathbf X^k$ is another such representation with $b_m 
e a_m$ for some $m \in Z$. Then: :$\map {	ilde f} {\mathbf X^m} = b_m 
e a_m = \map f {\mathbf X^m}$ Therefore $\hat f$ as defined above is the only such representation. {{qed}} [[Category:Polynomial Theory]]

statement: Recall [[Polynomial has Integer Coefficients iff Content is Integer]]. By hypothesis $f$ and $g$ have [[Definition:Content of Rational Polynomial|content]] $1 \in \Z$. Therefore: :$f, g \in \Z \sqbrk X$ {{AimForCont}} that $f g$ is not [[Definition:Primitive Polynomial (Ring Theory)|primitive]], say: :$\cont {f g} = d \ne 1$ By the [[Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic]] we can choose a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] $p$ [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|dividing]] $d$. Let $\pi : \Z \to \Z / p \Z$ be the [[Canonical Epimorphism from Integers by Principal Ideal|canonical epimorphism]] to the [[Definition:Ring of Integers Modulo m|ring of integers modulo $p$]]. From [[Ring of Integers Modulo Prime is Field]], $\Z / p \Z$ is a [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]]. Let $\Pi : \Z \sqbrk X \to \paren {\Z / p \Z} \sqbrk X$ be the [[Induced Homomorphism of Polynomial Forms|induced homomorphism of the polynomial rings]]. By construction, $p$ divides each coefficient of $f g$, so: :$\map \Pi {f g} = \map \Pi f \, \map \Pi g = 0$ From [[Polynomial Forms over Field form Integral Domain]], $\paren {\Z / p \Z} \sqbrk X$ is an [[Definition:Integral Domain|integral domain]]. Thus: :$\map \Pi f = 0$ or $\map \Pi g = 0$ After possibly exchanging $f$ and $g$, we may assume that $\map \Pi f = 0$. Now by [[Kernel of Induced Homomorphism of Polynomial Forms]], if: :$f = a_0 + a_1 X + \cdots + a_n X^n$ we must have: :$\map \pi {a_i} = 0$ for $i = 0, \ldots, n$. That is: :$a_i \in p \Z$ for $i = 0, \ldots, n$. But this says precisely that $p$ [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divides]] each $a_i$, $i = 0, \ldots, n$. Therefore $p$ [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divides]] the [[Definition:Content of Rational Polynomial|content]] of $f$, a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Hence our assumption that $f g$ is not [[Definition:Primitive Polynomial (Ring Theory)|primitive]] was invalid. The result follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{Qed}}
rationale: Recall [[Polynomial has Integer Coefficients iff Content is Integer]]. By hypothesis $f$ and $g$ have [[Definition:Content of Rational Polynomial|content]] $1 \in \Z$. Therefore: :$f, g \in \Z \sqbrk X$ {{AimForCont}} that $f g$ is not [[Definition:Primitive Polynomial (Ring Theory)|primitive]], say: :$\cont {f g} = d \ne 1$ By the [[Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic]] we can choose a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] $p$ [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|dividing]] $d$. Let $\pi : \Z \to \Z / p \Z$ be the [[Canonical Epimorphism from Integers by Principal Ideal|canonical epimorphism]] to the [[Definition:Ring of Integers Modulo m|ring of integers modulo $p$]]. From [[Ring of Integers Modulo Prime is Field]], $\Z / p \Z$ is a [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]]. Let $\Pi : \Z \sqbrk X \to \paren {\Z / p \Z} \sqbrk X$ be the [[Induced Homomorphism of Polynomial Forms|induced homomorphism of the polynomial rings]]. By construction, $p$ divides each coefficient of $f g$, so: :$\map \Pi {f g} = \map \Pi f \, \map \Pi g = 0$ From [[Polynomial Forms over Field form Integral Domain]], $\paren {\Z / p \Z} \sqbrk X$ is an [[Definition:Integral Domain|integral domain]]. Thus: :$\map \Pi f = 0$ or $\map \Pi g = 0$ After possibly exchanging $f$ and $g$, we may assume that $\map \Pi f = 0$. Now by [[Kernel of Induced Homomorphism of Polynomial Forms]], if: :$f = a_0 + a_1 X + \cdots + a_n X^n$ we must have: :$\map \pi {a_i} = 0$ for $i = 0, \ldots, n$. That is: :$a_i \in p \Z$ for $i = 0, \ldots, n$. But this says precisely that $p$ [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divides]] each $a_i$, $i = 0, \ldots, n$. Therefore $p$ [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divides]] the [[Definition:Content of Rational Polynomial|content]] of $f$, a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Hence our assumption that $f g$ is not [[Definition:Primitive Polynomial (Ring Theory)|primitive]] was invalid. The result follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{Qed}}

statement: The corresponding proof:{{NotZFC}} Let $x \in B$. Let $x'$ be the [[Definition:Transitive Closure (Set Theory)/Definition 2|transitive closure of $x$]]. Let $L = x' \cap B$. Then $x \in L$, so $L$ is not empty. Since $x'$ is a set, so is $L$, by the axiom of subset. Thus by the [[Axiom:Axiom of Foundation|Axiom of Foundation]], $L$ has an $\in$-minimal element $m$. By the definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]], $m \in B$. Suppose [[Proof by Contradiction|for the sake of contradiction]] that there is an element $b \in B$ such that $b \in m$. Then since $m \in x'$ and $x'$ is transitive, $b \in x'$. Thus $b \in L$, contradicting the minimality of $m$. So $m$ is an $\in$-minimal element of $B$. {{qed}}
rationale: Let $x \in B$. Let $x'$ be the [[Definition:Transitive Closure (Set Theory)/Definition 2|transitive closure of $x$]]. Let $L = x' \cap B$. Then $x \in L$, so $L$ is not empty. Since $x'$ is a set, so is $L$, by the axiom of subset. Thus by the [[Axiom:Axiom of Foundation|Axiom of Foundation]], $L$ has an $\in$-minimal element $m$. By the definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]], $m \in B$. Suppose [[Proof by Contradiction|for the sake of contradiction]] that there is an element $b \in B$ such that $b \in m$. Then since $m \in x'$ and $x'$ is transitive, $b \in x'$. Thus $b \in L$, contradicting the minimality of $m$. So $m$ is an $\in$-minimal element of $B$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $n$ be a [[Definition:Natural Number|natural number]]. Let $x$ be an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]. If the [[Definition:Root (Analysis)|$n$th root]] of $x$ is not an [[Definition:Integer|integer]], it must be [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational]].
rationale: We prove the [[Definition:Contrapositive Statement|contrapositive]]: if the [[Definition:Root (Analysis)|$n$th root]] of $x$ is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]], it must be an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]. By [[Existence of Canonical Form of Rational Number]], there exist an [[Definition:Integer|integer]] $a$ and a [[Definition:Natural Number|natural number]] $b$ which are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]] such that: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = x^{1/n} | r = \frac a b }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = x | r = \frac {a^n} {b^n} }} {{end-eqn}} Since $a$ and $b$ are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]], $a^n$ and $b^n$ are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]] by [[Powers of Coprime Numbers are Coprime]]. Hence $\dfrac {a^n} {b^n}$ is by definition in [[Definition:Canonical Form of Rational Number|canonical form]]. Suppose $b \ne 1$. As the [[Definition:Denominator|denominator]] of $\dfrac {a^n} {b^n}$ is not $1$, $x = \dfrac {a^n} {b^n}$ is not an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]. This is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Thus $b = 1$, and thus: :$x^{1/n} = a$ which is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $A, B, S$ be [[Definition:Set|sets]] or [[Definition:Class (Class Theory)|classes]]. Suppose that $A \subseteq B$. Then $S \setminus B \subseteq S \setminus A$, where $\setminus$ represents [[Definition:Set Difference|set difference]].
rationale:
Let $x \in S \setminus B$. Then by the definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|set difference]]: : $x \in S$ and $x 
otin B$ Suppose [[Proof by Contradiction|for the sake of contradiction]] that $x \in A$. Then since $A$ is a [[Definition:subset|subset]] (or [[Definition:subclass|subclass]]) of $B$, $x \in B$, a [[Definition:contradiction|contradiction]]. Thus $x 
otin A$. Since $x \in S$ and $x 
otin A$, we conclude that $x \in S \setminus A$. As this holds for all $x \in S \setminus B$: : $S \setminus B \subseteq S \setminus A$ {{qed}} [[Category:Set Difference]] t7nq6c7ruyp6dorjy26rdcerzo37il9

statement: Let $p: \C \to \C$ be a [[Definition:Complex Number|complex]], non-[[Definition:Constant Polynomial|constant]] [[Definition:Polynomial|polynomial]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} that $\map p z \ne 0$ for all $z \in \C$. Now consider the [[Definition:Closed Complex Contour Integral|closed contour integral]]: :$\displaystyle \oint \limits_{\gamma_R} \frac 1 {z \cdot \map p z} \rd z$ where $\gamma_R$ is a [[Definition:Circle|circle]] with [[Definition:Radius of Circle|radius]] $R$ around the [[Definition:Origin|origin]]. By [[Derivative of Complex Polynomial]], the polynomial $z \cdot \map p z$ is [[Definition:Holomorphic Function|holomorphic]]. Since $\map p z$ is assumed to have no [[Definition:Root of Function|zeros]], the only zero of $z \cdot \map p z$ is $0 \in \C$. Therefore by [[Reciprocal of Holomorphic Function]] $\dfrac 1 {z \cdot \map p z}$ is [[Definition:Holomorphic Function|holomorphic]] in $\C \setminus \set 0$. Hence the [[Cauchy-Goursat Theorem]] implies that the value of this integral is independent of $R > 0$. On the one hand, one can calculate the value of this integral in the [[Definition:Limit of Function|limit]] $R \to 0$ (or use the [[Residue Theorem]]), using the [[Definition:Parameterization (Curve)|parameterization]] $z = R e^{i \phi}$ of $\gamma_R$: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \lim \limits_{R \mathop \to 0} \oint \limits_{\gamma_R} \frac 1 {z \cdot \map p z} \rd z | r = \frac 1 {\map p 0} \lim \limits_{R \mathop \to 0} \int \limits_0^{2 \pi} \frac 1 {R e^{i \phi} } \, i R e^{i \phi} \rd \phi | c = [[Real Polynomial Function is Continuous]] and [[Product Rule for Limits of Functions|Product Rule]] }} {{eqn | r = \lim_{R \mathop \to 0} \frac 1 {\map p 0} \int_0^{2 \pi} i \rd \phi }} {{eqn | r = \frac {2 \pi i} {\map p 0} | c = }} {{end-eqn}} which is non-zero.
