On the other hand, we have the following [[Definition:Upper Bound of Mapping|upper bound]] for the [[Definition:Absolute Value|absolute value]] of the integral: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \size {\oint \limits_{\gamma_R} \frac 1 {z \cdot \map p z} \rd z} | o = \le | r = 2 \pi R \max \limits_{\size z \mathop = R} \paren {\frac 1 {\size {z \cdot \map p z} } } | c = [[Estimation Lemma]] }} {{eqn | r = 2 \pi \max \limits_{\size z \mathop = R} \paren {\frac 1 {\size {\map p z} } } }} {{end-eqn}} But this goes to zero for $R \to \infty$. We arrive at a contradiction. Hence the assumption that $\map p z \ne 0$ for all $z \in \C$ must be wrong. {{qed}}

statement: Let $S \cong T$.
rationale: Let $S \cong T$. {{AimForCont}} that $S \ne T$. Then from the [[Relation between Two Ordinals/Corollary|corollary to Relation between Two Ordinals]], either: :$S$ is an [[Definition:Initial Segment|initial segment]] of $T$ or: :$T$ is an [[Definition:Initial Segment|initial segment]] of $S$. But as $S \cong T$, from [[No Isomorphism from Woset to Initial Segment]], neither $S$ nor $T$ can be an [[Definition:Initial Segment|initial segment]] of the other. From this [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that $S = T$. {{qed}}

statement: The corresponding proof:By [[Ordinals are Totally Ordered]], the [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]] are [[Definition:Total Ordering|totally ordered]] by \(\subseteq\): {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = X       | o =\subsetneqq       | r = Y       | c =  }} {{eqn | lll=\leadstoandfrom       | ll= \exists a \in Y:       | l = X       | r = Y_a       | c = where $Y_a$ denotes the [[Definition:Initial Segment|initial segment of $Y$ determined by $a$]] }} {{eqn | lll=\leadstoandfrom       | l = X       | r = a       | c = since $Y_a = a$ }} {{eqn | lll=\leadstoandfrom       | l = X       | o = \in       | r = Y       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} Thus: :the [[Definition:Strict Total Ordering|strict ordering]] \(\subsetneqq\) on [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]] and :the [[Definition:Strict Total Ordering|strict ordering]] \(\in\) on [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]] are the same.
rationale: {{AimForCont}} the [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]] were not [[Definition:Well-Ordering|well-ordered]] by \(\subsetneqq\). Then we could find a [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] \(\sequence {X_n}_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty\) of [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]] such that: :\(X_0 \supsetneqq X_1 \supsetneqq X_2 \cdots\) So for all \(n > 0\): :\(X_n \subsetneqq X_0\) so: :\(X_n \in X_0\) Thus \(\sequence {X_{n + 1} }_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty\) is a [[Definition:Decreasing Sequence|decreasing sequence]] under \(\subsetneqq\) of elements of \(\sequence {X_n}\). But since \(X_0\) is an [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinal]] it is [[Definition:Well-Ordering|well-ordered]] by \(\subsetneqq\). From [[Condition for Well-Foundedness]], this demonstrates a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $A$ be a non-empty [[Definition:Set|set]] or [[Definition:Class (Class Theory)|class]] of [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]]. Let $m =  igcap A$ be the [[Definition:Intersection of Set of Sets|intersection]] of all the [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $A$. Then $m$ is the [[Definition:Smallest Set by Set Inclusion|smallest]] element of $A$.
rationale: By [[Intersection of Ordinals is Ordinal]], $m$ is an [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinal]]. By [[Intersection is Largest Subset]], $m \subseteq a$ for each $a \in A$. It remains to show that $m \in A$. Let $m^+ = m \cup \set m$ be the [[Definition:Successor Set|successor]] of $m$. By [[Relation between Two Ordinals]]: :for each $a \in A$, either $m^+ \subseteq a$ or $a \in m^+$. Let $m^+ \subseteq a$ for all $a \in A$. Then by [[Intersection is Largest Subset]] $m^+ \subseteq m$. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the fact that [[Ordinal is not Element of Itself]]. Thus there is an $a \in A$ such that $a \in m^+$. Thus $a \in m$ or $a = m$. Let $a \in m$. Then $a \subsetneqq m$. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the fact that $m \subseteq a$. Thus $a = m$. Thus it follows that $m \in A$. {{qed}} [[Category:Ordinals]]

statement: Let $x$ and $y$ be [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]] and let $x^+$ denote the [[Definition:Successor Set|successor set]] of $x$. Let $x \in y$. Then: :$x^+ \in y^+$
rationale: First note that by [[Successor Set of Ordinal is Ordinal]], $x^+$ and $y^+$ are [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]]. By [[Ordinal Membership is Trichotomy]], one of the following must be true: : $x^+ = y^+$ : $y^+ \in x^+$ : $x^+ \in y^+$ We will show that the first two are both false, so that the third must hold. Two preliminary facts: {{begin-axiom}} {{axiom |n = 1 |t = $x \\ne y$ |rc = $x \\in y$ and [[Ordinal is not Element of Itself]] }} {{axiom |n = 2 |t = $y \\notin x$ |rc = $x \\in y$ and [[Ordinal Membership is Asymmetric]] }} {{end-axiom}} By $(1)$ and [[Equality of Successors]]: : $x^+ ≠ y^+$ Thus the first of the three possibilities is false. Suppose [[Proof by Contradiction|for the sake of contradiction]] that $y^+ \\in x^+$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn |o = |r = y \\in y^+ |c = Definition of [[Definition:Successor Set|successor set]] }} {{eqn |o = \\implies |r = y \\in x^+ |c = $y^+ \\in x^+$ and $x^+$ is an [[Definition:Ordinal/Definition 1|ordinal]] and therefore [[Definition:Transitive Set|transitive]]. }} {{eqn |o = \\implies |r = y \\in x \\lor y = x |c = Definition of [[Definition:Successor Set|successor set]] }} {{end-eqn}} But we already know that $y \\notin x$ by $(2)$ and $y \\ne x$ by $(1)$, so this is a contradiction, and we conclude that $y^+ \\notin x^+$. Thus we have shown that the second possibility is false. Thus the third and final one must hold: $x^+ \\in y^+$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $R$ be a [[Definition:Noetherian Ring|noetherian]] [[Definition:Integral Domain|integral domain]]. Then $R$ is a [[Definition:Factorization Domain|factorization domain]].
rationale: Let $\mathcal F$ be the set of [[Definition:Ideal of Ring|ideals]] of $R$ of the form $x R$, with $x$ not a [[Definition:Unit of Ring|unit]] and such that $x$ cannot be [[Definition:Decomposable Element|decomposed]] in the form: :$x = u p_1 \dotsm p_r$ where $u$ is a [[Definition:Unit of Ring|unit]] and $p_1, \dotsc, p_r$ [[Definition:Irreducible Element of Ring|irreducible]]. We show by [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] that $\mathcal F = \O$. {{AimForCont}} $\mathcal F \ne \O$. Since $R$ is [[Definition:Noetherian Ring|noetherian]], we can choose a [[Definition:Maximal Element|maximal element]] $a R \in \mathcal F$. By construction, $a$ is not [[Definition:Irreducible Element of Ring|irreducible]], so we can write: : $a = b c$ with $b, c$ non-[[Definition:Unit of Ring|units]] and not [[Definition:Associate/Commutative and Unitary Ring|associates]]. By the [[Definition:Associate/Commutative and Unitary Ring|definition of associates in a commutative ring]] this means that $b R \subsetneq a R$ and $a R \subsetneq b R$. Since $a R$ is assumed [[Definition:Maximal Element|maximal]], this means that $b R$ and $c R$ do not belong to $\mathcal F$. Therefore there exist [[Definition:Unit of Ring|units]] $u, v$ and [[Definition:Irreducible Element of Ring|irreducible elements]] $p_1, \dotsc, p_r, q_1, \dotsc, q_s$ such that: :$b = u p_1 \dotsm p_r$ and: :$c = v q_1 \dotsm q_s$ But this implies that: :$a = b c = \paren {u v} p_1 \cdots p_r \cdot q_1 \dotsm q_s$ This is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], since [[Definition:By Hypothesis|by hypothesis]] $a$ cannot be written in this form. {{Qed}} [[Category:Ring Theory]] [[Category:Factorization]] qtrvz0wcnqlgi83sxmiqiv3zduptpbv

statement: Let $(S, \preceq)$ be a [[Definition:Totally Ordered Set|totally ordered set]]. Let $x, y \in S$. Suppose that $y$ is an [[Definition:Immediate Successor Element|immediate successor]] of $x$. Then $y$ is the ''only'' immediate successor of $x$.
rationale: Suppose [[Proof by Contradiction|for the sake of contradiction]] that $x$ has another [[Definition:Immediate Successor Element|immediate successor]], $z ≠ y$. Then by definition: : $x \prec y$ : $x \prec z$ Since $\preceq$ is a [[Definition:Total Ordering|total ordering]] and $y ≠ z$: : $y \prec z$ or $z \prec y$. If $y \prec z$ then $x \prec y \prec z$, contradicting the fact that $z$ is an immediate successor of $x$. If $z \prec y$ then $x \prec z \prec y$, contradicting the fact that $y$ is an immediate successor of $x$. Thus we conclude that there can be no such $z$. {{qed}}

statement: S is a set with a surjection f: S \to \powerset S.
rationale:
{{AimForCont}} $S$ is a [[Definition:Set|set]] with a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]] $f: S 	o \powerset S$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l =  orall x \in S: \map f x       | o = \in       | r = \powerset S       | c = [[Definition:By Hypothesis|By Hypothesis]] }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l =  orall x \in S: \map f x       | o = \subseteq       | r = S       | c = {{Defof|Power Set}} }} {{end-eqn}} Now by [[Law of Excluded Middle]], there are two choices for every $x \in S$: : $x \in \map f x$ : $x 
otin \map f x$ Let $T = \set {x \in S: x 
otin \map f x}$. As $f$ is supposed to be a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]], $\exists a \in S: T = \map f a$. Thus: : $a \in \map f a \implies a 
otin \map f a$ : $a 
otin \map f a \implies a \in \map f a$ This is a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]], so the initial supposition that there is such a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]] must be false. {{qed}}

statement: Let $S$ be a [[Definition:Set|set]]. Let \(\powerset S\) be the [[Definition:Power Set|power set]] of \(S\). Then there does not exist a [[Definition:Set|set]] \(B\) such that there is an [[Definition:Injection|injection]] from \(B\) into \(S\) and a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]] from \(B\) onto \(\powerset S\).
rationale: {{AimForCont}} there exists such a \(B\). Let \(i: B \to S\) be an [[Definition:Injection|injection]]. Let \(f: B \to \powerset S\) be a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]]. Let \(i^\gets: \powerset S \to \powerset B\) be the [[Definition:Inverse Image Mapping of Mapping|inverse image mapping]] of \(i\). By [[Mapping Induced by Inverse of Injection is Surjection]], \(i^\gets\) is a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]]. Let \(f^\to: \powerset B \to \powerset {\powerset S}\) be the [[Definition:Direct Image Mapping of Mapping|direct image mapping]] of \(f\). By [[Direct Image Mapping of Surjection is Surjection]], \(f^\to\) is a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]]: We have that \(i^\gets: \powerset S \to \powerset B\) and \(f^\to: \powerset B \to \powerset {\powerset S}\) are [[Definition:Surjection|surjective]]. By [[Composite of Surjections is Surjection]], their [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composition]] \(f^\to \circ i^\gets: \powerset S \to \powerset {\powerset S}\) is a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]] by [[Composite of Surjections is Surjection]]. But this violates [[Cantor's Theorem]], [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicting]] the assumption that such a \(B\) exists. {{qed}}

statement: Suppose for the sake of contradiction that $f: \powerset S \to S$ is an injection.
rationale: By Injection has Surjective Left Inverse Mapping, there is a surjection $g: S \to \powerset S$. But this contradicts Cantor's Theorem. Thus there can be no such injection. {{qed}} {{LEM|Injection has Surjective Left Inverse Mapping|3}}

statement: Define a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] $f: \powerset {\N_{>0} } \to \R$ thus: :$\map f S = 0.d_1 d_2 \ldots$, interpreted as a [[Definition:Ternary Notation|ternary expansion]] where $\sequence {d_n}$ is the characteristic function of $S$. That is: :$\displaystyle \map f S = \sum_{i \mathop \in S} 3^{-i}$ By the [[Real Numbers are Uncountable/Proof 2 using Ternary Notation/Lemma|lemma]], $f$ is an [[Definition:Injection|injection]]. {{AimForCont}} that $\R$ is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. Then there is an [[Definition:Injection|injection]] $g: \R \to \N$. By [[Composite of Injections is Injection]], $g \circ f: \powerset \N \to \N$ is an [[Definition:Injection|injection]]. But this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] [[No Injection from Power Set to Set]]. Hence, by [[Proof by Contradiction]], $\R$ is not [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. {{qed}}
rationale: Define a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] $f: \powerset {\N_{>0} } \to \R$ thus: :$\map f S = 0.d_1 d_2 \ldots$, interpreted as a [[Definition:Ternary Notation|ternary expansion]] where $\sequence {d_n}$ is the characteristic function of $S$. That is: :$\displaystyle \map f S = \sum_{i \mathop \in S} 3^{-i}$ By the [[Real Numbers are Uncountable/Proof 2 using Ternary Notation/Lemma|lemma]], $f$ is an [[Definition:Injection|injection]]. {{AimForCont}} that $\R$ is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. Then there is an [[Definition:Injection|injection]] $g: \R \to \N$. By [[Composite of Injections is Injection]], $g \circ f: \powerset \N \to \N$ is an [[Definition:Injection|injection]]. But this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] [[No Injection from Power Set to Set]]. Hence, by [[Proof by Contradiction]], $\R$ is not [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. {{qed}}

statement: The statement you need to judge:The corresponding proof:$T$ is [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]] {{iff}} there exists a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$ which is [[Definition:Everywhere Dense|everywhere dense]]. $T$ is [[Definition:Metacompact Space|metacompact]] {{iff}} every [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] of $S$ has an [[Definition:Open Refinement|open refinement]] which is [[Definition:Point Finite|point finite]]. $T$ is a [[Definition:Lindelöf Space|Lindelöf space]] if every [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] of $S$ has a [[Definition:Countable Subcover|countable subcover]]. Having established the definitions, we proceed. Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]] and [[Definition:Metacompact Space|metacompact]]. {{AimForCont}} there exists an [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] $\UU$ of $S$ which has no [[Definition:Countable Subcover|countable subcover]]. As $T$ is [[Definition:Metacompact Space|metacompact]], $\UU$ has an [[Definition:Open Refinement|open refinement]] $\VV$ which is [[Definition:Point Finite|point finite]]. By nature of $\UU$, which has no [[Definition:Countable Subcover|countable subcover]], $\VV$ is [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable]]. {{explain|How would $\VV$ being countable lead to a countable subcover of $\UU$? ACC is helpful for this.}} [[Definition:By Hypothesis|By hypothesis]], $T$ is [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]]. Let $\SS$ be a [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$ which is [[Definition:Everywhere Dense|everywhere dense]]. Then each $V \in \VV$ contains some $s \in \SS$. {{explain|why? Also, this is not true if $\VV$ contains the empty set.}} So some $s \in \SS$ is contained in an [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable]] number of elements of $\VV$. Thus, by definition, $\VV$ is not [[Definition:Point Finite|point finite]]. Thus no [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable]] [[Definition:Open Refinement|open refinement]] $\VV$ of $\UU$ exists which is [[Definition:Point Finite|point finite]]. It follows that $\VV$ must be [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. Thus $\UU$ has a [[Definition:Countable Subcover|countable subcover]]. That is, by definition, $T$ is a [[Definition:Lindelöf Space|Lindelöf space]]. {{qed}}
rationale: The proof uses the method of counterproof by assuming the existence of an open cover $\UU$ which has no countable subcover, leading to a contradiction. The contradiction arises from the properties of separable and metacompact spaces, ultimately proving that $T$ must be a Lindelöf space.

statement: Let $S$ be a [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty set]]. Let $\mathcal U$ be a [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set|ultrafilter]] on $S$. Let \\( \\{Y_1, \\dots, Y_n\\} \\) be a [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]] [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Subset|subsets]] of $S$ such that $S = Y_1 \\cup \\cdots \\cup Y_n$. Then there is a unique $k \\in \\{1, \\dots, n\\}$ such that $Y_k \\in \\mathcal U$.
rationale: Assume that none of the $Y_k$ are empty. If not, then any empty ones can simply be removed. === Uniqueness === {{AimForCont}} that $Y_j, Y_k \\in \\mathcal U$ with $j \\ne k$. Then since $Y_1, \\dots, Y_n$ are a [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]]: : $Y_j \\cap Y_k = \\varnothing$ But by the definition of an [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set/Definition 4|ultrafilter]], $\\mathcal U$ has the [[Definition:Finite Intersection Property|finite intersection property]]. It follows from this [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] that no such $Y_j, Y_k \\in \\mathcal U$ with $j \\ne k$ exists. {{qed|lemma}} === Existence === Aiming for a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose that $Y_1, \\dots, Y_n \\notin \\mathcal U$. Since the $Y_k$ are [[Definition:Pairwise Disjoint|pairwise disjoint]]: : $\\displaystyle Y_i^c = \\bigcup \\{Y_k: k \\ne i\\}$ Then by the definition of an [[Definition:Ultrafilter/Definition 4|ultrafilter]]: : $\\displaystyle \\forall i: Y_i^c = \\bigcup \\{Y_k: k \\ne i\\} \\in \\mathcal U$ But: : $\\displaystyle \\bigcap_{i \\mathop = 1}^n \\bigcup \\{Y_k: k \\ne i\\} = \\varnothing$ contradicting the fact that $\\mathcal U$ has the [[Definition:Finite Intersection Property|finite intersection property]]. Thus $Y_k \\in \\mathcal U$ for some $k$. {{qed}}

statement: The corresponding proof:Let $\preceq$ be an [[Definition:Ordering|ordering]] on the [[Definition:Set|set]] $S$. If $\preceq$ is a [[Definition:Total Ordering|total ordering]], the result is complete. Suppose, then, that $\preceq$ is not a [[Definition:Total Ordering|total ordering]]. Let $T$ be the [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Ordering|orderings]] on $S$ that [[Definition:Extension of Relation|extend]] $\preceq$, [[Subset Relation is Ordering|ordered by inclusion]]. Let $C$ be a [[Definition:Chain (Set Theory)|chain]] in $T$. By [[Union of Nest of Orderings is Ordering]], $\bigcup C$ is an [[Definition:Ordering|ordering]]. Thus every [[Definition:Chain (Set Theory)|chain]] in $T$ has an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] in $T$. By [[Zorn's Lemma]], $T$ has a [[Definition:Maximal Element|maximal element]], $\le$. $\le$ is seen to be a [[Definition:Total Ordering|total ordering]], as follows: Suppose that $a, b \in S$, $a \not \le b$, and $b \not \le a$. Let $\le'$ be the [[Definition:Relation|relation]] defined as: :$\le' \mathop {:=} \le \cup \left\{{(a, b)}\right\}$ Let $\le'^-$ be the [[Definition:Transitive Closure (Relation Theory)|transitive closure]] of $\le'$. Then by [[Ordering can be Expanded to compare Additional Pair]], $\le'^-$ is an [[Definition:Ordering|ordering]]. But $\le'^- \mathop {\supsetneq} \le$, contradicting the [[Definition:Maximal Element|maximality]] of $\le$. Thus, $\le$ is a [[Definition:Total Ordering|total ordering]]. {{qed}}
rationale: Let $\preceq$ be an [[Definition:Ordering|ordering]] on the [[Definition:Set|set]] $S$. If $\preceq$ is a [[Definition:Total Ordering|total ordering]], the result is complete. Suppose, then, that $\preceq$ is not a [[Definition:Total Ordering|total ordering]]. Let $T$ be the [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Ordering|orderings]] on $S$ that [[Definition:Extension of Relation|extend]] $\preceq$, [[Subset Relation is Ordering|ordered by inclusion]]. Let $C$ be a [[Definition:Chain (Set Theory)|chain]] in $T$. By [[Union of Nest of Orderings is Ordering]], $\bigcup C$ is an [[Definition:Ordering|ordering]]. Thus every [[Definition:Chain (Set Theory)|chain]] in $T$ has an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] in $T$. By [[Zorn's Lemma]], $T$ has a [[Definition:Maximal Element|maximal element]], $\le$. $\le$ is seen to be a [[Definition:Total Ordering|total ordering]], as follows: Suppose that $a, b \in S$, $a \not \le b$, and $b \not \le a$. Let $\le'$ be the [[Definition:Relation|relation]] defined as: :$\le' \mathop {:=} \le \cup \left\{{(a, b)}\right\}$ Let $\le'^-$ be the [[Definition:Transitive Closure (Relation Theory)|transitive closure]] of $\le'$. Then by [[Ordering can be Expanded to compare Additional Pair]], $\le'^-$ is an [[Definition:Ordering|ordering]]. But $\le'^- \mathop {\supsetneq} \le$, contradicting the [[Definition:Maximal Element|maximality]] of $\le$. Thus, $\le$ is a [[Definition:Total Ordering|total ordering]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\mathcal A\) be the [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Endorelation|relations]] \(A\) on \(S\) with the property that the [[Definition:Transitive Closure (Relation Theory)|transitive closure]] \(A^+\) of \(A\) is a [[Definition:Strict Ordering|strict ordering]] of \(S\). For each \(\left({x, y}\right) \in S \times S\), let \(\left({x, y}\right)' = \left({y, x}\right)\). Let \(A \in \mathcal A\). Let \(\left({x, y}\right) \in S \times S\). Let \(\left({x, y}\right) \in A^+\). Then: :\(\left({A \cup \left\{ {\left({x, y}\right)}\right\} }\right)^+ = A^+\) so: : \(A \cup \left\{ {\left({x, y}\right)}\right\} \in \mathcal A\) Let \(\left({y, x}\right) \in A^+\). Then: :\(\left({ A \cup \left\{ {\left({y, x}\right)}\right\} }\right)^+ = A^+\) so: :\(A \cup \left\{ {\left({x, y}\right)'}\right\} = A \cup \left\{ {\left({y, x}\right)}\right\} \in \mathcal A\) Otherwise, \(x\) and \(y\) are [[Definition:Non-Comparable|non-comparable]] by \(A^+\). So by [[Strict Ordering can be Expanded to Compare Additional Pair]]: :\(A \cup \left\{ {\left({x, y}\right)}\right\} \in \mathcal A\) Thus it has been shown that for each \(A \in \mathcal A\) and each \(\left({x, y}\right) \in S\), either: :\(A \cup \left\{ {\left({x, y}\right)}\right\} \in \mathcal A\) or: :\(A \cup \left\{ {\left({x, y}\right)'}\right\} \in \mathcal A\) {{qed|lemma}} Let \(A \subseteq S \times S\). Let \(A \in \mathcal A\). Let \(F\) be a [[Definition:Finite Subset|finite subset]] of \(A\). Since \(A^+\) is a [[Definition:Strict Ordering|strict ordering]], it is [[Definition:Asymmetric Relation|asymmetric]]. Since [[Transitive Closure is Closure Operator]], \(F^+ \subseteq A^+\). So \(F^+\) is also [[Definition:Asymmetric Relation|asymmetric]]. Since \(F^+\) is also [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]], it is a [[Definition:Strict Ordering|strict ordering]]. So \(F \in \mathcal A\). Suppose instead that each [[Definition:Finite Subset|finite subset]] of \(A\) is in \(\mathcal A\). We must show that \(A^+\) is [[Definition:Antireflexive Relation|antireflexive]]. Suppose for the sake of contradiction that for some \(x \in S\), \(\left({x, x}\right) \in A^+\). Then by the definition of [[Definition:Transitive Closure (Relation Theory)/Finite Chain|transitive closure]], there are elements \(y_0, \dots, y_n\) such that \(x = y_0 = y_n\) and: :\(\left({y_0, y_1}\right), \left({y_1, y_2}\right), \dotsc, \left({y_{n - 1}, y_n}\right) \in A\) Let \(F = \left\{ {\left({y_0, y_1}\right), \left({y_1, y_2}\right), \dotsc, \left({y_{n - 1}, y_n}\right)}\right\}\). Then \(F\) is a [[Definition:Finite Subset|finite subset]] of \(A\). But \(\left({x, x}\right) \in F^+\), contradicting the fact that \(F \in \mathcal A\). Thus we see that \(A^+\) is [[Definition:Antireflexive Relation|antireflexive]], and thus a [[Definition:Strict Ordering|strict ordering]] of \(S\). Therefore, \(\mathcal A\) has [[Definition:Finite Character|finite character]]. {{qed|lemma}} Note that \({\prec} = {\prec^+}\), so \({\prec} \in \mathcal A\). By the [[Restricted Tukey-Teichmüller Theorem (Strong Form)]], there exists an \(R \in \mathcal A\) such that: : \({\prec} \subseteq R\) : For each \(\left({m, n}\right) \in S \times S\), either \(\left({m, n}\right) \in R\) or \(\left({n, m}\right) = \left({m, n}\right)' \in R\). Then: : \(R^+\) is a [[Definition:Strict Total Ordering|strict total ordering]] of \(S\). : \(\forall a, b \in S: a \prec b \implies a < b\) {{qed}}
rationale: Let \(\mathcal A\) be the [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Endorelation|relations]] \(A\) on \(S\) with the property that the [[Definition:Transitive Closure (Relation Theory)|transitive closure]] \(A^+\) of \(A\) is a [[Definition:Strict Ordering|strict ordering]] of \(S\). For each \(\left({x, y}\right) \in S \times S\), let \(\left({x, y}\right)' = \left({y, x}\right)\). Let \(A \in \mathcal A\). Let \(\left({x, y}\right) \in S \times S\). Let \(\left({x, y}\right) \in A^+\). Then: :\(\left({A \cup \left\{ {\left({x, y}\right)}\right\} }\right)^+ = A^+\) so: : \(A \cup \left\{ {\left({x, y}\right)}\right\} \in \mathcal A\) Let \(\left({y, x}\right) \in A^+\). Then: :\(\left({ A \cup \left\{ {\left({y, x}\right)}\right\} }\right)^+ = A^+\) so: :\(A \cup \left\{ {\left({x, y}\right)'}\right\} = A \cup \left\{ {\left({y, x}\right)}\right\} \in \mathcal A\) Otherwise, \(x\) and \(y\) are [[Definition:Non-Comparable|non-comparable]] by \(A^+\). So by [[Strict Ordering can be Expanded to Compare Additional Pair]]: :\(A \cup \left\{ {\left({x, y}\right)}\right\} \in \mathcal A\) Thus it has been shown that for each \(A \in \mathcal A\) and each \(\left({x, y}\right) \in S\), either: :\(A \cup \left\{ {\left({x, y}\right)}\right\} \in \mathcal A\) or: :\(A \cup \left\{ {\left({x, y}\right)'}\right\} \in \mathcal A\) {{qed|lemma}} Let \(A \subseteq S \times S\). Let \(A \in \mathcal A\). Let \(F\) be a [[Definition:Finite Subset|finite subset]] of \(A\). Since \(A^+\) is a [[Definition:Strict Ordering|strict ordering]], it is [[Definition:Asymmetric Relation|asymmetric]]. Since [[Transitive Closure is Closure Operator]], \(F^+ \subseteq A^+\). So \(F^+\) is also [[Definition:Asymmetric Relation|asymmetric]]. Since \(F^+\) is also [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]], it is a [[Definition:Strict Ordering|strict ordering]]. So \(F \in \mathcal A\). Suppose instead that each [[Definition:Finite Subset|finite subset]] of \(A\) is in \(\mathcal A\). We must show that \(A^+\) is [[Definition:Antireflexive Relation|antireflexive]]. Suppose for the sake of contradiction that for some \(x \in S\), \(\left({x, x}\right) \in A^+\). Then by the definition of [[Definition:Transitive Closure (Relation Theory)/Finite Chain|transitive closure]], there are elements \(y_0, \dots, y_n\) such that \(x = y_0 = y_n\) and: :\(\left({y_0, y_1}\right), \left({y_1, y_2}\right), \dotsc, \left({y_{n - 1}, y_n}\right) \in A\) Let \(F = \left\{ {\left({y_0, y_1}\right), \left({y_1, y_2}\right), \dotsc, \left({y_{n - 1}, y_n}\right)}\right\}\). Then \(F\) is a [[Definition:Finite Subset|finite subset]] of \(A\). But \(\left({x, x}\right) \in F^+\), contradicting the fact that \(F \in \mathcal A\). Thus we see that \(A^+\) is [[Definition:Antireflexive Relation|antireflexive]], and thus a [[Definition:Strict Ordering|strict ordering]] of \(S\). Therefore, \(\mathcal A\) has [[Definition:Finite Character|finite character]]. {{qed|lemma}} Note that \({\prec} = {\prec^+}\), so \({\prec} \in \mathcal A\). By the [[Restricted Tukey-Teichmüller Theorem (Strong Form)]], there exists an \(R \in \mathcal A\) such that: : \({\prec} \subseteq R\) : For each \(\left({m, n}\right) \in S \times S\), either \(\left({m, n}\right) \in R\) or \(\left({n, m}\right) = \left({m, n}\right)' \in R\). Then: : \(R^+\) is a [[Definition:Strict Total Ordering|strict total ordering]] of \(S\). : \(\forall a, b \in S: a \prec b \implies a < b\) {{qed}}

statement: Let $T$ be a [[Definition:Finite Tree|finite]] [[Definition:Rooted Tree|rooted tree]] with [[Definition:Root Node|root node]] $r_T$. Let $\Gamma$ be a [[Definition:Branch (Graph Theory)|branch]] of $T$. Then $\Gamma$ is a [[Definition:Finite Branch|finite branch]].
rationale: Let $\Gamma$ be a [[Definition:Branch (Graph Theory)|branch]] of a [[Definition:Finite Tree|finite]] [[Definition:Rooted Tree|rooted tree]] $T$. Aiming for a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose $\Gamma$ were an [[Definition:Infinite Branch|infinite branch]] of $T$. By definition $\Gamma$ contains an [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite number]] of [[Definition:Node (Graph Theory)|nodes]]. {{explain|Technically, from the definition currently posted, it doesn't - that still needs to be demonstrated.}} From [[Subset of Finite Set is Finite]], it follows that $\Gamma$ has a [[Definition:Finite Set|finite number]] of [[Definition:Node (Graph Theory)|nodes]]. From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that $\Gamma$ can not be an [[Definition:Infinite Branch|infinite branch]] of $T$. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: The corresponding proof:We will show that we can choose an [[Definition:Infinite Sequence|infinite sequence]] of [[Definition:Node (Graph Theory)|nodes]] $t_0, t_1, t_2, \ldots$ of $T$ such that: * $t_0$ is the [[Definition:Root Node|root node]] * $t_{n+1}$ is a [[Definition:Child Node|child]] of $t_n$ Then the sequence $t_0, t_1, t_2, \ldots$ is such a [[Definition:Branch (Graph Theory)|branch]] of [[Definition:Infinite Branch|infinite]] [[Definition:Length of Branch|length]]. Let $I$ be the [[Definition:set|set]] of all nodes in $T$ that have [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinitely many]] [[Definition:Descendant Node|descendants]]. Define a [[Definition:Endorelation|relation]] $\mathcal R$ on $I$ by letting $x \mathrel{\mathcal R} y$ {{iff}} $y$ is a [[Definition:Child Node|child]] of $x$. Since $T$ has [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinitely many]] nodes, its root node is in $I$. Let $t \in I$. By the premise, $t$ has a [[Definition:Finite Set|finite number]] of [[Definition:Child Node|children]]. Suppose [[Proof by Contradiction|for the sake of contradiction]] that all of these childen had a [[Definition:Finite Set|finite number]] of [[Definition:Descendant Node|descendants]]. Then by [[Finite Union of Finite Sets is Finite]], that would mean that $t$ had a [[Definition:Finite Set|finite number]] of descendants, contradicting the fact that $t$ is in $I$. So $t$ has at least one child with [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinitely many]] [[Definition:Descendant Node|descendants]]. That is, $\mathcal R \left({t}\right)$ is [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] for each $t \in I$. That is, $\mathcal R$ is a [[Definition:Left-Total Relation|left-total relation]]. Thus by [[Dependent Choice for Finite Sets]], there is an [[Definition:Infinite Sequence|infinite sequence]] $\left\langle{t_n}\right\rangle$ such that: : $t_0$ is the root of $T$. : For all $n \in \N$, $t_n \mathrel{\mathcal R} t_{n+1}$. That is, $t_{n+1}$ is a child of $t_n$. {{qed}}
rationale: input proof

statement: Let $G = \left({V, E}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Simple Graph|simple graph]]. Let $r \in V$ be a [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]] in $G$. Let $P$ be the [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Finite Path|finite]] [[Definition:Open Path|open paths]] beginning at $r$ that are of minimal [[Definition:Length of Walk|length]] to reach their [[Definition:Endpoint of Open Path|endpoints]]. {{refactor|Extract the below sentence and write it as a definition of a "minimal length path".}} That is, an [[Definition:Open Path|open path]] $p$ beginning at $r$ and ending at some [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]] $s$ is in $P$ {{iff}} there is no [[Definition:Open Path|path]] $q$ beginning at $r$ and ending at $s$ such that the [[Definition:Length of Walk|length]] of $q$ is less than the [[Definition:Length of Walk|length]] of $p$. Let $p, q \in P$. Let \left\{{p, q}\right\} \in E'$ {{iff}} either: :$q$ is formed by extending $p$ with one [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]] and one [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]] of $G$ or: :$p$ is formed by extending $q$ with one [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]] and one [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]] of $G$. Then $T = \left({P, E'}\right)$ is a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]].
rationale: Let \left({r}\right) be the $0$-[[Definition:Length of Walk|length]] [[Definition:Path (Graph Theory)|$G$-path]] whose only [[Definition:Vertex (Graph Theory)|vertex]] is $r$.  === Connected === We will show that there is a $T$-path from \left({r}\right) to each element $p$ of $P$. We proceed by [[Principle of Mathematical Induction|induction]] on the [[Definition:Length of Walk|length]] of $p$. If $p$ has length $0$, then $p = \left({r}\right)$. Thus the $0$-length [[Definition:Path (Graph Theory)|$T$-path]] \left({\left({r}\right)}\right) connects \left({r}\right) to $p$. {{explain|Is \left({\left({r}\right)}\right) meant here or just \left({r}\right)? If the former, explain the meaning of the double brackets.}} Suppose that there is a [[Definition:Path (Graph Theory)|$T$-path]] from \left({r}\right) to each element of $P$ of length $n$. Let $p \in P$ have length $n + 1$ and final vertex $z$. Let $p^*$ be the $G$-path obtained from $p$ by removing the last vertex and the last edge. Then $p^*$ is a $G$-path of length $n$. We must show that $p^* \in P$. Let $w$ be the last vertex of $p^*$. Suppose [[Proof by Contradiction|for the sake of contradiction]] that $p^* \notin P$. Then by the definition of $P$, there is a $G$-path $m$ from $r$ to $w$ which is shorter than $p^*$. But then appending the last edge and vertex of $p$ to $m$, one obtains a $G$-path from $r$ to $z$ which is shorter than $p$. This contradicts the supposition that $p \in P$. Thus we conclude that $p^* \in P$. By the inductive hypothesis, there is a $T$-path $b$ from \left({r}\right) to $p^*$. Then by the definition of $E'$, there is an edge from $p^*$ to $p$. Appending that edge and $p$ to $b$ yields a $T$-path from \left({r}\right) to $p$. As such a $T$-path exists for each $p \in P$, $T$ is [[Definition:Connected Graph|connected]]. {{qed|lemma}} === Acyclic === {{finish}} [[Category:Tree Theory]] 585si5m2hji0ron60zdim1iqs4e4oc8

statement: Let $G = \struct {V, A}$ be a [[Definition:Directed Graph|directed graph]]. Let $r \in V$. {{TFAE|def = Arborescence}}
rationale:
=== Definition 1 implies Definition 3 === Let $G$ be an [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 1|$r$-arborescence by definition 1]]. Let $v \in V$ such that $v 
e r$. Then there is exactly one [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] $w$ from $r$ to $v$. Since $v 
e r$, either: :$w = 	uple {r, v}$ or: :$\exists m \in V: w = 	uple {r, \ldots, m, v}$ Thus $v$ is the [[Definition:Final Vertex of Arc|final vertex]] of the [[Definition:Arc of Digraph|arc]] $r v$ or the [[Definition:Arc of Digraph|arc]] $m v$. {{AimForCont}} that $v$ is the [[Definition:Final Vertex of Arc|final vertex]] of [[Definition:Distinct|distinct]] [[Definition:Arc of Digraph|arc]] $x v$ and $y v$. Then there exist [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walks]] $w_1$ and $w_2$ from $r$ to $x$ and $r$ to $y$ respectively. But appending $v$ to $w_1$ and to $w_2$ yields [[Definition:Distinct|distinct]] [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walks]] from $r$ to $v$. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the fact that there is [[Definition:Unique|exactly one]] such [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]]. Thus $v$ is the [[Definition:Final Vertex of Arc|final vertex]] of [[Definition:Unique|exactly one]] [[Definition:Arc of Digraph|arc]]. {{qed|lemma}} {{AimForCont}} that $r$ is the [[Definition:Final Vertex of Arc|final vertex]] of an [[Definition:Arc of Digraph|arc]] $x r$. By [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 1|Definition 1]], there is a [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] $w$ from $r$ to $x$. But then $w$ appended to $w$ is a [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $r$ to $x$ which is not equal to $w$. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 1|definition 1]]. Thus we conclude that $r$ is not the [[Definition:Final Vertex of Arc|final vertex]] of any [[Definition:Arc of Digraph|arc]]. It follows immediately from [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 1|definition 1]] that there is a [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $r$ to each [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]] $v 
e r$. Thus $G$ is an [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 3|$r$-arborescence by Definition 3]]. {{qed|lemma}} === Definition 3 implies Definition 1 === Suppose that $G$ is an $r$-arborescence by [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 3|Definition 3]]. Let $v \in V$. We must show that there is a [[Definition:Unique|unique]] [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $r$ to $v$. If $v = r$, then $	uple r$ is a [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $r$ to $v$. Since $r$ is not the [[Definition:Final Vertex of Arc|final vertex]] of any [[Definition:Arc of Digraph|arc]], $	uple r$ is the only such [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]]. If $v 
e r$, then there exists some [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] $w$ from $r$ to $v$. Suppose that $z$ is a [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $r$ to $v$. Since $v 
e r$, $v$ is the [[Definition:Final Vertex of Arc|final vertex]] of exactly one [[Definition:Arc of Digraph|arc]] $x v$. If $x = r$, then $z$ must end with $	uple {r, v}$. But $r$ is not the [[Definition:Final Vertex of Arc|final vertex]] of any [[Definition:Arc of Digraph|arc]]. So in fact: :$z = 	uple {r, v}$ If $x 
e r$, then: :$z = 	uple {r, \ldots, x, v}$ Continuing inductively from $x$ proves that $z = w$. {{explain|set up the induction more formally, or less formally, or something. This is messy.}} Thus for each $v \in V$ there is [[Definition:Unique|exactly one]] [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $r$ to $v$. So $G$ is an [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 1|$r$-arborescence by Definition 1]]. {{qed|lemma}} === Definitions 1 and 3 imply Definition 2 === Let $G$ be an [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 1|$r$-arborescence by Definition 1]]. From the above, $G$ is then also an [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 3|$r$-arborescence by Definition 3]]. Let $T = \struct {V, E}$ be the [[Definition:Simple Graph|simple graph]] corresponding to $G$. That is, for $x, y \in V$, let \set {x, y} \in E$ {{iff}} $	uple {x, y} \in A$ or $	uple {y, x} \in A$. We will show that $G$ is an [[Definition:Orientation (Graph Theory)|orientation]] of $T$ and that $T$ is a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. By [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 1|Definition 1]], there is [[Definition:Unique|exactly one]] [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $r$ to each [[Definition:Vertex (Graph Theory)|vertex]] $v$. Let $x, y \in V$ and suppose [[Proof by Contradiction|for the sake of contradiction]] that $	uple {x, y} \in A$ and $	uple {y, x} \in A$. Let $w_x$ be the [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $r$ to $x$. Then appending $y$ to $w_x$ yields a [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] $w_x + y$ from $r$ to $y$. But then appending $x$ to $w_x + y$ yields a [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] $w_x + y + x$ from $r$ to $x$, contradicting the fact that $w_x$ is unique. Thus $A$ is [[Definition:Asymmetric Relation|asymmetric]]. So $G$ is an [[Definition:Orientation (Graph Theory)|orientation]] of $T$. We must now show that $T$ is a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. By [[Equivalence of Definitions of Reachable]], each [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]] $v$ of $G$ is [[Definition:Reachable|reachable]] from $r$. Let $x, y \in V$. By [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 1|Definition 1]], there is [[Definition:Unique|exactly one]] [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $r$ to $x$ and [[Definition:Unique|exactly one]] [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $r$ to $y$. Thus there is a [[Definition:Walk (Graph Theory)|walk]] $w_x$ in $T$ from $r$ to $x$ and a [[Definition:Walk (Graph Theory)|walk]] $w_y$ from $r$ to $y$. Reversing $w_x$ and then appending $w_y$ to it (eliding the duplicate $r$) yields a [[Definition:Walk (Graph Theory)|walk]] from $x$ to $y$. Thus $T$ is [[Definition:Connected Graph|connected]]. Next we show that $G$ has no [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed]] [[Definition:Cycle (Graph Theory)|cycle]]. {{AimForCont}} that $x_0, x_1, \dots, x_n$ is a [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] with $n \ge 2$ and $x_0 = x_n$. By [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 1|Definition 1]], there is a [[Definition:Unique|unique]] [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] $w$ from $r$ to $x_0$. But then $w + 	uple {x_1, \dots, x_n}$ is another [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $r$ to $x_0$, contradicting [[Definition:Unique|uniqueness]]. Thus $G$ has no [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed]] [[Definition:Cycle (Graph Theory)|cycles]]. {{AimForCont}} that $T$ has a [[Definition:Cycle (Graph Theory)|cycle]] $	uple {x_0, x_1, \dots, x_n}$, where $x_0 = x_n$ and $n \ge 2$. Since $G$ has no [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed]] [[Definition:Cycle (Graph Theory)|cycles]], the [[Definition:Arc of Digraph|arcs]] corresponding to the [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]] in this [[Definition:Cycle (Graph Theory)|cycle]] cannot all go in the same direction around the [[Definition:Cycle (Graph Theory)|cycle]]. But this implies that some [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]] of $x_0, x_1, \dots, x_n$ is the [[Definition:Final Vertex of Arc|final vertex]] of two different [[Definition:Arc of Digraph|arcs]], contradicting [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 3|Definition 3]]. {{explain}} Thus $T$ has no [[Definition:Cycle (Graph Theory)|cycles]]. As $T$ is [[Definition:Connected Graph|connected]], it is a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. Thus we have shown that $G$ is an [[Definition:Orientation (Graph Theory)|orientation]] of $T$ and that $T$ is a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. {{qed|lemma}} === Definition 2 implies Definition 1 === Let $G$ be an [[Definition:Arborescence/Definition 2|$r$-arborescence by Definition 2]]. That is, let $G$ be an [[Definition:Orientation (Graph Theory)|orientation]] of a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]] $T$ and that every [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]] of $G$ is [[Definition:Reachable|reachable]] from $r$. Let $v \in V$. By the definition of [[Definition:Reachable/Definition 2|reachable]], there exists a [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] $w$ from $r$ to $v$. We must show that $w$ is the [[Definition:Unique|only]] [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $r$ to $v$. {{AimForCont}} that $z$ is a [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $r$ to $v$ and $z 
e v$. Then either $z$ extends $w$, $w$ extends $z$, or there is some $k$ such that $w_k 
e z_k$. First suppose that $z$ extends $w$. So $w = 	uple {x_0, \ldots, x_n}$ and $z = 	uple {x_0, \ldots, x_n, \ldots, x_m}$. Then $p = \left({x_n, \dots, x_m}ight)$ is a [[Definition:Directed Walk|directed walk]] from $v$ to $v$ with more than one [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]]. By [[Directed Circuit in Simple Digraph forms Circuit]], the [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]] of $p$ form a [[Definition:Circuit|circuit]], contradicting the fact that $T$ is a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. Thus there exists $k$ such that $w_k 
e z_k$. It follows from the [[Well-Ordering Principle]] that there must be some [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest]] $k$ such that $w_k 
e z_k$. Since $w$ and $z$ both end at $v$, it follows from the [[Well-Ordering Principle]] that: :there must be some [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest]] $n > k$ such that there exists $m > k$ such that $w_n = z_m$ :and that there exists a [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest]] such $m$. Then $	uple {w_{k - 1}, w_k, \ldots, w_n, z_{m - 1}, \dots, z_k, z_{k - 1} }$ forms a [[Definition:Cycle (Graph Theory)|cycle]], contradicting the fact that $T$ is a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. {{explain}} {{qed}} [[Category:Arborescences]] 3313oj1kghruvj5qbb8ynvtui1llsm8

statement: Let $f: Y \to Z$ be a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] which is [[Definition:Left Cancellable Mapping|left cancellable]]. Then $f$ is an [[Definition:Injection|injection]].
rationale:
We use a [[Proof by Contraposition]]. That is, we show that if $f: Y 	o Z$ is not [[Definition:Injection|injective]], then $f$ is not [[Definition:Left Cancellable Mapping|left cancellable]]. Hence, suppose $f: Y 	o Z$ is not [[Definition:Injection|injective]]. Then: : $\exists y_1 
e y_2 \in Y: f \left({y_1}ight) = f \left({y_2}ight)$ Let the two [[Definition:Mapping|mappings]] $g_1: Y 	o Y, g_2: Y 	o Y$ be defined as follows: :$ orall y \in Y: g_1 \left({y}ight) = y$ :$ orall y \in Y: g_2 \left({y}ight) =  egin{cases} y_2 & : y = y_1 \ y & : y 
e y_1 \end{cases}$ Thus we have $g_1 
e g_2$ such that $f \circ g_1 = f \circ g_2$. That is, $f$ is not [[Definition:Left Cancellable Mapping|left cancellable]]. From [[Rule of Transposition]] it follows that if $f$ is left cancellable, it is injective.

statement: Let \(\struct {\Z_m, \times_m}\) be the [[Definition:Multiplicative Monoid of Integers Modulo m|multiplicative monoid of integers modulo \(m\)]]. Then: :\(\eqclass k m \in \Z_m\) has an [[Definition:Inverse Element|inverse]] in \(\struct {\Z_m, \times_m}\) {{iff}}: :\(k \perp m\)
rationale: First, suppose \(k \perp m\). That is: :\(\gcd \set {k, m} = 1\) By [[Bézout's Identity]]: :\(\exists u, v \in \Z: u k + v m = 1\) Thus: :\(\eqclass {u k + v m} m = \eqclass {u k} m = \eqclass u m \eqclass k m = \eqclass 1 m\) Thus: :\(\eqclass u m\) is an [[Definition:Inverse Element|inverse]] of \(\eqclass k m\) Suppose that: :\(\exists u \in \Z: \eqclass u m \eqclass k m = \eqclass {u k} m = 1\) Then: :\(u k \equiv 1 \pmod m\) and: :\(\exists v \in \Z: u k + v m = 1\) Thus from [[Bézout's Identity]], \(k \perp m\). {{qed}}

statement: Let $S$ and $T$ be [[Definition:Disjoint Sets|disjoint sets]]. Let $S' \subseteq S$ and $T' \subseteq T$. Then $S'$ and $T'$ are [[Definition:Disjoint Sets|disjoint]].
rationale: Let $S \cap T = \O$. Let $S' \subseteq S$ and $T' \subseteq T$. {{AimForCont}} $S' \cap T' \ne \O$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \exists x       | o = \in       | r = S' \cap T'       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = x        | o = \in       | r = S'       | c = {{Defof|Set Intersection}} }} {{eqn | lo= \land       | l = x        | o = \in       | r = T'       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = x        | o = \in       | r = S       | c = {{Defof|Subset}} }} {{eqn | lo= \land       | l = x        | o = \in       | r = T       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = x        | o = \in       | r = S \cap T       | c = {{Defof|Set Intersection}} }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = S \cap T       | o = \ne       | r = \O       | c = {{Defof|Set Intersection}} }} {{end-eqn}} From this [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]]: :$S' \cap T' = \O$ Hence the result by definition of [[Definition:Disjoint Sets|disjoint sets]]. {{qed}}

statement: The corresponding proof:=== [[Definition:Antisymmetric Relation/Definition 1|Definition 1]] implies [[Definition:Antisymmetric Relation/Definition 2|Definition 2]] ===
Let $G$ be a [[Definition:Simple Graph|simple graph]]. Let $C$ be a [[Definition:Circuit|circuit]] in $G$. Then $C$ has at least $3$ [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]].
rationale: By definition, a [[Definition:Circuit|circuit]] contains at least one [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]]. That is, a single [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]] does not comprise a trivial degenerate [[Definition:Circuit|circuit]] with no [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]]. Suppose $C$ contains only one [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]] $e$. As $G$ is a [[Definition:Simple Graph|simple graph]] it contains no [[Definition:Loop (Graph Theory)|loops]]. Therefore $e$ starts and ends at two [[Definition:Distinct Elements|distinct]] [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]]. Therefore $C$, consisting entirely of $e$ can not be a [[Definition:Circuit|circuit]]. Suppose $C$ contains exactly $2$ [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]] $e$ and $f$. Let $e = u v$ where $v$ and $v$ are [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]] of $G$. Then for $C$ to be a [[Definition:Circuit|circuit]] it must follow that $f = v u$. Thus there are two [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]] between the same [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]] $v$ and $u$. As $G$ is an [[Definition:Undirected Graph|undirected graph]], it must be that $e$ and $f$ are part of a [[Definition:Multiple Edge|multiple edge]] between $u$ and $v$. But $G$ is not a [[Definition:Multigraph|multigraph]], and so such a [[Definition:Circuit|circuit]] can not exist. A [[Definition:Circuit|circuit]] containing $3$ [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]] definitely exists, though. Let $G = \struct {V, E}$ where $V = \set {u, v, w}$ and $E = \set {\set {u, v}, \set {u, w}, \set {v, w} }$. Then $\tuple {u, w, v, u}$ is a [[Definition:Edge of Graph|$3$-edge]] [[Definition:Circuit|circuit]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $G$ be a [[Definition:Connected Graph|connected graph]]. Let $e$ be a [[Definition:Bridge|bridge]] of $G$. Then the [[Definition:Edge Deletion|edge deletion]] $G - e$ contains exactly $2$ [[Definition:Component (Graph Theory)|components]].
rationale: Let $G$ be a [[Definition:Connected Graph|connected graph]] and $e = u v$ be a [[Definition:Bridge|bridge]] of $G$. By definition of [[Definition:Bridge|bridge]], $G - e$ has to be of at least $2$ [[Definition:Component (Graph Theory)|components]]. Aiming for a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose that $G - e$ were of more than $2$ [[Definition:Component (Graph Theory)|components]]. Let $G_1, G_2, G_3$ be $3$ of those [[Definition:Component (Graph Theory)|components]] such that $u \in G_1$ and $v \in G_2$. Note that $u$ and $v$ cannot both be in the same [[Definition:Component (Graph Theory)|component]] or $e$ would not be a [[Definition:Bridge|bridge]]. Now let $e$ be replaced so as to [[Definition:Connected Graph|connect]] $G_1$ and $G_2$ again. Then $G_3$ would still be [[Definition:Disconnected Graph|disconnected]] from the rest of $G$, and $G$ itself would therefore be a [[Definition:Disconnected Graph|disconnected graph]]. From this [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that $G - e$ can only be of two [[Definition:Component (Graph Theory)|components]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T$ be a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. Then there is exactly one [[Definition:Path (Graph Theory)|path]] between any two [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]].
rationale: Let $T$ be a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. {{AimForCont}} there exists a [[Definition:Doubleton|pair]] of [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]] $u$ and $v$ in $T$ such that there is not [[Definition:Unique|exactly one]] [[Definition:Path (Graph Theory)|path]] between them. If there is no [[Definition:Path (Graph Theory)|path]] between $u$ and $v$, $T$ is not [[Definition:Connected Graph|connected]]. In this case, $T$ is certainly not a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. So, in keeping with our supposition, there is more than one [[Definition:Path (Graph Theory)|path]] between $u$ and $v$. Let two of these [[Definition:Path (Graph Theory)|paths]] be: :$P_1 = \tuple {u, u_1, \ldots, u_i, r_1, r_2, \ldots, r_{j - 1}, r_j, u_{i + 1}, \ldots, v}$ :$P_2 = \tuple {u, u_1, \ldots, u_i, s_1, s_2, \ldots, s_{k - 1}, s_k, u_{i + 1}, \ldots, v}$ Now consider the [[Definition:Path (Graph Theory)|path]]: :$P_3 = \tuple {u_i, r_1, r_2, \ldots, r_{j - 1}, r_j, u_{i + 1}, s_k, s_{k - 1}, \ldots, s_2, s_1, u_i}$ It can be seen that $P_3$ is a [[Definition:Circuit|circuit]]. Thus by definition $T$ can not be a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. From [[Proof by Contradiction]] it follows that there is exactly one [[Definition:Path (Graph Theory)|path]] between any [[Definition:Doubleton|pair]] of [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]].

statement: Let $T$ be a [[Definition:Connected Graph|connected]] [[Definition:Simple Graph|simple graph]] of [[Definition:Order of Graph|order]] $n$. Let the [[Definition:Size of Graph|size]] of $T$ be $n-1$. Then $T$ is a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]].
rationale: Suppose $T$ is a [[Definition:Connected Graph|connected]] [[Definition:Simple Graph|simple graph]] of [[Definition:Order of Graph|order]] $n$ with $n - 1$ [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]]. We need to show that $T$ is a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. {{AimForCont}} $T$ is not a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. Then it contains a [[Definition:Circuit|circuit]]. It follows from [[Condition for Edge to be Bridge]] that there is at least one [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]] in $T$ which is not a [[Definition:Bridge|bridge]]. So we can remove this [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]] and obtain a graph $T'$ which is [[Definition:Connected Graph|connected]] and has $n$ [[Definition:Node of Graph|nodes]] and $n - 2$ [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]]. Let us try and construct a [[Definition:Connected Graph|connected graph]] with $n$ [[Definition:Node of Graph|nodes]] and $n - 2$ [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]]. We start with the [[Definition:Edgeless Graph|edgeless graph]] $N_n$, and add [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]] till the graph is connected. We pick any two [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]] of $N_n$, label them $u_1$ and $u_2$ for convenience, and use one [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]] to connect them, labelling that edge $e_1$. We pick any other [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]], label it $u_3$, and use one [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]] to connect it to either $u_1$ or $u_2$, labelling that edge $e_2$. We pick any other [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]], label it $u_4$, and use one [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]] to connect it to either $u_1, u_2$ or $u_3$, labelling that edge $e_3$. We continue in this way, until we pick a [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]], label it $u_{n - 1}$, and use one [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]] to connect it to either $u_1, u_2, \ldots, u_{n - 2}$, labelling that [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]] $e_{n - 2}$. That was the last of our [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]], and the last [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertex]] still has not been connected. Therefore a graph with $n$ [[Definition:Vertex of Graph|vertices]] and $n-2$ [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]] that such a graph ''cannot'' be connected. Therefore we cannot remove any [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]] from $T$ without leaving it [[Definition:Disconnected Graph|disconnected]]. Therefore all the [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]] in $T$ are [[Definition:Bridge|bridges]]. Hence $T$ can contain no [[Definition:Circuit|circuits]]. Hence, by [[Proof by Contradiction]], $T$ must be a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $p$ be an [[Definition:Odd Prime|odd prime]]. Let $a \not \equiv 0 \pmod p$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = a^{\frac {p-1} 2}       | o = \equiv       | r = 1       | rr= \pmod p       | c = {{iff}} $a$ is a [[Definition:Quadratic Residue|quadratic residue]] of $p$ }} {{eqn | l=a ^{\frac {p-1} 2}       | o = \equiv       | r = -1       | rr= \pmod p       | c = {{iff}} $a$ is a [[Definition:Quadratic Non-Residue|quadratic non-residue]] of $p$. }} {{end-eqn}}
rationale: First note that the [[Square Root of 1 Mod Prime|square roots of $1$]] are $1, -1 \pmod p$. Also, we have that $a^{p - 1} \equiv 1 \pmod p$ by [[Fermat's Little Theorem]]. Combining these two observations, we find: :$a^{\frac {p - 1} 2} \equiv 1 \text{ or } -1 \pmod p$ The theorem is therefore equivalent to stating that $a$ is a [[Definition:Quadratic Residue|quadratic residue]] modulo $p$ {{iff}} $a^{\frac{p - 1} 2} \equiv 1 \pmod p$. Namely, considering the above, we see this also implies that all [[Definition:Quadratic Non-Residue|quadratic non-residues]] will be [[Definition:Congruence (Number Theory)|congruent]] to $-1 \pmod p$. We prove each direction of the equivalent statement separately: === Sufficient Condition === Assume $a$ is a [[Definition:Quadratic Residue|quadratic residue]] modulo $p$. We pick $k$ such that $k^2 \equiv a \pmod p$. Then by [[Congruence of Powers]] and [[Fermat's Little Theorem]]: :$a^{\frac{p-1} 2} \equiv k^{p-1} \equiv 1 \pmod p$ === Necessary Condition === Now assume $a^{\frac{p - 1} 2} \equiv 1 \pmod p$. Then let $y$ be a [[Definition:Primitive Root|primitive root modulo $p$]], so that $a$ can be written as $y^j$. In particular: :$y^{j \frac {p - 1} 2} \equiv 1 \pmod p$ From the definition of $y$, it has [[Definition:Order of Group Element|order]] $p-1$. It follows that $p - 1 \divides j \dfrac {p - 1} 2$ from [[Element to Power of Multiple of Order is Identity]]. We conclude that $j$ is necessarily an [[Definition:Even Integer|even integer]], and denote $j' = \dfrac j 2$. Let $k$ be such that $k \equiv y^{j'} \pmod p$. By construction, we have: :$k^2 \equiv y^{2 j'} \equiv y^j \equiv a \pmod p$ Hence $a$ is a [[Definition:Quadratic Residue|quadratic residue]] modulo $p$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $I$ be a [[Definition:Real Interval|real interval]]. Let $f: I \to \R$ be a [[Definition:Continuous on Interval|continuous]] [[Definition:Real Function|real function]]. Then the [[Definition:Image of Mapping|image]] of $f$ is a [[Definition:Real Interval|real interval]].
rationale: As before, let $J$ be the [[Definition:Image of Mapping|image]] of $f$. By [[Subset of Real Numbers is Interval iff Connected]] we need to show that $J$ is connected (and hence an interval). Suppose not. Then there exists a [[Definition:Separation (Topology)|separation]] $S \mid T$ of $J$. Define $A = f^{-1}(S)$ and $B = f^{-1}(T)$. $A$ and $B$ are both non-empty. Because $f$ is continuous, by [[Continuous iff inverse image of any open set is open]] we must have $A$ and $B$ open. Now, $A \cap B = f^{-1}(S) \cap f^{-1}(T) = f^{-1}(S \cap T) = \varnothing$, because $S \mid T$ is a separation. Also, $A \cup B = f^{-1}(S) \cup f^{-1}(T) = f^{-1}(S \cup T) = f^{-1}(J) = I$ ($S \mid T$ is a separation of $J$). Hence $A \mid B$ is a separation of $I$. $I$ can certainly not be an interval (because it is not connected). This is a contradiction. Thus $J$ must be an interval. {{qed}}

statement: Let $S$ and $T$ be [[Definition:Set|sets]] such that $S \ne \O$. Let $f: S \to T$ be an [[Definition:Injection|injection]]. Then a [[Definition:Left Inverse Mapping|left inverse mapping]] of $f$ is in general not [[Definition:Unique|unique]]. [[Definition:Unique|Uniqueness]] occurs under either of two circumstances: :$(1): \quad S$ is a [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]] :$(2): \quad f$ is a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]].
rationale: If $f$ is a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]], then by definition $f$ is also a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]]. Then: :$T \setminus \Img f = \O$ :and we have that $g = f^{-1}$. As $f^{-1}$ is uniquely defined $g$ is itself unique. {{qed|lemma}} If $S$ is a [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]] then there can only be one [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] $g: T \to S$: :$\forall t \in T: \map g t = s$ {{qed|lemma}} If $f$ is not a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]], then as it is an [[Definition:Injection|injection]] it can not be a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]]. Then: :$T \setminus \Img f \ne \O$ Let $t \in T \setminus \Img f$. We can now choose any $x_0 \in S$ such that $\map g t = x_0$. If $S$ is not a [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]], such an $x_0$ is not [[Definition:Unique|unique]]. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: The corresponding proof:Let $a, b \in \Z$ such that $a \ge 0$ and $b > 0$ be given. Let $S$ be defined as the [[Definition:Set|set]] of all [[Definition:Positive Integer|positive integers]] of the form $a - z b$ where $z$ is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]: :$S = \\set {x \\in \\Z_{\\ge 0}: \\exists z \\in \\Z: x = a - z b}$ By setting $z = 0$ we have that $a \\in S$. Thus $S \\ne \\O$. We have that $S$ is [[Definition:Bounded Below Set|bounded below]] by $0$. From [[Set of Integers Bounded Below by Integer has Smallest Element]] it follows that $S$ has a [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]] $r$. Thus: :$\\exists q \\in \\Z: a - q b = r$ and so: :$a = q b + r$ So we have proved the existence of $q$ and $r$ such that $a = q b + r$. It remains to be shown that $0 \\le r < b$. We have that $r \\in S$ which is [[Definition:Bounded Below Set|bounded below]] by $0$. Therefore $0 \\le r$. {{AimForCont}} $b \\le r$. So: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = b       | o = \\le       | r = r       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = <       | r = r + b       | c = as $b > 0$ }} {{eqn | ll= \\leadsto       | l = 0       | o = \\le       | r = r - b       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = <       | r = r       | c = subtracting $b$ throughout }} {{end-eqn}} But then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = a       | r = q b + r       | c = from above }} {{eqn | ll= \\leadsto       | l = r - b       | r = \\paren {a - q b} - b       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = a - b \\paren {q + 1}       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \\leadsto       | l = r - b       | o = \\in       | r = S       | c = as $r - b$ is of the correct form }} {{end-eqn}} But $r - b < r$ [[Proof by Contradiction|contradicts]] the choice of $r$ as the [[Definition:Smallest Element|least element]] of $S$. Hence $r < b$ as required. Thus the existence of $q$ and $r$ satisfying $a = q b + r, 0 \\le r < b$ has been demonstrated. {{qed}}
rationale: Let $a, b \\in \\Z$ such that $a \\ge 0$ and $b > 0$ be given. Let $S$ be defined as the [[Definition:Set|set]] of all [[Definition:Positive Integer|positive integers]] of the form $a - z b$ where $z$ is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]: :$S = \\set {x \\in \\Z_{\\ge 0}: \\exists z \\in \\Z: x = a - z b}$ By setting $z = 0$ we have that $a \\in S$. Thus $S \\ne \\O$. We have that $S$ is [[Definition:Bounded Below Set|bounded below]] by $0$. From [[Set of Integers Bounded Below by Integer has Smallest Element]] it follows that $S$ has a [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]] $r$. Thus: :$\\exists q \\in \\Z: a - q b = r$ and so: :$a = q b + r$ So we have proved the existence of $q$ and $r$ such that $a = q b + r$. It remains to be shown that $0 \\le r < b$. We have that $r \\in S$ which is [[Definition:Bounded Below Set|bounded below]] by $0$. Therefore $0 \\le r$. {{AimForCont}} $b \\le r$. So: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = b       | o = \\le       | r = r       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = <       | r = r + b       | c = as $b > 0$ }} {{eqn | ll= \\leadsto       | l = 0       | o = \\le       | r = r - b       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = <       | r = r       | c = subtracting $b$ throughout }} {{end-eqn}} But then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = a       | r = q b + r       | c = from above }} {{eqn | ll= \\leadsto       | l = r - b       | r = \\paren {a - q b} - b       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = a - b \\paren {q + 1}       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \\leadsto       | l = r - b       | o = \\in       | r = S       | c = as $r - b$ is of the correct form }} {{end-eqn}} But $r - b < r$ [[Proof by Contradiction|contradicts]] the choice of $r$ as the [[Definition:Smallest Element|least element]] of $S$. Hence $r < b$ as required. Thus the existence of $q$ and $r$ satisfying $a = q b + r, 0 \\le r < b$ has been demonstrated. {{qed}}

statement: There are [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinitely many]] [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]] of the form $4 n - 1$.
rationale: {{AimForCont}} the contrary. That is, suppose there is a [[Definition:Finite Set|finite number]] of [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]] of the form $4 n - 1$. Let there be $k$ of them: $p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_k$. Let $S = \set {p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_k}$. Let $N$ be constructed as: :$\displaystyle N = 4 \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^k p_i - 1$ If $N$ is a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime number]], then it is of the form $4 n - 1$. But then we have that $N \notin S$, which means that $S$ is not the complete set of [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]] of the form $4 n - 1$. Therefore $N$ must be [[Definition:Composite Number|composite]]. Suppose all the [[Definition:Prime Factor|prime factors]] of $N$ are of the form $4 n + 1$. Then from [[Product of Integers of form 4n + 1|Product of Integers of form $4 n + 1$]] it follows that $N$ itself is of the form $4 n + 1$. Therefore $N$ must have at least one [[Definition:Prime Factor|prime factor]] $p$ of the form $4 n - 1$. Suppose $p \in S$. We have that: : $\displaystyle p \divides 4 \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^k p_i$ and so: : $\displaystyle p \divides 4 \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^k p_i - p$ So: :$N = q p + \left({p - 1}\right)$ where: :$q = \dfrac {\displaystyle 4 \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^k p_i - p} p$ So applying the [[Euclidean Algorithm]]: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \gcd \set {N, p}       | r = \gcd \set {p - 1, p}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \gcd \set {p - 1, 1}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = 1       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} So if $p \in S$, then it cannot be a [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisor]] of $N$. Therefore there must be a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]] of the form $4 n - 1$ which is not in $S$. Therefore $S$ is not the complete set of [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]] of the form $4 n - 1$. Therefore the assumption that $S$ is [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]] was [[Definition:False|false]]. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {\GF, +, \times}\) be a [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]] which has exactly $4$ [[Definition:Element|elements]]. Then: :\(\forall a \in \GF: a + a = 0_\GF\) where \(0_\GF\) is the [[Definition:Field Zero|zero]] of \(\GF\).
rationale:
By definition of [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]], both the [[Definition:Algebraic Structure|algebraic structures]] \(\struct {\GF, +}\) and \(\struct {\GF^*, 	imes}\) are [[Definition:Abelian Group|(abelian) groups]], where \(\GF^* := \GF \setminus \set 0\). By definition: :\(\struct {\GF, +}\) is of [[Definition:Order of Structure|order $4$]] :\(\struct {\GF^*, 	imes}\) is of [[Definition:Order of Structure|order $3$]]. From [[Classification of Groups of Order up to 15]], there are only two possibilities: :$(1): \quad \struct {\GF, +} \cong \Z_4$ and \(\struct {\GF^*, 	imes} \cong \Z_3\) :$(2): \quad \struct {\GF, +} \cong \Z_2 	imes \Z_2$ and \(\struct {\GF^*, 	imes} \cong \Z_3\). In case $(2)$: :\( orall a \in \GF: a + a = 0_\GF\) but in case $(1)$: :\(\exists a, b \in \GF: a + a = b 
e 0_\GF\) where \(b + b = 0_\GF\) as there exists an element of \(\struct {\GF, +}\) of [[Definition:Order of Group Element|order $4$]]. {{AimForCont}} $(1)$ describes a [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]]. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \paren {b + b} 	imes b       | r = 0_\GF 	imes b       | c = as $b + b = 0_\GF$ from above }} {{eqn | r = 0_\GF       | c = as $0_\GF$ is the [[Definition:Field Zero|zero]] of \(\struct {\GF, +, 	imes}\) }} {{end-eqn}} But then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \paren {b + b} 	imes b       | r = \paren {b 	imes b} + \paren {b 	imes b}       | c = as 	imes is [[Definition:Distributive Operation|distributive]] over $+$ }} {{end-eqn}} As \(\struct {\GF, +} \cong \Z_4\), both $a + a = b$ and \(\paren {-a} + \paren {-a} = b\). The only way for \(\paren {b 	imes b} + \paren {b 	imes b} = 0_\GF\) is for $b 	imes b = b$ or $b 	imes b = 0_\GF$. The second case is eliminated as $0_\GF 
otin \struct {\GF^*, 	imes}$. So it must be the case that $b 	imes b = b$. So as \(\struct {\GF^*, 	imes} \cong \Z_3\) it must follow that $a 	imes b = a, a 	imes \paren {-a} = b$ and then $a 	imes a = -a$. It follows that the [[Definition:Cayley Table|Cayley tables]] of \(\struct {\GF, +}\) and \(\struct {\GF^*, 	imes}\) must therefore be as follows: :\( egin{array}{c|cccc} + & 0_\GF & a & b & -a \ \hline 0_\GF & 0_\GF & a & b & -a \ a & a & b & -a & 0_\GF \ b & b & -a & 0_\GF & a \ -a & -a & 0_\GF & a & b \ \end{array} \qquad  egin{array}{c|cccc} 	imes & 0_\GF & b & a & -a \ \hline 0_\GF & 0_\GF & 0_\GF & 0_\GF & 0_\GF \ b & 0_\GF & b & a & -a \ a & 0_\GF & a & -a & b \ -a & 0_\GF & -a & b & a \ \end{array}\) {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \paren {a + b} 	imes a       | r = \paren {-a} 	imes a       | c = as $a + b = -a$ from above }} {{eqn | r = b       | c = as \paren {-a} 	imes a = b$ from above }} {{end-eqn}} But: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \paren {a 	imes a} + \paren {b 	imes a}       | r = \paren {-a} + a       | c = from above }} {{eqn | r = 0_\GF       | c = from above }} {{end-eqn}} So: :\(\paren {a + b} 	imes a 
e \paren {a 	imes a} + \paren {b 	imes a}\) demonstrating that 	imes is not [[Definition:Distributive Operation|distributive]] over $+$. Thus \(\GF\) as has been defined: :\(\struct {\GF, +} \cong \Z_4\) and \(\struct {\GF^*, 	imes} \cong \Z_3\) is not a [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]]. It follows that our supposition that \(\struct {\GF, +} \cong \Z_4\) was false. Thus, if \(\GF\) is a [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]], then \(\struct {\GF, +} \cong \Z_2 	imes \Z_2\). That is: :\( orall a \in \GF: a + a = 0_\GF\) as needed to be proved. {{qed}}

statement: Let \struct {S, \preceq} be an [[Definition:Ordered Set|ordered set]]. Let \struct {S, \preceq} be [[Definition:Well-Founded|well-founded]]. Then there is no [[Definition:Infinite Sequence|infinite sequence]] \sequence {a_n} of [[Definition:Element|elements]] of S such that \forall n \in \N: a_{n + 1} \prec a_n.
rationale: Suppose there exists an [[Definition:Sequence|infinite sequence]] \sequence {a_n} in S such that: :\forall n \in \N: a_{n + 1} \prec a_n We let T = \set {a_0, a_1, a_2, \ldots}. Clearly T has no [[Definition:Minimal Element|minimal element]]. Thus by definition S is not [[Definition:Well-Founded|well-founded]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $q, n \in \Z_{>0}$. Then: :$\paren {q + 1} \divides \paren {q^n + 1}$ {{iff}} $n$ is [[Definition:Odd Integer|odd]]. In the above, $\divides$ denotes [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisibility]].
rationale: Let $n$ be [[Definition:Odd Integer|odd]]. Then from [[Sum of Odd Positive Powers]]: :$\displaystyle q^n + 1 = \paren {q + 1} \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n \paren {-1}^k q^{k - 1}$ Let $n$ be [[Definition:Even Integer|even]]. Consider the equation: :$q^n + 1 = 0$ We have: :$\paren {-1}^n + 1 = 2$ So $-1$ is not a root of $q^n + 1 = 0$. By [[Polynomial Factor Theorem]], $q + 1$ is not a [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisor]] of $q^n + 1$ when $n$ is [[Definition:Even Integer|even]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {G, \circ}\) be a [[Definition:Non-Trivial Group|non-trivial]] [[Definition:Group|group]] whose [[Definition:Identity Element|identity]] is \(e\). Let \(*: G \times G \to G\) be the [[Definition:Conjugacy Action|conjugacy group action]]: : \(\forall g, h \in G: g * h = g \circ h \circ g^{-1}\) Then \(*\) is ''not'' a [[Definition:Transitive Group Action|transitive group action]].
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: For \(G\) to be a [[Definition:Transitive Group Action|transitive group action]], the [[Definition:Orbit (Group Theory)|orbit]] of any [[Definition:Element|element]] of \(G\) needs to be the whole of \(G\). Take \(h = e\). Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | ll= \forall g \in G:       | l = g * e       | r = g \circ e \circ g^{-1}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = g \circ g^{-1}       | c = {{GroupAxiom|2}} }} {{eqn | r = e       | c = {{GroupAxiom|3}} }} {{end-eqn}} Thus by definition of [[Definition:Orbit (Group Theory)|orbit]]: :\(\Orb e = \set e\) Only when \(G\) is the [[Definition:Trivial Group|trivial group]], that is: \(G = \set e\), does \(\Orb e = G\). Hence the result by definition of [[Definition:Transitive Group Action|transitive group action]]. {{qed}}

statement: Consider the [[Definition:Categorical Statement|categorical statements]]: :$\mathbf I: \quad$ The [[Definition:Particular Affirmative|particular affirmative]]: $\exists x: \map S x \land \map P x$ :$\mathbf O: \quad$ The [[Definition:Particular Negative|particular negative]]: $\exists x: \map S x \land \neg \map P x$ Then: :$\mathbf I$ and $\mathbf O$ are [[Definition:Subcontrary Statements|subcontrary]] {{iff}}: :$\exists x: \map S x$ Using the [[Definition:Symbolic Logic|symbology]] of [[Definition:Predicate Logic|predicate logic:]] :$\exists x: \map S x \iff \paren {\paren {\exists x: \map S x \land \map P x} \lor \paren {\exists x: \map S x \land \neg \map P x} }$
rationale:
=== Sufficient Condition === Let $\exists x: \map S x$. Suppose $\mathbf I$ and $\mathbf O$ are both [[Definition:False|false]]. As $\mathbf I$ is [[Definition:False|false]], then by the [[Rule of Conjunction/Proof Rule|Rule of Conjunction]]: :$
eg \map P x$ As $\mathbf O$ is [[Definition:False|false]], then by the [[Rule of Conjunction/Proof Rule|Rule of Conjunction]]: :$
eg 
eg \map P x$ and so by [[Double Negation]]: :$\map P x$ It follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]] that $\mathbf I$ and $\mathbf O$ are not both [[Definition:False|false]]. Thus, by definition, $\mathbf I$ and $\mathbf O$ are [[Definition:Subcontrary Statements|subcontrary statements]]. {{qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === Let $\mathbf I$ and $\mathbf O$ be [[Definition:Subcontrary Statements|subcontrary statements]] Suppose $
eg \exists x: \map S x$. From the definition of [[Definition:Conjunction|logical conjunction]], it follows that: :$
eg \paren {\exists x: \map S x \land \map P x}$ Similarly from the definition of [[Definition:Conjunction|logical conjunction]], it follows that: :$
eg \paren {\exists x: \map S x \land 
eg \map P x}$ That is, both $\mathbf I$ and $\mathbf O$ are [[Definition:False|false]]. So, by definition, $\mathbf I$ and $\mathbf O$ are not [[Definition:Subcontrary Statements|subcontrary]]. It follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]] that $\exists x: \map S x$. {{qed}}

statement:
Consider the [[Definition:Categorical Statement|categorical statements]]: :$\map {\mathbf E} {S, P}: \quad$ The [[Definition:Universal Negative|universal negative]]: $ orall x: \map S x \implies 
eg \map P x$ :$\map {\mathbf O} {S, P}: \quad$ The [[Definition:Particular Negative|particular negative]]: $\exists x: \map S x \land 
eg \map P x$ Then: :$\map {\mathbf E} {S, P} \implies \map {\mathbf O} {S, P}$ {{iff}}: :$\exists x: \map S x$ Using the [[Definition:Symbolic Logic|symbology]] of [[Definition:Predicate Logic|predicate logic:]] :$\exists x: \map S x \iff \paren {\paren { orall x: \map S x \implies 
eg \map P x} \implies \paren {\exists x: \map S x \land 
eg \map P x} }$
rationale:
=== Sufficient Condition === Let $\exists x: \map S x$. Let $\map {\mathbf E} {S, P}$ be [[Definition:True|true]]. As $\map {\mathbf E} {S, P}$ is [[Definition:True|true]], then by [[Modus Ponendo Ponens]]: :$
eg \map P x$ From the [[Rule of Conjunction/Proof Rule|Rule of Conjunction]]: :$\map S x \land 
eg \map P x$ Thus $\map {\mathbf O} {S, P}$ holds. So by the [[Rule of Implication]]: :$\map {\mathbf E} {S, P} \implies \map {\mathbf O} {S, P}$ {{qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === Let $\map {\mathbf E} {S, P} \implies \map {\mathbf O} {S, P}$. {{AimForCont}}: :$
eg \exists x: \map S x$ that is, $\map S x$ is [[Definition:Vacuous Truth|vacuous]]. From [[Denial of Existence|De Morgan's Laws: Denial of Existence]]: :$ orall x: 
eg \map S x \dashv \vdash 
eg \exists x: \map S x$ it follows that $ orall x: \map S x$ is [[Definition:False|false]]. From [[False Statement implies Every Statement]]: :$ orall x: \map S x \implies 
eg \map P x$ is [[Definition:True|true]]. So $\map {\mathbf E} {S, P}$ holds. Again, $
eg \exists x: \map S x$. Then by the [[Rule of Conjunction/Proof Rule|Rule of Conjunction]]: :$
eg \paren {\exists x: \map S x \land 
eg \map P x}$ That is, $\map {\mathbf O} {S, P}$ does not hold. So $\map {\mathbf E} {S, P}$ is [[Definition:True|true]] and $\map {\mathbf O} {S, P}$ is [[Definition:False|false]]. This [[Proof by Contradiction|contradicts]] $\map {\mathbf E} {S, P} \implies \map {\mathbf O} {S, P}$ by definition of [[Definition:Conditional|implication]]. Thus $\exists x: \map S x$ must hold. {{qed}}

statement: Let $Q$ be a [[Definition:Valid Argument|valid]] [[Definition:Categorical Syllogism|categorical syllogism]]. Then at least one of the [[Definition:Premise of Syllogism|premises]] of $Q$ is [[Definition:Universal Categorical Statement|universal]].
rationale: Suppose both [[Definition:Premise of Syllogism|premises]] of $Q$ are [[Definition:Particular Categorical Statement|particular]]. Then the pattern of $Q$ is one of $\text{II}x$, $\text{IO}x$, $\text{OI}x$ or $\text{OO}x$, where $x$ is the [[Definition:Conclusion of Syllogism|conclusion]]. $\text{I}$ is neither [[Definition:Universal Categorical Statement|universal]] nor [[Definition:Negative Categorical Statement|negative]]. Thus the $\text{II}x$ pattern does not [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distribute]] the [[Definition:Middle Term of Syllogism|middle term]] of $Q$. So $\text{II}x$ violates the rule [[Middle Term of Valid Categorical Syllogism is Distributed at least Once]]. $\text{O}$ is [[Definition:Negative Categorical Statement|negative]]. Thus $\text{OO}x$ violates the rule [[No Valid Categorical Syllogism contains two Negative Premises]]. It remains to investigate $\text{IO}x$ and $\text{OI}x$. By [[Conclusion of Valid Categorical Syllogism is Negative iff one Premise is Negative]], the [[Definition:Conclusion of Syllogism|conclusion]] of $Q$ is [[Definition:Negative Categorical Statement|negative]], either $\text{E}$ or $\text{O}$. By the definition of [[Definition:Distributed Predicate of Categorical Syllogism|Distributed Predicate of Categorical Syllogism]], the [[Definition:Predicate of Categorical Statement|predicate]] of the [[Definition:Conclusion of Syllogism|conclusion]] of $Q$ is [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributed]]. Thus, by construction, the [[Definition:Primary Term of Syllogism|primary term]] $P$ of $Q$ is [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributed]]. By [[Distributed Term of Conclusion of Valid Categorical Syllogism is Distributed in Premise]], it follows that $P$ is [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributed]] in the [[Definition:Major Premise of Syllogism|major premise]] of $Q$. This eliminates $\text{IO}x$ as the [[Definition:Particular Affirmative|particular affirmative]] $\text{I}$ [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributes]] neither its [[Definition:Subject of Categorical Statement|subject]] nor its [[Definition:Predicate of Categorical Statement|predicate]]. The final pattern to be investigated is $\text{OI}x$. By definition, $\text{O}$ [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributes]] only its [[Definition:Predicate of Categorical Statement|predicate]]. As $\text{O}$ needs to [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distribute]] the [[Definition:Primary Term of Syllogism|primary term]] $P$, it cannot also [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distribute]] the [[Definition:Middle Term of Syllogism|middle term]] $M$ of $Q$. But the [[Definition:Particular Affirmative|particular affirmative]] $\text{I}$ (as has been seen above) also does not [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distribute]] $M$. Thus $M$ remains [[Definition:Undistributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|undistributed]], so violating the rule [[Middle Term of Valid Categorical Syllogism is Distributed at least Once]]. This eliminates $\text{OI}x$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $Q$ be a [[Definition:Valid Argument|valid]] [[Definition:Categorical Syllogism|categorical syllogism]]. Let one of the [[Definition:Premise of Syllogism|premises]] of $Q$ be [[Definition:Particular Categorical Statement|particular]]. Then the [[Definition:Conclusion of Syllogism|conclusion]] of $Q$ is also [[Definition:Particular Categorical Statement|particular]].
rationale: Let the [[Definition:Major Premise of Syllogism|major premise]] of $Q$ be denoted $\text{Maj}$. Let the [[Definition:Minor Premise of Syllogism|minor premise]] of $Q$ be denoted $\text{Min}$. Let the [[Definition:Conclusion of Syllogism|conclusion]] of $Q$ be denoted $\text{C}$.
