From [[No Valid Categorical Syllogism contains two Particular Premises]], either $\text{Maj}$ or $\text{Min}$ has to be [[Definition:Universal Categorical Statement|universal]]. Let the other [[Definition:Premise of Syllogism|premise]] of $Q$ be [[Definition:Particular Categorical Statement|particular]]. Suppose $\text{C}$ is the [[Definition:Universal Affirmative|universal affirmative]] $\mathbf A \left({S, P}\right)$. From [[Conclusion of Valid Categorical Syllogism is Negative iff one Premise is Negative]] it follows that $\text{Maj}$ and $\text{Min}$ are also both [[Definition:Affirmative Categorical Statement|affirmative]]. The only patterns fitting the criteria are $\text{AI}x$ and $\text{IA}x$, both of which [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distribute]] only one [[Definition:Term of Syllogism|term]] in $Q$. We have that $\text{C}$ [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributes]] $S$. From [[Distributed Term of Conclusion of Valid Categorical Syllogism is Distributed in Premise]], $S$ must also be [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributed]] in $\text{Min}$. From [[Middle Term of Valid Categorical Syllogism is Distributed at least Once]], the [[Definition:Middle Term of Syllogism|middle term]] $M$ of $Q$ needs to be [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributed]]. Thus we require two [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributed terms]] in the [[Definition:Premise of Syllogism|premises]] for $\text{C}$ to be the [[Definition:Universal Affirmative|universal affirmative]]. So if $\text{C}$ is [[Definition:Affirmative Categorical Statement|affirmative]], neither [[Definition:Premise of Syllogism|premise]] of $Q$ can be [[Definition:Particular Categorical Statement|particular]]. From this contradiction it follows that $\text{C}$ is not $\mathbf A \left({S, P}\right)$. Suppose $\text{C}$ is the [[Definition:Universal Negative|universal negative]] $\mathbf E \left({S, P}\right)$. In this case, both $S$ and $P$ are [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributed]] in $C$, as the [[Definition:Universal Negative|universal negative]] [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributes]] both $S$ and $P$. By [[Middle Term of Valid Categorical Syllogism is Distributed at least Once]], the [[Definition:Middle Term of Syllogism|middle term]] $M$ of $Q$ needs to be [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributed]]. Thus there are three terms needing to be [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributed]] in two [[Definition:Premise of Syllogism|premises]]. So at least one [[Definition:Premise of Syllogism|premises]] needs to be the [[Definition:Universal Negative|universal negative]]. The other premise is not $\mathbf O$ as this violates [[No Valid Categorical Syllogism contains two Negative Premises]]. But it also is not $\mathbf I$, as $\mathbf I$ does not distribute any terms. So if $\text{C}$ is the [[Definition:Universal Negative|universal negative]], neither [[Definition:Premise of Syllogism|premise]] can be [[Definition:Particular Categorical Statement|particular]]. From this contradiction it follows that $\text{C}$ is not $\mathbf E \left({S, P}\right)$. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {G, \circ}\) be a [[Definition:Group|group]] whose [[Definition:Identity Element|identity]] is \(e\). Let \(g \in G\) be an [[Definition:Element|element]] of \(G\) such that: :\(\order g = n\) where \(\order g\) denotes the [[Definition:Order of Group Element|order]] of \(g\). Then: :\(\forall m \in \Z: \order {g^m} = \dfrac n {\gcd \set {m, n} }\) where \(\gcd \set {m, n}\) denotes the [[Definition:Greatest Common Divisor of Integers|greatest common divisor]] of \(m\) and \(n\).
rationale: Let \(\gcd \set {m, n} = d\). From [[Integers Divided by GCD are Coprime]]: there exists \(m', n' \in \Z\) such that \(m = d m'\), \(n = d n'\). Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \paren {g^m}^{n'}       | r = \paren {g^{d m'} }^{n'}       | c = Definition of \(m'\) }} {{eqn | r = \paren {g^{d n'} }^{m'}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \paren {g^n}^{m'}       | c = Definition of \(n'\) }} {{eqn | r = e^{m'}       | c = \(n\) is the [[Definition:Order of Group Element|order]] of \(g\) }} {{eqn | r = e       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} By [[Element to Power of Multiple of Order is Identity]]: :\(\order {g^m} \divides n'\). {{AimForCont}} \(\order {g^m} = n'' < n'\). By [[Bézout's Lemma]]: :\(\exists x, y \in \Z: m x + n y = d\) {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = g^{d n''}       | r = g^{\paren {m x + n y} n''}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \paren {g^{m n''} }^x \paren {g^n}^{y n''}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = e^x \paren {g^n}^{y n''}       | c = \(n''\) is the [[Definition:Order of Group Element|order]] of \(g^m\) }} {{eqn | r = e^x e^{y n''}       | c = \(n\) is the [[Definition:Order of Group Element|order]] of \(g\) }} {{eqn | r = e       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} But \(d n'' < d n' = n\), [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicting]] the fact that \(n\) is the [[Definition:Order of Group Element|order]] of \(g\). Therefore: :\(\order {g^m} = n'\) Recalling the definition of \(n'\): :\(\order {g^m} = \dfrac n {\gcd \set {m, n} }\) as required. {{qed}}

statement: Let $S$ be a [[Definition:Set|set]]. Let \(\RR \subseteq S \times S\) be a [[Definition:Relation|relation]] in \(S\). Then: : \(\RR\) is both [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]] and [[Definition:Antitransitive Relation|antitransitive]] {{iff}}: : \(\neg \paren {\exists x, y, z \in S: x \mathrel {\RR} y \land y \mathrel {\RR} z}\)
rationale:
=== Necessary Condition === Suppose \(
eg \paren {\exists x, y, z \in S: x \mathrel {\RR} y \land y \mathrel {\RR} z}\). Then \(\RR\) is both [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]] and [[Definition:Antitransitive Relation|antitransitive]] [[Definition:Vacuous Truth|vacuously]]. {{qed|lemma}} === Sufficient Condition === Suppose \(\RR\) is both [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]] and [[Definition:Antitransitive Relation|antitransitive]]. {{AimForCont}} it is not the case that \(
eg \paren {\exists x, y, z \in S: x \mathrel {\RR} y \land y \mathrel {\RR} z}\). Then \(\exists x, y, z \in S: x \mathrel {\RR} y \land y \mathrel {\RR} z\). By [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitivity]]: :\(x \mathrel {\RR} z\) By [[Definition:Antitransitive Relation|antitransitivity]]: :\(
eg \paren {x \mathrel {\RR} z}\) This is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Hence we must have \(
eg \paren {\exists x, y, z \in S: x \mathrel {\RR} y \land y \mathrel {\RR} z}\). {{qed}}

statement: Let $Q$ be a [[Definition:Valid Argument|valid]] [[Definition:Categorical Syllogism|categorical syllogism]] in [[Definition:Third Figure of Categorical Syllogism|Figure $\text {III}$]]. Then it is a [[Definition:Necessary Condition|necessary condition]] that: :The [[Definition:Conclusion of Syllogism|conclusion]] of $Q$ be a [[Definition:Particular Categorical Statement|particular categorical statement]] and: :If the [[Definition:Conclusion of Syllogism|conclusion]] of $Q$ be a [[Definition:Negative Categorical Statement|negative categorical statement]], then so is the [[Definition:Major Premise of Syllogism|major premise]] of $Q$.
rationale: Consider [[Definition:Third Figure of Categorical Syllogism|Figure $\text {III}$]]: {{:Definition:Figure of Categorical Syllogism/III}} Let the [[Definition:Major Premise of Syllogism|major premise]] of $Q$ be denoted $\text{Maj}$. Let the [[Definition:Minor Premise of Syllogism|minor premise]] of $Q$ be denoted $\text{Min}$. Let the [[Definition:Conclusion of Syllogism|conclusion]] of $Q$ be denoted $\text{C}$. $M$ is: : the [[Definition:Subject of Categorical Statement|subject]] of $\text{Maj}$ : the [[Definition:Subject of Categorical Statement|subject]] of $\text{Min}$. So, in order for $M$ to be [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributed]], either: : $(1): \quad$ From [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism/Subject|Universal Categorical Statement Distributes its Subject]]: $\text{Maj}$ must be [[Definition:Universal Categorical Statement|universal]] or: : $(2): \quad$ From [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism/Subject|Universal Categorical Statement Distributes its Subject]]: $\text{Min}$ must be [[Definition:Universal Categorical Statement|universal]]. Suppose $\text{Min}$ to be a [[Definition:Negative Categorical Statement|negative categorical statement]]. Then by [[No Valid Categorical Syllogism contains two Negative Premises]]: : $\text{Maj}$ is an [[Definition:Affirmative Categorical Statement|affirmative categorical statement]]. From [[Conclusion of Valid Categorical Syllogism is Negative iff one Premise is Negative]]: : $\text{C}$ is a [[Definition:Negative Categorical Statement|negative categorical statement]]. From [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism/Predicate|Negative Categorical Statement Distributes its Predicate]]: : $P$ is [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributed]] in $\text{C}$. From [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism/Predicate|Negative Categorical Statement Distributes its Predicate]]: : $P$ is [[Definition:Undistributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|undistributed]] in $\text{Maj}$. From [[Distributed Term of Conclusion of Valid Categorical Syllogism is Distributed in Premise]]: : $P$ is [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributed]] in $\text{Maj}$. That is, $P$ is both [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|distributed]] and [[Definition:Undistributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|undistributed]] in $\text{Maj}$. From this [[Proof by Contradiction]] it follows that $\text{Min}$ is an [[Definition:Affirmative Categorical Statement|affirmative categorical statement]]. Thus from [[Conclusion of Valid Categorical Syllogism is Negative iff one Premise is Negative]]: : if $\text{C}$ is a [[Definition:Negative Categorical Statement|negative categorical statement]], then so is $\text{Maj}$ {{qed|lemma}} We have that $\text{Min}$ is an [[Definition:Affirmative Categorical Statement|affirmative categorical statement]]. Hence from [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism/Predicate|Negative Categorical Statement Distributes its Predicate]]: : $S$ is [[Definition:Undistributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|undistributed]] in $\text{Min}$. From [[Distributed Term of Conclusion of Valid Categorical Syllogism is Distributed in Premise]]: : $S$ is [[Definition:Undistributed Term of Categorical Syllogism|undistributed]] in $\text{C}$. So from [[Definition:Distributed Term of Categorical Syllogism/Subject|Universal Categorical Statement Distributes its Subject]]: : $\text{C}$ is a [[Definition:Particular Categorical Statement|particular categorical statement]]. {{qed|lemma}} Hence, in order for $Q$ to be [[Definition:Valid Argument|valid]]: : $\text{C}$ must be a [[Definition:Particular Categorical Statement|particular categorical statement]] : if $\text{C}$ is a [[Definition:Negative Categorical Statement|negative categorical statement]], then so is $\text{Maj}$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $\Q$ be the [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Rational Number|rational numbers]]. Let $\struct {\R, \tau}$ denote the [[Definition:Real Number Line with Euclidean Topology|real number line with the usual (Euclidean) topology]]. Then $\Q$ is not a [[Definition:G-Delta Set|$G_\delta$ set]] in $\R$.
rationale: {{AimForCont}} $\Q$ is a [[Definition:G-Delta Set|$G_\delta$ set]] in $\R$. Let $\Q = \displaystyle \bigcap_{i \mathop \in \N} V_i$. Since [[Rational Numbers are Countably Infinite]], there exists an [[Definition:Enumeration|enumeration]] of $\Q$. Write $\Q = \set {q_i}_{i \mathop \in \N}$. Define $U_i = V_i \setminus \set {q_i}$. We show that $U_i$ is [[Definition:Everywhere Dense|dense]] in $\R$. :Let $A \subseteq \R$ be an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] of $\struct {\R, \tau}$. :From [[Basis for Euclidean Topology on Real Number Line]], the set of all [[Definition:Open Real Interval|open real intervals]] of $\R$ form a basis for $\struct {\R, \tau}$. :So there exists \openint a b \subseteq A$ for some $a < b$. :One of $q_i \le a$, $q_i > a$ must hold. :Suppose $q_i \le a$. :By [[Between two Real Numbers exists Rational Number]] we have: ::$\exists r \in Q: a < r < b$. :Since $r > a \ge q_i$: ::$r \in \Q \setminus \set {q_i} \subseteq V_i \setminus \set {q_i} = U_i$. :Suppose $q_i > a$. :By [[Between two Real Numbers exists Rational Number]] we have: ::$\exists r \in Q: a < r < \min \set {q_i, b}$. :Since $r < q_i$: ::$r \in \Q \setminus \set {q_i} \subseteq V_i \setminus \set {q_i} = U_i$. :In both cases we see that $r \in \openint a b \cap U_i \subseteq A \cap U_i$. :Therefore $A \cap U_i \ne \O$. :Thus $U_i$ is [[Definition:Everywhere Dense|dense]] in $\R$. Also we have: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \bigcap_{i \mathop \in \N} U_i | r = \bigcap_{i \mathop \in \N} \paren {V_i \setminus \set {q_i} } }} {{eqn | r = \paren {\bigcap_{i \mathop \in \N} V_i} \setminus \paren {\bigcup_{i \mathop \in \N} \set {q_i} } | c = [[De Morgan's Laws (Set Theory)/Set Difference/General Case/Difference with Union|Difference with Union]] }} {{eqn | r = \Q \setminus \Q }} {{eqn | r = \O | c = [[Set Difference with Self is Empty Set]] }} {{end-eqn}} By [[Real Number Line is Complete Metric Space]] and [[Baire Category Theorem]], $\struct {\R, \tau}$ is a [[Definition:Baire Space (Topology)|Baire space]]. By definition of [[Definition:Baire Space (Topology)/Definition 2|Baire Space]], $\displaystyle \bigcap_{i \mathop \in \N} U_i$ is [[Definition:Everywhere Dense|dense]] in $\R$. But [[Empty Set is Nowhere Dense]]. This is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Hence $\Q$ is not a [[Definition:G-Delta Set|$G_\delta$ set]] in $\R$. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {\Q, \tau_d}\) be the [[Definition:Rational Number Space|rational number space]] under the [[Definition:Euclidean Topology on Real Number Line|Euclidean topology]] \(\tau_d\). Let \(S \subseteq \Q\) be a [[Definition:Compact Topological Subspace|compact set]] of \(\Q\). Then \(S\) is [[Definition:Nowhere Dense|nowhere dense]] in \(\Q\).
rationale:
By [[Compact Subspace of Hausdorff Space is Closed]], \(S\) is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] in \(\Q\). By [[Set is Closed iff Equals Topological Closure]], \(S = S^-\). {{AimForCont}} \(S\) is not [[Definition:Nowhere Dense|nowhere dense]] in \(\Q\). Then \(S^-\) contains some [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]]. From [[Basis for Euclidean Topology on Real Number Line]], the set of all [[Definition:Open Real Interval|open real intervals]] of \(\R\) form a basis for \(\struct {\R, 	au_d}\). By [[Basis for Topological Subspace]], the set of all intersections of \(\Q\) and [[Definition:Open Real Interval|open real intervals]] of \(\R\) form a basis for \(\struct {\Q, 	au_d}\). So there exists \(V = \Q \cap \openint {a'} {b'} \subseteq S^- = S\) for some \(a' < b'\). By [[Between two Real Numbers exists Irrational Number]] we have: :\(\exists r \in \R \setminus \Q: a' < r < b'\) By [[Between two Real Numbers exists Rational Number]] we have: :\(\exists a, b \in \Q: a' < a < r < b < b'\) Thus \(\Q \cap \closedint a b\) is a [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of \(S\) in \(\Q\). By [[Closed Subspace of Compact Space is Compact]], \(\Q \cap \closedint a b\) is [[Definition:Compact Topological Space|compact]]. Now we construct an [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] for \(\Q \cap \closedint a b\): Let \(C = \openint r {b + 1} \cap \Q\). Let \(C_q = \openint {a - 1} q \cap \Q\) for each \(q \in \openint a r \cap \Q\). Then \(C\) and \(C_q\) are [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]]. Let \(\CC = \set C \cup \set {C_q: q \in \openint a r \cap \Q}\). To show that \(\CC\) is an [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] for \(\Q \cap \closedint a b\): :Pick any \(x \in \Q \cap \closedint a b\). :Suppose \(x > r\).  :Then \(r < x \le b < b + 1\). :Therefore \(x \in \openint r {b + 1} = C \in \CC\). :Suppose \(x < r\). :By [[Between two Real Numbers exists Rational Number]] we have: ::\(\exists q \in \Q: a - 1 < a \le x < q < r\) :Then \(x \in \openint {a - 1} q\) and \(q \in \openint a r\). :Thus \(x \in C_q \in \CC\). :Therefore \(x \in  igcup \CC\), showing that \(\CC\) is an [[Definition:Open Cover|open cover]] for \(\Q \cap \closedint a b\).  Since \(\Q \cap \closedint a b\) is [[Definition:Compact Topological Space|compact]], \(\CC\) has a [[Definition:Finite Subcover|finite subcover]], \(\CC'\). This [[Definition:Finite Subcover|finite subcover]] can only contain a finite number of sets in \(\set {C_q: q \in \openint a r \cap \Q}\). Therefore \(\set {q: C_q \in \CC'}\) has a greatest element, \(q'\). We have that \(q' \in \openint a r \cap \Q\). By [[Between two Real Numbers exists Rational Number]] we have: :\(\exists q^* \in \Q: a < q' < q^* < r < b\) So \(q^* \in \Q \cap \closedint a b\). But for all \(q \in \hointl a {q'} \cap \Q\): :\(q^* 
otin C_q = \openint {a - 1} q \cap \Q\) We also have \(q^* 
otin C = \openint r {b + 1} \cap \Q\). Hence \(q^* 
otin  igcup \CC'\). So \(\CC'\) is not a [[Definition:Cover of Set|cover]] for \(\Q \cap \closedint a b\). This is a contradiction. Thus \(S\) is [[Definition:Nowhere Dense|nowhere dense]] in \(\Q\). {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {\Q, \tau_d}\) be the [[Definition:Rational Number Space|rational number space]] under the [[Definition:Euclidean Topology on Real Number Line|Euclidean topology]] \(\tau_d\). Then \(\struct {\Q, \tau_d}\) is not a [[Definition:Locally Compact Hausdorff Space|locally compact Hausdorff Space]].
rationale: For \(\struct {\Q, \tau_d}\) to be a [[Definition:Locally Compact Hausdorff Space|locally compact Hausdorff Space]], it is required that every point of \(\Q\) has a [[Definition:Compact Topological Subspace|compact]] [[Definition:Neighborhood of Point|neighborhood]]. Let \(x \in \Q\). Let \(N \subseteq \Q\) be a [[Definition:Neighborhood of Point|neighborhood]] of \(x\). Then: :\(\exists U \in \tau: x \in U \subseteq N \subseteq \Q\). {{AimForCont}} \(N\) is [[Definition:Compact Topological Subspace|compact]]. By [[Compact Set of Rational Numbers is Nowhere Dense]], \(N\) is [[Definition:Nowhere Dense|nowhere dense]]. Thus \(N^-\) contains no [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] of \(\Q\) which is [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]]. But \(U\) is a [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] of \(\Q\). By [[Set is Subset of its Topological Closure]], \(N \subseteq N^-\). Because [[Subset Relation is Transitive]]: :\(U \subseteq N^-\) This is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Hence \(\struct {\Q, \tau_d}\) is not a [[Definition:Locally Compact Hausdorff Space|locally compact Hausdorff Space]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}\) be the [[Definition:Irrational Number Space|irrational number space]] under the [[Definition:Euclidean Topology on Real Number Line|Euclidean topology]] \(\tau_d\). Then \(\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}\) is not a [[Definition:Locally Compact Hausdorff Space|locally compact Hausdorff Space]].
rationale: For \(\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}\) to be a [[Definition:Locally Compact Hausdorff Space|locally compact Hausdorff Space]], it is required that every point of \(\R \setminus \Q\) has a [[Definition:Compact Topological Subspace|compact]] [[Definition:Neighborhood of Point|neighborhood]]. Let \(x \in \R \setminus \Q\). Let \(N \subseteq \R \setminus \Q\) be a [[Definition:Neighborhood of Point|neighborhood]] of \(x\). Then: :\(\exists U \in \tau: x \in U \subseteq N \subseteq \R \setminus \Q\). {{AimForCont}} \(N\) is [[Definition:Compact Topological Subspace|compact]]. By [[Compact Set of Irrational Numbers is Nowhere Dense]], \(N\) is [[Definition:Nowhere Dense|nowhere dense]]. Thus \(N^-\) contains no [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] of \(\R \setminus \Q\) which is [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]]. But \(U\) is a [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] of \(\R \setminus \Q\). By [[Set is Subset of its Topological Closure]], \(N \subseteq N^-\). Because [[Subset Relation is Transitive]]: :\(U \subseteq N^-\) This is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Hence \(\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}\) is not a [[Definition:Locally Compact Hausdorff Space|locally compact Hausdorff Space]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {A, \tau_1}\) and \(\struct {B, \tau_2}\) be [[Definition:Topological Space|topological spaces]]. Let \(f: A \to B\) be a [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous mapping]]. Let \(\struct {\Img f, \tau_3}\) be the [[Definition:Image (Set Theory)/Mapping/Mapping|image of \(f\)]] with [[Definition:Topological Subspace|the subspace topology of \(B\)]]. Let \(\struct {A, \tau_1}\) be [[Definition:Locally Connected Space|locally connected]]. Then it is not necessarily the case that \(\struct {\Img f, \tau_3}\) is also [[Definition:Locally Connected Space|locally connected]].
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let \(\struct {A, \tau_1}\) be any [[Definition:Countable Discrete Space|countable discrete space]]. Let \(B \subseteq \R\) be the [[Definition:Set|set]] of all points on \(\R\) defined as: :\(B := \set 0 \cup \set {\dfrac 1 n: n \in \Z_{>0} }\) Let \(\struct {B, \tau_2}\) be the [[Definition:Integer Reciprocal Space|integer reciprocal space]] with [[Definition:Zero (Number)|zero]] under the [[Definition:Euclidean Topology on Real Number Line|usual (Euclidean) topology]]. From [[Discrete Space is Locally Connected]], \(\struct {A, \tau_1}\) is [[Definition:Locally Connected Space|locally connected]]. Let \(f: A \to B\) be a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]]. From [[Mapping from Discrete Space is Continuous]], \(f: A \to B\) is a [[Definition:Everywhere Continuous Mapping (Topology)|continuous mapping]]. From [[Integer Reciprocal Space with Zero is not Locally Connected]], \(\struct {B, \tau_2} = \struct {\Img f, \tau_3}\) is not [[Definition:Locally Connected Space|locally connected]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $\mathbb H$ be a [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Subset|subsets]] of $T$. That is, let $\mathbb H \subseteq \powerset T$ where $\powerset T$ is the [[Definition:Power Set|power set]] of $T$. Then it is not necessarily the case that: :$\displaystyle \paren {\bigcap_{H \mathop \in \mathbb H} H}^\circ = \bigcap_{H \mathop \in \mathbb H} H^\circ$ where $H^\circ$ denotes the [[Definition:Interior (Topology)|interior]] of $H$.
rationale: From [[Intersection of Interiors contains Interior of Intersection]] it is seen that it is always the case that: :$\displaystyle \paren {\bigcap_{H \mathop \in \mathbb H} H}^\circ \subseteq \bigcap_{H \mathop \in \mathbb H} H^\circ$ From [[Interior of Finite Intersection equals Intersection of Interiors]] it is seen that if $\mathbb H$ is [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]], then: :$\displaystyle \paren {\bigcap_{H \mathop \in \mathbb H} H}^\circ = \bigcap_{H \mathop \in \mathbb H} H^\circ$ It remains to be shown that in the case where $\mathbb H$ is [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite]], then it is possible that: :$\displaystyle \paren {\bigcap_{H \mathop \in \mathbb H} H}^\circ \ne \bigcap_{H \mathop \in \mathbb H} H^\circ$ [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let $A_n$ denote the [[Definition:Open Real Interval|open real interval]]: :$A_n := \openint {1 - \dfrac 1 n} {1 + \dfrac 1 n}$ for all $n \in \Z_{>0}$. From [[Open Sets in Real Number Line]], each of $A_n$ is an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] in $\R$. From [[Interior of Open Set]]: :$\forall n \in \Z_{>0}: A_n^\circ = A_n$ Thus: :$\displaystyle \bigcap A_n = \bigcap A_n^\circ = \set 1$ However: :$\displaystyle \paren {\bigcap A_n}^\circ = \set 1^\circ = \O$ Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $A \subseteq S$ be a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of the [[Definition:Underlying Set of Topological Space|underlying set]] $S$ of $T$. Let $A^e$ be the [[Definition:Exterior (Topology)|exterior]] of $A$. Let $A^\circ$ be the [[Definition:Interior (Topology)|interior]] of $A$. Then it is not necessarily the case that: :$A^{ee} = A^\circ$
rationale: We have from [[Interior is Subset of Exterior of Exterior]]: :$A^\circ \subseteq A^{ee}$ It remains to be shown that there exist $A \subseteq S$ such that: :$A^\circ \ne A^{ee}$ Let $a, b, c \in R$ where $a < b < c$. Let $A$ be the [[Definition:Union of Adjacent Open Intervals|union of the two adjacent open intervals]]: :$A := \openint a b \cup \openint b c$ From [[Exterior of Exterior of Union of Adjacent Open Intervals]]: :$A^{ee} = \openint a c$ From [[Interior of Union of Adjacent Open Intervals]]: :$A^\circ := \openint a b \cup \openint b c$ Thus: :$b \in A^{ee}$ but: :$b \notin A^\circ$ and so: :$A^{ee} \subsetneq A^\circ$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $U$ and $V$ be [[Definition:Regular Open Set|regular open sets]] of $T$. Then $U \cup V$ is not also necessarily a [[Definition:Regular Open Set|regular open set]] of $T.
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: By [[Open Real Interval is Regular Open]], the [[Definition:Open Real Interval|open real intervals]]: :$\openint 0 {\dfrac 1 2}, \openint {\dfrac 1 2} 1$ are both [[Definition:Regular Open Set|regular open sets]] of $\R$. Consider $A$, the [[Definition:Union of Adjacent Open Intervals|union of the adjacent open intervals]]: :$A := \openint 0 {\dfrac 1 2} \cup \openint {\dfrac 1 2} 1$ From [[Interior of Closure of Interior of Union of Adjacent Open Intervals]]: :$A^{- \circ} = \openint 0 1$ Thus $A$ is not a [[Definition:Regular Open Set|regular open set]] of $\R$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $H_1$ and $H_2$ be [[Definition:Subset|subsets]] of $S$. Let ${H_1}^-$ and ${H_2}^-$ denote the [[Definition:Closure (Topology)|closures]] of $H_1$ and $H_2$ respectively. Then it is not necessarily the case that: :$\paren {H_1 \cap H_2}^- = {H_1}^- \cap {H_2}^-$
rationale: Let $\\struct {\\R, \\tau_d}$ be the [[Definition:Real Number Line|real number line]] under the [[Definition:Euclidean Topology on Real Number Line|usual (Euclidean) topology]]. Let $H_1 = \\openint 0 {\\dfrac 1 2}$ and $H_2 = \\openint {\\dfrac 1 2} 1$. By inspection it can be seen that: :$H_1 \\cap H_2 = \\O$ Thus from [[Closure of Empty Set is Empty Set]]: :$\\paren {H_1 \\cap H_2}^- = \\O$ From [[Closure of Open Real Interval is Closed Real Interval]]: :$H_1 = \\closedint 0 {\\dfrac 1 2}, H_2 = \\closedint {\\dfrac 1 2} 1$ Thus: :${H_1}^- \\cap {H_2}^- = \\set {\\dfrac 1 2}$ So $\\paren {H_1 \\cap H_2}^- \\ne {H_1}^- \\cap {H_2}^-$ Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $U$ and $V$ be [[Definition:Regular Closed Set|regular closed]] sets of $T$. Then $U \cap V$ is not also necessarily a [[Definition:Regular Closed Set|regular closed]] set of $T.
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: By [[Closed Real Interval is Regular Closed]], the [[Definition:Closed Real Interval|closed real intervals]]: :$\closedint 0 {\dfrac 1 2}, \closedint {\dfrac 1 2} 1$ are both [[Definition:Regular Closed Set|regular closed]] sets of \R. Consider $A$, the [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]] of the two half-unit [[Definition:Closed Real Interval|closed intervals]]: :$A := \closedint 0 {\dfrac 1 2} \cap \closedint {\dfrac 1 2} 1 = \set {\dfrac 1 2} = \closedint {\dfrac 1 2} {\dfrac 1 2}$ From [[Interior of Closed Real Interval is Open Real Interval]]: :$A^\circ = \openint {\dfrac 1 2} {\dfrac 1 2} = \O$ From [[Closure of Empty Set is Empty Set]]: :$A^{\circ -} = \O \ne A$ Thus $A$ is not a [[Definition:Regular Closed Set|regular closed]] set of \R. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $H_1$ and $H_2$ be [[Definition:Subset|subsets]] of $S$. Let ${H_1}^\circ$ and ${H_2}^\circ$ denote the [[Definition:Interior (Topology)|interiors]] of $H_1$ and $H_2$ respectively. Then it is not necessarily the case that: :$\left({H_1 \cup H_2}\right)^\circ = {H_1}^\circ \cup {H_2}^\circ$
rationale: From [[Union of Interiors is Subset of Interior of Union]]: :$\paren {H_1 \cup H_2}^\circ \supseteq {H_1}^\circ \cup {H_2}^\circ$ It remains to be shown that it is not necessarily the case that: :$\paren {H_1 \cup H_2}^\circ = {H_1}^\circ \cup {H_2}^\circ$ [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ be the [[Definition:Real Number Line|real number line]] under the [[Definition:Euclidean Topology on Real Number Line|usual (Euclidean) topology]]. Let $H_1 = \closedint 0 {\dfrac 1 2}$ and $H_2 = \closedint {\dfrac 1 2} 1$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \paren {H_1 \cup H_2}^\circ       | r = \paren {\closedint 0 {\dfrac 1 2} \cup \closedint {\dfrac 1 2} 1}^\circ       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \closedint 0 1^\circ       | c = by definition }} {{eqn | r = \openint 0 1       | c = [[Interior of Closed Real Interval is Open Real Interval]] }} {{end-eqn}} and: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = {H_1}^\circ \cup {H_2}^\circ       | r = \closedint 0 {\dfrac 1 2}^\circ \cup \closedint {\dfrac 1 2} 1^\circ       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \openint 0 {\dfrac 1 2} \cup \openint {\dfrac 1 2} 1       | c = [[Interior of Closed Real Interval is Open Real Interval]] }} {{eqn | o = \ne       | r = \openint 0 1       | c = as $\dfrac 1 2$ is in one but not the other }} {{end-eqn}} Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T_1 = \struct {S_1, \tau_1}$ and $T_2 = \struct {S_2, \tau_2}$ be [[Definition:Topological Space|topological spaces]]. Let $H_1 \subseteq S_1$ and $H_2 \subseteq S_2$. Let $H_1$ and $H_2$ be a [[Definition:Homeomorphic Topological Spaces|homeomorphic]]. Then it may be the case that there does not exist a [[Definition:Homeomorphism (Topological Spaces)|homeomorphism]] $g: T_1 \to T_2$ such that: :$g \restriction_{H_1} = f$ where: :$g \restriction_{H_1}$ is the [[Definition:Restriction of Mapping|restriction of $g$ to $H_1$]] :$f: H_1 \to H_2$ is a [[Definition:Homeomorphism (Topological Spaces)|homeomorphism]].
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let \struct {\R, \tau_d} be the [[Definition:Real Number Line with Euclidean Topology|real number line with the usual (Euclidean) topology]]. Let $H_1 := \set 0 \cup \closedint 1 2 \cup \set 3$, where \closedint 1 2 denotes the [[Definition:Closed Real Interval|closed interval]] from $1$ to $2$. Let $H_2 := \closedint 0 1 \cup \set 2 \cup \set 3$. $H_1$ and $H_2$ are [[Definition:Homeomorphic Topological Spaces|homeomorphic]], as can be demonstrated by the [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] \phi: H_1 \to \H_2 defined as: :\forall x \in H_1: \map \phi x = \begin {cases} 2 & : x = 0 \\ 3 & : x = 3 \\ x - 1 & : x \in \closedint 1 2 \end {cases}$ which is trivially a [[Definition:Homeomorphism (Topological Spaces)|homeomorphism]]. So, let $g$ be a [[Definition:Homeomorphism (Topological Spaces)|homeomorphism]] from $H_1$ and $H_2$. Each of the [[Definition:Singleton|singletons]] in $H_1$ has to map to one of the [[Definition:Singleton|singletons]] in $H_2$. As a result, $g$ is not [[Definition:Monotone Real Function|monotone]]. Let $f: \R \to \R$ be a [[Definition:Homeomorphism (Topological Spaces)|homeomorphism]] such that $g$ is a [[Definition:Restriction of Mapping|restriction]] of $f$. From [[Continuous Real Function on Closed Interval is Bijective iff Strictly Monotone]], $f$ is [[Definition:Monotone Real Function|monotone]]. {{explain|We need another result for the above over the whole range \R -- for some reason this does not exist. We have [[Surjective Monotone Function is Continuous]] but not in the other direction.}} Hence $f$ cannot be a [[Definition:Bijection|bijection]]. Hence $f$ cannot be a [[Definition:Homeomorphism (Topological Spaces)|homeomorphism]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $a, b, c \in \Z_{>0}$ be [[Definition:Strictly Positive Integer|(strictly) positive integers]]. Let: :$c \divides a b$ where $\divides$ expresses the [[Definition:Relation|relation]] of [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisibility]]. Then it is not necessarily the case that either $c \divides a$ or $c \divides b$.
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let $c = 6, a = 3, b = 4$. Then $6 \\times 2 = 12$ so $c \\divides a b$. But neither $6 \\divides 4$ nor $6 \\divides 3$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $p$ be a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime number]]. Then there exists a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime number]] $q$ such that: :$p < q \le p! + 1$ where $p!$ denotes the [[Definition:Factorial|factorial]] of $p$.
rationale: Let $N = p! + 1$. If $N$ is [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]], then the proof is complete. Otherwise, from [[Positive Integer Greater than 1 has Prime Divisor]], $N$ has a [[Definition:Prime Factor|prime divisor]] $q$. From [[Absolute Value of Integer is not less than Divisors]]: :$q < N$ {{AimForCont}} $q \le p$. Then by the definition of [[Definition:Factorial|factorial]]: :$q \divides p!$ But $q$ was chosen so that :$q \divides N$. Let $p! = q m_1, N = q m_2$. Then: :$1 = N - p! = q \paren {m_2 - m_1}$ and so: :$q \divides 1$ From [[Absolute Value of Integer is not less than Divisors]]: :$q \le 1$ and so $q$ cannot be a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime number]]. It follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]] that $q > p$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $\LL$ be a [[Definition:Logical Language|logical language]]. Let $\mathscr M$ be a [[Definition:Formal Semantics|formal semantics]] for $\LL$. Let $\FF$ be an [[Definition:Unsatisfiable Set of Formulas|$\mathscr M$-unsatisfiable set of formulas]] from $\LL$. Let $\FF'$ be a [[Definition:Superset|superset]] of $\FF$. Then $\FF'$ is also [[Definition:Unsatisfiable Set of Formulas|$\mathscr M$-unsatisfiable]].
rationale: By assumption, $\FF$ is [[Definition:Unsatisfiable Set of Formulas|unsatisfiable]]. Suppose now $\FF'$ were [[Definition:Satisfiable Set of Formulas|satisfiable]]. Then it would follow from [[Subset of Satisfiable Set is Satisfiable]] that $\FF$ were also [[Definition:Satisfiable Set of Formulas|satisfiable]]. We conclude that $\FF'$ must be [[Definition:Unsatisfiable Set of Formulas|unsatisfiable]]. {{qed}} [[Category:Formal Semantics]] fca2oi6sx6lh7lv4yg1ci7rqrwdwlqq

statement: Equivalently this is to say: :$z_1 z_2 = 0 \implies z_1 = 0 \lor z_2 = 0$
rationale: Let $z_1 z_2 = 0$. {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = z_1       | r = \tuple {x_1, y_1}       | c = {{Defof|Complex Number|index = 2}}: for some $x_1, y_1 \in \R$ }} {{eqn | l = z_2       | r = \tuple {x_2, y_2}       | c = {{Defof|Complex Number|index = 2}}: for some $x_2, y_2 \in \R$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = z_1 z_2       | r = \tuple {x_1 x_2 - y_1 y_2, x_1 y_2 + y_1 x_2}       | c = Definition of [[Definition:Complex Number/Definition 2/Multiplication|Complex Multiplication]] }} {{eqn | n = 1       | ll= \leadsto       | l = x_1 x_2       | r = y_1 y_2       | c =  }} {{eqn | n = 2       | lo= \land       | l = x_1 y_2       | r = -y_1 x_2       | c = as $z_1 z_2 = 0$ }} {{end-eqn}} {{WLOG}}, let \tuple {x_2, y_2} \ne \tuple {0, 0}$. Suppose also that \tuple {x_1, y_1} \ne \tuple {0, 0}$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = x_1       | r = \frac {y_1 y_2} {x_2}       | c = from $(1)$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = \frac {y_1 y_2} {x_2} y_2       | r = -y_1 x_2       | c = substituting in $(2)$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = y_2^2       | r = - x_2^2       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = x_2 = y_2       | r = 0       | c = as both $x_2$ and $y_2$ are [[Definition:Real Number|real]] }} {{end-eqn}} From this [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that: :$\tuple {x_1, y_1} = \tuple {0, 0}$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $\mathbf A$ be a [[Definition:WFF of Propositional Logic|WFF of propositional logic]]. Let $\mathbf A$ be [[Definition:Unsatisfiable (Boolean Interpretations)|unsatisfiable for boolean interpretations]]. Then every [[Definition:Completed Tableau|completed tableau]] for $\mathbf A$ is [[Definition:Closed Tableau|closed]].
rationale: The proof proceeds by contradiction. That is, we assume that some [[Definition:Open Tableau|open tableau]] $T$ for $\mathbf A$ exists, and prove that $\mathbf A$ must be [[Definition:Satisfiable (Boolean Interpretations)|satisfiable]]. This claim is proved by inductively establishing the following claim for all [[Definition:Node (Graph Theory)|nodes]] $t$ of $T$: :If a [[Definition:Descendant Node|descendant]] [[Definition:Leaf Node|leaf node]] of $t$ is [[Definition:Marked Open Leaf|marked open]], then $U \left({t}\right)$ is [[Definition:Satisfiable (Boolean Interpretations)|satisfiable]]. By the [[Semantic Tableau Algorithm]], this statement is immediate for [[Definition:Leaf Node|leaf nodes]]. For, sought [[Definition:Satisfiable (Boolean Interpretations)|satisfiability]] is the condition for a [[Definition:Leaf Node|leaf]] to be [[Definition:Marked Open Leaf|marked open]]. Inductively suppose that all [[Definition:Child Node|children]] of $t$ satisfy the mentioned condition. Now suppose that $t$ has a [[Definition:Descendant Node|descendant]] [[Definition:Marked Open Leaf|marked open leaf]]. Then obviously some [[Definition:Child Node|child]] $t'$ of $t$ also has a [[Definition:Descendant Node|descendant]] [[Definition:Marked Open Leaf|marked open leaf]]. By induction hypothesis, $U \left({t'}\right)$ is [[Definition:Satisfiable (Boolean Interpretations)|satisfiable]]. First, the case that the formula $\mathbf B$ used at $t$ by the [[Semantic Tableau Algorithm]] is an [[Definition:Alpha-Formula|$\alpha$-formula]]. Then $U \left({t'}\right)$ is obtained from $U \left({t}\right)$ by replacing $\mathbf B$ by $\mathbf B_1$ and $\mathbf B_2$. Here, $\mathbf B_1$ and $\mathbf B_2$ are the formulas such that $\mathbf B$ is [[Definition:Semantic Equivalence (Boolean Interpretations)|semantically equivalent]] to $\mathbf B_1 \land \mathbf B_2$. It follows that if: :$v \models_{\mathrm{BI}} U \left({t'}\right)$ for some [[Definition:Boolean Interpretation|boolean interpretation]] $v$, then also: :$v \models_{\mathrm{BI}} U \left({t}\right)$ by the [[Definition:Conjunction/Boolean Interpretation|boolean interpretation]] of $\land$. Consequently, $U \left({t}\right)$ is [[Definition:Satisfiable (Boolean Interpretations)|satisfiable]]. Next, the case that $\mathbf B$ is a [[Definition:Beta-Formula|$\beta$-formula]]. Then $\mathbf B$ is [[Definition:Semantic Equivalence (Boolean Interpretations)|semantically equivalent]] to $\mathbf B_1 \lor \mathbf B_2$. Then, by the [[Rule of Addition/Sequent Form/Proof 2|Rule of Addition]]: :$\mathbf B_1 \models_{\mathrm{BI}} \mathbf B$ :$\mathbf B_2 \models_{\mathrm{BI}} \mathbf B$ Consequently, by the definitions of $U \left({t'}\right)$ and $U \left({t''}\right)$: :$U \left({t'}\right) \models_{\mathrm{BI}} U \left({t}\right)$ :$U \left({t''}\right) \models_{\mathrm{BI}} U \left({t}\right)$ By hypothesis, one of $U \left({t'}\right)$ and $U \left({t''}\right)$ must be [[Definition:Satisfiable (Boolean Interpretations)|satisfiable]]. Hence, so must $U \left({t}\right)$ be. This establishes our claim. Applying the claim to the [[Definition:Root Node|root node]], i.e., to the whole [[Definition:Semantic Tableau|tableau]], we obtain the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $z = x + i y \in \C$ be a [[Definition:Complex Number|complex number]]. Then: :$\size x + \size y \le \sqrt 2 \cmod z$ where: :$\size x$ and $\size y$ denote the [[Definition:Absolute Value|absolute value]] of $x$ and $y$ :$\cmod z$ denotes the [[Definition:Complex Modulus|complex modulus]] of $z$.
rationale: Let $z = x + i y \in \C$ be an arbitrary [[Definition:Complex Number|complex number]]. {{AimForCont}} the contrary: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \size x + \size y | o = > | r = \sqrt 2 \cmod z | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \paren {\size x + \size y}^2 | o = > | r = 2 \cmod z^2 | c = squaring both sides }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \size x^2 + 2 \size x \, \size y + \size y^2 | o = > | r = 2 \cmod z^2 | c = multiplying out }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = x^2 + 2 \size x \, \size y + y^2 | o = > | r = 2 \cmod z^2 | c = {{Defof|Absolute Value}} }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = x^2 + 2 \size x \, \size y + y^2 | o = > | r = 2 \paren {x^2 + y^2} | c = {{Defof|Complex Modulus}} }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = 2 \size x \, \size y | o = > | r = x^2 + y^2 | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = 2 \size x \, \size y | o = > | r = \size x^2 + \size y^2 | c = {{Defof|Absolute Value}} }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \size x^2 - 2 \size x \, \size y + \size y^2 | o = < | r = 0 | c = rearranging }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \paren {\size x - \size y}^2 | o = < | r = 0 | c = factoring }} {{end-eqn}} But as $\size x$ and $\size y$ are both [[Definition:Real Number|real]] this cannot happen. Thus our initial assumption $\size x + \size y > \sqrt 2 \cmod z$ is false. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: $\forall m, n, p \in S: m \preceq n \iff m \circ p \preceq n \circ p$
rationale: The forward implication is immediate from \preceq being [[Definition:Relation Compatible with Operation|compatible]] with \circ: :$\forall m, n, p \in S: m \preceq n \implies m \circ p \preceq n \circ p$ Conversely, suppose that $m \circ p \preceq n \circ p$. Suppose that $n \prec m$. Then as \preceq is [[Definition:Relation Compatible with Operation|compatible]] with \circ: :$n \circ p \preceq m \circ p$ Since \preceq is an [[Definition:Ordering|ordering]], this implies: :$n \circ p = m \circ p$ By [[Definition:Naturally Ordered Semigroup Axioms|axiom $(\text {NO} 2)$]], it follows that: :$n = m$ contradicting our assumption that $n \prec m$. Hence, since \preceq is a [[Definition:Total Ordering|total ordering]]: :$m \preceq n$ as desired. {{qed}}

statement: $\forall m, n, p \in S: m \prec n \iff m \circ p \prec n \circ p$
rationale: By [[Definition:Naturally Ordered Semigroup Axioms|axiom $(NO2)$]], all $n \in S$ are [[Definition:Cancellable Element|cancellable]]. Hence from [[Strict Ordering Preserved under Product with Cancellable Element]]: :$\forall m, n, p \in S: m \prec n \implies m \circ p \prec n \circ p$ By [[Definition:Naturally Ordered Semigroup Axioms|axiom $(NO1)$]], $\preceq$ is a [[Definition:Total Ordering|total ordering]]. Therefore, the [[Definition:Contrapositive Statement|contrapositive]] of: :$\forall m, n, p \in S: m \circ p \prec n \circ p \implies m \prec n$ is: :$\forall m, n, p \in S: m \preceq n \implies m \circ p \preceq n \circ p$ which we know to be true by virtue of [[Definition:Naturally Ordered Semigroup Axioms|axiom $(NO2)$]]. The result follows. {{qed}}

statement: Let $f$ be a [[Definition:Real Function|real function]] which is: :$(1): \quad$ [[Definition:Differentiable on Interval|Differentiable]] on $\R$ :$(2): \quad$ [[Definition:Bounded Real-Valued Function|Bounded]] on $\R$ :$(3): \quad$ [[Definition:Concave Real Function|Concave]] on $\R$. Then $f$ is [[Definition:Constant Mapping|constant]].
rationale: Let $f$ be [[Definition:Differentiable on Interval|differentiable]] and [[Definition:Bounded Real-Valued Function|bounded]] on $\R$. Let $f$ be [[Definition:Concave Real Function|concave]] on $\R$. Let $\xi \in \R$. Aiming for a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose $f' \left({\xi}\right) > 0$. Then by [[Mean Value of Concave Real Function]] it follows that: : $f \left({x}\right) \le f \left({\xi}\right) + f' \left({\xi}\right) \left({x - \xi}\right) \to -\infty$ as $x \to +\infty$ and therefore is not [[Definition:Bounded Real-Valued Function|bounded]]. Similarly, suppose $f' \left({\xi}\right) < 0$. Then by [[Mean Value of Concave Real Function]] it follows that: : $f \left({x}\right) \le f \left({\xi}\right) + f' \left({\xi}\right) \left({x - \xi}\right) \to -\infty$ as $x \to -\infty$ and therefore is likewise not [[Definition:Bounded Real-Valued Function|bounded]]. Hence $f' \left({\xi}\right) = 0$. From [[Zero Derivative implies Constant Function]], it follows that $f$ is [[Definition:Constant Mapping|constant]]. {{qed}}

statement: [[Definition:Euler's Number|Euler's Number]] $e$ is [[Definition:Transcendental|transcendental]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} there exist [[Definition:Integer|integers]] $a_0, \ldots, a_n$ with $a_0 \ne 0$ such that: :$(1): \quad a_n e^n + a_{n - 1} e^{n - 1} + \cdots + a_0 = 0$ Define $M$, $M_1, \ldots, M_n$ and $\epsilon_1, \ldots, \epsilon_n$ as follows: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = M       | r = \int_0^\infty \frac {x^{p - 1} \sqbrk {\paren {x - 1} \cdots \paren {x - n} }^p e^{-x} } {\paren {p - 1}!} \rd x }} {{eqn | l = M_k       | r = e^k \int_k^\infty \frac {x^{p - 1} \sqbrk {\paren {x - 1} \cdots \paren {x - n} }^p e^{-x} } {\paren {p - 1}!} \rd x }} {{eqn | l = \epsilon_k       | r = e^k \int_0^k \frac {x^{p - 1} \sqbrk {\paren {x - 1} \cdots \paren {x - n} }^p e^{-x} } {\paren {p - 1}!} \rd x }} {{end-eqn}} where $p$ is a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime number]] with $p > n$ and $p > \size {a_0}$. The expression $\sqbrk {\paren {x - 1} \cdots \paren {x - n} }^p$ is a [[Definition:Polynomial (Abstract Algebra)|polynomial]] of [[Definition:Degree of Polynomial/Field|degree]] $n p$ with integer coefficients. Hence: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = M       | r = \sum_{\alpha \mathop = 0}^{n p} \frac {C_\alpha} {\paren {p - 1}!} \int_0^\infty x^{p - 1 + \alpha} e^{-x} \rd x       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \sum_{\alpha \mathop = 0}^{n p} C_\alpha \dfrac {\paren {p - 1 + \alpha}!} {\paren {p - 1}!}       | c = [[Gamma Function Extends Factorial]] }} {{end-eqn}} where $C_\alpha$ are integers and $C_0 = \pm \paren {n!}^p$. For $\alpha = 0$ we have: :$C_0 \dfrac {\paren {p - 1}!} {\paren {p - 1}!} = \pm \paren {n!}^p$ Since $p > n$, it follows from [[Prime iff Coprime to all Smaller Positive Integers]] and [[Euclid's Lemma]] that this term is not divisible by $p$. For $\alpha \ge 1$ we have: :$C_\alpha \dfrac {\paren {p - 1 + \alpha}!} {\paren {p - 1}!} = C_\alpha \paren {p - 1 + \alpha} \paren {p - 2 + \alpha} \cdots p$ which is clearly divisible by $p$. It follows from [[Common Divisor Divides Difference]] that $M$ is an integer not [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisible]] by $p$. We also have: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = M_k       | r = \int_k^\infty \frac {x^{p - 1} \sqbrk {\paren {x - 1} \cdots \paren {x - n} }^p e^{-\paren {x - k} } } {\paren {p - 1}!} \rd x       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \int_0^\infty \frac {\paren {x + k}^{p - 1} \sqbrk {\paren {x + k - 1} \cdots \paren {x + k - n} }^p e^{- x} } {\paren {p - 1}!} \rd x       | c = [[Integration by Substitution|substituting]] $x - k \mapsto x$ }} {{end-eqn}} The expression $\sqbrk {\paren {x + k - 1} \cdots \paren {x + k - n} }$ is divisible by $x$. So $\paren {x + k}^{p - 1} \sqbrk {\paren {x + k - 1} \cdots \paren {x + k - n} }^p$ is a polynomial of degree at least $p$ with integer coefficients. Hence: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = M_k       | r = \sum_{\alpha \mathop = 1}^{n p} \frac {D_{\alpha} } {\paren {p - 1}!} \int_0^\infty x^{p - 1 + \alpha} e^{-x} \rd x       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \sum_{\alpha \mathop = 1}^{n p} D_{\alpha} \frac {\paren {p - 1 + \alpha}!} {\paren {p - 1}!}       | c = [[Gamma Function Extends Factorial]] }} {{end-eqn}} where $D_\alpha$ are integers. Since this sum begins with $\alpha = 1$, each term is divisible by $p$.  Thus each $M_k$ is an integer divisible by $p$. By the above definitions we have: :$e^k = \dfrac {M_k + \epsilon_k} M$ Substituting this into $(1)$ and multiplying by $M$ we obtain: :$\paren {a_0 M + a_1 M_1 + \cdots + a_n M_n} + \paren {a_1 \epsilon_1 + \cdots + a_n \epsilon_n} = 0$ Since $p > \size {a_0}$, it follows from [[Prime iff Coprime to all Smaller Positive Integers]] that $p$ does not divide $a_0$. So by [[Euclid's Lemma]], $a_0 M$ is not divisible by $p$. Since each $M_k$ is divisible by $p$, it follows from [[Common Divisor Divides Difference]] that $a_0 M + a_1 M_1 + \cdots + a_n M_n$ is not divisible by $p$. Therefore $a_0 M + a_1 M_1 + \cdots + a_n M_n$ is a non-zero integer. We also have: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \size {\epsilon_k}       | r = e^k \size {\int_0^k \frac {x^{p - 1} \sqbrk {\paren {x - 1} \cdots \paren {x - n} }^p e^{-x} } {\paren {p - 1}!} \rd x}       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = \le       | r = e^k \int_0^k \frac {\size {x^{p - 1} \sqbrk {\paren {x - 1} \cdots \paren {x - n} }^p} e^{-x} } {\paren {p - 1}!} \rd x       | c = [[Absolute Value of Definite Integral]] }} {{eqn | o = \le       | r = e^n \int_0^n \frac {n^{p - 1} \size {\sqbrk {\paren {x - 1} \cdots \paren {x - n} }^p} e^{-x} } {\paren {p - 1}!} \rd x       | c = [[Relative Sizes of Definite Integrals]] }} {{end-eqn}} Let $A$ be the maximum value of $\size {\paren {x - 1} \cdots \paren {x - n} }$ for $x$ in the [[Definition:Closed Interval|interval]] $\closedint 0 n$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | o = \le       | l = \size {\epsilon_k}       | r = \frac {e^n n^{p - 1} A^p} {\paren {p - 1}!} \int_0^n e^{-x} \rd x       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = \le       | r = \frac {e^n n^{p - 1} A^p} {\paren {p - 1}!} n       | c = as $e^{- x} \le 1$ for $x \ge 0$  }} {{eqn | o = \le       | r = \frac {e^n \paren {n A}^p} {p!}       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} By [[Power over Factorial]]: :$\displaystyle \lim_{p \mathop \to \infty} \frac {e^n \paren {n A}^p} {p!} = 0$ So $\size {\epsilon_k}$, and therefore $\size {a_1 \epsilon_1 + \cdots + a_n \epsilon_n}$, can be made arbitrarily small by choosing $p$ sufficiently large.  It follows that $\paren {a_0 M + a_1 M_1 + \cdots + a_n M_n} + \paren {a_1 \epsilon_1 + \cdots + a_n \epsilon_n}$ is non-zero. This is a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]], so $e$ must be [[Definition:Transcendental|transcendental]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $f: \R \to \R$ be a [[Definition:Real Function|real function]]. Let $F$ be a [[Definition:Primitive (Calculus)|primitive]] of $f$ that is [[Definition:Bounded Mapping|bounded]] on all of $\R$. Let $f$ be [[Definition:Real Periodic Function|periodic]] with [[Definition:Period of Function|period]] $L$. Then $F$ is also [[Definition:Real Periodic Function|periodic]] with [[Definition:Period of Function|period]] $L$.
rationale: Let $f$ be [[Definition:Real Periodic Function|periodic]] with [[Definition:Period of Function|period]] $L$. Let $f$ have a [[Definition:Primitive (Calculus)|primitive]] $F$ that is [[Definition:Bounded Mapping|bounded]] on all of $\R$. By definition of a [[Definition:Real Periodic Function|periodic function]], it is seen that: :$\map f x = \map f {x + L}$. Then: :$\displaystyle \int \map f x \rd x$ and: :$\displaystyle \int \map f {x + L} \rd x$ are both [[Definition:Primitive (Calculus)|primitives]] of the same function. So by [[Primitives which Differ by Constant]]: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \int \map f x \rd x + C       | r = \int \map f {x + L} \rd x }} {{eqn | r = \int \map f {x + L} \frac {\map \d {x + L} } {\d x} \rd x       | c = as $\dfrac {\map \d {x + L} } {\d x} = 1$ }} {{eqn | r = \int \map f {x + L} \map \d {x + L}       | c = [[Integration by Substitution]] }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = \map F x + C       | r = \map F {x + L} }} {{end-eqn}} {{AimForCont}} that $C \ne 0$. Then it is to be shown that for all $k \in \N_{> 0}$: :$\map F x + k C = \map F {x + k L}$ The case for $k = 1$ has already been proven, so this will be proven by [[Principle of Mathematical Induction|induction]]. Suppose that for some $n \in \N_{> 0}$ we have: :$\map F x + n C = \map F {x + n L}$ Then {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \map F {x + \paren {n + 1} L}       | r = \map F {x + L + n L} }} {{eqn | r = \map F {x + L} + n C       | c = by the induction hypothesis }} {{eqn | r = \map F x + \paren {n + 1} C       | c = by the base case }} {{end-eqn}} {{qed|lemma}} Holding $x$ fixed yields: :$\displaystyle \lim_{k \mathop \to \infty} \size {\map F {x + k L} } = \lim_{k \mathop \to \infty} \size {\map F x + k C} = \infty$ and so $\map F x$ is unbounded. But we had previously established that $\map F x$ was bounded. This is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] Therefore our assumption that $C \ne 0$ was false. Hence $C = 0$ and so: :$\map F x = \map F {x + L}$ It has been shown that $F$ is [[Definition:Real Periodic Function|periodic]]. {{qed|lemma}} Let $L'$ be the [[Definition:Period of Function|period]] of $F$. Suppose that $\size {L'} < \size L$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \map F x       | r = \map F {x + L'} }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = \map {F'} x       | r = \map {F'} {x + L'}       | c = [[Chain Rule for Derivatives]] }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = \map f x       | r = \map f {x + L'}       | c = {{Defof|Primitive of Real Function}} }} {{end-eqn}} But it was previously established that $L$ was the [[Definition:Period of Function|period]] of $f$. This is a contradiction, therefore $L' = L$. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $G_n = \sequence {a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_n}$ be a [[Definition:Geometric Sequence of Integers|geometric sequence of integers]]. Let: :$a_0 \perp a_n$ where \perp denotes [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprimality]]. Then $G_n$ is [[Definition:Geometric Sequence of Integers in Lowest Terms|in its lowest terms]].
rationale: Let $G_n = \sequence {a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_n}$ be [[Definition:Natural Number|natural numbers]] in [[Definition:Geometric Sequence|geometric sequence]] such that $a_0 \perp a_n$. {{AimForCont}}, suppose there were to exist another set of [[Definition:Natural Number|natural numbers]] in [[Definition:Geometric Sequence|geometric sequence]]: :$G\,'_n = \sequence {b_0, b_1, \cdots, b_n}$ with the same [[Definition:Common Ratio of Geometric Sequence|common ratio]] where: :$\forall k \in \N_{\le n}: a_k > b_k$ From {{EuclidPropLink|book = VII|prop = 14|title = Proportion of Numbers is Transitive}}: :$a_0 : a_n = b_0 : b_n$ But [[Definition:By Hypothesis|by hypothesis]]: :$a_0 \perp a_n$ and so from: :{{EuclidPropLink|prop = 21|title = Coprime Numbers form Fraction in Lowest Terms}} and: :{{EuclidPropLink|prop = 20|title = Ratios of Fractions in Lowest Terms}} it follows that: :$a_0 \divides b_0$ However, this contradicts the assumption that $b_0 < a_0$. Therefore $a_0, a_1, \cdots, a_n$ are the least of those with the same [[Definition:Common Ratio of Geometric Sequence|common ratio]]. {{qed}}

statement: Given two [[Definition:Infinite Straight Line|infinite straight lines]] which are cut by a [[Definition:Transversal (Geometry)|transversal]], if the lines are [[Definition:Parallel Lines|parallel]], then the [[Definition:Alternate Angles of Transversal|alternate angles]] are equal.
rationale:
[[File:Parallel Cut by Transversal.png|200px]] Let $AB$ and $CD$ be [[Definition:Parallel Lines|parallel]] [[Definition:Infinite Straight Line|infinite straight lines]]. Let $EF$ be a [[Definition:Transversal (Geometry)|transversal]] that cuts them. Aiming for a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose the [[Definition:Alternate Angles of Transversal|alternate angles]] are not equal. Then one of the pair $\angle AGH$ and $\angle GHD$ must be greater. {{WLOG}}, let $\angle AGH$ be greater. From [[Two Angles on Straight Line make Two Right Angles]], $\angle AGH + \angle BGH$ equal two [[Definition:Right Angle|right angles]]. So $\angle GHD + \angle BGH$ is less than two [[Definition:Right Angle|right angles]]. By [[Axiom:Euclid's Fifth Postulate|Euclid's fifth postulate]], lines extended infinitely from [[Definition:Angle|angles]] less than two [[Definition:Right Angle|right angles]] must meet. But the lines are [[Definition:Parallel Lines|parallel]]. So by definition the lines do not [[Definition:Intersection (Geometry)|intersect]]. From this [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that the [[Definition:Alternate Angles of Transversal|alternate angles]] are be equal. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|29|I|{{EuclidNoteConverse|prop = 27|title = Equal Alternate Angles implies Parallel Lines}}

This is the first proposition of {{BookLink|The Elements|Euclid}} to make use of [[Axiom:Euclid's Fifth Postulate|Euclid's fifth postulate]].|part = first}}

statement: Let $ABCD$ be a [[Definition:Rectangle|rectangle]]. Then $ABCD$ is a [[Definition:Parallelogram|parallelogram]].
rationale: Let $ABCD$ be a [[Definition:Rectangle|rectangle]]. [[Proof by Contradiction|Seeking a contradiction]], assume $ABCD$ is ''not'' a [[Definition:Parallelogram|parallelogram]]. {{image wanted|PW gives an error message when uploading images. An email has been sent to Joe.}} {{WLOG}} let [[Definition:Line Segment|line segments]] $AD$ and $BC$ ''not'' be parallel. Then [[Axiom:Euclid's Second Postulate|extend $AD$ and $BC$]] into two [[Definition:Line/Infinite Straight Line|infinite straight lines]]. By the [[Axiom:Parallel Postulate|Parallel Postulate]], the lines will eventually meet at one side or the other. Let their point of [[Definition:Intersection (Geometry)|intersection]] be $E$. There are two possibilities: :$ABE$ is a [[Definition:Triangle (Geometry)|triangle]] :$CDE$ is a [[Definition:Triangle (Geometry)|triangle]]. {{WLOG}}, let $ABE$ be a triangle. If $ABE$ is a triangle, then by [[Sum of Angles of Triangle equals Two Right Angles]], $\angle ABE + \angle BEA + \angle EAB$ add to two [[Definition:Right Angle|right angles]]. But by the [[Definition:Rectangle|definition of a rectangle]], $\angle ABE + \angle EAB$ add to two right angles. As $\angle BEA$ is not a [[Definition:Zero Angle|zero angle]] (else $ABD$ would not be a triangle), this cannot be so. We are forced to conclude that that $ABCD$ is not a rectangle, a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. {{qed}} [[Category:Rectangles]] [[Category:Parallelograms]] qiwnxy6fxk3n89o4f39a7c37oltaget

statement: The corresponding proof: Let $A, B$ be [[Definition:Natural Number|(natural) numbers]] which are the least of those which have the same [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] with them. We need to show that $A$ and $B$ are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|prime to one another]].
rationale: Aiming for a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose $A$ and $B$ are not [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. Then by definition there exists some [[Definition:Natural Number|(natural) number]] $C > 1$ which [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|measures]] them both. As many times as $C$ [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|measures]] $A$, let that many [[Definition:One|units]] be in $D$. As many times as $C$ [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|measures]] $B$, let that many [[Definition:One|units]] be in $E$. So by {{EuclidDefLink|VII|15|Multiply}}: :$A = C \times D$ :$B = C \times E$ Thus by {{EuclidPropLink|book=VII|prop=17|title=Multiples of Ratios of Numbers}}: :$D : E = A : B$ So $D$ and $E$ are in the same [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] with $A$ and $B$. But by [[Absolute Value of Integer is not less than Divisors/Corollary|Absolute Value of Integer is not less than Divisors: Corollary]]: :$D < A$ :$E < B$ This [[Proof by Contradiction|contradicts]] our [[Definition:By Hypothesis|hypothesis]] that $A$ and $B$ are the least of those numbers that are in the same [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] with $A$ and $B$. It follows that $A$ and $B$ must be [[Definition:Coprime Integers|prime to one another]]. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|22|VII|{{EuclidNoteConverse|prop = 21|title = Coprime Numbers form Fraction in Lowest Terms}}}}

statement: Let $a, b \in \N$ be [[Definition:Natural Number|numbers]] such that $a$ and $b$ are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]: :$a \perp b$ Let $c > 1$ be a [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisor]] of $a$: :$c \divides a$ Then $c$ and $b$ are coprime: :$c \perp b$ {{:Euclid:Proposition/VII/23}}
rationale: Let $a \perp b$ and $c > 1: c \divides a$. {{AimForCont}} $c \not \perp b$. So by definition of [[Definition:Coprime Integers|not coprime]]: :$\exists d > 1: d \divides c, d \divides b$ But from [[Divisor Relation is Transitive]]: :$d \divides c, c \divides a \implies d \divides a$ So $d$ is a [[Definition:Common Divisor of Integers|common divisor]] of both $a$ and $b$. So, by definition, $a$ and $b$ are not [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. The result follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $a, b, c \in \Z$. Let $c$ be [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]] to each of $a$ and $b$. Then $c$ is [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]] to $a b$. {{:Euclid:Proposition/VII/24}}
rationale: This proof follows the structure of {{AuthorRef|Euclid}}'s proof, if not its detail.'' Let $a, b, c \in \Z$ such that $c$ is [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]] to each of $a$ and $b$. Let $d = a b$. {{AimForCont}} $c$ and $d$ are not [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. Then: :$\exists e \in \Z_{>1}: e \divides c, e \divides d$ We have that $c \perp a$ and $e \divides c$ From {{EuclidPropLink|book=VII|prop=23|title=Divisor of One of Coprime Numbers is Coprime to Other}}: :$e \perp a$ As $e \divides d$ it follows by definition of [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisibility]] that: :$\exists f \in \Z: e f = d$ We also have that: :$a b = d$ So: :$a b = e f$ But from {{EuclidPropLink|book=VII|prop=19|title=Relation of Ratios to Products}}: :$e : a = b : f$ or in more contemporary language: :$\dfrac a e = \dfrac b f$ But $a \perp e$. From {{EuclidPropLink|book = VII|prop = 21|title = Coprime Numbers form Fraction in Lowest Terms}}, $\dfrac a e$ is in [[Definition:Canonical Form of Rational Number|canonical form]]. From {{EuclidPropLink|book = VII|prop = 20|title = Ratios of Fractions in Lowest Terms}}: :$e \divides b$ But we already have that: :$e \divides c$ So $e$ is a [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisor]] of both $b$ and $c$. But this is a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] of the assertion that $c$ and $b$ are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $p$ be a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime number]]. Let $a \in \Z$ be such that $p$ is not a [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisor]] of $a$.
rationale: {{AimForCont}} $p$ and $a$ are not [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. Then: :$\exists c \in \Z_{>1}: c \divides p, c \divides a$ where $\divides$ denotes [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisibility]]. But then by definition of [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]]: :$c = p$ Thus: :$p \divides a$ The result follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement:
Let $a, b \in \Z$ be [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. Then: :$a 
mid b \iff a^2 
mid b^2$ where $a 
mid b$ denotes that $a$ is not a [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisor]] of $b$. {{:Euclid:Proposition/VIII/16}}
rationale:
Let $a 
mid b$. {{AimForCont}}: :$a^2 \divides b^2$ where $\divides$ denotes [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisibility]]. Then by [[Number divides Number iff Square divides Square]]: :$a \divides b$ From [[Proof by Contradiction]] it follows that $a^2 \divides b^2$ is [[Definition:False|false]]. Thus $a^2 
mid b^2$. {{qed|lemma}} Let $a^2 
mid b^2$. {{AimForCont}}: :$a \divides b$ Then by [[Number divides Number iff Square divides Square]]: :$a^2 \divides b^2$ From [[Proof by Contradiction]] it follows that $a \divides b$ is [[Definition:False|false]]. Thus $a 
mid b$. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|16|VIII}}

statement: Let $G_n = \sequence {a_j}_{0 \mathop \le j \mathop \le n}$ be a [[Definition:Geometric Sequence of Integers|geometric sequence of integers]] such that $a_0 \ne 1$. Let $a_0 \perp a_n$, where \perp denotes [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprimality]]. Then there does not exist an [[Definition:Integer|integer]] $b$ such that: :$\dfrac {a_0} {a_1} = \dfrac {a_n} b$ {{:Euclid:Proposition/IX/17}}
rationale: {{AimForCont}} there exists $b$ such that $\dfrac {a_0} {a_1} = \dfrac {a_n} b$. Then: :$\dfrac {a_0} {a_n} = \dfrac {a_1} b$ By [[Ratios of Fractions in Lowest Terms]]: :$a_0 \divides a_1$ where $\divides$ denotes [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisibility]]. From [[Divisibility of Elements in Geometric Sequence of Integers]]: :$a_0 \divides a_n$ But $a_0 \perp a_n$. From this [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that there can be no such $b$. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|17|IX}}

statement: Let $AB$ and $CD$ be two [[Definition:Commensurable|commensurable]] [[Definition:Strictly Positive Real Number|magnitudes]] such that $AB < CD$. $AB$ either [[Definition:Divisor of Real Number|measures]] $CD$ or it does not.

Let $A$ and $B$ be [[Definition:Incommensurable|incommensurable]] [[Definition:Strictly Positive Real Number|magnitudes]]. Suppose $A$ and $B$ have the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] which a [[Definition:Natural Number|number]] has to a [[Definition:Natural Number|number]]
rationale: Then by {{EuclidPropLink|book=X|prop=6|title=Magnitudes with Rational Ratio are Commensurable}}, $A$ and $B$ are [[Definition:Commensurable|commensurable]]. From this [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] follows the result. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|7|X}}

statement: The corresponding proof: Let $A$ and $B$ be [[Definition:Commensurable in Length|commensurable in length]]. Then $A$ has to $B$ the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] which a [[Definition:Natural Number|number]] has to a [[Definition:Natural Number|number]]. Let \(\dfrac A B = \dfrac C D\). From [[Similar Polygons are composed of Similar Triangles/Porism|Similar Polygons are composed of Similar Triangles: Porism]]: :\(\dfrac {A^2} {B^2} = \paren {\dfrac C D}^2 = \dfrac {C^2} {D^2}\) {{qed|lemma}} Let: :\(\dfrac {A^2} {B^2} = \dfrac {C^2} {D^2}\) Then it follows that: :\(\dfrac A B = \dfrac C D\) and from [[Magnitudes with Rational Ratio are Commensurable]] it follows that $A$ and $B$ are [[Definition:Commensurable in Length|commensurable in length]]. {{qed|lemma}} Let $A$ and $B$ be [[Definition:Incommensurable in Length|incommensurable in length]]. Suppose: :\(\dfrac {A^2} {B^2} = \dfrac {C^2} {D^2}\) where $C$ and $D$ are [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. Then $A$ and $B$ would be [[Definition:Commensurable in Length|commensurable in length]], which they are not. So the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] on $A$ and the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] on $B$ do not have to one another the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] which a [[Definition:Square Number|square number]] has to a [[Definition:Square Number|square number]]. {{qed|lemma}} Let the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] on $A$ not have to the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] on $B$ not have the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] which a [[Definition:Square Number|square number]] has to a [[Definition:Square Number|square number]]. Suppose $A$ was [[Definition:Commensurable in Length|commensurable in length]] with $B$. Then the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] on $A$ would have to the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] on $B$ the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] which a [[Definition:Square Number|square number]] has to a [[Definition:Square Number|square number]], which it does not. So $A$ is [[Definition:Incommensurable in Length|not commensurable in length]] with $B$. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|9|X}}
rationale: Let $A$ and $B$ be [[Definition:Commensurable in Length|commensurable in length]]. Then $A$ has to $B$ the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] which a [[Definition:Natural Number|number]] has to a [[Definition:Natural Number|number]]. Let \(\dfrac A B = \dfrac C D\). From [[Similar Polygons are composed of Similar Triangles/Porism|Similar Polygons are composed of Similar Triangles: Porism]]: :\(\dfrac {A^2} {B^2} = \paren {\dfrac C D}^2 = \dfrac {C^2} {D^2}\) {{qed|lemma}} Let: :\(\dfrac {A^2} {B^2} = \dfrac {C^2} {D^2}\) Then it follows that: :\(\dfrac A B = \dfrac C D\) and from [[Magnitudes with Rational Ratio are Commensurable]] it follows that $A$ and $B$ are [[Definition:Commensurable in Length|commensurable in length]]. {{qed|lemma}} Let $A$ and $B$ be [[Definition:Incommensurable in Length|incommensurable in length]]. Suppose: :\(\dfrac {A^2} {B^2} = \dfrac {C^2} {D^2}\) where $C$ and $D$ are [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. Then $A$ and $B$ would be [[Definition:Commensurable in Length|commensurable in length]], which they are not. So the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] on $A$ and the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] on $B$ do not have to one another the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] which a [[Definition:Square Number|square number]] has to a [[Definition:Square Number|square number]]. {{qed|lemma}} Let the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] on $A$ not have to the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] on $B$ not have the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] which a [[Definition:Square Number|square number]] has to a [[Definition:Square Number|square number]]. Suppose $A$ was [[Definition:Commensurable in Length|commensurable in length]] with $B$. Then the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] on $A$ would have to the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] on $B$ the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] which a [[Definition:Square Number|square number]] has to a [[Definition:Square Number|square number]], which it does not. So $A$ is [[Definition:Incommensurable in Length|not commensurable in length]] with $B$. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|9|X}}

statement: Let $A$ and $B$ be [[Definition:Strictly Positive Real Number|magnitudes]] which are [[Definition:Commensurable|commensurable]] with each other. Let $A$ be [[Definition:Incommensurable|incommensurable]] with any other [[Definition:Strictly Positive Real Number|magnitude]] $C$. Suppose $B$ is [[Definition:Commensurable|commensurable]] with $C$. But $A$ is [[Definition:Commensurable|commensurable]] with $B$. So from [[Commensurability is Transitive Relation]] it follows that $A$ is [[Definition:Commensurable|commensurable]] with $C$. From that [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that $B$ cannot be [[Definition:Commensurable|commensurable]] with $C$. Hence the result. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|13|X}}
rationale: Let $A$ and $B$ be [[Definition:Strictly Positive Real Number|magnitudes]] which are [[Definition:Commensurable|commensurable]] with each other. Let $A$ be [[Definition:Incommensurable|incommensurable]] with any other [[Definition:Strictly Positive Real Number|magnitude]] $C$. Suppose $B$ is [[Definition:Commensurable|commensurable]] with $C$. But $A$ is [[Definition:Commensurable|commensurable]] with $B$. So from [[Commensurability is Transitive Relation]] it follows that $A$ is [[Definition:Commensurable|commensurable]] with $C$. From that [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that $B$ cannot be [[Definition:Commensurable|commensurable]] with $C$. Hence the result. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|13|X}}

statement: Let $AB$ be a [[Definition:Minor (Euclidean)|minor]]. Let $BC$ be added to $AB$ such that: : $AC$ and $CB$ are [[Definition:Incommensurable in Square|incommensurable in square]] : $AC^2 + CB^2$ is [[Definition:Rational Area|rational]] : $2 \cdot AC \cdot CB$ is a [[Definition:Medial Area|medial]] [[Definition:Rectangle|rectangle]]. It is to be proved that no other [[Definition:Line Segment|straight line]] can be added to $AB$ which fulfils these conditions.
rationale: Suppose $BD$, different from $BC$, can be added to $AB$ such that: :$AD$ and $DB$ are [[Definition:Incommensurable in Square|incommensurable in square]] :$AD^2 + DB^2$ is [[Definition:Rational Area|rational]] :$2 \cdot AD \cdot DB$ is a [[Definition:Medial Area|medial]] [[Definition:Rectangle|rectangle]]. From {{EuclidPropLink|book = II|prop = 7|title = Square of Difference}}: :$AD^2 + DB^2 - 2 \cdot AD \cdot DB = AC^2 + CB^2 - 2 \cdot AC \cdot CB = AB^2$ Therefore: :$AD^2 + DB^2 - AC^2 + CB^2 = 2 \cdot AD \cdot DB - 2 \cdot AC \cdot CB$ But :$AD^2 + DB^2$ and $AC^2 + CB^2$ are both [[Definition:Rational Area|rational]]. Therefore $AD^2 + DB^2 - AC^2 + CB^2$ is [[Definition:Rational Area|rational]]. Therefore $2 \cdot AD \cdot DB - 2 \cdot AC \cdot CB$ is [[Definition:Rational Area|rational]]. But by definition of [[Definition:Medial Area|medial area]], this is impossible. The result follows. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|82|X}}

statement: Let $AB$ be a [[Definition:Straight Line|straight line]] which is [[Definition:Line Perpendicular to Plane|perpendicular]] to each of the [[Definition:Plane|planes]] $CD$ and $EF$. It is to be demonstrated that $CD$ and $EF$ are [[Definition:Parallel Planes|parallel]].
rationale: Suppose, to the contrary, that $CD$ and $EF$ are not [[Definition:Parallel Planes|parallel]]. Then when produced they will meet. From {{EuclidPropLink|book = XI|prop = 3|title = Common Section of Two Planes is Straight Line}}: :let the [[Definition:Common Section|common section]] be the [[Definition:Straight Line|straight line]] $GH$. Let $K$ be an arbitrary [[Definition:Point|point]] on $GH$. Let $AK$ and $BK$ be joined. We have that $AB$ is [[Definition:Line Perpendicular to Plane|perpendicular]] to $EF$. So from {{EuclidDefLink|XI|3|Line at Right Angles to Plane}}: :$AB$ is [[Definition:Perpendicular|perpendicular]] to the [[Definition:Straight Line|straight line]] $BK$ in the [[Definition:Plane|planes]] $EF$ produced. Therefore $\angle ABK$ is a [[Definition:Right Angle|right angle]]. For the same reason $\angle BAK$ is a [[Definition:Right Angle|right angle]]. Thus, in $\triangle ABK$, there are two [[Definition:Angle|angles]] which are [[Definition:Right Angle|right angles]]. From {{EuclidPropLink|book = I|prop = 17|title = Two Angles of Triangle Less than Two Right Angles}} this is impossible. Therefore $CD$ and $EF$ do not meet when produced. So from {{EuclidDefLink|XI|8|Parallel Planes}}: :$CD$ and $EF$ are [[Definition:Parallel Planes|parallel]]. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|14|XI}}

statement: The corresponding proof::[[File:Euclid-XI-16.png|500px]] Let $AB$ and $CD$ be two [[Definition:Plane|planes]] which are [[Definition:Parallel Planes|parallel]]. Let $AB$ and $CD$ be cut by the [[Definition:Plane|plane]] $EFGH$. Let: :$EF$ be the [[Definition:Common Section|common section]] of $EFGH$ and $AB$ and: :$GH$ be the [[Definition:Common Section|common section]] of $EFGH$ and $CD$. It is to be shown that $EF$ is [[Definition:Parallel Lines|parallel]] to $GH$.
rationale: Suppose that $EF$ and $GH$ are not [[Definition:Parallel Lines|parallel]]. Then when produced, they will meet, either in the direction of $F$ and $H$, or in the direction of $E$ and $G$. [[Definition:WLOG|WLOG]] suppose they meet at $K$ when produced in the direction of $F$ and $H$. We have that $EFK$ is in the [[Definition:Plane|plane]] $AB$. Therefore from {{EuclidPropLink|book = XI|prop = 1|title = Straight Line cannot be in Two Planes}}: :all the [[Definition:Point|points]] of $EFK$ are in the [[Definition:Plane|plane]] $AB$. But $K$ is one of the [[Definition:Point|points]] of $EFK$. Therefore $K$ is in the [[Definition:Plane|plane]] $AB$. For the same reason, $K$ is also in the [[Definition:Plane|plane]] $CD$. Therefore the [[Definition:Plane|planes]] $AB$ and $CD$ will meet when produced. But they do not meet, because they are [[Definition:Parallel Planes|parallel]]. Therefore $EF$ and $GH$ will not meet when produced in the direction of $F$ and $H$. By the same argument, $EF$ and $GH$ will not meet when produced in the direction of $E$ and $G$. But from {{EuclidDefLink|I|23|Parallel Lines}}: :$EF$ is [[Definition:Parallel Lines|parallel]] to $GH$. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|16|XI}}

statement:
The corresponding proof:From [[Form of Geometric Sequence of Integers]], the [[Definition:Term of Geometric Sequence|terms]] of $P$ are in the form: :$\paren 1: \quad: a_j = k q^j p^{n - j}$ where $p \perp q$. Let $a_0 
mid a_1$. That is: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = a_0       | o =

mid       | r = k p q^{n - 1}       | c = from $\paren 1$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = \paren {k q^{n - 1} } q       | o = 
mid       | r = \paren {k q^{n - 1} } p       | c = rearranging }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = q       | o = 
mid       | r = p       | c = [[Definition:Contrapositive Statement|Contrapositive]] of [[Multiple of Divisor Divides Multiple]] }} {{end-eqn}} Aiming for a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose that: : $\exists i, j \in \set {0, 1, \ldots, n}, i 
e j: a_i \divides a_j$ {{WLOG}} let $i < j$. {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = a_i       | o = \divides       | r = a_j       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = k q^i p^{n - i}       | o = \divides       | r = k q^j p^{n - j}       | c = from $\paren 1$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = m \paren {k q^j p^{n - i} } q^{j - i}       | r = \paren {k q^j p^{n - i} } p^{j - i}       | c = for some $m \in \Z$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = m q^{j - i}       | r = p^{j - i}       | c = [[Definition:Contrapositive Statement|Contrapositive]] of [[Multiple of Divisor Divides Multiple]] }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = q^{j - i}       | o = \divides       | r = p^{j - i}       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} But we have that $p \perp q$. From [[Powers of Coprime Numbers are Coprime]]: :$q^{j - i} \perp p^{j - i}$ This can happen only when $q = 1$. This is incompatible with $q 
mid p$. From this contradiction, the result follows. {{qed}}
rationale:
From [[Form of Geometric Sequence of Integers]], the [[Definition:Term of Geometric Sequence|terms]] of $P$ are in the form: :$\paren 1: \quad: a_j = k q^j p^{n - j}$ where $p \perp q$. Let $a_0 
mid a_1$. That is: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = a_0       | o = 
mid       | r = a_1       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = k q^n       | o = 
mid       | r = k p q^{n - 1}       | c = from $\paren 1$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = \paren {k q^{n - 1} } q       | o = 
mid       | r = \paren {k q^{n - 1} } p       | c = rearranging }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = q       | o = 
mid       | r = p       | c = [[Definition:Contrapositive Statement|Contrapositive]] of [[Multiple of Divisor Divides Multiple]] }} {{end-eqn}} Aiming for a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose that: : $\exists i, j \in \set {0, 1, \ldots, n}, i 
e j: a_i \divides a_j$ {{WLOG}} let $i < j$. {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = a_i       | o = \divides       | r = a_j       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = k q^i p^{n - i}       | o = \divides       | r = k q^j p^{n - j}       | c = from $\paren 1$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = m \paren {k q^j p^{n - i} } q^{j - i}       | r = \paren {k q^j p^{n - i} } p^{j - i}       | c = for some $m \in \Z$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = m q^{j - i}       | r = p^{j - i}       | c = [[Definition:Contrapositive Statement|Contrapositive]] of [[Multiple of Divisor Divides Multiple]] }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = q^{j - i}       | o = \divides       | r = p^{j - i}       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} But we have that $p \perp q$. From [[Powers of Coprime Numbers are Coprime]]: :$q^{j - i} \perp p^{j - i}$ This can happen only when $q = 1$. This is incompatible with $q 
mid p$. From this contradiction, the result follows. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\R_{> 0}\) be the [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Strictly Positive Real Number|strictly positive real numbers]]. For all \(x \in \R_{> 0}\), let \(A_x\) be the [[Definition:Open Real Interval|open real interval]] \(\openint 0 x\). Then: :\(\displaystyle \bigcap_{x \mathop \in \R_{> 0} } A_x = \O\)
rationale:
Let \(\displaystyle A =  igcap_{x \mathop \in \R_{> 0} } A_x\). {{AimForCont}} \(A 
e \O\). Then: :\(\exists y \in \R_{> 0}: y \in A\) By definition of [[Definition:Open Real Interval|open interval]]: :\(y 
otin \openint 0 y = A_y\) and so by definition of [[Definition:Intersection of Family|intersection of family]]: :\(y
