Consider \(\struct {\N, -}\), the [[Definition:Natural Numbers|natural numbers]] under [[Definition:Natural Number Subtraction|subtraction]]. We have that [[Natural Number Subtraction is not Closed]]. For example: : \(1 - 2 = -1 \notin \N\) Thus \(\struct {\N, -}\) is not [[Definition:Closed Algebraic Structure|closed]]. So \(\struct {\N, -}\) is not a [[Definition:Submagma|submagma]] of \(\struct {\Z, -}\) Hence it is not true to write \(\struct {\N, -} \subseteq \struct {\Z, -}\), despite the fact that \(\N \subseteq \Z\). Thus \(\struct {\N, -}\) is not a [[Definition:Submagma|submagma]] of \(\struct {\Z, -}\). {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\Z\) be the [[Definition:Integer|set of integers]]. Let \(\RR\) be the [[Definition:Relation|relation]] on \(\Z\) defined as: :\(\forall x, y \in \Z: \tuple {x, y} \in \RR \iff \size x = \size y\) where \(\size x\) denotes the [[Definition:Absolute Value|absolute value]] of \(x\). Then \(\RR\) is not a [[Definition:Congruence Relation|congruence relation]] for [[Definition:Integer Addition|integer addition]].
rationale: From [[Absolute Value Function on Integers induces Equivalence Relation]], \(\RR\) is an [[Definition:Equivalence Relation|equivalence relation]]. However, consider that: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \size {-1} = \size 1       | o = \leadsto       | r = -1 \mathop \RR 1       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = \size 2 = \size 2       | o = \leadsto       | r = 2 \mathop \RR 2       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} By conventional [[Definition:Integer Addition|integer addition]]: :$-1 + 2 = 1$ while: :$1 + 2 = 3$ But it does not hold that: :$\size 1 = \size 3$ Therefore \(\RR\) is not a [[Definition:Congruence Relation|congruence relation]] for [[Definition:Integer Addition|integer addition]]. Hence the result, by [[Proof by Counterexample]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $\left({\R, \leqslant}\right)$ be the [[Definition:Ordered Structure|ordered structure]] consisting of the [[Definition:Real Number|real numbers]] under the [[Definition:Conventional Ordering|conventional ordering]]. Then $\left({\R, \leqslant}\right)$ is not a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]].
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]] Consider the [[Definition:Set|set]]: : $A := \left\{ {x \in \R: x > 1}\right\}$ Suppose $a$ were the [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]] of $A$. Then $a > 1$. But then: :$1 < \dfrac {a + 1} 2 < a$ and so $a$ has been shown not to be the [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]] of $A$ after all. Hence $A$ has no [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]]. Thus there exists a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $\R$ which has no [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]]. Thus $\R$ is not a [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered]] under $\leqslant$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countable]] [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Then $T$ is [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff]] {{iff}} all [[Definition:Convergent Sequence|convergent sequences]] on $T$ have a [[Definition:Unique|unique]] [[Definition:Limit Point of Sequence|limit point]].
rationale:
=== Sufficient Condition === This is shown in [[Convergent Sequence in Hausdorff Space has Unique Limit]]. Note that it does not require [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countability]]. {{qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === We prove the [[Definition:Contrapositive Statement|contrapositive]]. Suppose $T$ is not [[Definition:Hausdorff Space|Hausdorff]]. Then by definition: :$\exists x, y \in S, x 
e y:  orall U, V \in 	au: x \in U, y \in V: U \cap V 
e \O$ By [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countability]], $x$ and $y$ has [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Local Basis|local basis]]. Let $\set {X_n: n \in \N}$ and $\set {Y_n: n \in \N}$ be [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] [[Definition:Local Basis|local bases]] for $x$ and $y$ respectively. Let $U_n = \displaystyle  igcap_{k \mathop = 1}^n X_n$ and $V_n = \displaystyle  igcap_{k \mathop = 1}^n Y_n$. We have for all $n \in \N$: :$x \in U_n, y \in V_n$ :$U_m \subseteq U_n, V_m \subseteq V_n$ for all $m \ge n$ We have that: :$ orall n \in \N: U_n \cap V_n 
e \O$ hence we can pick any $z_n \in U_n \cap V_n$. We show that $\sequence {z_n}$ [[Definition:Convergent Sequence|converges]] to both $x$ and $y$. Let $A$ be an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] such that $x \in A$. By definition of a [[Definition:Local Basis|local basis]]: :$\exists N \in \N: X_N \subseteq A$ We also have: :$ orall n \ge N: U_n \subseteq U_N \subseteq X_N \subseteq A$ Therefore for any $n \ge N$: :$z_n \in U_n \cap V_n \subseteq U_n \subseteq A$ By definition of [[Definition:Convergent Sequence|convergence]], $\sequence {z_n}$ [[Definition:Convergent Sequence|converges]] to $x$. Similarly $\sequence {z_n}$ [[Definition:Convergent Sequence|converges]] to $y$. Hence $\sequence {z_n}$ does not have [[Definition:Unique|unique]] [[Definition:Limit Point of Sequence|limit point]]. {{qed}} [[Category:First-Countable Spaces]] [[Category:Hausdorff Spaces]] hjqs2yokgfjt4z0o78tp2r10yrx7q1e

statement: $\forall x \in \R: x > 0 \implies \dfrac 1 x > 0$
rationale: Let $x > 0$. {{AimForCont}} $\dfrac 1 x < 0$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = x       | o = >       | r = 0       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = x \times \dfrac 1 x       | o = <       | r = 0 \times 0       | c = [[Real Number Ordering is Compatible with Multiplication/Negative Factor|Real Number Ordering is Compatible with Multiplication: Negative Factor]] }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = 1       | o = <       | r = 0       | c = [[Definition:Real Number Axioms|Real Number Axioms: $\R \text M 4$: Inverse]] }} {{end-eqn}} But from [[Real Zero is Less than Real One]]: :$1 > 0$ Therefore by [[Proof by Contradiction]]: :$\dfrac 1 x > 0$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $S \subseteq \N_{>0}$. Then, despite [[Non-Empty Subset of Initial Segment of Natural Numbers has Greatest Element]], it is not necessarily the case that $S$ has a [[Definition:Greatest Element|greatest element]].
rationale: Let: :$S = \set {x \in \N_{>0}: x > 1}$ Then $S \subseteq \N_{>0}$. {{AimForCont}} $S$ has a [[Definition:Greatest Element|greatest element]]. Let the [[Definition:Greatest Element|greatest element]] of $S$ be $k$. But $\N_{>0}$ is an [[Definition:Inductive Set as Subset of Real Numbers|inductive set]]. Therefore $k + 1 \in \N_{>0}$. By definition of $S$: :$k + 1 \in S$ Therefore $k$ cannot be the [[Definition:Greatest Element|greatest element]] of $S$. By [[Proof by Contradiction]] it follows that $S$ has no [[Definition:Greatest Element|greatest element]]. It is not possible to apply [[Non-Empty Subset of Initial Segment of Natural Numbers has Greatest Element]], because $S$ is not a subset of an [[Definition:Initial Segment of Natural Numbers|initial segment]] of $\N_{>0}$. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\left({S, \circ}\right)\) be an [[Definition:Algebraic Structure|algebraic structure]]. If \(\left({S, \circ}\right)\) has more than one [[Definition:Right Identity|right identity]], then it has no [[Definition:Left Identity|left identity]].
rationale: Let \(\left({S, \circ}\right)\) be an [[Definition:Algebraic Structure|algebraic structure]] with more than one [[Definition:Right Identity|right identity]]. Take any two of these, and call them \(e_{R_1}\) and \(e_{R_2}\), where \(e_{R_1} \ne e_{R_2}\). Suppose \(\left({S, \circ}\right)\) has a [[Definition:Left Identity|left identity]]. Call this [[Definition:Left Identity|left identity]] \(e_L\). Then, by the behaviour of \(e_L\), \(e_{R_1}\) and \(e_{R_2}\): : \(e_{R_1} = e_{R_1} \circ e_L = e_L\) : \(e_{R_2} = e_{R_2} \circ e_L = e_L\) So \(e_{R_1} = e_L = e_{R_2}\), which contradicts the supposition that \(e_{R_1}\) and \(e_{R_2}\) are different. Therefore, in an algebraic structure with more than one [[Definition:Right Identity|right identity]], there can be no [[Definition:Left Identity|left identity]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $X$ be an [[Definition:F-Sigma Set|$F_\\sigma$ set]] of $T$. Then it is not necessarily the case that $X$ is a [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed set]] of $T$.
rationale: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Uncountable Finite Complement Topology|finite complement topology]] on an [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable set]] $S$. Let $X \\subseteq S$ be an [[Definition:F-Sigma Set|$F_\\sigma$ set]] of $T$. From [[F-Sigma and G-Delta Subsets of Uncountable Finite Complement Space|$F_\\sigma$ and $G_\\delta$ Subsets of Uncountable Finite Complement Space]]: :$X$ is neither [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] nor [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] in $T$. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $X$ be a [[Definition:G-Delta Set|$G_\delta$ set]] of $T$. Then it is not necessarily the case that $X$ is a [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] of $T$.
rationale: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Uncountable Finite Complement Topology|finite complement topology]] on an [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable set]] $S$. Let $X \subseteq S$ be a [[Definition:G-Delta Set|$G_\delta$ set]] of $T$. From [[F-Sigma and G-Delta Subsets of Uncountable Finite Complement Space|$F_\sigma$ and $G_\delta$ Subsets of Uncountable Finite Complement Space]]: :$X$ is neither [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] nor [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] in $T$. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $A \subseteq S$. Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] in $A$. Let $\alpha$ be a [[Definition:Limit Point of Sequence|limit point of $\sequence {x_n}$]]. Then $\alpha$ may be only an [[Definition:Adherent Point|adherent point]] of $A$ and not a [[Definition:Limit Point of Set|limit point]] of $A$.
rationale: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the [[Definition:Discrete Space|discrete space]] on $S$. Let $x \in S$. Then by definition of [[Definition:Discrete Space|discrete space]]: :$U = \set x$ is an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] of $T$. Consider the [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] $\sequence {x_n}$ defined as: :$\forall n \in \N: x_n = x$ That is: :$\sequence {x_n} = \tuple {x, x, x, \ldots}$ From [[Limit Point of Sequence in Discrete Space not always Limit Point of Open Set]]: :$x$ is not a [[Definition:Limit Point of Set|limit point]] of $U$. But from [[Limit Point of Sequence is Adherent Point of Range]]: :$x$ is an [[Definition:Adherent Point|adherent point]] of $\set x$. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $S \subseteq \Z$ be a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of the [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. Let $n_0 \in \Z$ be given. Suppose that: :$(1): \quad n_0 \in S$ :$(2): \quad \forall n \ge n_0: n \in S \implies n + 1 \in S$ Then: :$\forall n \ge n_0: n \in S$ That is: :$S = \set {n \in \Z: n \ge n_0}$
rationale:
Let \Z_{\ge n_0} := \set {n \in \Z: n \ge n_0}. {{AimForCont}} $S 
e \Z_{\ge n_0}$. Let $S' = \Z_{\ge n_0} \setminus S$. Because $S 
e \Z_{\ge n_0}$ and $S \subseteq \Z_{\ge n_0}$, we have that $S' 
e \O$. By definition, \Z_{\ge n_0} is [[Definition:Bounded Below Set|bounded below]] by $n_0$. From [[Set of Integers Bounded Below by Integer has Smallest Element]], $S'$ has a [[Definition:Minimal Element|minimal element]]. Let $k$ be this [[Definition:Minimal Element|minimal element]] of $S'$. By $(1)$ we have that: :$n_0 \in S$ and so: :$n_0 
otin S'$ Hence: :$k 
e n_0$ and so: :$k > n_0$ It follows that: :$k - 1 \le n_0$ Because $k$ is the [[Definition:Minimal Element|minimal element]] of $S'$: :$k - 1 
otin S'$ and so: :$k - 1 \in S$ But by $(2)$: :$\paren {k - 1} + 1 = k \in S$ So we have: :$k \in S$ and: :$k 
otin S$ Hence by [[Proof by Contradiction]] $S = \Z_{\ge n_0}$. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {S, \circ, \preceq}\) be a [[Definition:Naturally Ordered Semigroup|naturally ordered semigroup]]. Let \(T \subseteq S\) such that \(0 \in T\) and \(n \in T \implies n \circ 1 \in T\). Then \(T = S\).
rationale:
{{AimForCont}} that \(T \subsetneq S\). That is, \(T\) is a [[Definition:Proper Subset|proper subset]] of \(S\): : \(T 
e S\) Let \(T' = S \setminus T\). Then by [[Set Difference with Proper Subset]]: :\(T' 
e \O\) By [[Definition:Naturally Ordered Semigroup Axioms|axiom NO1]], \(S\) is [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered]]. By definition of [[Definition:Well-Ordered Set|well-ordered set]], it follows that \(T'\) has a [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]] \(x\). By definition of \(T\): :\(0 \in T\) and so by  definition of \(T'\): :\(0 
otin T'\) so: :\(0 \prec x\) By [[Sum with One is Immediate Successor in Naturally Ordered Semigroup]]: :\(1 \preceq x\) By the definition of a [[Definition:Naturally Ordered Semigroup|naturally ordered semigroup]]: :\(\exists y \in S: y \circ 1 = x\) Again by [[Sum with One is Immediate Successor in Naturally Ordered Semigroup]]: :\(y \prec x\) We have that \(x\) is the [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]] of \(T'\) and \(y \prec x\). Therefore: :\(y 
otin T'\) and so :\(y \in T\) But from the definition of \(T\): :\(y \in T \implies y \circ 1 = x \in T\) But then by the definition of \(T'\): :\(x \in T' \implies x 
otin T\) From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], it follows that: :\(T = S\) {{qed}}

statement: $\forall x \in \R: x < 0 \implies \dfrac 1 x < 0$
rationale: Let $x < 0$. {{AimForCont}} $\dfrac 1 x > 0$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = x | o = < | r = 0 | c = }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = x \times \dfrac 1 x | o = < | r = 0 \times 0 | c = [[Real Number Ordering is Compatible with Multiplication/Negative Factor|Real Number Ordering is Compatible with Multiplication: Negative Factor]] }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = 1 | o = < | r = 0 | c = [[Definition:Real Number Axioms|Real Number Axioms: $\R \text M 4$: Inverse]] }} {{end-eqn}} But from [[Real Zero is Less than Real One]]: :$1 > 0$ Therefore by [[Proof by Contradiction]]: :$\dfrac 1 x < 0$ {{qed}}

statement: The [[Definition:Positive Square Root|positive square root function]] is [[Definition:Strictly Increasing Real Function|strictly increasing]], that is: :$ \forall x,y \in \R_{>0}: x < y \implies \sqrt x < \sqrt y$
rationale: Let $x$ and $y$ be [[Definition:Positive/Real Number|positive real numbers]] such that $x < y$. {{AimForCont}} $\sqrt x \ge \sqrt y$. {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | n = 1       | l = \sqrt x       | o = \ge       | r = \sqrt y       | c =  }} {{eqn | n = 2       | l = \sqrt x       | o = \ge       | r = \sqrt y       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = x       | o = \ge       | r = y       | c = [[Definition:Real Number Axioms|Real Number Axioms: $\R O2$]]: [[Definition:Relation Compatible with Operation|compatibility]] with [[Definition:Real Multiplication|multiplication]], $(1) \times (2)$ }} {{end-eqn}} Thus a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] is created. Therefore: :$\forall x, y \in \R_{>0}: x < y \implies \sqrt x < \sqrt y$ {{qed}} [[Category:Real Numbers]] [[Category:Square Roots]] fdvd6p7g0m570jrvlsjkqp533pis13w

statement: Let $\N_{> 0}$ be the [[Axiom:Axiomatization of 1-Based Natural Numbers|$1$-based natural numbers]]. Let $+$ be [[Definition:Addition on 1-Based Natural Numbers|addition]] on $\N_{>0}$. Then: :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a + c = b + c \implies a = b$ :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a + b = a + c \implies b = c$ That is, $+$ is [[Definition:Cancellable Operation|cancellable]] on $\N_{>0}$.
rationale: By [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]], one and only one of the following holds: :$a = b$ :$a < b$ :$b < a$ Suppose $a < b$. Then by [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Addition|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Addition]]: :$a + c < b + c$ By [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]], this contradicts the fact that $a + c = b + c$. Similarly, suppose $b > a$. Then by [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Addition|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Addition]]: :$b + c < a + c$ By [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]], this also contradicts the fact that $a + c = b + c$. The only other possibility is that $a = b$. So  :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a + c = b + c \implies a = b$ and so $+$ is [[Definition:Right Cancellable Operation|right cancellable]] on $\N_{>0}$. From [[Natural Number Addition is Commutative]] and [[Right Cancellable Commutative Operation is Left Cancellable]]: :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a + b = a + c \implies b = c$ So $+$ is both [[Definition:Right Cancellable Operation|right cancellable]] and [[Definition:Left Cancellable Operation|left cancellable]] on $\N_{>0}$. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $\N_{> 0}$ be the [[Definition:1-Based Natural Numbers|$1$-based natural numbers]]. Let $<$ be the [[Definition:Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers|strict ordering on $\N_{>0}$]]. Let $+$ be [[Definition:Addition on 1-Based Natural Numbers|addition]] on $\N_{>0}$. Then: :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a + c < b + c \implies a < b$ :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a + b < a + c \implies b < c$ That is, $+$ is [[Definition:Cancellable Operation|cancellable]] on $\N_{>0}$ for $<$.
rationale: By [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]], one and only one of the following holds: :$a = b$ :$a < b$ :$b < a$ Let $a + c < b + c$. Suppose $a = b$. Then by [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Addition|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Addition]]: :$a + c = b + c$ By [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]], this contradicts the fact that $a + c < b + c$. Similarly, suppose $b < a$. Then by [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Addition|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Addition]]: :$b + c < a + c$ By [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]], this also contradicts the fact that $a + c < b + c$. The only other possibility is that $a < b$. So  :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a + c = b + c \implies a < b$ and so $+$ is [[Definition:Right Cancellable Operation|right cancellable]] on $\N_{>0}$ for $<$. Let $a + b < a + c$. Suppose $b = c$. Then by [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Addition|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Addition]]: :$a + b = a + c$ By [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]], this contradicts the fact that $a + b < a + c$. Similarly, suppose $c < b$. Then by [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Addition|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Addition]]: :$a + c < a + b$ By [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]], this also contradicts the fact that $a + b < a + c$. The only other possibility is that $b < c$. So  :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a + b < a + c \implies b < c$ and so $+$ is [[Definition:Left Cancellable Operation|left cancellable]] on $\N_{>0}$ for $<$. From [[Natural Number Addition is Commutative]] and [[Right Cancellable Commutative Operation is Left Cancellable]]: :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a + b = a + c \implies b = c$ So $+$ is both [[Definition:Right Cancellable Operation|right cancellable]] and [[Definition:Left Cancellable Operation|left cancellable]] on $\N_{>0}$. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $\N_{> 0}$ be the [[Definition:1-Based Natural Numbers|$1$-based natural numbers]]. Let $\times$ be [[Definition:Multiplication on 1-Based Natural Numbers|multiplication]] on $\N_{>0}$. Let $<$ be the [[Definition:Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers|strict ordering on $\N_{>0}$]]. Then: :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a \times c < b \times c \implies a < b$ :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a \times b < a \times c \implies b < c$ That is, $\times$ is [[Definition:Cancellable Operation|cancellable]] on $\N_{>0}$ for $<$.
rationale: By [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]], one and only one of the following holds: :$a = b$ :$a < b$ :$b < a$ Let $a \times c < b \times c$. Suppose $a = b$. Then by [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Multiplication|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Multiplication]]: :$a \times c = b \times c$ By [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]], this contradicts the fact that $a \times c < b \times c$. Similarly, suppose $b < a$. Then by [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Multiplication|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Multiplication]]: :$b \times c < a \times c$ By [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]], this also contradicts the fact that $a \times c < b \times c$. The only other possibility is that $a < b$. So  :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a \times c = b \times c \implies a < b$ and so $\times$ is [[Definition:Right Cancellable Operation|right cancellable]] on $\N_{>0}$ for $<$. Let $a \times b < a \times c$. Suppose $b = c$. Then by [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Multiplication|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Multiplication]]: :$a \times b = a \times c$ By [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]], this contradicts the fact that $a \times b < a \times c$. Similarly, suppose $c < b$. Then by [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Multiplication|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Compatible with Multiplication]]: :$a \times c < a \times b$ By [[Ordering on 1-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy|Ordering on $1$-Based Natural Numbers is Trichotomy]], this also contradicts the fact that $a \times b < a \times c$. The only other possibility is that $b < c$. So  :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a \times b < a \times c \implies b < c$ and so $\times$ is [[Definition:Left Cancellable Operation|left cancellable]] on $\N_{>0}$ for $<$. From [[Natural Number Multiplication is Commutative]] and [[Right Cancellable Commutative Operation is Left Cancellable]]: :$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a \times b = a \times c \implies b = c$ So $+$ is both [[Definition:Right Cancellable Operation|right cancellable]] and [[Definition:Left Cancellable Operation|left cancellable]] on $\N_{>0}$. Hence the result. {{qed}}

The corresponding proof uses proof by contradiction, which involves assuming the negation of what you want to prove and showing that this leads to a contradiction. This method is evident in the steps where we assume $\map f {x_1} = \map f {x_2}$ while $x_1 \ne x_2$, and this assumption contradicts the given properties of an injection, leading to the conclusion that the initial assumption must be false.

statement: There exists no [[Definition:Set|set]] which is an absolutely [[Definition:Universe (Set Theory)|universal set]]. That is: :$\neg \left({\exists \mathcal U: \forall T: T \in \mathcal U}\right)$ where $T$ is any arbitrary [[Definition:Object|object]] at all. That is, a [[Definition:Set|set]] that contains ''everything'' cannot exist.
rationale: Suppose such a $\mathcal U$ exists. Using the [[Axiom:Axiom of Specification|Axiom of Specification]], we can create the [[Definition:Set|set]]: :$R = \left\{{x \in \mathcal U: x \notin x}\right\}$ But from [[Russell's Paradox]], this set cannot exist. Thus: :$R \notin \mathcal U$ and so $\mathcal U$ cannot contain everything. {{qed}}

statement: Let $S$ and $T$ be [[Definition:Set|sets]]. Let $\mathcal R \subseteq S \times T$ be a [[Definition:Relation|relation]]. Let \mathrel R^\to be the [[Definition:Direct Image Mapping of Relation|direct image mapping]] of $\mathcal R$. Let \mathrel R^\gets be the [[Definition:Inverse Image Mapping of Relation|inverse image mapping]] of $\mathcal R$. Then it is not necessarily the case that: :$\paren {\mathrel R^\to}^{-1} = \mathcal R^\gets$ where $\paren {\mathrel R^\to}^{-1}$ denote the [[Definition:Inverse of Mapping|inverse]] of $\mathrel R^\to$. That is, the [[Definition:Inverse Relation|inverse]] of the [[Definition:Direct Image Mapping of Relation|direct image mapping]] of $\mathcal R$ does not always equal the [[Definition:Inverse Image Mapping of Relation|inverse image mapping]] of $\mathcal R$.
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let $S = T = \set {0, 1}$. Let $\mathcal R = \set {\tuple {0, 0}, \tuple {0, 1} }$. We have that: :$\mathcal R^{-1} = \set {\tuple {0, 0}, \tuple {1, 0} }$ :$\powerset S = \powerset T = \set {\O, \set 0, \set 1, \set {0, 1} }$ Thus, by inspection: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \map {\mathrel R^\to} \O       | r = \O       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = \map {\mathrel R^\to} {\set 0}       | r = \set {0, 1}       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = \map {\mathrel R^\to} {\set 1}       | r = \O       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = \map {\mathrel R^\to} {\set {0, 1} }       | r = \set {0, 1}       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} Note that $\paren {\mathrel R^\to}^{-1}$ is the [[Definition:Inverse of Mapping|inverse of a mapping]] which is neither an [[Definition:Injection|injection]] nor a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]], and so is itself not a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] from $\powerset T$ to $\powerset S$. {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \map {\paren {\mathrel R^\to}^{-1} } \O       | r = \set {\O, \set 1}       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = \map {\paren {\mathrel R^\to}^{-1} } {\set 0}       | r = \O       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = \map {\paren {\mathrel R^\to}^{-1} } {\set 1}       | r = \O       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = \map {\paren {\mathrel R^\to}^{-1} } {\set {0, 1} }       | r = \set {\set 0, \set {0, 1} }       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} This can be seen to be completely different from $\mathrel R^\gets$, which can be determined by inspection to be: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \map {\mathrel R^\gets} \O       | r = \O       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = \map {\mathrel R^\gets} {\set 0}       | r = \set 0       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = \map {\mathrel R^\gets} {\set 1}       | r = \set 0       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = \map {\mathrel R^\gets} {\set {0, 1} }       | r = \set 0       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} {{qed}} [[Category:Direct Image Mappings]] [[Category:Inverse Image Mappings]] 35arzqf6eutbis2oqntixzfkvhvw995

statement: Let \(\struct {S, \preceq}\) be an [[Definition:Ordered Set|ordered set]]. Let \(T \subseteq S\) be a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of \(S\). {{TFAE|def = Minimal Element}}
rationale:
=== Definition 1 implies Definition 2 === Let \(x\) be an [[Definition:Minimal/Ordered Set/Definition 1|minimal element by definition 1]]. That is: :$(1): \quad  orall y \in T: y \preceq x \implies x = y$ {{AimForCont}}: :$\exists y \in T: y \prec x$ Then by definition: :$y \preceq x \land x 
e y$ which [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] $(1)$. Thus by [[Proof by Contradiction]]: :$
exists y \in T: y \prec x$ That is $x$ is a [[Definition:Minimal/Ordered Set/Definition 2|minimal element by definition 2]]. {{qed|lemma}} === Definition 2 implies Definition 1 === Let $x$ be a [[Definition:Minimal/Ordered Set/Definition 2|minimal element by definition 2]]. That is: :$(2): \quad 
exists y \in T: y \prec x$ {{AimForCont}}: :$\exists y \in T: y \preceq x: x 
e y$ That is: :$\exists y \in T: y \prec x$ which [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] $(2)$. Thus: :$ orall y \in T: y \preceq x \implies x = y$ Thus $x$ is a [[Definition:Minimal/Ordered Set/Definition 1|minimal element by definition 1]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $S$ be a [[Definition:Set|set]] which is [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]]. Let $\mathcal C = \mathcal P \left({S}\right) \setminus \varnothing$, that is, the [[Definition:Power Set|power set]] of $S$ without the [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]]. Then the [[Definition:Ordered Structure|ordered structure]] $\left({\mathcal C, \subseteq}\right)$ has no [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]] {{iff}} $S$ is not a [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]].
rationale: === Necessary Condition === Let $S$ not be a [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]. Then $\exists x, y \in S: x \ne y$. Let $Z \in \mathcal C$ be the [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]] of $\mathcal C$. Then: :$\forall T \in \mathcal C: Z \subseteq T$ But by [[Singleton of Power Set less Empty Set is Minimal Subset]], both $\left\\{{x}\right\\}$ and $\left\\{{y}\right\\}$ are [[Definition:Minimal Element|minimal elements]] of $\left({\mathcal C, \subseteq}\right)$. Therefore it cannot be the case that $Z \subseteq \left\\{{x}\right\\}$ and $Z \subseteq \left\\{{y}\right\\}$. Therefore $\left({\mathcal C, \subseteq}\right)$ has no [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]]. {{qed|lemma}} === Sufficient Condition === Let the [[Definition:Ordered Structure|ordered structure]] $\left({\mathcal C, \subseteq}\right)$ has no [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]]. Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose $S$ is a [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]. Let $S = \left\\{{x}\right\\}$. Then: :$\mathcal C = \left\\{{\left\\{{x}\right\\}}\right\\}$ Then: :$\forall y \in \mathcal C: y \subseteq \left\\{{x}\right\\}$ trivially. Thus $\left({\mathcal C, \subseteq}\right)$ has a [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]] which is $\left\\{{x}\right\\}$. By [[Proof by Contradiction]] it follows that $S$ is not a [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]. {{qed}}

statement: There is no [[Definition:Compass and Straightedge Construction|compass and straightedge construction]] for the [[Definition:Trisection|trisection]] of the general [[Definition:Angle|angle]].
rationale: Let $OA$ and $OB$ [[Definition:Intersection (Geometry)|intersect]] at $O$. It will be shown that there is no general method using a [[Definition:Compass and Straightedge Construction|compass and straightedge construction]] to construct $OC$ such that $\angle AOB = 3 \times \angle AOC$. It is [[Definition:Sufficient Condition|sufficient]] to demonstrate that this is impossible for one specific [[Definition:Plane Angle|angle]]. Hence we choose $\angle AOB = 60 \degrees$. Let $A$ and $B$ be [[Definition:Point|points]] on the [[Definition:Unit Circle|unit circle]] whose [[Definition:Center of Circle|center]] is at $\tuple {0, 0}$. Let $A$ lie on the [[Definition:X-Axis|$x$-axis]]. Thus: :$O$ is the point $\tuple {0, 0}$ :$A$ is the point $\tuple {1, 0}$ :$B$ is the point $\tuple {\cos 60 \degrees, \sin 60 \degrees}$ These all belong to $\Q \sqbrk {\sqrt 3}$. [[Definition:Trisection|trisection]] of $AOB$ is equivalent to constructing the [[Definition:Point|point]] $\tuple {\cos 20 \degrees, \sin 20 \degrees}$. From [[Triple Angle Formula for Cosine]]: :$\cos 3 \theta = 4 \cos^3 \theta - 3 \cos \theta$ so: :$8 \cos^3 20 \degrees - 6 \cos 20 \degrees = 2 \cos 60 \degrees = 1$ Thus $\cos 20 \degrees$ is a [[Definition:Root of Polynomial|root]] of the [[Definition:Polynomial|polynomial]]: :$8 x^3 = 6 x - 1$ which by [[Irreducible Polynomial/Examples/8 x^3 - 6 x - 1 in Rationals|Irreducible Polynomial: $8 x^3 - 6 x - 1$ in Rationals]] is [[Definition:Irreducible Polynomial|irreducible]] over $\Q$. Thus $\cos 20 \degrees$ is [[Definition:Algebraic Number|algebraic]] over $\Q$ with [[Definition:Degree of Algebraic Number|degree]] $3$. Thus by [[Algebraic Element of Degree 3 is not Element of Field Extension of Degree Power of 2]], $\cos 20 \degrees$ is not an [[Definition:Element|element]] of any [[Definition:Field Extension|extension]] of $\Q$ of [[Definition:Degree of Field Extension|degree]] $2^m$. The result follows from [[Point in Plane is Constructible iff Coordinates in Extension of Degree Power of 2]]. {{qed}}

statement: There is no [[Definition:Compass and Straightedge Construction|compass and straightedge construction]] to allow a [[Definition:Cube (Geometry)|cube]] to be constructed whose [[Definition:Volume|volume]] is double that of a given [[Definition:Cube (Geometry)|cube]].
rationale: Suppose it is possible. Then from a [[Definition:Cube (Geometry)|cube]] of [[Definition:Edge of Polyhedron|edge]] [[Definition:Length of Line|length]] $L$ we can construct a new [[Definition:Cube (Geometry)|cube]] with [[Definition:Edge of Polyhedron|edge]] [[Definition:Length of Line|length]] $\sqrt [3] 2 L$. $\sqrt [3] 2$ is [[Definition:Algebraic Number|algebraic]] of [[Definition:Degree of Algebraic Number|degree]] $3$. This contradicts [[Constructible Length with Compass and Straightedge]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $A \subseteq \R$ be a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of the [[Definition:Real Number|real numbers]]. Let $b$ be a [[Definition:Supremum of Subset of Real Numbers|supremum]] of $A$. Let $\epsilon \in \R_{>0}$. Then: :$\exists x \in A: b − x < \epsilon$
rationale: Note that $A$ is [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] as the [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]] does not admit a [[Definition:Supremum of Subset of Real Numbers|supremum]] (in $\R$). Suppose $\epsilon \in \R_{>0}$ such that: :$\forall x \in A: b − x \ge \epsilon$ Then: :$\forall x \in A: b − \epsilon \ge x$ and so $b − \epsilon$ would be an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Subset of Real Numbers|upper bound]] of $A$ which is less than $b$. But since $b$ is a [[Definition:Supremum of Subset of Real Numbers|supremum]] of $A$ there can be no such $b − \epsilon$. From that [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that: :$\exists x \in A: b − x < \epsilon$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $A$ be a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$. Let $x$ be a point of $T$. Let $A^-$ denote the [[Definition:Closure (Topology)|closure]] of $A$. Then $x \in A^-$ {{iff}}: :for every [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] $U$ of $T$: ::$x \in U \implies A \cap U \ne \varnothing$
rationale:
=== Sufficient Condition === Let $x \in A^-$. {{AimForCont}} there exists an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] $U$ of $T$ such that: :$x \in U$ and $A \cap U = \varnothing$ We have that $U$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] in $T$. So by definition of [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed set]], $\complement_S \left({U}ight)$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] in $T$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = A \cap U       | r = \varnothing       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \implies       | l = A       | o = \subseteq       | r = \complement_S \left({U}ight)       | c = [[Empty Intersection iff Subset of Complement]] }} {{eqn | ll= \implies       | l = A^-       | o = \subseteq       | r = \complement_S \left({U}ight)       | c = Definition of [[Definition:Closure (Topology)/Definition 3|Set Closure]]: $\complement_S \left({U}ight)$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] }} {{eqn | ll= \implies       | l = A^- \cap U       | r = \varnothing       | c = [[Empty Intersection iff Subset of Complement]] }} {{end-eqn}} But we have: :$x \in A^-$ and also: :$x \in U$ and thus by definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|set intersection]]: :$x \in A^- \cap U$ This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] $A^- \cap U = \varnothing$ Hence by [[Proof by Contradiction]] the assumption that there exists an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] $U$ of $T$ such that $x \in U$ and $A \cap U = \varnothing$ was false. So for every [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] $U$ of $T$: :$x \in U \implies A \cap U 
e \varnothing$ {{qed|lemma}}  === Necessary Condition === Let $x$ be such that for every [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] $U$ of $T$: :$x \in U \implies A \cap U 
e \varnothing$ {{AimForCont}} $x 
otin A^-$. Then: :$x \in \complement_S \left({A^-}ight)$ Then by assumption: :$A \cap \complement_S \left({A^-}ight) 
e \varnothing$ as $\complement_S \left({A^-}ight)$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]. By definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|complement]]: :$A \cap \complement_S \left({A}ight) = \varnothing$ So by [[Empty Intersection iff Subset of Complement]]: :$A 
ot \subseteq A^-$ From [[Set is Subset of its Topological Closure]]: :$A \subseteq A^-$ But from [[Set Complement inverts Subsets]]: :$\complement_S \left({A^-}ight) \subseteq \complement_S \left({A}ight)$ from which by [[Empty Intersection iff Subset of Complement]]: :$A \cap \complement_S \left({A^-}ight) = \varnothing$ Hence by [[Proof by Contradiction]] the assumption that $x 
otin A^-$ was false. So $x \in A^-$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a [[Definition:T1 Space|$T_1$ topological space]]. Let $A$ be a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$. Then :$A'' \subseteq A'$ where :$A'$ denotes the [[Definition:Set Derivative|derivative]] of $A$
rationale:
Let: : $(1): \quad x \in A''$. Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose that $x 
otin A'$. Then by [[Characterization of Derivative by Open Sets]] there exists an open subset $G$ of $T$ such that: : $(2): \quad x \in G$ and : $(3): \quad \lnot \exists y: y \in A \cap G \land x 
e y$. By definition of [[Definition:Fréchet Space (Topology)/Definition 2|$T_1$ space]]: :$\left\{{x}ight\}$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. Then by [[Open Set minus Closed Set is Open]]: :$(4): \quad G \setminus \{x\}$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]. By $(1)$, $(2)$, and [[Characterization of Derivative by Open Sets]] there exists a point $y$ of $T$ such that: :$(5): \quad y \in A' \cap G$ and :$(6): \quad x 
e y$. Then by definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: : $y \in A'$. Then by $(6)$ and definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|set difference]]: :$(7): \quad y \in A' \setminus \{x\}$. By definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]] and $(5)$: : $y \in G$. By $(6)$ and definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$y 
otin \left\{{x}ight\}$ Then by definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|set difference]]: :$(8): \quad y \in G \setminus \{x\}$ We will prove: :$(9): \quad G \cap \left({A \setminus \{x\}}ight) = \varnothing$ :Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that: :: $G \cap \left({A \setminus \left\{{x}ight\}}ight) 
e \varnothing$. :Then by definition of the [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]] there exists $g$ such that: ::$g \in G \cap \left({A \setminus \left\{{x}ight\}}ight)$ :Hence by definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: :: $g \in G$ and :: $g \in A \setminus \left\{{x}ight\}$. :Then by definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|set difference]]: ::$g \in A$  :Hence by definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: :: $g \in A \cap G$ :Then by $(3)$: :: $x = g$ :Hence this by definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]] contadicts with $g 
otin \left\{{x}ight\}$ obtained by definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|set difference]]. :Thus $G \cap \left({A \setminus \left\{{x}ight\}}ight) = \varnothing$. Define $U = G \setminus \{x\}$ as an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] set by $(4)$. By $(5)$ and definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|set difference]]: :$y \in A'$ Then by $(8)$ and [[Characterization of Derivative by Open Sets]] there exists a [[Definition:Element|point]] $q$ of $T$ such that :$(10): \quad q \in A \cap U$ and :$(11): \quad y 
e q$. By $(10)$ and definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: : $q \in A$ By $(11)$ and definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$q 
otin \left\{{y}ight\}$ Then by definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|set difference]] :$(12): \quad q \in A \setminus \left\{{y}ight\}$. By definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: : $q \in U$. Then by $(12)$ and by definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|set difference]] :$q 
e x$ and $q \in A$. Then by definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|set difference]]: : $q \in A \setminus \{x\}$ and  :$q \in G$. Hence this contradicts with $(9)$ by definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]. Thus the result by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let: :$S = \set {4 n + 1: n \in \N} = \set {1, 5, 9, 13, 17, \ldots}$ be the [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Natural Number|natural numbers]] of the form $4 n + 1$. Then not all [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $S$ have a [[Definition:Complete Factorization|complete factorization]] by other [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $S$ which is [[Definition:Unique|unique]].
rationale:
[[Proof by Counterexample]]: Consider the [[Definition:Natural Number|number]]: :$m = 693 = 3^2 	imes 7 	imes 11$ Thus: :$m = 9 	imes 77 = 21 	imes 33$ We have that: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = 9       | r = 4 	imes 2 + 1       | rr= \in S }} {{eqn | l = 77       | r = 4 	imes 19 + 1       | rr= \in S }} {{eqn | l = 21       | r = 4 	imes 5 + 1       | rr= \in S }} {{eqn | l = 33       | r = 4 	imes 8 + 1       | rr= \in S }} {{end-eqn}} The [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisors]] of these numbers are as follows: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = 9       | r = 3^2       | c = where $3 
otin S$ }} {{eqn | l = 77       | r = 7 	imes 11       | c = where $7 
otin S$ and $11 
otin S$ }} {{eqn | l = 21       | r = 3 	imes 7       | c = where $3 
otin S$ and $7 
otin S$ }} {{eqn | l = 33       | r = 3 	imes 11       | c = where $3 
otin S$ and $11 
otin S$ }} {{end-eqn}} Thus $693$ has two different [[Definition:Complete Factorization|complete factorizations]] into [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $S$. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {\R, \tau}$ be the [[Definition:Sorgenfrey Line|Sorgenfrey line]]. Then $\map w T = \mathfrak c$ where :$\map w T$ denotes the [[Definition:Weight of Topological Space|weight]] of $T$ :$\mathfrak c$ denotes [[Definition:Cardinality of Continuum|continuum]], the [[Definition:Cardinality|cardinality]] of [[Definition:Real Number|real numbers]].
rationale:
By definition of [[Definition:Sorgenfrey Line|Sorgenfrey line]], the [[Definition:Set|set]]: :$\BB = \set {\hointr x y: x, y \in \R \land x < y}$ is a [[Definition:Analytic Basis|basis]] of $T$. By definition of [[Definition:Weight of Topological Space|weight]]: :$\map w T \le \card \BB$ where $\card \BB$ denotes the [[Definition:Cardinality|cardinality]] of $\mathcal B$. By [[Cardinality of Basis of Sorgenfrey Line not greater than Continuum]]: :$\card \BB \le \mathfrak c$ Thus :$\map w T \le \mathfrak c$ It remains to show that: :$\mathfrak c \le \map w T$ Aiming for a contradiction, suppose that :$\mathfrak c 
ot \le \map w T$ Then: :$\map w T < \mathfrak c$ By definition of [[Definition:Weight of Topological Space|weight]], there exists a [[Definition:Analytic Basis|basis]] $\BB_0$ of $T$: :$\map w T = \card {\BB_0}$ Then by [[Set of Subset of Reals with Cardinality less than Continuum has not Interval in Union Closure]]: :$\exists x, y \in \R: x < y \land \hointr x y 
otin \set { igcup A: A \subseteq \BB_0} = 	au$ By definition of $\BB$: :$\hointr x y \in \BB \subseteq 	au$ Thus this contradicts by definition of [[Definition:Subset|subset]] with: :$\hointr x y 
otin 	au$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $X, Y$ be [[Definition:Set|sets]]. Let :$\left\vert{X}\right\vert < \left\vert{Y}\right\vert$ where $\left\vert{X}\right\vert$ denotes the [[Definition:Cardinality|cardinality]] of $X$. Then: :$Y \setminus X \ne \varnothing$
rationale: Aiming for a contradiction suppose that : $Y \setminus X = \varnothing$ Then by [[Set Difference with Superset is Empty Set]]: :$Y \subseteq X$ Hence by [[Subset implies Cardinal Inequality]]: :$\left\vert{Y}\right\vert \leq \left\vert{X}\right\vert$ This contradicts: :$\left\vert{X}\right\vert < \left\vert{Y}\right\vert$ Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a [[Definition:T1/2 Space|$T_{\frac 1 2}$ topological space]]. Then $T$ is [[Definition:T0 Space|$T_0$ space]].
rationale:
By [[Characterization of T0 Space by Closures of Singletons]] it suffices to prove that :$ orall x, y \in S: x 
e y \implies x 
otin \set y^- \lor y 
otin \set x^-$ where $\set y^-$ denotes the [[Definition:Closure (Topology)|closure]] of $\set y$. Let $x, y$ be [[Definition:Element|points]] of $T$ such that: :$x 
e y$ {{AimForCont}}: :$x \in \set y^- \land y \in \set x^-$ We will prove that: :$x 
otin \set x'$ where $\set x'$ denotes the [[Definition:Set Derivative|derivative]] of $\set x$. {{AimForCont}}: :$x \in \set x'$ As $S$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] by definition of [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] by [[Characterization of Derivative by Open Sets]]: :$\exists z \in S: z \in \set x \cap S \land z 
e x$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: :$z \in \set x$ This contradicts $z 
e x$ by definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]. Thus $x 
otin \set x'$. We will prove that: :$(1): \quad \lnot  orall G \in 	au: y \in G \implies \set x \cap G 
e \O$ {{AimForCont}}: :$ orall G \in 	au: y \in G \implies \set x \cap G 
e \O$ As sublemma we will show that: :$ orall U \in 	au: y \in U \implies \exists r \in S: r \in \set x \cap U \land y 
e r$ Let $U \in 	au$ such that: :$y \in U$ Then by assumption: :$\set x \cap U 
e \O$ By definition of [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]]: :$\exists z: z \in \set x \cap U$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: :$z \in \set x$ Then by definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$z = x 
e y$ Thus: :$\exists r \in S: r \in \set x \cap U \land y 
e r$ Then by [[Characterization of Derivative by Open Sets]]: :$y \in \set x'$ By definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]]: :$y 
otin elcomp S {\set x'} \land x \in elcomp S {\set x'}$ By definition of [[Definition:T1/2 Space|$T_{ rac 1 2}$ space]]: :$\set x'$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] By definition of [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed set]]: :$elcomp S {\set x'}$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] By $x \in \set y^-$ and by [[Condition for Point being in Closure]]: :$\set y \cap elcomp S {\set x'} 
e \O$ Then by definition of [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]]: :$\exists z: z \in \set y \cap elcomp S {\set x'}$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: :$z \in \set y \land z \in elcomp S {\set x'}$ By definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$z = y$ Thus $z \in elcomp S {\set x'}$ contradicts $y 
otin elcomp S {\set x'}$. This ends the proof of $(1)$. Then by $(1)$ and [[Condition for Point being in Closure]]: :$y 
otin \set x^-$ This contradicts $y \in \set x^-$. {{qed}}

statement:
Let $T = \left({S, 	au}ight)$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Then :$T$ is a [[Definition:T0 Space|$T_0$ space]] {{iff}} ::$ orall x, y \in S: x 
e y \implies x 
otin \left\{{y}ight\}^- \lor y 
otin \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ where $\left\{{y}ight\}^-$ denotes the [[Definition:Closure (Topology)|closure]] of $\left\{{y}ight\}$.
rationale:
=== Sufficient Condition === Let $T$ be a [[Definition:T0 Space|$T_0$ space]]. Let $x, y \in S$ such that :$x 
e y$ Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$x \in \left\{{y}ight\}^- \land y \in \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ Then: :$\left\{{x}ight\} \subseteq \left\{{y}ight\}^- \land \left\{{y}ight\} \subseteq \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ By [[Topological Closure of Subset is Subset of Topological Closure]]: :$\left\{{x}ight\}^- \subseteq \left({\left\{{y}ight\}^-}ight)^- \land \left\{{y}ight\}^- \subseteq \left({\left\{{x}ight\}^-}ight)^-$ By [[Closure of Topological Closure equals Closure]]: :$\left\{{x}ight\}^- \subseteq \left\{{y}ight\}^- \land \left\{{y}ight\}^- \subseteq \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ Then by definition of [[Definition:Set Equality|set equality]]: :$\left\{{x}ight\}^- = \left\{{y}ight\}^-$ By [[Characterization of T0 Space by Distinct Closures of Singletons|Characterization of $T_0$ Space by Distinct Closures of Singletons]]: :$\left\{{x}ight\}^- 
e \left\{{y}ight\}^-$ This contradicts the equality. Thus the result by [[Proof by Contradiction]] {{qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === Assume that: :$(1): \quad  orall x, y \in S: x 
e y \implies x 
otin \left\{{y}ight\}^- \lor y 
otin \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ By [[Characterization of T0 Space by Distinct Closures of Singletons|Characterization of $T_0$ Space by Distinct Closures of Singletons]] it suffices to prove :$ orall x, y \in S: x 
e y \implies \left\{{y}ight\}^- 
e \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ Let $x, y \in S$ such that :$x 
e y$ Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$(2): \quad \left\{{y}ight\}^- = \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ By definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$x \in \left\{{x}ight\} \land y \in \left\{{y}ight\}$ By [[Set is Subset of its Topological Closure]] :$\left\{{x}ight\} \subseteq \left\{{x}ight\}^- \land \left\{{y}ight\} \subseteq \left\{{y}ight\}^-$ Then by definition of [[Definition:Subset|subset]] and $(2)$: :$x \in \left\{{y}ight\}^- \land y \in \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ This contradicts the assumption $(1)$. Thus the result by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Then :$T$ is a [[Definition:T0 Space|$T_0$ space]] {{iff}} ::$\forall x, y \in S: x \ne y \implies \left\{{x}\right\}^- \ne \left\{{y}\right\}^-$ where $\left\{{y}\right\}^-$ denotes the [[Definition:Closure (Topology)|closure]] of $\left\{{y}\right\}$.
rationale:
=== Sufficient Condition === Let $T$ be a [[Definition:T0 Space|$T_0$ space]]. Let $x, y \in S$ such that :$x 
e y$ By definition of [[Definition:T0 Space|$T_0$ space]]: :$\left({\exists U \in 	au: x \in U \land y 
otin U}ight) \lor \left({\exists U \in 	au: x 
otin U \land y \in U}ight)$ [[Definition:WLOG|WLOG]]: Suppose :$\exists U \in 	au: x \in U \land y 
otin U$ By definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$x \in \left\{{x}ight\}$ By [[Set is Subset of its Topological Closure]]: :$\left\{{x}ight\} \subseteq \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ Then by definition of [[Definition:Subset|subset]]: :$x \in \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ Hence by definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: :$\left\{{x}ight\}^- \cap U 
e \varnothing$ By definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$ orall z: z \in \left\{{y}ight\} \implies z = y$ Then by definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: :$\left\{{y}ight\} \cap U = \varnothing$ Hence by [[Disjoint Open Sets remain Disjoint with one Closure]] :$\left\{{y}ight\}^- \cap U = \varnothing$ Thus: :$\left\{{x}ight\}^- 
e \left\{{y}ight\}^-$ {{qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === Assume that: :$(1): \quad  orall x, y \in S: x 
e y \implies \left\{{x}ight\}^- 
e \left\{{y}ight\}^-$ By [[Characterization of T0 Space by Closed Sets|Characterization of $T_0$ Space by Closed Sets]] it suffices to prove that :$\left({\exists F \subseteq S: F}ight.$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] $\left. {\land x \in F \land y 
otin F}ight)$ or :$\left({\exists F \subseteq S: F}ight.$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] $\left. {\land x 
otin F \land y \in F}ight)$ Then assume: :$(2): \quad  orall F \subseteq S: F$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] $\land x \in F \implies y \in F$ Define $F := \left\{{y}ight\}^-$ By [[Topological Closure is Closed]]: :$F$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. We will prove now that :$x 
otin F$ Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$x \in F$ Then: :$\left\{{x}ight\} \subseteq F$ By [[Topological Closure of Subset is Subset of Topological Closure]]: :$\left\{{x}ight\}^- \subseteq F^-$ By [[Set is Closed iff Equals Topological Closure]]: :$(3): \quad \left\{{x}ight\}^- \subseteq F$ By definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$x \in \left\{{x}ight\}$ By [[Set is Subset of its Topological Closure]]: :$\left\{{x}ight\} \subseteq \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ Then by definition of [[Definition:Subset|subset]]: :$x \in \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ Because $\left\{{x}ight\}^-$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] therefore by $(2)$: :$y \in \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ Then: :$\left\{{y}ight\} \subseteq \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ By [[Topological Closure of Subset is Subset of Topological Closure]]: :$F \subseteq \left({\left\{{x}ight\}^-}ight)^-$ Then by [[Closure of Topological Closure equals Closure]]: :$F \subseteq \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ Hence by $(3)$ and definition of [[Definition:Set Equality|set equality]]: :$F = \left\{{x}ight\}^-$ This contradicts the assumption $(1)$. Thus $x 
otin F$. By definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$y \in \left\{{y}ight\}$ By [[Set is Subset of its Topological Closure]]: :$\left\{{y}ight\} \subseteq \left\{{y}ight\}^- = F$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Subset|subset]]: :$y \in F$ Hence :$\exists F \subseteq S: F$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] $\land x 
otin F \land y \in F$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $x$ be a [[Definition:Element|point]] of $S$. Then: :if $x$ is [[Definition:Condensation Point|condensation point]] of $A \cup B$, :then $x$ is [[Definition:Condensation Point|condensation point]] of $A$ or $x$ is [[Definition:Condensation Point|condensation point]] of $B$.
rationale: Assume $x$ is [[Definition:Condensation Point|condensation point]] of $A \cup B$. Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$x$ is not [[Definition:Condensation Point|condensation point]] of $A$ and $x$ is not [[Definition:Condensation Point|condensation point]] of $B$. By definition of [[Definition:Condensation Point|condensation point]]: :$\exists U_1 \in \tau: x \in U_1 \land A \cap U_1$ is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] By definition of [[Definition:Condensation Point|condensation point]]: :$\exists U_2 \in \tau: x \in U_2 \land B \cap U_2$ is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] By definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: :$x \in U_1 \cap U_2$ By definition of [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]: :$U_1 \cap U_2 \in \tau$ By [[Intersection is Subset]]: :$A \cap U_1 \cap U_2 \subseteq A \cap U_1 \land B \cap U_1 \cap U_2 \subseteq B \cap U_2$ By [[Set Union Preserves Subsets]]: :$\left({A \cap U_1 \cap U_2}\right) \cup \left({B \cap U_1 \cap U_2}\right) \subseteq \left({A \cap U_1}\right) \cup \left({B \cap U_2}\right)$ By [[Countable Union of Countable Sets is Countable]]: :$\left({A \cap U_1}\right) \cup \left({B \cap U_2}\right)$ is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] Then by [[Subset of Countable Set is Countable]]: :$(1): \quad \left({A \cap U_1 \cap U_2}\right) \cup \left({B \cap U_1 \cap U_2}\right)$ is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]] By [[Intersection Distributes over Union]]: :$\left({A \cap U_1 \cap U_2}\right) \cup \left({B \cap U_1 \cap U_2}\right) = \left({A \cup B}\right) \cap \left({U_1 \cap U_2}\right)$ By definition of [[Definition:Condensation Point|condensation point]]: :$\left({A \cup B}\right) \cap \left({U_1 \cap U_2}\right)$ is [[Definition:Countable Set|uncountable]] This contradicts $(1)$. Thus the result fallows by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $A$ be a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$. Then: :if $A$ is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]], :then $A^0 = \varnothing$.
rationale: Assume :$A$ is [[Definition:Countable Set|countable]]. Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$A^0 \ne \varnothing$ By definition of [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]]: :$\exists x: x \in A^0$ Then by definition of [[Definition:Set of Condensation Points|set of condensation points]]: :$x$ is a [[Definition:Condensation Point|condensation point]] of $A$. This contradicts [[Set of Condensation Points of Countable Set is Empty/Lemma|Lemma]]. Thus the result follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\map {y_p} x\) be a [[Definition:Particular Solution|particular solution]] to the [[Definition:Homogeneous Linear Second Order ODE|homogeneous linear second order ODE]]: :$(1): \quad \dfrac {\d^2 y} {\d x^2} + \map P x \dfrac {\d y} {\d x} + \map Q x y = 0$ on a [[Definition:Closed Real Interval|closed interval]] \(\closedint a b\). Let there exist \(\xi \in \closedint a b\) such that the [[Definition:Curve|curve]] in the [[Definition:Cartesian Plane|cartesian plane]] described by \(y = \map {y_p} x\) is [[Definition:Tangent to Curve|tangent]] to the [[Definition:X-Axis|$x$-axis]] at \(\xi\). Then \(\map {y_p} x\) is the [[Definition:Constant Mapping|zero constant function]]: :\(\forall x \in \closedint a b: \map {y_p} x = 0\)
rationale: {{AimForCont}} $y_p$ is not the [[Definition:Constant Mapping|zero constant function]]. From [[Particular Solution to Homogeneous Linear Second Order ODE gives rise to Another]], there exists another [[Definition:Particular Solution|particular solution]] to $(1)$ such that $y_1$ and $y_2$ are [[Definition:Linearly Independent Real Functions|linearly independent]]. At the point $\xi$: :$\map {y_p} \xi = 0$ :$\map { {y_p}'} \xi = 0$ Taking the [[Definition:Wronskian|Wronskian]] of $y_p$ and $y_2$: :$\map W {y_p, y_2} = y_p {y_2}' - {y_p}' y_2$ But at $\xi$ this works out as [[Definition:Zero (Number)|zero]]. It follows from [[Zero Wronskian of Solutions of Homogeneous Linear Second Order ODE iff Linearly Dependent]] that $y_p$ and $y_2$ cannot be [[Definition:Linearly Independent Real Functions|linearly independent]] after all. From this contradiction, $y_p$ must the [[Definition:Constant Mapping|zero constant function]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $K$ be a [[Definition:Cone|cone]] whose [[Definition:Base of Cone|base]] is of [[Definition:Area|area]] $A$ and whose [[Definition:Height of Cone|height]] is $h$. Then the [[Definition:Volume|volume]] of $K$ is given by: :$V_K = \dfrac {A h} 3$
rationale: Let a [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]] and a [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] have the same [[Definition:Base of Solid Figure|base]] $ABCD$. Let them be of equal [[Definition:Height of Solid Figure|height]]. Suppose the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] is not three times the [[Definition:Volume|volume]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]]. Then the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] will either be greater than or less than three times the [[Definition:Volume|volume]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]]. First suppose that the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] is greater than three times the [[Definition:Volume|volume]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]]. From {{EuclidPropLink|book = IV|prop = 6|title = Inscribing Square in Circle}}: :let the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] $ABCD$ be [[Definition:Polygon Inscribed in Circle|inscribed]] in the [[Definition:Circle|circle]] $ABCD$. From [[Square Inscribed in Circle is greater than Half Area of Circle]]: :the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] $ABCD$ is greater than half the [[Definition:Circle|circle]] $ABCD$. From the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] $ABCD$, let a [[Definition:Prism|prism]] be set up whose [[Definition:Height of Prism|height]] equals the [[Definition:Height of Cylinder|height]] of the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]]. Again using the reasoning of: :{{EuclidPropLink|book = XII|prop = 2|title = Areas of Circles are as Squares on Diameters}} in conjunction with :{{EuclidPropLink|book = XI|prop = 32|title = Parallelepipeds of Same Height have Volume Proportional to Bases}} this [[Definition:Prism|prism]] is greater than half the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]]. Let the [[Definition:Arc of Circle|arcs]] $AB, BC, CD, DA$ be [[Definition:Bisection|bisected]] at $E, F, G, H$. Let $AE, EB, BF, FC, CG, GD, DH, HA$ be joined. From {{EuclidPropLink|book = XII|prop = 2|title = Areas of Circles are as Squares on Diameters}}: :each of $\triangle AEB, \triangle BFC, \triangle CGD, \triangle DHA$ is greater than half the [[Definition:Segment of Circle|segment]] of the [[Definition:Circle|circle]] $ABCD$ around it. On each of $\triangle AEB, \triangle BFC, \triangle CGD, \triangle DHA$, let [[Definition:Prism|prisms]] be set up with the same [[Definition:Height of Solid Figure|height]] as the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]]. Again from the reasoning in {{EuclidPropLink|book = XII|prop = 2|title = Areas of Circles are as Squares on Diameters}}: :each of these [[Definition:Prism|prisms]] is greater than half the [[Definition:Segment of Circle|segment]] of the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] around it. The operation: : [[Definition:Bisection|bisecting]] the [[Definition:Arc of Circle|arcs]] remaining, joining the points of bisection with [[Definition:Straight Line|straight lines]] and setting up [[Definition:Prism|prisms]] on the resulting [[Definition:Triangle (Geometry)|triangles]] the same [[Definition:Height of Solid Figure|height]] as the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] can be repeated indefinitely. From {{EuclidPropLink|book = X|prop = 1|title = Existence of Fraction of Number Smaller than Given}}: : eventually we will leave some [[Definition:Segment of Circle|segments]] of the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] which will be less than the amount by which the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] is greater than triple the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]]. Let such [[Definition:Segment of Circle|segments]] be left, and let them be $AE, EB, BF, FC, CG, GD, DH, HA$. The remainder, the [[Definition:Prism|prism]] whose [[Definition:Base of Prism|base]] is the [[Definition:Polygon|polygon]] $AEBFCGDH$ and whose [[Definition:Height of Prism|height]] equals the [[Definition:Height of Cylinder|height]] of the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]], is then greater than three times the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]]. But from {{EuclidPropLink|book = XII|prop = 7|qual=Porism|title = Prism on Triangular Base divided into Three Equal Tetrahedra}}: :the [[Definition:Prism|prism]] whose [[Definition:Base of Prism|base]] is the [[Definition:Polygon|polygon]] $AEBFCGDH$ and whose [[Definition:Height of Prism|height]] equals the [[Definition:Height of Cylinder|height]] of the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] is three times the [[Definition:Pyramid|pyramid]] whose [[Definition:Base of Pyramid|base]] is $AEBFCGDH$ and whose [[Definition:Apex of Pyramid|apex]] is the same as the [[Definition:Apex of Cone|apex]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]]. Therefore the [[Definition:Pyramid|pyramid]] whose [[Definition:Base of Pyramid|base]] is $AEBFCGDH$ and whose [[Definition:Apex of Pyramid|apex]] is the same as the [[Definition:Apex of Cone|apex]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]] is greater than the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]] which has the [[Definition:Circle|circle]] $ABCD$ as base. But it is also less, as it is enclosed by it. From this impossibility it follows that the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] cannot be greater than three times the [[Definition:Volume|volume]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]]. Now suppose that the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] is less than three times the [[Definition:Volume|volume]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]]. That is, the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]] is greater than a third part of the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]]. From {{EuclidPropLink|book = IV|prop = 6|title = Inscribing Square in Circle}}: :let the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] $ABCD$ be [[Definition:Polygon Inscribed in Circle|inscribed]] in the [[Definition:Circle|circle]] $ABCD$. From [[Square Inscribed in Circle is greater than Half Area of Circle]]: :the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] $ABCD$ is greater than half the [[Definition:Circle|circle]] $ABCD$. From the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|square]] $ABCD$, let a [[Definition:Pyramid|pyramid]] be set up whose [[Definition:Apex of Pyramid|apex]] is the same as the [[Definition:Apex of Cone|apex]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]]. Again using the reasoning of: :{{EuclidPropLink|book = XII|prop = 2|title = Areas of Circles are as Squares on Diameters}} in conjunction with the reasoning of: :{{EuclidPropLink|book = XI|prop = 32|title = Parallelepipeds of Same Height have Volume Proportional to Bases}} this [[Definition:Pyramid|pyramid]] is greater than half the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]]. Let the [[Definition:Arc of Circle|arcs]] $AB, BC, CD, DA$ be [[Definition:Bisection|bisected]] at $E, F, G, H$. Let $AE, EB, BF, FC, CG, GD, DH, HA$ be joined. From {{EuclidPropLink|book = XII|prop = 2|title = Areas of Circles are as Squares on Diameters}}: :each of $\triangle AEB, \triangle BFC, \triangle CGD, \triangle DHA$ is greater than half the [[Definition:Segment of Circle|segment]] of the [[Definition:Circle|circle]] $ABCD$ around it. On each of $\triangle AEB, \triangle BFC, \triangle CGD, \triangle DHA$, let [[Definition:Pyramid|pyramids]] be set up whose [[Definition:Apex of Pyramid|apex]] is the same as the [[Definition:Apex of Cone|apex]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]]. Again from the reasoning in {{EuclidPropLink|book = XII|prop = 2|title = Areas of Circles are as Squares on Diameters}}: :each of these [[Definition:Pyramid|pyramids]] is greater than half the [[Definition:Segment of Circle|segment]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]] around it. The operation: : [[Definition:Bisection|bisecting]] the [[Definition:Arc of Circle|arcs]] remaining, joining the points of bisection with [[Definition:Straight Line|straight lines]] and setting up [[Definition:Pyramid|pyramids]] on the resulting [[Definition:Triangle (Geometry)|triangles]] whose [[Definition:Apex of Pyramid|apex]] is the same as the [[Definition:Apex of Cone|apex]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]] can be repeated indefinitely. From {{EuclidPropLink|book = X|prop = 1|title = Existence of Fraction of Number Smaller than Given}}: : eventually we will leave some [[Definition:Segment of Circle|segments]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]] which will be less than the amount by which the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]] is greater than one third the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]]. Let such [[Definition:Segment of Circle|segments]] be left, and let them be $AE, EB, BF, FC, CG, GD, DH, HA$. The remainder, the [[Definition:Pyramid|pyramid]] whose [[Definition:Base of Pyramid|base]] is the [[Definition:Polygon|polygon]] $AEBFCGDH$ and whose [[Definition:Apex of Pyramid|apex]] is the same as the [[Definition:Apex of Cone|apex]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]], is then greater than one third the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]]. But from {{EuclidPropLink|book = XII|prop = 7|qual=Porism|title = Prism on Triangular Base divided into Three Equal Tetrahedra}}: :the [[Definition:Pyramid|pyramid]] whose [[Definition:Base of Pyramid|base]] is the [[Definition:Polygon|polygon]] $AEBFCGDH$ and whose [[Definition:Apex of Pyramid|apex]] is the same as the [[Definition:Apex of Cone|apex]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]] is one third the [[Definition:Prism|prism]] whose [[Definition:Base of Prism|base]] is $AEBFCGDH$ and whose [[Definition:Height of Prism|height]] equals the [[Definition:Height of Cylinder|height]] of the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]]. Therefore the [[Definition:Prism|prism]] whose [[Definition:Base of Prism|base]] is $AEBFCGDH$ and whose [[Definition:Height of Prism|height]] equals the [[Definition:Height of Cylinder|height]] of the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] is greater than the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] which has the [[Definition:Circle|circle]] $ABCD$ as base. But it is also less, as it is enclosed by it. From this impossibility it follows that the [[Definition:Cylinder|cylinder]] cannot be less than three times the [[Definition:Volume|volume]] of the [[Definition:Right Circular Cone|cone]]. The result follows. {{qed}}

statement: [[Definition:Pi|$\pi$ (pi)]] is [[Definition:Transcendental Number|transcendental]].
rationale: [[Proof by Contradiction]]: {{AimForCont}} $\pi$ is not [[Definition:Transcendental Number|transcendental]]. Hence by definition, $\pi$ is [[Definition:Algebraic Number|algebraic]]. Let $\pi$ be the root of a non-zero [[Definition:Polynomial (Analysis)|polynomial]] with [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]] coefficients, namely $\map f x$. Then, $\map g x := \map f {i x} \map f {-i x}$ is also a non-zero [[Definition:Polynomial (Analysis)|polynomial]] with [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]] coefficients such that: :$\map g {i \pi} = 0$ Hence, $i \pi$ is also [[Definition:Algebraic Number|algebraic]]. From the [[Hermite-Lindemann-Weierstrass Theorem/Weaker|Weaker Hermite-Lindemann-Weierstrass Theorem]], $e^{i \pi}$ is [[Definition:Transcendental Number|transcendental]]. However, from [[Euler's Identity]]: :$e^{i \pi} = -1$ which is the [[Definition:Root of Polynomial|root]] of $\map h z = z + 1$, and so is [[Definition:Algebraic Number|algebraic]]. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the conclusion that $e^{i \pi}$ is [[Definition:Transcendental Number|transcendental]]. Hence by [[Proof by Contradiction]] it must follow that $\pi$ is [[Definition:Transcendental Number|transcendental]]. {{qed}}

statement:
Let $r$ be a [[Definition:Rational Number|rational number]] such that $r 
e 0$. Then: :$e^r$ is [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational]] where $e$ is [[Definition:Euler's Number|Euler's number]].
rationale: Let $r = \dfrac p q$ be [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]] such that $r \ne 0$. {{AimForCont}} $e^r$ is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]]. Then \paren {e^r}^q = e^p$ is also [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]]. Then if $e^{-p}$ is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]], it follows that $e^p$ is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]]. It is therefore sufficient to derive a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] from the supposition that $e^p$ is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]] for every $p \in \Z_{>0}$. Let $e^p = \dfrac a b$ for $a, b \in \Z_{>0}$. Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a [[Definition:Strictly Positive Integer|strictly positive integer]]. Let \map f x$ be the [[Definition:Real Function|function]] defined as: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | n = 1       | l = \map f x       | o = :=       | r = \frac {x^n \paren {1 - x}^n} {n!}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \frac 1 {n!} \sum_{k \mathop = n}^{2 n} c_k x^k       | c = where the $c_k$'s are some [[Definition:Integer|integers]] }} {{end-eqn}} Note that: :$(2): \quad 0 < x < 1 \implies 0 < \map f x < \dfrac 1 {n!}$ We also have: :$\map f 0 = 0$ :$\map {f^{\paren m} } 0 = 0$ if $m < n$ or $m > 2 n$ and: :$n \le m \le 2 n \implies \map {f^{\paren m} } 0 = \dfrac {m!} {n!} c_m$ and this number is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]. Thus at $x = 0$, $\map f x$ and all its [[Definition:Higher Derivative|derivatives]] are [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. Since $\map f {1 - x} = \map f x$, the same is true for $x = 1$. Let $\map F x$ be the [[Definition:Real Function|function]] defined as: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | n = 3       | l = \map F x       | o = :=       | r = \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^{2 n} \paren {-1}^k p^{2 n - k} \map {f^{\paren k} } x       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = p^{2 n} \map f x - p^{2 n - 1} \map {f'} x + p^{2 n - 2} \map {f''} x - \cdots - p \map {f^{\paren {2 n - 1} } } x + \map {f^{\paren {2 n} } } x       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} Because of the properties of $\map f x$ and its [[Definition:Higher Derivative|derivatives]] above, $\map F 0$ and $\map F 1$ are [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. Next we have: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | n = 4       | l = \map {\frac {\d} {\d x} } {e^{p x} \map F x}       | r = e^{p x} \paren {\map {F'} x + p \, \map F x}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = p^{2 n + 1} e^{p x} \map f x       | c = from $\map {F'} x + p \, \map F x$ based on $(3)$ }} {{end-eqn}} $(4)$ leads to: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = b \int_0^1 p^{2 n + 1} e^{p x} \map f x \d x       | r = b \bigintlimits {e^{p x} \map F x} 0 1       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = a \, \map F 1 - b \, \map F 0       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} which is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]. But from $(2)$: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = 0       | o = <       | r = b \int_0^1 p^{2 n + 1} e^{p x} \map f x \rd x       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = <       | r = \frac {b p^{2 n + 1} e^p} {n!}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = b p e^p \frac {\paren {p^2}^n e^p} {n!}       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} The expression on the {{RHS}} tends to $0$ as $n$ tends to $\infty$. Hence: :$0 < a \, \map F 1 - b \, \map F 0 < 1$ for sufficiently large $n$. But there exists no [[Definition:Integer|integer]] strictly between $0$ and $1$. From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that our original assumption, that is, that $e^r$ is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]], must have been false. {{qed}}

statement: The [[Definition:Square Root|square root]] of $2$ is an [[Definition:Algebraic Number|algebraic number]] of [[Definition:Degree of Algebraic Number|degree]] $2$.
rationale: Suppose \(\sqrt 2\) could be expressed as the [[Definition:Root of Polynomial|root]] of the [[Definition:Linear Polynomial|linear polynomial]]: :\(a_1 x + a_0 = 0\) for some \(a_0, a_1 \in \Q\). Then: :\(\sqrt 2 = -\dfrac {a_0} {a_1}\) and would be [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]]. But as [[Square Root of 2 is Irrational]], this is not the case. However, \(\sqrt 2\) is a [[Definition:Root of Polynomial|root]] of the [[Definition:Polynomial (Analysis)|polynomial]] of [[Definition:Degree of Polynomial|degree]] $2$: :\(x^2 - 2 = 0\) Hence the result by definition of [[Definition:Degree of Algebraic Number|degree of algebraic number]]. {{qed}}

statement: It is not possible to extend the [[Definition:Complex Number|complex numbers]] to an [[Definition:Algebra over Field|algebra]] of $3$ [[Definition:Dimension (Linear Algebra)|dimensions]] with [[Definition:Real Number|real]] [[Definition:Scalar (Vector Space)|scalars]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} that \(\set {1, i, j}\) forms a [[Definition:Basis (Linear Algebra)|basis]] for an [[Definition:Algebra over Field|algebra]] of $3$ [[Definition:Dimension (Linear Algebra)|dimensions]] with [[Definition:Real Number|real]] [[Definition:Scalar (Vector Space)|scalars]]. Let $1$ and $i$ have their usual properties as they do as [[Definition:Complex Number|complex numbers]]: :\(\forall a: 1 a = a 1 = a\) :\(i \cdot i = -1\) Then: :\(i j = a_1 + a_2 i + a_3 j\) for some \(a_1, a_2, a_3 \in \R\). Multiplying through by \(i\): :\((1): \quad i \paren {i j} = \paren {i i} j = -j\) and: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = i \paren {a_1 + a_2 i + a_3 j}       | r = a_1 i - a_2 + a_3 i j       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = a_1 i - a_2 + a_3 \paren {a_1 + a_2 i + a_3 j}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = a_1 i - a_2 + a_1 a_3 + a_2 a_3 i + {a_3}^2 j       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = 0       | r = \paren {a_1 a_3 - a_2} + \paren {a_1 + a_2 a_3} i + \paren { {a_3}^2 + 1} j       | c = from $(1)$ }} {{end-eqn}} But this implies that ${a_3}^2 = -1$, which contradicts our supposition that $a_3 \in \R$. Hence the result by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $U$ be an [[Definition: Open Set of Metric Space | open]], [[Definition: Connected | connected]] subset of $\C$. Let $S \subseteq U$ contain a [[Definition:Limit Point (Complex Analysis)|limit point]] $\sigma$. Let $\sequence {f_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ be a [[Definition: Normal Family | normal family]] of [[Definition:Analytic Complex Function|holomorphic]] [[Definition:Mapping|mappings]] $f_n : U \to \C$. Let $\sequence {f_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ [[Definition:Pointwise Convergence | converge]] to some [[Definition:Holomorphic Complex Function|holomorphic mapping]] $f : U \to \C$ at $\sigma$. Then $f_n$ [[Definition:Uniform Convergence/Metric Space|converges uniformly]] to $f$ on all [[Definition:Compact Metric Space|compact]] [[Definition:Subset|subsets]] of $U$.
rationale:
{{AimForCont}} there exists some compact subset $K$ of $U$ such that $f_n$ does not converge uniformly to $f$ on $K$. Consider $K^* := K \cup \set \sigma$. From [[Subsets Inherit Uniform Convergence]], $f_n$ does not converge uniformly to $f$ on $K^*$. From [[Uniformly Convergent iff Difference Under Supremum Norm Vanishes]], the above is [[Definition:Logical Equivalence|equivalent]] to: :$\exists \epsilon > 0 :  orall N \in \N : \exists n \ge N : 
orm {f_n - f}_{K^*} \ge \epsilon$ where $
orm {\cdot}_{K^*}$ denotes the [[Definition:Supremum Norm|supremum norm]] over $K^*$. From [[Finite Union of Compact Sets is Compact]], $K^{*}$ is [[Definition:Compact Metric Space|compact]]. Since $\sequence {f_n}$ is a [[Definition: Normal Family | normal family]], there is some [[Definition:Subsequence|subsequence]] $\sequence {f_{n_r} }$ of $\sequence {f_n}$ and some mapping $g \in \map {\mathcal H} U$ such that: :$\sequence {f_{n_r} }$ [[Definition:Uniform Convergence/Metric Space|converges uniformly]] to $g$ on $K^*$. Further: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \map f \sigma       | r = \lim_{n \mathop 	o \infty} \map {f_n} \sigma       | c = Definition of $f$ at $\sigma$ }} {{eqn | r = \lim_{r \mathop 	o \infty} \map {f_{n_r} } \sigma       | c = [[Limit of Subsequence equals Limit of Sequence]] }} {{eqn | r = \map g \sigma       | c = Definition of $g$ at $\sigma$ }} {{end-eqn}} From the [[Identity Theorem]], $f$ and $g$ [[Definition:Agreement of Mappings|agree]] on $U$. From [[Uniformly Convergent iff Difference Under Supremum Norm Vanishes]]: :$\exists N \in \N: r \ge N \implies 
orm {f_{n_r} - f}_{K^*} < \epsilon$ This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the result that: :$ orall N \in \N: \exists n \ge N: 
orm {f_n - f}_{K^*} \ge \epsilon$ Hence the result, by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}} {{Namedfor|Giuseppe Vitali|cat = Vitali}}

statement: Let $G = \left({V, E}\right)$ be an [[Definition:Ore Graph|Ore graph]]. Then $G$ is [[Definition:Connected Graph|connected]].
rationale: Let $G$ be an [[Definition:Ore Graph|Ore graph]]. {{AimForCont}} $G$ is not [[Definition:Connected Graph|connected]]. Then it has at least two [[Definition:Component of Graph|components]]. Call these [[Definition:Component of Graph|components]] $C_1$ and $C_2$. Thus, there exist non-[[Definition:Adjacent Vertices (Undirected Graph)|adjacent vertices]] $u$ and $v$ such that $u$ is in $C_1$ and $v$ is in $C_2$. Let $m_1$ and $m_2$ be the number of vertices in $C_1$ and $C_2$ respectively. It is clear that: :$m_1 + m_2 \le n$ By definition of [[Definition:Ore Graph|Ore graph]], $G$ is [[Definition:Simple Graph|simple]]. Thus it follows that: :$\deg_G \left({u}\right) \le m_1 - 1$ and $\deg_G \left({v}\right) \le m_2 - 1$ Thus: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \deg_G \left({u}\right) + \deg_G \left({v}\right)       | o = \le       | r = m_1 - 1 + m_2 - 1       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = m_1 + m_2 - 2       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = <       | r = m_1 + m_2       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = \le       | r = n       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} That is: :$\deg_G \left({u}\right) + \deg_G \left({v}\right) < n$ But by definition of [[Definition:Ore Graph|Ore graph]]: :$\deg_G \left({u}\right) + \deg_G \left({v}\right) \ge n$ By [[Proof by Contradiction]], it follows that our assumption that $G$ is not [[Definition:Connected Graph|connected]] was [[Definition:False|false]]. Hence the result. {{Qed}}
