statement: The [[Definition:Open Unit Interval|open unit interval]]: :$I_o = \left({0 \,.\,.\, 1}\right)$ is a [[Definition:Proper Subset|proper subset]] of the [[Definition:Closed Unit Interval|closed unit interval]]: :$I_c = \left[{0 \,.\,.\, 1}\right]$
rationale: Let $x \in I_o$. Then by definition: :$0 < x < 1$ and so: :$0 \le x \le 1$ and so: :$x \in I_c$. Thus: :$I_o \subseteq I_c$ Consider: :$0 \in I_c$ by definition of [[Definition:Closed Real Interval|closed interval]]. But it is not the case that $0 < 0$. So $0 \notin I_o$ and so $I_c \not \subseteq I_o$. Hence the result by definition of [[Definition:Proper Subset|proper subset]]. {{qed}}

statement: Set union is not a cancellable operation. That is, for a given $A, B, C \subseteq S$ for some $S$, it is not always the case that: :$A \cup B = A \cup C \implies B = C$
rationale: Proof by Counterexample: Let $S = \set {a, b}$. Let: :$A = \set {a, b}$ :$B = \set a$ :$C = \set b$ Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = A \cup B       | r = \set {a, b}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = A \cup C       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} but: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = B       | r = \set a       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = \ne       | r = \set b       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = C       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} {{qed}}

statement: [[Definition:Set Intersection|Set intersection]] is not a [[Definition:Cancellable Operation|cancellable operation]]. That is, for a given $A, B, C \subseteq S$ for some $S$, it is not always the case that: :$A \cap B = A \cap C \implies B = C$
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let $S = \left\{ {a, b, c}\right\}$. Let: :$A = \left\{ {a}\right\}$ :$B = \left\{ {a, b}\right\}$ :$C = \left\{ {a, c}\right\}$ Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = A \cap B       | r = \left\{ {a}\right\}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = A \cap C       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} but: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = B       | r = \left\{ {a, b}\right\}       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = \ne       | r = \left\{ {a, c}\right\}       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = C       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} {{qed}}

statement: Let $I_1$ and $I_2$ be [[Definition:Real Interval|real intervals]]. Then $I_1 \cup I_2$ is not necessarily a [[Definition:Real Interval|real interval]].
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Consider the [[Definition:Real Interval|real intervals]]: :$I_1 = \left({0 \,\.\, 2}\right)$ :$I_2 = \left({4 \,\.\, 6}\right)$ Then we have that: :$1 < 3 < 5$ where: :$1 \in I_1 \cup I_2$ :$5 \in I_1 \cup I_2$ but: :$3 \notin I_1 \cup I_2$ Thus $I_1 \cup I_2$ is not a [[Definition:Real Interval|real interval]]. {{qed}}

statement: The set of non-negative real numbers $\R_{\ge 0}$ is not well-ordered under the usual ordering $\le$.
rationale: Assume for the sake of contradiction that $\R_{\ge 0}$ is a well-ordered set. Then by definition, all subsets of $\R_{\ge 0}$ has a smallest element. Take the subset $\R_{> 0}$: :$\R_{> 0} = \\left\\{ {x \\in \\R_{\ge 0}: x > 0}\\right\\} = \\R_{\ge 0} \\setminus \\left\\{ {0}\\right\\}$ Suppose $x \\in \\R_{> 0}$ is a smallest element. Then $\\dfrac x 2 \\in \\R_{> 0}$. But $\\dfrac x 2 < x$, which contradicts the supposition that $x \\in \\R_{> 0}$ is a smallest element. Hence there can be no such smallest element. So by proof by contradiction, $\\R_{\ge 0}$ is not well-ordered by $\\le$.

statement: The [[Common Logarithm of 2|common logarithm of $2$]]: :$\log_{10} 2 \approx 0.30102 \, 99956 \, 63981 \, 19521 \, 37389 \ldots$ is [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} $\log_{10} 2$ is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]]. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \log_{10} 2 | r = \frac p q | c = for some $p, q \in \Z_{\ne 0}$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = 2 | r = 10^{p / q} | c = {{Defof|General Logarithm}} }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = 2^q | r = 10^p | c = raising both sides to the [[Definition:Integer Power|power of $q$]] }} {{end-eqn}} Both $10^p$ and $2^q$ are [[Definition:Integer|integers]], by construction. But $10^p$ is [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisible]] by $5$, while $2^p$, which has only $2$ as a [[Definition:Prime Factor|prime factor]], is not. So $10^p \ne 2^q$. So, by [[Proof by Contradiction]], it follows that $\log_{10} 2$ is [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let \left \langle {x_n} \right \rangle, \left \langle {a_n} \right \rangle, and \left \langle {b_n} \right \rangle be [[Definition:Convergent Real Sequence|convergent sequences in \R]]. Let \left \langle {x_n} \right \rangle, \left \langle {a_n} \right \rangle, and \left \langle {b_n} \right \rangle [[Definition:Convergent Real Sequence|converge]] to x, a, b \in \R, respectively. Suppose that: :\exists N \in \N : n \geq N \implies a_n \leq x_n \leq b_n Then: :$ a \le x \le b$
rationale: {{AimForCont}} that $x < a$. Let \epsilon = \dfrac{a - x} 2 > 0$ From the convergence of \left \langle {x_n} \right \rangle: :\exists M_1 \in \N : n \ge M \implies x - \epsilon < x_n < x + \epsilon$ Or, [[Definition:Logical Equivalence|equivalently]]: :\exists M_1 \in \N : n \ge M \implies \dfrac {3x - a} 2 < x_n < \dfrac{x + a} 2$ From the convergence of \left \langle {a_n} \right \rangle: :\exists M_2 \in \N : n \ge M \implies a - \epsilon < a_n < a + \epsilon$ Or, [[Definition:Logical Equivalence|equivalently]]: :\exists M_2 \in \N : n \ge M \implies \dfrac {x + a} 2 < a_n < \dfrac{3a - x} 2$ Let $M = \max\left\{ {N, M_1, M_2} \right\}$ Then, for any $n \ge M$: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = x_n       | o = <       | r = \dfrac {x + a} 2 }} {{eqn | o = <       | r = a_n }} {{end-eqn}} This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the hypothesis that: :\forall n \ge N : a_n \le x_n$ The same argument, [[Definition:Mutatis Mutandis|mutatis mutandis]], brings us to a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] if we suppose $x > b$. Hence the result, by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}} [[Category:Limits of Sequences]] [[Category:Real Analysis]]

statement: Let \(\mathscr S = \left({S, \wedge, \preceq}\right)\) be an [[Definition:Up-Complete|up-complete]] [[Definition:Meet Semilattice|meet semilattice]]. Let :\(\forall x \in S: x^\ll\) is [[Definition:Directed Subset|directed]] Then :\(\mathscr S\) satisfies [[Definition:Axiom of Approximation|axiom of approximation]] {{iff}} :\(\forall x, y \in S: x \npreceq y \implies \exists u \in S: u \ll x \land u \npreceq y\)
rationale:
=== Sufficient Condition === Let :\(\mathscr S\) satisfies [[Definition:Axiom of Approximation|axiom of approximation]]. Let \(x, y \in S\) such that :\(x 
preceq y\) By assumption: :\(x^\ll\) is [[Definition:Directed Subset|directed]]. By definition of [[Definition:Up-Complete|up-complete]]: :\(x^\ll\) admits a [[Definition:Supremum of Set|supremum]]. By definition of [[Definition:Axiom of Approximation|axiom of approximation]]: :\(x = \sup \left({x^\ll}ight)\) By definition of [[Definition:Supremum of Set|supremum]]: :if \(y\) is [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] for \(x^\ll\), then \(x \preceq y\) By definition of [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]]: :\(\exists u \in x^\ll: u 
preceq y\) Thus by definition of [[Definition:Way Below Closure|way below closure]]: :\(\exists u \in S: u \ll x \land u 
preceq y\) {{qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === Let :\( orall x, y \in S: x 
preceq y \implies \exists u \in S: u \ll x \land u 
preceq y\) Let \(x \in S\). By assumption: :\(x^\ll\) is [[Definition:Directed Subset|directed]]. By definition of [[Definition:Up-Complete|up-complete]]: :\(x^\ll\) admits a [[Definition:Supremum of Set|supremum]]. By [[Operand is Upper Bound of Way Below Closure]]: :\(x\) is [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] for \(x^\ll\) We will prove that :\( orall y \in S: y\) is [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] for \(x^\ll \implies x \preceq y\) Let \(y \in S\) such that :\(y\) is [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] for \(x^\ll\) Aiming at a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :\(x 
preceq y\) By assumption: :\(\exists u \in S: u \ll x \land u 
preceq y\) By definition of [[Definition:Way Below Closure|way below closure]]: :\(u \in x^\ll\) By definition of [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] :\(u \preceq y\) This contradicts \(u 
preceq y\) {{qed|lemma}} Thus by definition of [[Definition:Supremum of Set|supremum]]: :\(x = \sup \left({x^\ll}ight)\) Thus by definition: :\(\mathscr S\) satisfies [[Definition:Axiom of Approximation|axiom of approximation]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $S$ and $T$ be [[Definition:Real Number|real sets]]. Let $S$ and $T$ admit [[Definition:Supremum of Subset of Real Numbers|suprema]]. Then: : $\sup S \le \sup T \iff \forall \epsilon \in \R_{>0}: \forall s \in S: \exists t \in T: s < t + \epsilon$
rationale: === Necessary Condition === Let $\sup S \le \sup T$. The aim is to establish that: :$\forall \epsilon \in \R_{>0}: \forall s \in S: \exists t \in T: s < t + \epsilon$ Let $\epsilon \in \R_{>0}$. Let: :$S' = \set {s \in S : \exists t \in T : s \le t}$ There are two cases for an $s \in S$: :$s \in S'$, in other words: $\exists t \in T : s \le t$ and: :$s \in S \setminus S'$, in other words: $\nexists t \in T : s \le t$ First, consider the case that $s \in S'$. Let $s \in S'$. Then $t \in T$ exists such that: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = s | o = \le | r = t }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = s | o = \le | r = t < t + \epsilon | c = as $t < t + \epsilon$ is true }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = s | o = < | r = t + \epsilon | c = }} {{end-eqn}} We have found: : $\forall \epsilon \in \R_{>0}: \forall s \in S': \exists t \in T: s < t + \epsilon$ Next, consider the second case, that $s \in S \setminus S'$. Let $s \in S \setminus S'$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \nexists t \in T : s | o = \le | r = t }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \forall t \in T : s | o = > | r = t | c = so, $s$ is an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Subset of Real Numbers|upper bound]] for $T$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = s | o = \ge | r = \sup T | c = as (a) $s$ is an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Subset of Real Numbers|upper bound]] for $T$ and (b) $\sup T$ is the [[Definition:Supremum of Subset of Real Numbers|least upper bound]] of $T$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \sup S | o = \ge | r = s \ge \sup T | c = as $\sup S \ge s$ is true since (a) $\sup S$ is an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Subset of Real Numbers|upper bound]] for $S$ and (b) $s \in S$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \sup T | o = \ge | r = \sup S \ge s \ge \sup T | c = as $\sup S \le \sup T$ is true }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \sup T | o = \ge | r = s \ge \sup T }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = s | r = \sup T }} {{end-eqn}} So, $s = \sup T$ is the only [[Definition:Element|element]] of $S \setminus S'$. A $t \in T$ exists such that: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \sup T - t | o = < | r = \epsilon | c = by [[Supremum of Subset of Real Numbers is Arbitrarily Close]] }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \sup T | o = < | r = t + \epsilon }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = s | o = < | r = t + \epsilon | c = as $s = \sup T$ }} {{end-eqn}} We have found: : $\forall \epsilon \in \R_{>0}: \forall s \in S \setminus S': \exists t \in T: s < t + \epsilon$ We conclude by combining the results for the two cases: : $\forall \epsilon \in \R_{>0}: \forall s \in S: \exists t \in T: s < t + \epsilon$ {{qed|lemma}} === Sufficient Condition === Let $\forall \epsilon \in \R_{>0}: \forall s \in S: \exists t \in T: s < t + \epsilon$. The aim is to establish that $\sup S \le \sup T$. Let $\epsilon \in \R_{>0}$. An $s \in S$ exists such that: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \sup S - s | o = < | r = \epsilon | c = by [[Supremum of Subset of Real Numbers is Arbitrarily Close]] }} {{eqn | ll = \iff | l = s | o = > | r = \sup S - \epsilon }} {{end-eqn}} Let $s$ be such an [[Definition:Element|element]] of $S$. A $t \in T$ exists such that: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = s | o = < | r = t + \epsilon | c = as $\forall \epsilon' \in \R_{>0}: \forall s' \in S: \exists t \in T: s' < t + \epsilon'$ }} {{eqn | ll = \iff | l = t | o = > | r = s - \epsilon }} {{end-eqn}} Let $t$ be such an [[Definition:Element|element]] of $T$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = t | o = > | r = s - \epsilon }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = t | o = > | r = s - \epsilon \text { and } s > \sup S - \epsilon | c = as $s > \sup S - \epsilon$ is true }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = t | o = > | r = s - \epsilon \text{ and } s - \epsilon > \sup S - 2 \epsilon }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = t | o = > | r = s - \epsilon > \sup S - 2 \epsilon }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = t | o = > | r = \sup S - 2 \epsilon }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \sup T | o = \ge | r = t > \sup S - 2 \epsilon | c = as $\sup T \ge t$ is true since (a) $\sup T$ is an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Subset of Real Numbers|upper bound]] for $T$ and (b) $t \in T$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \sup T | o = > | r = \sup S - 2 \epsilon }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \sup T | o = \ge | r = \sup S | c = as $\epsilon$ is an arbitrary [[Definition:Element|element]] of $\R_{>0}$ }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \sup S | o = \le | r = \sup T }} {{end-eqn}} {{qed}}

statement: $x \ge n \iff \left \lfloor{x}\right \rfloor \ge n$
rationale: === Necessary Condition === Let \(\left \lfloor{x}\right \rfloor \ge n\). By definition of the [[Definition:Floor Function|floor]] of \(x\): :\(x \ge \left \lfloor{x}\right \rfloor\) Hence: :\(x \ge n\) {{qed|lemma}} === Sufficient Condition === Let \(x \ge n\). {{AimForCont}} \(\left \lfloor{x}\right \rfloor < n\). We have that: :\(\forall m, n \in \Z: m < n \iff m + 1 \le n\) Hence: :\(\left \lfloor{x}\right \rfloor + 1 \le n\) and so [[Definition:By Hypothesis|by hypothesis]]: :\(\left \lfloor{x}\right \rfloor + 1 \le x\) This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the definition of the [[Definition:Floor Function|floor]] of \(x\): :\(\left \lfloor{x}\right \rfloor + 1 > x\) Thus by [[Proof by Contradiction]]: :\(\left \lfloor{x}\right \rfloor \ge n\) {{qed|lemma}} Hence the result: :\(\left \lfloor{x}\right \rfloor \ge n \iff x \ge n\) {{qed}}

statement: $\left \lceil{x}\right \rceil \le n \iff x \le n$
rationale: === Necessary Condition === Let $\left \lceil{x}\right \rceil \le n$. By [[Number is between Ceiling and One Less]]: :$x \le \left \lceil{x}\right \rceil$ Hence: :$x \le n$ {{qed|lemma}} === Sufficient Condition === Let $x \le n$. {{AimForCont}} $\left \lceil{x}\right \rceil > n$. We have that: :$\forall m, n \in \Z: m < n \iff m \le n - 1$ Hence: :$\left \lceil{x}\right \rceil - 1 \ge n$ and so [[Definition:By Hypothesis|by hypothesis]]: :$\left \lceil{x}\right \rceil - 1 \ge x$ This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the result [[Number is between Ceiling and One Less]]: :$\left \lceil{x}\right \rceil - 1 < x$ Thus by [[Proof by Contradiction]]: :$\left \lceil{x}\right \rceil \le n$ {{qed|lemma}} Hence the result: :$\left \lceil{x}\right \rceil \le n \iff x \le n$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $T$ be [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} $S$ is [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable]]. Then by [[Uncountable Discrete Space is not Separable]], $T$ is not [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]]. Hence the result by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $f: \R \to \R$ be the [[Definition:Real Function|real function]] defined as: :$\forall x \in \R: \map f x = \sqbrk {x \in \Z}$ where $\sqbrk {\cdots}$ is [[Definition:Iverson's Convention|Iverson's convention]]. Then $f$ is a [[Definition:Replicative Function|replicative function]].
rationale: First note that the interval between $x$ and $x + \dfrac {n - 1} n$ is less than $1$. Thus there can be no more than one $k$ such that $0 \le k < n$ such that: :$x + \dfrac k n \in \Z$ Hence: :$\displaystyle \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^{n - 1} \sqbrk {x + \frac k n \in \Z} \le 1$ First let: :$\displaystyle \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^{n - 1} \sqbrk {x + \frac k n \in \Z} = 1$ Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = x + \frac k n       | o = \in        | r = \Z       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = n \paren {x + \frac k n}       | o = \in        | r = \Z       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = n x + k       | o = \in        | r = \Z       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = n x       | o = \in        | r = \Z       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = \sqbrk {n x \in \Z}       | r = 1       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} {{qed|lemma}} Let: :$\displaystyle \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^{n - 1} \sqbrk {x + \frac k n \in \Z} = 0$ {{AimForCont}} $\sqbrk {n x \in \Z} = 1$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = n x       | o = \in       | r = \Z       | c =  }} {{eqn | lll= \leadsto       | ll= \forall k \in \Z:       | l = n x + k       | o = \in       | r = \Z       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} But at least one $n x + k$ such that $0 \le k < n$ is a [[Definition:Multiple of Integer|multiple]] of $n$. Hence: :$\exists k \in \Z: 0 \le k < n: \sqbrk {x + \dfrac k n \in \Z} = 1$ So: :$\displaystyle \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^{n - 1} \sqbrk {x + \frac k n \in \Z} = 1$ which [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the supposition that $\sqbrk {n x \in \Z} = 1$. Hence the result by definition of [[Definition:Replicative Function|replicative function]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Lattice|lattice]]. Let $x \in S$. Let : $x^\succeq \setminus \left\{ {x}\right\}$ be a [[Definition:Filter in Ordered Set|filter]] in $L$. Then $x$ is [[Definition:Meet Irreducible|meet irreducible]].
rationale: Let $a, b \in S$. Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$x = a \wedge b$ and $x \ne a$ and $x \ne b$ By [[Meet Precedes Operands]]: :$x \preceq b$ and $x \preceq a$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure/Element|upper closure of element]]: :$b, a \in x^\succeq$ By definitions of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]] and [[Definition:Set Difference|difference]]: :$b, a \in x^\succeq \setminus \left\{ {x}\right\}$ By definition of [[Definition:Filtered Subset|filtered]]: :$\exists z \in x^\succeq \setminus \left\{ {x}\right\}: z \preceq a \land z \preceq b$ By definition of [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]]: :$z \preceq x$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Set|upper set]]: :$x \in x^\succeq \setminus \left\{ {x}\right\}$ Thus this contradicts $x \in \left\{ {x}\right\}$ by definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Lattice|lattice]]. Let $F$ be a [[Definition:Filter in Ordered Set|filter]] in $L$. Let $p \in S$. Let $p = \max \complement_S\left({F}\right)$. Then $p$ is [[Definition:Meet Irreducible|meet irreducible]].
rationale:
Let $x, y \in S$. Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$p = x \wedge y$ and $p 
e x$ and $p 
e y$ By [[Meet Precedes Operands]]: :$p \preceq x$ and $p \preceq y$ By definition of $\prec$: :$p \prec x$ and $p \prec y$ We will prove that :$x 
otin F$ or $y 
otin F$ Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$x \in F \land y \in F$ By definition of [[Definition:Filtered Subset|filtered]]: :$\exists z \in F: z \preceq x \land z \preceq y$ By definition of [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]]: :$z \preceq p$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Set|upper set]]: :$p \in F$ Thus this contradicts $p \in \complement_S\left({F}ight)$ by definition of [[Definition:Greatest Element|greatest element]]. {{qed|lemma}} By definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]]: :$x \in \complement_S\left({F}ight)$ or $y \in \complement_S\left({F}ight)$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Greatest Element|greatest element]]: this contradicts $p \prec x$ and $p \prec y$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Bounded Below Set|bounded below]] [[Definition:Continuous Ordered Set|continuous]] [[Definition:Lattice|lattice]]. Let $x, y \in S$ such that :$y \npreceq x$ Then :$\exists p \in S: p$ is [[Definition:Meet Irreducible|meet irreducible]] and $x \preceq p$ and $y \npreceq p$
rationale: By definition of [[Definition:Continuous Ordered Set|continuous]]: :$L$ satisfies [[Definition:Axiom of Approximation|axiom of approximation]] and :$\forall x \in S: x^\ll$ is [[Definition:Directed Subset|directed]]. By [[Axiom of Approximation in Up-Complete Semilattice]] :$\exists u \in S: u \ll y \land u \npreceq x$ By [[Way Below implies There Exists Way Below Open Filter Subset of Way Above Closure]]: :there exists [[Definition:Way Below Open|way below open]] [[Definition:Filter in Ordered Set|filter]] $F$ in $L$: $y \in F \subseteq u^\gg$ By [[Way Above Closure is Subset of Upper Closure of Element]]: :$u^\gg \subseteq u^\succeq$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Set|upper set]]: :$x \notin F$ By definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]]: :$x \in \complement_S\left({F}\right)$ By [[Upper Way Below Open Subset Complement is Non Empty implies There Exists Maximal Element of Complement]]: :$\exists m \in \complement_S\left({F}\right): x \preceq m \land m = \max \complement_S\left({F}\right)$ Thus by [[Maximal Element of Complement of Filter is Meet Irreducible]]: :$m$ is [[Definition:Meet Irreducible|meet irreducible]]. Thus :$x \preceq m$ Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$y \preceq m$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Set|upper set]]: :$m \in F$ This contradicts $m \in \complement_S\left({F}\right)$ by definition of [[Definition:Greatest Element|greatest element]]. {{qed}}

statement: While it is true that the [[Definition:Cayley Table|Cayley table]] of a [[Definition:Finite Group|(finite) group]] is in the form of a [[Definition:Latin Square|Latin square]] it is not necessarily the case that a [[Definition:Latin Square|Latin square]] is the [[Definition:Cayley Table|Cayley table]] of a [[Definition:Group|group]].
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be the [[Definition:Algebraic Structure|algebraic structure]] defined by the following [[Definition:Cayley Table|Cayley table]]: :$\begin{array}{c|ccccc} \circ & e & a & b & c & d \\ \hline e & e & a & b & c & d  \\ a & a & e & d & b & c  \\ b & b & c & e & d & a  \\ c & c & d & a & e & b  \\ d & d & b & c & a & e  \\ \end{array}$ By inspection it can be seen that the [[Definition:Cayley Table|Cayley table]] for $\struct {S, \circ}$ is a [[Definition:Latin Square|Latin square]]. However, we have that: :$\paren {a \circ b} \circ c = d \circ c = a$ :$a \circ \paren {b \circ c} = a \circ d = c$ Thus $\circ$ is not an [[Definition:Associative Operation|associative operation]]. So, by definition, $\struct {S, \circ}$ is not a [[Definition:Group|group]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\order g = n\).
rationale: === Necessary Condition === Let \(m \perp n\). Then by [[Bézout's Lemma]]: :\(\exists x, y \in \Z: x m + y n = 1\) Let \(h = g^m\). Then: :\(h^x = g^{m x} = g^{1 - y n} = g g^{- y n} = g e = g\) and so \(g\) is also a [[Definition:Power of Group Element|power]] of \(h\). Hence from [[Order of Group Element not less than Order of Power]]: :\(\order g \le \order h \le \order g\) and it follows that: :\(\order g = \order h\) {{qed|lemma}} === Sufficient Condition === We prove the [[Definition:Contrapositive Statement|contrapositive]]. Suppose \(m \not \perp n\). Then: :\(\exists d \in \Z_{>1}: \exists a, b \in \Z: m = a d \land n = b d\) Let \(h = g^m\). Then: :\(h^b = \paren {g^m}^{n/d} = g^{a n} = \paren {g^n}^a = e^a = e\) Hence: :\(\order h \le b < n\) and it follows that: :\(\order g \ne \order h\) {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \struct {S, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a [[Definition:Meet Semilattice|meet semilattice]]. Let $p \in S$, Then: :$p$ is [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]] {{iff}}: :for all [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]] [[Definition:Subset|subsets]] $A$ of $S$: ::if $\inf A \preceq p$, then there exists [[Definition:Element|element]] $x$ of $A$ such that $x \preceq p$.
rationale:
=== Sufficient Condition === Let $p$ be [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]]. Let $A$ be [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]] [[Definition:Subset|subsets]] of $S$. Define :$\map P X : \equiv X 
e \O \land \inf X \preceq p \implies \exists x \in X: x \preceq p$ where $X \subseteq S$. We will prove that :$ orall x \in A, B \subseteq A: \map P B \implies \map P {B \cup \set x}$ Let $x \in A, B \subseteq A$ such that :$\map P B$ and :$B \cup \set x 
e \O$ and $\map \inf {B \cup \set x} \preceq p$ Case $B = \O$. By [[Union with Empty Set]]: :$B \cup \set x = \set x$ By [[Infimum of Singleton]]: :$\inf \set x = x$ By definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$x \in \set x$ Thus :$\exists z \in B \cup \set x: z \preceq p$ {{qed|lemma}} Case $B 
e \O$. By [[Subset of Finite Set is Finite]]: :$B$ is [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]]. By [[Existence of Non-Empty Finite Infima in Meet Semilattice]]: :$B, \set x$ admit [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infima]]. By [[Infimum of Infima]]: :$\map \inf {B \cup \set x} = \inf B \wedge \inf \set x$ By definition of [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]]: :$\inf B \preceq p$ or $x \preceq p$ Case $\inf B \preceq p$. By assumption: :$\exists z \in B: z \preceq p$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Union|union]]: :$z \in B \cup \set x$ Thus :$\exists z \in B \cup \set x: z \preceq p$ {{qed|lemma}} Case $x \preceq p$. By definitions of [[Definition:Set Union|union]] and [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$x \in B \cup \set x$ Thus :$\exists z \in B \cup \set x: z \preceq p$ {{qed|lemma}} By definition of [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]]: :$\map P \O$ By [[Induction of Finite Set]]: :$\map P A$ Thus :if $\inf A \preceq p$, then there exists [[Definition:Element|element]] $x$ of $A$ such that $x \preceq p$. {{qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === Suppose that :for all [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]] [[Definition:Subset|subsets]] $A$ of $S$: ::if $\inf A \preceq p$, then there exists [[Definition:Element|element]] $x$ of $A$ such that $x \preceq p$. Let $x, y \in S$ such that :$x \wedge y \preceq p$ Define $A := \set {x, y}$ By definitions of [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty set]] and [[Definition:Finite Set|finite set]]: :$A$ is [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$. By definition of [[Definition:Meet (Order Theory)|meet]]: :$\inf A = x \wedge y$ By assumption: :$\exists z \in A: z \preceq p$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Unordered Tuple|unordered tuple]]: :$x \preceq p$ or $y \preceq p$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $\SS = \family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be an [[Definition:Indexed Family|indexed family]] of [[Definition:Topological Space|topological spaces]] where $I$ is an arbitrary [[Definition:Indexing Set|index set]]. Let $\displaystyle T = \struct{S, \tau} = \prod \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be the [[Definition:Product Space of Topological Spaces|product space]] of \SS. Then $T$ is a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]] {{iff}} each of $\struct{S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ is a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]].
rationale:
=== Sufficient Condition === Suppose $\exists  eta: \struct {S_ eta, 	au_ eta}$ is not a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ space]]. Then $\exists a, b \in S_ eta$ such that  orall U_ eta \in 	au_ eta$, either $a, b \in U_ eta$ or $a, b 
otin U_ eta$. Consider the elements $y, z \in S$ defined as: :$y =  amily {x_\alpha} : x_\alpha =  egin {cases} s_\alpha & : \alpha 
e  eta \ a & : \alpha =  eta \end {cases}$ :$z =  amily {x_\alpha} : x_\alpha =  egin {cases} s_\alpha & : \alpha 
e  eta \ b & : \alpha =  eta \end {cases}$ That is, $y$ and $z$ match (arbitrarily) on all ordinates except that for $ eta$. Let $H \subseteq S: y \in H$. Then $z \in H$ as $ orall U_ eta \in \map {\pr_ eta} H : b \in U_ eta$ Similarly, let $K \subseteq S: z \in K$. Then $y \in K$ as $ orall U_ eta \in \map {\pr_ eta} H : a \in U_ eta$ So $T$ is not a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]]. {{qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === Suppose $T$ is not a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]]. Then $\exists a, b \in S, a 
e b$ such that for all $U \in 	au$, either $a, b \in U$ or $a, b 
otin U$. Then $a$ and $b$ are different in at least one ordinate. Suppose, $a_m = p, b_m = q$ for some ordinate $m$. Then either $a_m, b_m \in U_m$ or $a_m, b_m 
otin U_m$. It follows that $\struct{S_m, 	au_m}$ is not a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]]. {{qed}}

statement: Not every [[Definition:Two-Person Zero-Sum Game|two-person zero-sum game]] has a [[Definition:Saddle Point (Game Theory)|saddle point]].
rationale: Consider the [[Definition:Matching Pennies|game of Matching Pennies]]. Recall its [[Definition:Matching Pennies/Payoff Table|payoff table]]: {{:Definition:Matching Pennies/Payoff Table}} Trivially, by inspection, this has no [[Definition:Entry in Payoff Table|entry]] which is the smallest [[Definition:Entry in Payoff Table|entry]] in its row and the largest [[Definition:Entry in Payoff Table|entry]] in its column. {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a [[Definition:Bounded Above Set|bounded above]] [[Definition:Lattice|lattice]]. Let $p \in S$ such that :$p \ne \top$ where $\top$ denotes the [[Definition:Top (Lattice Theory)|top]] of $L$. Then: :$p$ is a [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]] {{iff}} :$\relcomp S {p^\preceq}$ is [[Definition:Filter in Ordered Set|filter]] in $L$ where :$p^\preceq$ denotes the [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure]] of $p$ :$\relcomp S {p^\preceq}$ denotes the [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]] of $p^\preceq$ relative to $S$.
rationale:
=== Sufficient Condition === Assume that $p$ is a [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]]. By definition of the [[Definition:Greatest Element|greatest element]]: :$p \preceq 	op$ By definition of \prec$: :$p \prec 	op$ By definition of [[Definition:Antisymmetric Relation|antisymmetry]]: :$	op 
preceq p$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$	op 
otin p^\preceq$ By definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]]: :$	op \in elcomp S {p^\preceq}$ By definition :$X := elcomp S {p^\preceq}$ is a [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty set]] We will prove that :$X$ is [[Definition:Filtered Subset|filtered]]. Let $x, y \in X$. By definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]]: :$x 
otin p^\preceq$ and $y 
otin p^\preceq$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$x 
preceq p$ and $y 
preceq p$ Then by definition of [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]]: :$x \wedge y 
preceq p$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$x \wedge y 
otin p^\preceq$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]]: :$x \wedge y \in X$ Thus by [[Meet Precedes Operands]]: :$x \wedge y \preceq x$ and $x \wedge y \preceq y$ Thus :$\exists z \in X: z \preceq x \land z \preceq y$ {{qed|lemma}} We will prove that $X$ is an [[Definition:Upper Set|upper set]]. Let $x \in X, y \in S$ such that: :$x \preceq y$ By definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]]: :$x 
otin p^\preceq$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$x 
preceq p$ By definition of [[Definition:Transitivity|transitivity]]: :$y 
preceq p$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$y 
otin p^\preceq$ Thud by definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]]: :$y \in X$ {{qed|lemma}} Hence, by definition, $X$ is [[Definition:Filter in Ordered Set|filter]] in $L$. {{qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === Assume that $elcomp S {p^\preceq}$ is [[Definition:Filter in Ordered Set|filter]] in $L$. Let $x, y \in S$ such that: :$x \wedge y \preceq p$ {{AimForCont}} that: :$x 
preceq p$ and $y 
preceq p$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: $x 
otin p^\preceq$ and $y 
otin p^\preceq$ By definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]]: :$x \in elcomp S {p^\preceq}$ and $y \in elcomp S {p^\preceq}$ By definition of [[Definition:Filtered Subset|filtered]]: :$\exists z \in elcomp S {p^\preceq}: z \preceq x 	ext { and } z \preceq y$ Then: $z \preceq x \wedge y$ By definition of [[Definition:Transitivity|transitivity]]: :$z \preceq p$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Set|upper set]]: :$p \in elcomp S {p^\preceq}$ By definition of [[Definition:Reflexivity|reflexivity]]: :$p \preceq p$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$p \in p^\preceq$ This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] $p \in elcomp S {p^\preceq}$. Hence it is not the case that $x 
preceq p$ and $y 
preceq p$. That is: :$x \preceq p$ or $y \preceq p$ and so, by definition, $p$ is a [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]] of \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}. {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Boolean Lattice|Boolean lattice]]. Let $p \in S$ such that :$p \ne \top$ Then :$p$ is [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]] {{iff}} :$\forall x \in S: \left({ p \prec x \implies x = \top }\right)$
rationale:
=== Sufficient Condition === Suppose that :$p$ is [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]] Let $x \in S$ such that :$p \prec x$ By definition of [[Definition:Boolean Lattice|Boolean lattice]]: :$L$ is [[Definition:Complemented Lattice|complemented]] [[Definition:Distributive Lattice|distributive lattice]]. By definition of [[Definition:Complemented Lattice|complemented]]: :$\exists y \in S: y$ is [[Definition:Complement (Lattice Theory)|complement]] of $x$. By definition of [[Definition:Complement (Lattice Theory)|complement]] :$x \wedge y =  ot$ By definition of [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]]: :$x \wedge y \preceq p$ By definition of [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]]: :$x \preceq p$ or $y \preceq p$ Then by definition of [[Definition:Antisymmetric Relation|antisymmetry]]: :$y \prec x$ By definition of $\prec$: :$y \preceq x$ By definition of [[Definition:Complement (Lattice Theory)|complement]]: :$x \vee y = 	op$ Thus by [[Preceding iff Join equals Larger Operand]]: :$x = 	op$ {{qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === Suppose that :$ orall x \in S: \left({ p \prec x \implies x = 	op }ight)$ Let $x, y \in S$ such that :$x \wedge y \preceq p$ {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = p | r = p \vee \left({x \wedge y}ight) | c = [[Preceding iff Join equals Larger Operand]] }} {{eqn | r = \left({p \vee x}ight) \wedge \left({p \vee y}ight) | c = definition of [[Definition:Distributive Lattice|distributive lattice]] }} {{end-eqn}} Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$x 
preceq p$ and $y 
preceq p$ By [[Preceding iff Join equals Larger Operand]]: :$p 
e p \vee y$ and $p 
e p \vee x$ By [[Join Succeeds Operands]]: :$p \preceq p \vee y$ and $p \preceq p \vee x$ By definition of $\prec$: :$p \prec p \vee y$ and $p \prec p \vee x$ By assumption: :$p \vee y = 	op$ and $p \vee x = 	op$ By [[Meet is Idempotent]]: :$p = 	op$ This contradicts $p 
e 	op$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a [[Definition:Lattice|lattice]]. Let $I$ be an [[Definition:Ideal (Order Theory)|ideal]] in $L$. Then: :$I$ is a [[Definition:Prime Ideal (Order Theory)|prime ideal]] {{iff}}: :$I$ is a [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]] in \struct {\map {\mathit {Ids} } L, \precsim}$ where: :$\map {\mathit {Ids} } L$ denotes the [[Definition:Set of Sets|set]] of all [[Definition:Ideal (Order Theory)|ideals]] in $L$ :$\mathord \precsim := \mathord \subseteq \restriction_{\map {\mathit {Ids} } L \times \map {\mathit {Ids} } L}$
rationale:
=== Sufficient Condition === Let $I$ be a [[Definition:Prime Ideal (Order Theory)|prime ideal]]. Let $x, y \in \map {\mathit {Ids} } L$ such that :$x \wedge y \precsim I$ By definition of $\precsim$: :$x \wedge y \subseteq I$ By [[Meet is Intersection in Set of Ideals]]: :$x \cap y \subseteq I$ {{AimForCont}}: :$x 
ot \precsim I$ and $y 
ot \precsim I$ By definition of $\precsim$: $x 
subseteq I$ and $y 
subseteq I$ By definition of [[Definition:Subset|subset]]: :$\exists a \in x: a 
otin I$ and :$\exists b \in y: b 
otin I$ By [[Meet Precedes Operands]]: :$a \wedge b \preceq a$ and $a \wedge b \preceq b$ By definition [[Definition:Lower Set|lower set]]: :$a \wedge b \in x$ and $a \wedge b \in y$ By definitions [[Definition:Subset|subset]] and [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: :$a \wedge b \in I$ By [[Characterization of Prime Ideal]]: :$a \in I$ or $b \in I$ This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] $a 
otin I$ and $b 
otin I$ Hence the assumption: :$x 
ot \precsim I$ and $y 
ot \precsim I$ was false. {{qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === Let $I$ be [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]] in \struct {\map {\mathit {Ids} } L, \precsim}$ Let $x, y \in S$ such that: :$x \wedge y \in I$ By [[Lower Closure of Element is Ideal]]: :$X := x^\preceq$ and $Y := y^\preceq$ are [[Definition:Ideal (Order Theory)|ideals]] in $L$ By [[Meet is Intersection in Set of Ideals]]: :$X \cap Y = X \wedge Y$ We will prove that: :$X \wedge Y \subseteq I$ Let $a \in X \wedge Y$. By definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: :$a \in X$ and $a \in Y$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$a \preceq x$ and $a \preceq y$ By definition of [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]]: :$a \preceq x \wedge y$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Lower Set|lower set]]: :$a \in I$ {{qed|lemma}} By definition of $\precsim$: :$X \wedge Y \precsim I$ By definition of [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]]: :$X \precsim I$ or $Y \precsim I$ By definition of $\precsim$: :$X \subseteq I$ or $Y \subseteq I$ By definition of [[Definition:Reflexive Relation|reflexivity]]: :$x \preceq x$ and $y \preceq y$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$x \in X$ and $y \in Y$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Subset|subset]]: :$x \in I$ or $y \in I$ Hence by [[Characterization of Prime Ideal]]: :$I$ is [[Definition:Prime Ideal (Order Theory)|prime ideal]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $B = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \neg, \preceq}$ be a [[Definition:Boolean Lattice|Boolean lattice]]. Let $F$ be a [[Definition:Filter|filter]] in $B$. Then :$F$ is [[Definition:Prime Filter (Order Theory)|prime]] {{iff}} :$\forall x \in S: x \in F \lor \left({\neg x}\right) \in F$

The corresponding proof:We have been given that $r > 1$. Let \dfrac 1 r + \dfrac 1 s = 1$. Then: :$s = \dfrac r {r - 1}$ It is to be shown that every [[Definition:Positive Integer|positive integer]] lies in exactly one of the two [[Definition:Beatty Sequence|Beatty sequences]] \BB_r and \BB_s.
rationale: Consider the [[Definition:Ordinal Number|ordinal positions]] occupied by all the [[Definition:Fraction|fractions]] \dfrac j r and \dfrac k s when they are jointly listed in nondecreasing order for [[Definition:Positive Integer|positive integers]] j and k. {{AimForCont}} that \dfrac j r = \dfrac k s for some j, k \in \Z_{>0}. Then: :\dfrac r s = \dfrac j k which is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]]. But also: :\dfrac r s = r \paren {1 - \dfrac 1 r} = r - 1 which is not [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]]. Therefore, no two of the numbers occupy the same position. Consider some \dfrac j r. There are j numbers \dfrac i r \le \dfrac j r. There are also \floor {\dfrac {j s} r} numbers \dfrac k s \le \dfrac j r. So the position of \dfrac j r in the list is j + \floor {\dfrac {j s} r}. The equation \dfrac 1 r + \dfrac 1 s = 1 implies: :j + \floor {\dfrac {j s} r} = j + \floor {j \paren {s - 1} } = \floor {j s} Likewise, the position of \dfrac k s in the list is \floor {k r}. It is concluded that every [[Definition:Positive Integer|positive integer]] corresponding to every position in the list is of the form \floor {n r} or of the form \floor {n r}, but not both. The converse statement is also true: if p and q are two [[Definition:Real Number|real numbers]] such that every [[Definition:Positive Integer|positive integer]] occurs precisely once in the above list, then p and q are [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational]] and the sum of their [[Definition:Reciprocal|reciprocals]] is 1. {{qed}}

statement: Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a [[Definition:Strictly Positive Integer|(strictly) positive integer]]. Then $n$ can be expressed as the [[Definition:Integer Addition|sum]] of $2$ or more consecutive [[Definition:Strictly Positive Integer|(strictly) positive integers]] {{iff}} $n$ is not a [[Definition:Integer Power|power]] of $2$.
rationale: === Necessary Condition === Let $a$ be the smallest of $m$ consecutive [[Definition:Strictly Positive Integer|(strictly) positive integers]], where $m \ge 2$. From [[Sum of Arithmetic Sequence]], their [[Definition:Integer Addition|sum]] is \dfrac {m \paren {2 a + m - 1} } 2.  {{AimForCont}} \dfrac {m \paren {2 a + m - 1} } 2 is a [[Definition:Integer Power|power]] of $2$. Then $m$ and $2 a + m - 1$ must also be [[Definition:Integer Power|powers]] of $2$. Since $m \ge 2$, $m$ must be [[Definition:Even Integer|even]]. Then $2 a + m - 1$ is [[Definition:Odd Integer|odd]]. Together with $2 a + m - 1$ being a [[Definition:Integer Power|power]] of $2$, we have $2 a + m - 1 = 1$. However, $2 a + m - 1 > 2 \times 0 + 2 - 1 = 1$. This is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Therefore any [[Definition:Integer Addition|sum]] of $2$ or more consecutive [[Definition:Integer|integers]] cannot be a [[Definition:Integer Power|power]] of $2$. {{qed|lemma}} === Sufficient Condition === Let $n$ be an [[Definition:Integer|integer]] that is not a [[Definition:Integer Power|power]] of $2$. Then $n$ contains an [[Definition:Odd Integer|odd]] [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|factor]] greater than $1$. Let $d = 2 m + 1$ be such a [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|factor]]. Then: :\dfrac n d - m, \dfrac n d - m + 1, \dots, \dfrac n d + m is a [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] of $2 m + 1$ consecutive [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. From [[Sum of Arithmetic Sequence]]: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \paren {\dfrac n d - m} + \paren {\dfrac n d - m + 1} + \cdots + \paren {\dfrac n d + m}       | r = \dfrac {\paren {2 m + 1} \paren {\dfrac n d - m + \dfrac n d + m} } 2       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \dfrac d 2 \times \dfrac {2 n} d       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = n       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} It may happen that \dfrac n d - m \le 0. In that case, notice that: :\dfrac n d - m \le m - \dfrac n d \le \dfrac n d + m and so $m - \dfrac n d$ is also (somewhere) in our [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] of $2 m + 1$ consecutive [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. So all [[Definition:Negative Integer|negative integers]] in our [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] of $2 m + 1$ consecutive [[Definition:Integer|integers]] cancel out with their [[Definition:Positive Integer|positive]] counterparts. Hence we can remove all numbers from \dfrac n d - m to $m - \dfrac n d$. As a result of that process, the sum remains unchanged. We see that the number of [[Definition:Integer|integers]] eliminated is $2 \paren {m - \dfrac n d} + 1$. Since \dfrac n d is a [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|factor]] of $n$, we have \dfrac n d \ge 1. Hence the number of [[Definition:Integer|integers]] remaining is: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = 2 m + 1 - \paren {2 \paren {m - \dfrac n d} + 1}       | r = \dfrac {2 n} d }} {{eqn | o = \ge       | r = 2 }} {{end-eqn}} This finishes our proof. {{qed}}

statement: Let $n \in \Z_{> 1}$ be a [[Definition:Strictly Positive Integer|(strictly) positive integer]]. Then: :$\paren {n - 1} n \paren {n + 1}$ cannot be expressed in the form $a^k$ for $a, k \in \Z$ where $k \ge 2$. That is, the [[Definition:Multiplication|product]] of $3$ consecutive [[Definition:Strictly Positive Integer|(strictly) positive integers]] can never be a [[Definition:Perfect Power|perfect power]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} $\paren {n - 1} n \paren {n + 1} = a^k$ for $a, k \in \Z$ where $k \ge 2$. We have that: :$\gcd \set {n − 1, n} = 1 = \gcd \set {n, n + 1}$ Thus $n$ must itself be a [[Definition:Perfect Power|perfect power]] of the form $z^k$ for some $z \in \Z$. That means $\paren {n - 1} \paren {n + 1} = n^2 - 1$ must also be a [[Definition:Perfect Power|perfect power]] of the same form. Let: :$n = r^k$ and $n^2 − 1 = s^k$ for $r, s \in \Z$. Then: :$\paren {r^2}^k = 1 + s^k$ But the only consecutive [[Definition:Integer|integers]] that are $k$th powers are (trivially) $0$ and $1$. Hence by [[Proof by Contradiction]] there can be no such $n$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $AB$ be a [[Definition:Diameter of Circle|diameter]] of a [[Definition:Circle|circle]] $ADBE$ whose [[Definition:Center of Circle|center]] is at $C$. By definition of [[Definition:Diameter of Circle|diameter]], $AB$ passes through $C$.

Take a [[Definition:Strictly Positive Integer|(strictly) positive integer]] $n$, written in conventional [[Definition:Decimal Notation|decimal notation]]. Let $m$ be the [[Definition:Reversal|reversal]] of $n$. Let $m = k n$ where $k$ is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]. Then $k$ is either $4$ or $9$.
rationale: === Existence === $8712 = 4 \times 2178$ $9801 = 9 \times 1089$ === Uniqueness === Write $n = \sqbrk {a \dots b}$. Then $m = \sqbrk {b \dots a} = k n$. Comparing the leftmost [[Definition:Digit|digit]], we must have $k a \le b < k \paren {a + 1}$. Hence $k a < 10$. Comparing the rightmost [[Definition:Digit|digit]], we must have $a \equiv k b \pmod {10}$. We only consider $2 \le k < 10$ since the case $k = 1$ is trivially satisfied by [[Definition:Palindrome|palindromes]]. For $k \ge 5$, we must have $a = 1$. $1 \equiv k b \pmod {10}$ has solutions only for $k = 7$ or $9$. For $k = 7$, we must have $b = 3$. However $3 < 7 \times 1$. Hence $k = 9$. {{qed|lemma}} For $k = 3$, $a \le 3$. From $a \equiv 3 b \pmod {10}$ we have: :$\tuple {a, b} = \tuple {1, 7}, \tuple {2, 4}, \tuple {3, 1}$ However none of the above satisfy the condition: :$3 a \le b < 3 \paren {a + 1}$ {{qed|lemma}} For $k = 2$, $a \le 4$. From $a \equiv 2 b \pmod {10}$, both sides must be [[Definition:Even Integer|even]]. Hence $a = 2$ or $4$, giving $b = 1$ or $6$ or $2$ or $7$. However none of the above satisfy the condition: :$2 a \le b < 2 \paren {a + 1}$ {{qed|lemma}} Hence the only possible values of $k$ are $4$ and $9$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $p$ be a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime number]] greater than $3$. Then $p$ is either of the form: :$p = 6 n + 1$ or: :$p = 6 n - 1$ That is: :$p = \pm 1 \pmod 6$
rationale: To demonstrate that there are [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]] of either form, note: :$5 = 6 \\times 1 - 1$ :$7 = 6 \\times 1 + 1$ The only other possibilities for $p$ are: :$p = 6 n$, in which case $6 \\divides p$ and so $p$ is not [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] :$p = 6 n + 2$, in which case $2 \\divides p$ and so $p$ is not [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] :$p = 6 n + 3$, in which case $3 \\divides p$ and so $p$ is not [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] :$p = 6 n + 4$, in which case $2 \\divides p$ and so $p$ is not [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] :$p = 6 n + 5$, which is the same as $p = 6 \\paren {n + 1} - 1$, which is covered above. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $n \in \Z_{> 0}$ be a [[Definition:Strictly Positive Integer|(strictly) positive integer]]. Then there exists either one or two [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci numbers]] between $n$ and $2 n$ inclusive.
rationale: First existence is demonstrated. Let $F_m \ge n$ such that $F_{m - 1} < n$. {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = F_m | r = F_{m - 1} + F_{m - 2} | c = Definition of [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci Numbers]] }} {{eqn | o = < | r = 2 F_{m - 1} | c = as $F_{m - 2} < F_{m - 1}$ }} {{eqn | o = < | r = 2 n | c = as $F_{m - 1} < n$ }} {{end-eqn}} This shows that the smallest [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci number]] greater than $n$ is less than $2 n$. Thus there exists at least one [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci number]] between $n$ and $2 n$. {{AimForCont}} there exist $3$ [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci numbers]] between $n$ and $2 n$. Let $F_m \ge n$ be the smallest of those [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci numbers]]. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = F_{m + 2} | r = F_m + F_{m + 1} | c = Definition of [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci Numbers]] }} {{eqn | o = > | r = 2 F_m | c = as $F_m < F_{m + 1}$ }} {{eqn | o = > | r = 2 n | c = as $F_m > n$ }} {{end-eqn}} But $F_{m + 2} < 2 n$ [[Definition:By Hypothesis|by hypothesis]]. Hence by [[Proof by Contradiction]] there can be no more than $2$ [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci numbers]] between $n$ and $2 n$. Let $n = 2$. Then between $2$ and $4$ there exist $F_3 = 2$ and $F_4 = 3$. Let $n = 10$. Then between $10$ and $20$ there exists $F_7 = 13$ and no other [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci numbers]]. Thus it has been demonstrated: :There always exists at least one [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci number]] between $n$ and $2 n$ :There never exist more than $2$ [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci number]] between $n$ and $2 n$ :There exist $n$ such that there exists exactly one [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci number]] between $n$ and $2 n$ :There exist $n$ such that there exist exactly $2$ [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci numbers]] between $n$ and $2 n$. The result is complete. {{qed}}

statement: Let $F_n$ denote the $n$th [[Definition:Fibonacci Number|Fibonacci number]]. Let $F_n$ be a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime number]]. Then, apart from $F_4 = 3$, $n$ is a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime number]].
rationale: Let $F_n$ be a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime number]]. {{AimForCont}} $n$ is a [[Definition:Composite Number|composite number]] greater than $4$. Then $n = r s$ for some $1 < r, s < n$. Except for the case where $n = 4$, at least one of $r$ and $s$ is greater than $2$. From [[Divisibility of Fibonacci Number]]: :$F_r \divides F_n$ and: :$F_s \divides F_n$ where \divides denotes [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisibility]]. When $k > 2$ we have that $F_k > 1$. Thus when $n$ is [[Definition:Composite Number|composite]] such that $n > 4$, $F_n$ has at least one [[Definition:Proper Divisor of Integer|proper divisor]]. That is, $F_n$ is not [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]]. Thus by [[Proof by Contradiction]], $n$ cannot be [[Definition:Composite Number|composite]]. The exception is when $n = 4$, as noted above in which case its only [[Definition:Proper Divisor of Integer|proper divisor]] is $2$. But $F_2 = 1$, and so [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisibility]] by $F_2$ does not preclude [[Definition:Prime Number|primality]]. Indeed, $F_4 = 3$, which is [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $p \in \Z_{>0}$ be a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime number]]. Let $F_p$ be the $p$th [[Definition:Fibonacci Numbers|Fibonacci number]]. Then $F_p$ is not itself necessarily [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]].
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: :$F_{19} = 4181 = 37 \times 113$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $m, n \in \Z$ be [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. Suppose $\size m, \size n \ge 3$. Let $F_m$ and $F_n$ be the $m$th and $n$th [[Definition:Fibonacci Number|Fibonacci numbers]]. Then $F_m \times F_n$ is not a [[Definition:Fibonacci Number|Fibonacci number]].
rationale: From [[Fibonacci Number in terms of Smaller Fibonacci Numbers]], we have that: :$F_n = F_{k - 1} F_{n - k + 2} + F_{k - 2} F_{n - k + 1}$ for $2 \\le k \\le n$. {{AimForCont}} $F_n = F_m F_k$ for some $m, k \\ge 3$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = F_m | r = \\dfrac {F_n} {F_k} | c = }} {{eqn | r = \\dfrac {F_{k - 1} F_{n - k + 2} + F_{k - 2} F_{n - k + 1} } {F_k} | c = }} {{eqn | r = \\paren {\\dfrac {F_{k - 1} } {F_{k - 1} + F_{k - 2} } } F_{n - k + 2} + \\paren {\\dfrac {F_{k - 2} } {F_{k - 1} + F_{k - 2} } } F_{n - k + 1} | c = }} {{end-eqn}} The {{RHS}} is a [[Definition:Weighted Mean|weighted mean]] of $2$ consecutive [[Definition:Fibonacci Number|Fibonacci numbers]]. Thus: :$F_{n - k + 2} < F_m < F_{n - k + 1}$ which cannot happen. The result follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Distributive Lattice|distributive lattice]]. Let $I$ be an [[Definition:Ideal (Order Theory)|ideal]] in $L$. Let $x$ be an [[Definition:Element|element]] of $S$. Suppose $x \notin I$ Then there exists a [[Definition:Prime Ideal (Order Theory)|prime ideal]] $P$ in $L$: $I \subseteq P$ and $x \notin P$
rationale: By [[Upper Closure of Element is Filter]]: :$x^\succeq$ is a [[Definition:Filter|filter]]. Wr will prove that :$I \cap x^\succeq = \varnothing$ Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$\exists y: y \in I \cap x^\succeq$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: :$y \in I$ and $y \in x^\succeq$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure/Element|upper closure of element]]: :$x \preceq y$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Set|lower set]]: :$x \in I$ This contradicts $x \notin I$ {{qed|lemma}} Thus by [[If Ideal and Filter are Disjoint then There Exists Prime Ideal Including Ideal and Disjoint from Filter]]: :there exists [[Definition:Prime Ideal (Order Theory)|prime ideal]] $P$ in $L$: $I \subseteq P$ and $P \cap x^\succeq = \varnothing$ By definition of [[Definition:Reflexivity|reflexivity]]: :$x \preceq x$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure/Element|upper closure of element]]: :$x \in x^\succeq$ Thus by definitions of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]] and [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]]: :$x \notin P$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Bounded Below Set|bounded below]] [[Definition:Continuous Ordered Set|continuous]] [[Definition:Lattice|lattice]] such that :$\ll$ is [[Definition:Multiplicative Relation|multiplicative relation]] where $\ll$ denotes the [[Definition:Element is Way Below|way below relation]] of $L$. Let $p \in S$. Then $p$ is a [[Definition:Pseudoprime (Order Theory)|pseudoprime element]] is a [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]].
rationale:
Let $p$ be a [[Definition:Pseudoprime (Order Theory)|pseudoprime element]]. Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$p$ is not a [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]]. By definition of [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]]: :$\exists x, y \in S: x \wedge y \preceq p$ and $x 
preceq p$ and $y 
preceq p$ By definition of [[Definition:Continuous Ordered Set|continuous]]: :$ orall z \in S: z^\ll$ is [[Definition:Directed Subset|directed]]. and :$L$ satisfies [[Definition:Axiom of Approximation|axiom of approximation]]. By [[Axiom of Approximation in Up-Complete Semilattice]]: :$\exists u \in S: u \ll x \land u 
preceq p$ and :$\exists v \in S: v \ll y \land v 
preceq p$ By [[Way Below Relation is Auxiliary Relation]]: :$\ll$ is [[Definition:Auxiliary Relation|auxiliary relation]]. By [[Multiplicative Auxiliary Relation iff Congruent]]: :$u \wedge v \ll x \wedge y$ By definition of [[Definition:Transitivity|transitivity]]: :$u \wedge v \ll p$ By [[Characterization of Pseudoprime Element when Way Below Relation is Multiplicative]]: :$u \preceq p$ or $v \preceq p$ This contradicts $u 
preceq p$ and $v 
preceq p$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Bounded Below Set|bounded below]] [[Definition:Continuous Ordered Set|continuous]] [[Definition:Distributive Lattice|distributive lattice]]. Let every [[Definition:Element|element]] $p \in S$: $p$ is [[Definition:Pseudoprime (Order Theory)|pseudoprime]] $\implies p$ is [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime]]. Then $\ll$ is [[Definition:Multiplicative Relation|multiplicative]] where $\ll$ denotes the [[Definition:Element is Way Below|way below relation]] of $L$.
rationale:
Let $a, x, y \in S$ such that :$a \ll x$ and $a \ll y$ Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$a 
ot\ll x \wedge y$ We will prove that :$ orall z \in S: z \in \left({x \wedge y}ight)^\ll \implies z 
otin a^\succeq$ Let $z \in S$ such that :$z \in \left({x \wedge y}ight)^\ll$ By definition of [[Definition:Way Below Closure|way below closure]]: :$z \ll x \wedge y$ Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$z \in a^\succeq$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure/Element|upper closure of element]]: :$a \preceq z$ By [[Preceding and Way Below implies Way Below]] :$a \ll x \wedge y$ This contradicts $a 
ot\ll x \wedge y$ {{qed|lemma}} By definitions of [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]] and [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: :$\left({x \wedge y}ight)^\ll \cap a^\succeq = \varnothing$ By [[Way Below Closure is Ideal in Bounded Below Join Semilattice]]: :$\left({x \wedge y}ight)^\ll$ is [[Definition:Ideal (Order Theory)|ideal]] in $L$. By [[Upper Closure of Element is Filter]]: :$a^\succeq$ is [[Definition:Filter|filter]] on $L$. By [[If Ideal and Filter are Disjoint then There Exists Prime Ideal Including Ideal and Disjoint from Filter]]: :there exists [[Definition:Prime Ideal (Order Theory)|prime ideal]] $P$ in $L$: :$\left({x \wedge y}ight)^\ll \subseteq P$ and $P \cap a^\succeq = \varnothing$ By definition of [[Definition:Pseudoprime (Order Theory)|pseudoprime element]]: :$\sup P$ is [[Definition:Pseudoprime (Order Theory)|pseudoprime]]. By assumption: :$\sup P$ is [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime]]. By definition of [[Definition:Reflexivity|reflexivity]]: :$a \preceq a$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure/Element|upper closure of element]]: :$a \in a^\succeq$ By definition of [[Definition:Axiom of Approximation|axiom of approximation]]: :$\sup \left({x \wedge y}ight)^\ll = x \wedge y$ By definition of [[Definition:Up-Complete|up-complete]]: :$\left({x \wedge y}ight)^\ll$ admits a [[Definition:Supremum of Set|supremum]] and :$P$ admits a [[Definition:Supremum of Set|supremum]]. By [[Supremum of Subset]]: :$x \wedge y \preceq \sup P$ By definition of [[Definition:Prime Element (Order Theory)|prime element]]: :$x \preceq \sup P$ or $y \preceq \sup P$ By [[Way Below iff Second Operand Preceding Supremum of Ideal implies First Operand is Element of Ideal]]: :$a \in P$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]]: :$a \in P \cap a^\succeq$ This contradicts $P \cap a^\succeq = \varnothing$ {{qed}}

statement: The corresponding proof:From [[Complex Numbers form Integral Domain]], \struct {\C, +, \times} is an [[Definition:Integral Domain|integral domain]].
rationale: {{AimForCont}} that \struct {\C, +, \times} can be [[Definition:Ordered Integral Domain|ordered]]. Thus, by definition, it possesses a [[Definition:Strict Positivity Property|(strict) positivity property]] $P$. Then from [[Strict Positivity Property induces Total Ordering]], let \le be the [[Definition:Total Ordering Induced by Strict Positivity Property|total ordering induced by $P$]]. From [[Unity of Ordered Integral Domain is Strictly Positive]]: :$1$ is [[Definition:Strictly Positive|strictly positive]]. Thus by [[Definition:Strict Positivity Property|strict positivity, axiom $3$]]: :$-1$ is not [[Definition:Strictly Positive|strictly positive]]. Consider the [[Definition:Element|element]] $i \in \C$. By definition of [[Definition:Strict Positivity Property|strict positivity, axiom $3$]], either: :$i$ is [[Definition:Strictly Positive|strictly positive]] or: :$-i$ is [[Definition:Strictly Positive|strictly positive]]. Suppose $i$ is [[Definition:Strictly Positive|strictly positive]]. Then by [[Square of Non-Zero Element of Ordered Integral Domain is Strictly Positive]]: :$i^2 = -1$ is [[Definition:Strictly Positive|strictly positive]]. Similarly, suppose $-i$ is [[Definition:Strictly Positive|strictly positive]]. Then by [[Square of Non-Zero Element of Ordered Integral Domain is Strictly Positive]]: :$\paren {-i}^2 = -1$ is [[Definition:Strictly Positive|strictly positive]]. In both cases we have that $-1$ is [[Definition:Strictly Positive|strictly positive]]. But it has already been established that $-1$ is not [[Definition:Strictly Positive|strictly positive]]. Hence, by [[Proof by Contradiction]], there can be no such [[Definition:Ordered Integral Domain|ordering]]. {{qed}}

statement: [[Definition:Composition of Relations|Composition]] of [[Definition:Relation|relations]] is, in general, not [[Definition:Commutative Operation|commutative]]: That is, it is usually the case that: :$\mathcal R_1 \circ \mathcal R_2 \ne \mathcal R_2 \circ \mathcal R_1$ for [[Definition:Relation|relations]] $\mathcal R_1$ and $\mathcal R_2$.
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let $\mathcal R_1 := \left({S, S, R_1}\right)$ and $\mathcal R_2 := \left({S, S, R_2}\right)$ be [[Definition:Relation|relations]] defined as: Let: :$S = \left\{ {0, 1, 2}\right\}$ :$R_1 = \left\{ {\left({0, 1}\right)}\right\}$ :$R_2 = \left\{ {\left({1, 2}\right)}\right\}$ We have that: :$\mathcal R_1 \circ \mathcal R_2 = \left({S, S, \left\{ {\left({0, 2}\right)}\right\} }\right\}$ while: :$\mathcal R_2 \circ \mathcal R_1 = \left({S, S, \varnothing}\right\}$ {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {S, \preceq}\) and \(\struct {T, \preccurlyeq}\) be [[Definition:Totally Ordered Set|tosets]]. Let \(f: S \to T\) and \(g: S \to T\) be [[Definition:Increasing Mapping|increasing mappings]] from \(S\) to \(T\). Let \(H \subseteq S\) be a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of \(S\). Let \(f\) and \(g\) [[Definition:Agreement of Mappings|agree]] on \(H\). Let \(K = f \sqbrk H\) be the [[Definition:Image of Subset under Mapping|image set]] of \(H\) under \(f\). Let the [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]] of \(K\) with every [[Definition:Set|set]] of the form: :\(\set {y \in T: u < y < v: u, v \in T, u < v}\) be [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]]. Then \(f = g\).
rationale: [[Definition:By Hypothesis|By hypothesis]], let the [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]] of \(K\) with every [[Definition:Set|set]] of the form: :\(\set {y \in T: u \prec y \prec v: u, v \in T, u \prec v}\) be [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]]. {{AimForCont}} \(f \ne g\). Then: :\(\exists x \in S: \map f x \ne \map g x\) {{WLOG}}, suppose that \(\map f x < \map g x\). Let: :\(a \in H\) such that \(a \preceq x\) :\(b \in H\) such that \(b \succeq x\) We have that \(f\) and \(g\) are [[Definition:Increasing Mapping|increasing]]. Thus: :\(\map f a \preccurlyeq \map f x\) :\(\map g b \succcurlyeq \map g x\) Thus no [[Definition:Element|element]] of \(H\) maps to the [[Definition:Set|set]]: :\(\set {y \in T: \map f x \prec y \prec \map g x}\) That is, the [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]] of \(K\) with this [[Definition:Set|set]], which is of the form: :\(\set {y \in T: u \prec y \prec v: u, v \in T, u \prec v}\) is [[Definition:Empty Set|empty]]. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] our hypothesis. Thus, by [[Proof by Contradiction]]: :\(f = g\) {{qed}}

statement: Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ and $\struct {T, \preccurlyeq}$ be [[Definition:Totally Ordered Set|tosets]]. Let $T$ be [[Definition:Order Complete Set|order complete]]. Let $H \subseteq S$ be a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$. Let $f: H \to T$ be an [[Definition:Increasing Mapping|increasing mapping]] from $H$ to $T$. Then: :$f$ has an [[Definition:Extension of Mapping|extension]] to $S$ which is [[Definition:Increasing Mapping|increasing]] {{iff}}: :for all $A \subseteq H$: if $A$ is [[Definition:Bounded Ordered Set|bounded in $S$]], then $f \sqbrk A$ is [[Definition:Bounded Ordered Set|bounded in $T$]] where $f \sqbrk A$ denotes the [[Definition:Image of Subset under Mapping|image set]] of $A$ under $f$.
rationale: === Necessary Condition === Suppose $f$ is such that it is not the case that: :for all $A \subseteq H$: if $A$ is [[Definition:Bounded Ordered Set|bounded in $S$]], then $f \sqbrk A$ is [[Definition:Bounded Ordered Set|bounded in $T$]]. [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let $S = \R_{>0}$ be the [[Definition:Set|set]] of all [[Definition:Strictly Positive Real Number|(strictly) positive real numbers]]. Let $H \subseteq S$ be the [[Definition:Open Real Interval|open real interval]] $H = \openint 0 1$. Let $T = H$. By the [[Definition:Real Number/Axiomatic Definition|axiomatic definition of real numbers]], $S$ and $T$ are [[Definition:Totally Ordered Set|totally ordered]]. From the [[Continuum Property]], $T$ is [[Definition:Order Complete Set|order complete]]. Let $f: H \to T$ be the [[Definition:Identity Mapping|identity mapping]]. Note that while $H$ has an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] in $S$, for example $1$ Let $y \in T$ be an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] of $f \sqbrk H$. By construction: :$y < 1$ and so: :$\exists \epsilon \in \R_{>0}: y + \epsilon = 1$ Thus: :$y < y + \dfrac \epsilon 2 < 1$ and so there exists $y' = y + \dfrac \epsilon 2 \in T$ such that: :$y < y'$ and such that: :$y' = \map f {y'} \in f \sqbrk H$ So $y$ is not an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] of $f \sqbrk H$. Thus $f \sqbrk H$ has no [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] in $T$. Let $g: S \to T$ be an [[Definition:Extension of Mapping|extension]] of $f$ to $S$. Consider $\map g 1$. We have that $1$ is an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] of $H$. Let $\map g 1 = y$. As $y \in \openint 0 1$ it follows that: :$y > 1$ and so: :$\exists \epsilon \in \R_{>0}: y + \epsilon = 1$ But then: :$y < y + \dfrac \epsilon 2 < 1$ and so: :$\map g 1 < \map g {y + \dfrac \epsilon 2}$ and so $g$ is not [[Definition:Increasing Mapping|increasing]]. Thus it has been demonstrated that if it is not the case that: :for all $A \subseteq H$: if $A$ is [[Definition:Bounded Ordered Set|bounded in $S$]], then $f \sqbrk A$ is [[Definition:Bounded Ordered Set|bounded in $T$]] where: :$\struct {S, \preceq}$ and $\struct {T, \preccurlyeq}$ be [[Definition:Totally Ordered Set|tosets]] and: :$T$ is [[Definition:Order Complete Set|order complete]] and: :$f: H \to T$ is an [[Definition:Increasing Mapping|increasing mapping]] from $H$ to $T$. and: :$H \subseteq S$ is a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$ then it is not necessarily the case that $f$ always has an [[Definition:Extension of Mapping|extension]] to $S$ which is [[Definition:Increasing Mapping|increasing]]. {{qed|lemma}} === Sufficient Condition === Let $f$ be such that: :for all $A \subseteq H$: if $A$ is [[Definition:Bounded Ordered Set|bounded in $S$]], then $f \sqbrk A$ is [[Definition:Bounded Ordered Set|bounded in $T$]]. An [[Definition:Increasing Mapping|increasing mapping]] $g: S \to T$ is to be constructed such that $g$ is an [[Definition:Extension of Mapping|extension]] of $f$. So, let $A \subseteq H$ such that $A$ is [[Definition:Bounded Ordered Set|bounded in $S$]]. Let $x \in A$. Consider the [[Definition:Set|set]]: :$A' = \set {y \in A: y \preceq x}$ $A'$ is [[Definition:Bounded Ordered Set|bounded in $S$]]: :[[Definition:Bounded Below Set|bounded below]] by a [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]] of $A$ :[[Definition:Bounded Above Set|bounded above]] by $y$. Thus [[Definition:By Hypothesis|by hypothesis]] $f \sqbrk {A'}$ is [[Definition:Bounded Ordered Set|bounded in $T$]]. A [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]] of $f \sqbrk {A'}$ is also a [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]] of $f \sqbrk A$. Similarly for [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bounds]]. {{explain|{{BookReference|General Topology|1955|John L. Kelley}}, from which this has been taken, is unclear here exactly what is being demonstrated by the above.}} For each $x \in S$ let $L_x$ be defined as: :$L_x = \set {y \in H: y \le x}$ Note that $L_x$ is [[Definition:Bounded Above Set|bounded above]] by $x$ by definition of [[Definition:Bounded Above Set|bounded above]]. Suppose $L_x = \O$. Then $x$ is a [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]] for $H$. Thus $f \sqbrk H$ has an [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]] $v$, and $\map g x$ can be defined as: :$\map g x = v$ Suppose $L_x \ne O$. We have that $x$ is an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]] of $L_x$. Hence [[Definition:By Hypothesis|by hypothesis]] $f \sqbrk {L_x}$ has an [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]]. As $T$ is [[Definition:Order Complete Set|order complete]], $f \sqbrk {L_x}$ admits a [[Definition:Supremum of Set|supremum]]. Thus $\map g x$ can be defined as: :$\map g x = \sup \set {f \sqbrk {L_x} }$ It remains to be proved that $g$ is an [[Definition:Increasing Mapping|increasing mapping]]. {{finish}}

statement: Let \(\Gamma\) denote the [[Definition:Gamma Function|gamma function]]. Let \(f \left({t}\right) = \Gamma \left({t+1}\right) = t!\). Then: :\(f\) is not of [[Definition:Exponential Order|exponential order]]. That is, it grows faster than any exponential.
rationale: From [[Gamma Function is Continuous on Positive Reals]], \(f\) is continuous for \(t \ge 0\). Set \(t > 0\). From [[Stirling's Formula]]: :\(\displaystyle t! \sim \sqrt {2 \pi t} \left({\frac t e}\right)^t\) where \(\sim\) denotes [[Definition:Asymptotically Equal|asymptotic equality]]. That is,  {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = t!       | o = \sim       | r = \sqrt {2 \pi t} \left({\frac t e}\right)^t }} {{eqn | o = >       | r = t^t \, e^{-t} }} {{end-eqn}} [[Proof by Contradiction|Seeking a contradiction]], assume \(t^t \, e^{-t}\) is of exponential order \(a\).  Then, for \(t\) [[Definition:Sufficiently Large|sufficiently large]], there exists a \(K>0\) such that: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l =  t^t \, e^{-t}       | o = <        | r = K e^{at} }} {{eqn | ll = \impliedby       | l = t^t       | o = <       | r = K e^{\left({a+1}\right)t} }} {{end-eqn}} This implies that \(t^t\) is of exponential order, [[X to the x is not of Exponential Order|which is false]]. From this contradiction it follows that \(t!\) is also not of exponential order. {{qed}} [[Category:Gamma Function]] [[Category:Exponential Order]]

statement: Let $f: \R \to \R$ be defined on $\hointr 0 \to$ with $\map f x = x^x$. Then: :$f$ is not of [[Definition:Exponential Order|exponential order]]. That is, it grows faster than any [[Definition:Exponential Function|exponential]].
rationale: === [[X to the x is not of Exponential Order/Lemma|Lemma]] === {{:X to the x is not of Exponential Order/Lemma}}{{qed|lemma}} By the definition of [[Definition:Power (Algebra)/Real Number|power]]: :$\map f t = \map \exp {t \ln t}$  The theorem is equivalent to that there do not exist [[Definition:Strictly Positive Real Number|strictly positive]] [[Definition:Real Number|real]] [[Definition:Constant|constants]] $M$, $K$, $a$ such that: :$\forall t \ge M: \size {\map f t} < K e^{a t}$ {{AimForCont}} such constants $M$, $K$ and $a$ exist. From the [[X to the x is not of Exponential Order/Lemma|lemma]], there exists a [[Definition:Constant|constant]] $C$ such that: :$\forall t > C: \size {\map f t} > K e^{a t}$ For any $M$ chosen, $M + C > C$, thus from the lemma: :$\size {\map f {M + C} } > K e^{a t}$ However, $M + C > M$, thus from the assumption: :$\size {\map f {M + C} } < K e^{a t}$ Thus a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] has arisen. It follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]] that our assumption was false. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $W$ denote the [[Definition:Lambert W Function|(general) Lambert W function]]. Let $a$ be a non-zero [[Definition:Algebraic Number|algebraic number]]. Then, $W \left({a}\right)$ is [[Definition:Transcendental|transcendental]].
rationale: From the definition of [[Definition:Lambert W Function|Lambert W function]]: :$a = W \left({a}\right) e^{W \left({a}\right)}$ {{AimForCont}} $W \left({a}\right)$ is not [[Definition:Transcendental|transcendental]]. Hence, $W \left({a}\right)$ is [[Definition:Algebraic Number|algebraic]]. From the [[Hermite-Lindemann-Weierstrass Theorem/Weaker|weaker Hermite-Lindemann-Weierstrass theorem]], $e^{W \left({a}\right)}$ is [[Definition:Transcendental|transcendental]]. However, from the equation above, it is also equal to: :$\dfrac a {W \left({a}\right)}$ which must be [[Definition:Algebraic Number|algebraic]], considering the fact that $a$ and $W \left({a}\right)$ are both [[Definition:Algebraic Number|algebraic]]. From this contradiction, it follows that $W \left({a}\right)$ must be [[Definition:Transcendental|transcendental]] whenever $a$ is a non-zero [[Definition:Algebraic Number|algebraic number]]. {{qed}} [[Category:Lambert W Function]] [[Category:Transcendental Number Theory]] 802x6rh25dp5ck883xvcfzybyt700pr

statement: [[Definition:Pi|Pi]] [[Definition:Square (Algebra)|squared]] ($\pi^2$) is [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational]].
rationale: A slightly modified proof of [[Pi is Irrational/Proof 2]] also proves it for $\pi^2$: {{AimForCont}} $\pi^2$ is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]]. Then $\pi^2 = \dfrac p q$ where $p$ and $q$ are [[Definition:Integer|integers]] and $q \ne 0$. Note that \paren {q \pi}^2 = q^2 \paren {\dfrac p q} = p q$ is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]. Now let: :$\displaystyle A_n = \frac {q^n} {n!} \int_0^\pi \paren {x \paren {\pi - x} }^n \sin x \rd x $ [[Integration by Parts]] twice gives: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = A_n       | r = \frac {q^n} {n!} \int_0^\pi n \paren {x \paren {\pi - x} }^{n - 1} \paren {\pi - 2 x} \cos x \rd x       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \frac {q^n} {n!} \int_0^\pi 2 n \paren {x \paren {\pi - x} }^{n - 1} \sin x - n \paren {n - 1} \paren {x \paren {\pi - x} }^{n - 2} \paren {\pi - 2 x}^2 \sin x \rd x       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} Writing: :$\paren {\pi - 2 x}^2 = \pi^2 - 4 x \paren {\pi - x}$ gives the result: :$(1): \quad A_n = \paren {4 n - 2} q A_{n - 1} - \paren {q \pi}^2 A_{n - 2}$  We will deduce that $A_n$ is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]] for all $n$. First confirm by direct integration that $A_0$ and $A_1$ are [[Definition:Integer|integers]]: :$\displaystyle A_0 = \int_0^\pi \sin x \rd x = 2$ :$\displaystyle A_1 = q \int_0^\pi x \paren {\pi - x} \sin x \rd x = 4 q$ Suppose $A_{k - 2}$ and $A_{k - 1}$ are [[Definition:Integer|integers]].  Then by $(1)$ and the assumption that $q$ and $\paren {q \pi}^2$ are [[Definition:Integer|integers]], $A_k$ is also an [[Definition:Integer|integer]].  So $A_n$ is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]] for all $n$ by [[Second Principle of Mathematical Induction]]. For $x \in \closedint 0 \pi$, we have: :$0 \le \sin x \le 1$ and: :$0 \le x \paren {\pi - x} \le \pi^2 / 4$ hence: :$0 < A_n < \pi \dfrac {\paren {q \pi^2 / 4}^n} {n!}$ From [[Power over Factorial]]: :$\displaystyle \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \frac {\paren {q \pi^2 / 4}^n} {n!} = 0$ It follows from the [[Squeeze Theorem]] that: :$\displaystyle \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} A_n = 0$ Hence for [[Definition:Sufficiently Large|sufficiently large]] $n$, $A_n$ is strictly between $0$ and $1$. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the supposition that $A_n$ is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]. It follows that $\pi^2$ is [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be of the form $4 k + 2$ for some $k \in \Z$. Then $n$ cannot be expressed in the form: :$n = a^2 - b^2$ for $a, b \in \Z$.
rationale: Let $n = a^2 - b^2$ for some $a, b \in \Z$. By [[Square Modulo 4]], both $a$ and $b$ are of the form $4 k$ or $4 k + 1$ for some [[Definition:Integer|integer]] $k$. There are $4$ cases: ;$a \equiv b \equiv 0 \pmod 4$: Then: :$a^2 - b^2 \equiv 0 \pmod 4$ and so $n$ is in the form $4 k$. ;$a \equiv 0 \pmod 4$, $b \equiv 1 \pmod 4$: Then: :$a^2 - b^2 \equiv -1 \pmod 4 \equiv 3 \pmod 4$ and so $n$ is in the form $4 k + 3$. ;$a \equiv 1 \pmod 4$, $b \equiv 0 \pmod 4$: Then: :$a^2 - b^2 \equiv 1 \pmod 4$ and so $n$ is in the form $4 k + 1$. ;$a \equiv b \equiv 1 \pmod 4$: Then: :$a^2 - b^2 \equiv 0 \pmod 4$ and so $n$ is in the form $4 k$. Thus it is never the case that $a^2 - b^2 = 4 k + 2$. {{qed}}

statement: There are [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinitely many]] [[Definition:Superabundant Number|superabundant numbers]].
rationale:
{{AimForCont}} the [[Definition:Set|set]] $S$ of [[Definition:Superabundant Number|superabundant numbers]] is [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]]. Let $m$ be the [[Definition:Greatest Element|greatest element]] of $S$. By definition of [[Definition:Superabundant Number|superabundant]], $m$ has the largest [[Definition:Abundancy Index|abundancy index]] of all the [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $S$.

Consider the [[Definition:Integer|integer]] $2 m$. From [[Abundancy Index of Product is greater than Abundancy Index of Proper Factors]], $2 m$ has a higher [[Definition:Abundancy Index|abundancy index]] than $m$.

There are two possibilities:

:$(1): \quad 2 m$ is the smallest [[Definition:Integer|integer]] greater that $n$ which has a higher [[Definition:Abundancy Index|abundancy index]] than $m$. By definition, that would make $m$ [[Definition:Superabundant Number|superabundant]].

:$(2) \quad$ There exists a [[Definition:Finite Set|finite set]] $T := \set {n \in \Z: m < n < 2 m: \map A n > \map A m}$, where $\map A n$ denotes the [[Definition:Abundancy Index|abundancy index]] of $n$. The [[Definition:Smallest Element|smallest element]] $t$ of $T$ therefore has an [[Definition:Abundancy Index|abundancy index]] greater than all smaller [[Definition:Positive Integer|positive integers]]. Thus by definition $t$ is [[Definition:Superabundant Number|superabundant]].

In either case, there exists a [[Definition:Superabundant Number|superabundant number]] not in $S$. Thus $S$ cannot contain all [[Definition:Superabundant Number|superabundant numbers]]. But this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] our initial assumption that the [[Definition:Set|set]] $S$, containing all [[Definition:Superabundant Number|superabundant numbers]] is [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]].

It follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]] that $S$ is [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite]]. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\alpha \left({x, y}\right)\), \(h \left({x, y}\right)\) be functions in \(\R\). Let \(\alpha \in C^0\) in a closed region \(R\) whose boundary is \(\Gamma\). Let \(h \in C^2\) in \(R\) and \(h = 0\) on \(\Gamma\). Let: : \(\displaystyle \int \int_R \alpha \left({x, y}\right) h \left({x, y}\right) \rd x \rd y = 0\) Then \(\alpha \left({x, y}\right)\) vanishes everywhere in \(R\).
rationale: {{AimForCont}} \alpha \left({x, y}\right) is nonzero at some point in R. Then \alpha \left({x, y}\right) is also nonzero in some [[Definition:Disk|disk]] D such that: :\left({x - x_0}\right)^2 + \left({y - y_0}\right)^2 \le \epsilon^2 Suppose: :\left({x, y}\right) = \operatorname {sgn} \left({\alpha \left({x, y}\right)}\right) \left({\epsilon^2 - \left({x - x_0}\right)^2 + \left({y - y_0}\right)^2}\right)^3 in this disk and 0 elsewhere. Thus h \left({x, y}\right) satisfies conditions of the theorem. However: :\displaystyle \int \int_R \alpha \left({x, y}\right) h \left({x, y}\right) \rd x \rd y = \int \int_D \left\vert{\alpha \left({x, y}\right)}\right\vert \left({\epsilon^2 - \left({x - x_0}\right)^2 + \left({y - y_0}\right)^2}\right)^3 \ge 0 Hence the result, by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an [[Definition:Up-Complete|up-complete]] [[Definition:Ordered Set|ordered set]]. Let $X$ be a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$ with [[Definition:Property (S)|property (S)]].
