Then $\complement_S\left({X}\right)$ is [[Definition:Closed under Directed Suprema|closed under directed suprema]].
rationale: Let $D$ be a [[Definition:Directed Subset|directed subset]] of $S$ such that :$D \subseteq \complement_S\left({X}\right)$ Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$\sup D \notin \complement_S\left({X}\right)$ By definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]]: :$\sup D \in X$ By definition of [[Definition:Property (S)|property (S)]]: :$\exists y \in D: \forall x \in D: y \preceq x \implies x \in X$ By definition of [[Definition:Reflexivity|reflexivity]]: :$y \in X$ By definitions of [[Definition:Set Intersection|intersection]] and [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]]: :$D \cap X \ne \varnothing$ Thus this by [[Empty Intersection iff Subset of Complement]] contradicts :$D \subseteq \complement_S\left({X}\right)$ {{qed}}

statement: [[Definition:Rational Number|Rational number]] plus [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational number]] is [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational]]. That is, let $x \in \Q$, $y \in \R \setminus \Q$ and $x + y = z$. Then $z \in \R \setminus \Q$.
rationale: {{AimForCont}} $z \in \Q$. By definition of [[Definition:Rational Number|rational numbers]]: :$\exists a, b \in \Z, b \ne 0: x = \dfrac a b$ :$\exists c, d \in \Z, d \ne 0: z = \dfrac c d$ Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = x + y | r = z | c = }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = \dfrac a b + y | r = \dfrac c d | c = }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto | l = y | r = \dfrac {b c - a d} {b d} | c = by rearrangement }} {{end-eqn}} This shows that $y$ is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]], which is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. By [[Proof by Contradiction]], $z$ is [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational]]. {{qed}} [[Category:Rational Numbers]] [[Category:Irrational Numbers]] oewkqy1szldvm50y77fqhvs2pevj8ei

statement: Let $n$ be an [[Definition:Integer|integer]] greater than $17$. Then $n$ is the [[Definition:Integer Addition|sum]] of $3$ [[Definition:Integer|integers]] greater than $1$ which are [[Definition:Pairwise Coprime Integers|pairwise coprime]].
rationale: === Case $1$: $n$ is even === There is some [[Definition:Integer|integer]] $k > 2$ such that one of the following holds: :$n = 6 k = 2 + 3 + \paren {6 k - 5}$ :$n = 6 k + 2 = 4 + 3 + \paren {6 k - 7}$ :$n = 6 k + 4 = 2 + 3 + \paren {6 k - 5}$ All terms are greater than $1$. The first two terms are [[Definition:Integer Power|powers]] of $2$ and $3$, so they are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. The last term is not [[Definition:Divisor|divisible]] by $2$ or $3$, so the three numbers are [[Definition:Pairwise Coprime Integers|pairwise coprime]]. {{qed|lemma}} === Case $2$: $n$ is odd === There is some [[Definition:Integer|integer]] $k \ge 1$ such that one of the following holds: :$n = 12 k + 1 = 3 + \paren {6 k - 7} + \paren {6 k + 5}$ and $k \ge 2$ :$n = 12 k + 3 = 9 + \paren {6 k - 5} + \paren {6 k - 1}$ and $k \ge 2$ :$n = 12 k + 5 = 3 + \paren {6 k - 5} + \paren {6 k + 7}$ and $k \ge 2$ :$n = 12 k + 7 = 3 + \paren {6 k - 1} + \paren {6 k + 5}$ :$n = 12 k + 9 = 3 + \paren {6 k - 1} + \paren {6 k + 7}$ :$n = 12 k + 11 = 3 + \paren {6 k + 1} + \paren {6 k + 7}$ All terms are greater than $1$. The first term is a [[Definition:Integer Power|power]] of $3$. The last two terms are not [[Definition:Divisor|divisible]] by $3$, so they are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]] with $3$. {{AimForCont}} the last two terms are not [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. Then they must have a [[Definition:Common Divisor of Integers|common divisor]] greater than $1$. This [[Definition:Common Divisor of Integers|common divisor]] must also [[Definition:Divisor|divide]] their difference. However their difference is only [[Definition:Divisor|divisible]] by $2$ and $3$, and the terms themselves are not. Hence they cannot have a [[Definition:Common Divisor of Integers|common divisor]] greater than $1$. So they must be [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let \( \map P x : \closedint a b \to \R \)  \( \map h x : \closedint a b \to \R \). Let \( \map h x \) be [[Definition:Continuously Differentiable|continuously differentiable]] \( \forall x \in \closedint a b \). Suppose: \( \forall x \in \closedint a b: \map P x > 0 \) Then: \( \ds \forall \map h x : \map h a = \map h b = 0 : \int_a^b \paren {P h'^2 + Q h^2} \rd x > 0 \) {{iff}} the [[Definition:Closed Interval|interval]] \( \closedint a b \) contains no [[Definition:Point|points]] [[Definition:Conjugate Point|conjugate]] to \( a \).

The corresponding proof: By [[Subset of Real Numbers is Interval iff Connected]], $\closedint a b$ is [[Definition:Connected (Topology)|connected]]. {{AimForCont}} there is no [[Definition:Fixed Point|fixed point]]. Then $\map f a > a$ and $\map f b < b$. Let: :$U = \set {x \in \closedint a b: \map f x > x}$ :$V = \set {x \in \closedint a b: \map f x < x}$ Then $U$ and $V$ are [[Definition:Open Set (Real Analysis)|open]] in $\closedint a b$. Because $a \in U$ and $b\in V$, $U$ and $V$ are [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]]. By assumption: :$U \cup V = \closedint a b$ Thus $\closedint a b$ is not [[Definition:Connected (Topology)|connected]], which is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Thus, by [[Proof by Contradiction]], there exists at least one [[Definition:Fixed Point|fixed point]]. {{qed}}
rationale: By [[Subset of Real Numbers is Interval iff Connected]], $\closedint a b$ is [[Definition:Connected (Topology)|connected]]. {{AimForCont}} there is no [[Definition:Fixed Point|fixed point]]. Then $\map f a > a$ and $\map f b < b$. Let: :$U = \set {x \in \closedint a b: \map f x > x}$ :$V = \set {x \in \closedint a b: \map f x < x}$ Then $U$ and $V$ are [[Definition:Open Set (Real Analysis)|open]] in $\closedint a b$. Because $a \in U$ and $b\in V$, $U$ and $V$ are [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]]. By assumption: :$U \cup V = \closedint a b$ Thus $\closedint a b$ is not [[Definition:Connected (Topology)|connected]], which is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Thus, by [[Proof by Contradiction]], there exists at least one [[Definition:Fixed Point|fixed point]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \left({S, \preceq, \tau}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Complete Lattice|complete]] [[Definition:Scott Topology|Scott]] [[Definition:Topological Lattice]]. Let \mathcal B = \left\{ {x^\succeq: x \in K\left({L}\right)}\right\}$ be a [[Definition:Basis (Topology)/Analytic Basis|basis]] of $L$ where :$x^\succeq$ denotes the [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure]] of $x$, :$K\left({L}\right)$ denotes the [[Definition:Compact Subset of Lattice|compact subset]] of $L$. Then $L$ is [[Definition:Algebraic Ordered Set|algebraic]].
rationale:
Thus by [[Compact Closure is Directed]]: :$ orall x \in S:x^{\mathrm{compact} }$ is [[Definition:Directed Subset|directed]] where $x^{\mathrm{compact} }$ denotes the [[Definition:Compact Closure|compact closure]] of $x$. Thus by definition of [[Definition:Complete Lattice|complete lattice]]: :$L$ is [[Definition:Up-Complete|up-complete]]. Let $x \in S$. By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$x$ is [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper closure]] for $x^\preceq$ By definition of [[Definition:Supremum of Set|supremum]]: :$\sup \left({x^\preceq}ight) \preceq x$ By [[Compact Closure is Intersection of Lower Closure and Compact Subset]]: :$x^{\mathrm{compact} } = x^\preceq \cap K\left({L}ight)$ By [[Intersection is Subset]]: :$x^{\mathrm{compact} } \subseteq x^\preceq$ By [[Supremum of Subset]]: :$\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) \preceq \sup \left({x^\preceq}ight)$ By definition of [[Definition:Transitivity|transitivity]]: :$\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) \preceq x$ Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$x 
e \sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight)$ We will prove that :$x 
otin \left({\left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) }ight)^\preceq$ Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$x \in \left({\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) }ight)^\preceq$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$x \preceq \sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight)$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Antisymmetric Relation|antisymmetry]]: :this contrasicts $x 
e \sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight)$ {{qed|lemma}} By definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]]: :$x \in \complement_S\left({\left({\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) }ight)^\preceq}ight)$ By [[Complement of Lower Closure of Element is Open in Scott Topological Ordered Set]]: :$\complement_S\left({\left({\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) }ight)^\preceq}ight)$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]. By definition of [[Definition:Basis (Topology)/Analytic Basis|basis]]: :$\complement_S\left({\left({\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) }ight)^\preceq}ight) =  igcup\left\{ {G \in \mathcal B: G \subseteq \complement_S\left({\left({\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) }ight)^\preceq}ight)}ight\}$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Union/General Definition|union]] :$\exists X \in \left\{ {G \in \mathcal B: G \subseteq \complement_S\left({\left({\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) }ight)^\preceq}ight)}ight\}: x \in X$ Then :$X \in \mathcal B \land X \subseteq \complement_S\left({\left({\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) }ight)^\preceq}ight)$ By definition of $\mathcal B$: :$\exists k \in K\left({L}ight): X = k^\succeq$ By definition of [[Definition:Compact Subset of Lattice|compact subset]]: :$k$ is [[Definition:Compact Element|compact]]. By definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of element]]: :$k \preceq x$ By definition of [[Definition:Compact Closure|compact closure]]: :$k \in x^{\mathrm{compact} }$ By definitions of [[Definition:Supremum of Set|supremum]] and [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]]: :$k \preceq \sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight)$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of element]]: :$\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) \in X$ By gefinition of [[Definition:Subset|subset]]: :$\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) \in \complement_S\left({\left({\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) }ight)^\preceq}ight)$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|difference]]: :$\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) 
otin \left({\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight)}ight)^\preceq$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :this contradicts $\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight) \in \left({\sup \left({x^{\mathrm{compact} } }ight)}ight)^\preceq$ {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\struct {\mathbb K, \norm {\, \cdot \,} }\) be a [[Definition:Valued Field|valued field]]. Let the [[Definition:Infinite Product|infinite product]] \(\displaystyle \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \paren {1 + a_n}\) be [[Definition:Absolute Convergence of Product|absolutely convergent]]. Then it is not [[Definition:Divergent Product|divergent]] to 0.
rationale:
By [[Factors in Absolutely Convergent Product Converge to One]], \(
orm {a_n} < 1\) for \(n \ge n_0\). Let \(n_1 \ge n_0\). {{AimForCont}} the product [[Definition:Divergent Product|diverges]] to 0. Then: :\(\displaystyle \prod_{n \mathop = n_1}^\infty \paren {1 + a_n} = 0\) By [[Norm of Limit]]: :\(\displaystyle \prod_{n \mathop = n_1}^\infty 
orm {1 + a_n} = 0\) By the [[Triangle Inequality]] and [[Squeeze Theorem]]: :\(\displaystyle \prod_{n \mathop = n_1}^\infty \paren {1 - 
orm {a_n} } = 0\) By the [[Weierstrass Product Inequality]], we have for \(N \ge n_1\): :\(\displaystyle \prod_{n \mathop = n_1}^N \paren {1 - 
orm {a_n} } \ge 1 - \sum_{n \mathop = n_1}^N 
orm{a_n}\) Taking limits: :\(0 \ge 1 - \displaystyle \sum_{n \mathop = n_1}^\infty 
orm {a_n}\) Because \(\displaystyle \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \paren  {1 + a_n}\) is [[Definition:Absolute Convergence of Product|absolutely convergent]]: :\(\displaystyle \sum_{n \mathop = n_1}^\infty 
orm {a_n} < 1\) for \(n_1\) [[Definition:Sufficiently Large|sufficiently large]]. This is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a [[Definition:Trimorphic Number|trimorphic number]]. Then it is not necessarily the case that $n$ is also an [[Definition:Automorphic Number|automorphic number]].
rationale: Take as an example $n = 49$. We have that: :$49^3 = 117 \\, 6 \\mathbf{49}$ demonstrating that $49$ is [[Definition:Trimorphic Number|trimorphic]]. However, we also have that: :$49^2 = 2401$ demonstrating that $49$ is not [[Definition:Automorphic Number|automorphic]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $f:\C\to\C$ be an [[Definition:Entire Function|entire function]] of [[Definition:Order of Entire Function|order]] $\omega$. Let $P:\C\to\C$ be a [[Definition:Zero Polynomial|nonzero]] [[Definition:Complex Polynomial Function|polynomial]]. Then $f\cdot P$ has [[Definition:Order of Entire Function|order]] $\omega$.
rationale: By [[Order of Product of Entire Functions]] and [[Polynomial has Order Zero]], $f\cdot P$ has order at most $\omega$. By [[Limit at Infinity of Polynomial]], there exist $r,\\delta>0$ such that $|P(z)| \\geq \\delta$ for $|z|\\geq r$. Suppose $\\displaystyle \\log\\left(\\max_{|z|\\leq R}|f(z)P(z)|\\right) = O(R^\\beta)$ for some $\\beta < \\omega$. By the [[Maximum Modulus Principle]] $\\max_{|z|\\leq R}|f(z)| \\leq \\frac1\\delta \\max_{|z|\\leq R}|f(z)P(z)|$ for $R\\geq r$. Thus $\\displaystyle \\log\\left(\\max_{|z|\\leq R}|f(z)|\\right) = O(R^\\beta)$. This is a contradiction. Thus $f\\cdot P$ has [[Definition:Order of Entire Function|order]] $\\omega$. {{qed}}

statement: Let $A$ be a [[Definition:Class (Class Theory)|class]]. Let $\mathrm P$ be a [[Definition:Proper Class|proper class]]. Let $f: A \to \mathrm P$ be a [[Definition:Class Surjection|surjection]]. Then $A$ is [[Definition:Proper Class|proper]].
rationale: {{NotZFC}} {{AimForCont}} $A$ is not [[Definition:Proper Class|proper]]. Then $A$ must be a [[Definition:Set|set]]. By the [[Axiom:Axiom of Powers|Axiom of Powers]], $\powerset A$ is also a [[Definition:Set|set]]. Let $g: f \sqbrk A \to \powerset A$ be defined as: :$\map g {\map f a} = f^{-1} \sqbrk {\set {\map f a} }$ It should be noted that: :$\forall a \in A: \map {\paren {g \circ f} } a \ne \O$: Suppose that $\map g {\map f a} = \map g {\map f b}$. Let $x \in f^{-1} \sqbrk {\set {\map f a} }$. Then by the definition of a [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$x \in f^{-1} \sqbrk {\set {\map f a} } \implies \map f x \in \set {\map f a} \implies \map f x = \map f a$ By the same argument: :$x \in f^{-1} \sqbrk {\set {\map f b} } \implies \map f x = \map f b$ Hhence by the [[Diagonal Relation is Equivalence|properties of equality]]: :$\map f a = \map f b$ It has been shown that $g$ is an [[Definition:Class Injection|injection]]. Because $f$ is a [[Definition:Class Surjection|surjection]], it follows by definition of [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]] that: :$f \sqbrk A = \mathrm P$ But this contradicts [[Injection from Proper Class to Class]]. Thus by [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] $A$ must be [[Definition:Proper Class|proper]]. Hence the result. {{qed}} [[Category:Gödel-Bernays Class Theory]] [[Category:Class Mappings]] 2uu2rcmfr75ya31wcu0fnuzvv5xm95i

statement: Let $A$ be a [[Definition:Class (Class Theory)|class]]. Let $\mathrm U$ denote the [[Definition:Universal Class|universal class]]. Let $f: A \to \mathrm U$ be a [[Definition:Class Mapping|class mapping]]. Let $S$ be a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $A$. {{explain|Note that further work is needed on the Subset page to clarify that a "subset" of a "proper class" is indeed a "set". Some words are already on that page, but this needs to be formalised and separated out into its own transcluded "class theoretic" page.}} Then the [[Definition:Class Mapping|image]] $f \sqbrk S$ is also a [[Definition:Set|set]]. If $A$ is a [[Definition:Set|set]], then this result is known as the [[Axiom:Axiom of Replacement|Axiom of Replacement]] in [[Definition:Zermelo-Fraenkel Set Theory|Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory]].
rationale: {{NotZFC}} Aiming for [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose that $f \sqbrk S$ is not a set. Then $f \sqbrk S$ must be [[Definition:Class/Proper Class|proper]]. By [[Restriction of Mapping to Image is Surjection]], the [[Definition:Restriction of Mapping|restriction]] $f \restriction_{S \times f \sqbrk S}$ is a [[Definition:Class Surjection|surjection]]. But this contradicts [[Surjection from Class to Proper Class]]. Thus by [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], $f \sqbrk S$ is a [[Definition:Set|set]]. Hence the result. {{qed}} [[Category:Gödel-Bernays Class Theory]] [[Category:Class Mappings]] fdsyztfl8n7ytacauy3trwyj6gk3y16

statement: Let \(\mathbb K\) be a [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]]. Let \(V\) be a [[Definition:Vector Space|vector space]] over \(\mathbb K\). Let \(f\) be a [[Definition:Bilinear Form|bilinear form]] on \(V\). Let \(f\) be [[Definition:Reflexive Bilinear Form|reflexive]]. Then \(f\) is [[Definition:Symmetric Bilinear Form|symmetric]] or [[Definition:Alternating Bilinear Form|alternating]].

There cannot exist a [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] $\left\langle{x_n}\right\rangle$ whose [[Definition:Domain (Set Theory)/Mapping|domain]] is $\N_{\gt 0}$ such that: :$\forall n \in \N_{\gt 0}: x_{n+1} \in x_n$
rationale: Aiming for contradiction, suppose that there is a sequence like that. From the definition of a [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]], let $f$ be the the [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] that is defined by $\left\langle{x_n}\right\rangle$. Let $\omega$ denote the [[Definition:Minimal Infinite Successor Set|minimal infinite successor set]]. Let $g: \omega \to \N_{\gt 0}$ be defined as: :$g \left({\alpha}\right) = \alpha + 1$ Then the [[Definition:Composition of Mappings|composition]] $f \circ g$ is a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] whose [[Definition:Domain (Set Theory)/Mapping|domain]] is $\omega$ such that: :$\forall n \in \omega: \left({f \circ g}\right) \left({n^+}\right) \in \left({f \circ g}\right) \left({n}\right)$ But this contradicts [[No Infinitely Descending Membership Chains]]. Therefore by contradiction there cannot exist such a sequence. Hence the result. {{qed}} [[Category:Axiom of Foundation]]

statement:
The corresponding proof:It should be noted that for any two [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]], $x \lt y \iff x \in y$. Let $\phi \left({x}ight)$ be a [[Definition:Property|property]] that satisfies the above conditions. Aiming for [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], let $y$ be an [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinal]] such that $
eg \phi \left({y}ight)$. It is noted that $y 
e \varnothing$. Therefore $y$ must be either a [[Definition:Successor Ordinal|successor ordinal]] or a [[Definition:Limit Ordinal|limit ordinal]]. If $y$ is a [[Definition:Successor Ordinal|successor ordinal]], then let $x$ be the [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinal]] such that $x^+ = y$. By the [[Rule of Transposition]], it is seen that $
eg \phi \left({x}ight)$. By [[Set is Element of Successor]], it follows that $x \in y$, and so $x \lt y$. If $y$ is a [[Definition:Limit Ordinal|limit ordinal]], then by the [[Rule of Transposition]] there exists an ordinal $x \lt y \iff x \in y$ such that $
eg \phi \left({x}ight)$. It has been shown that if $y$ is an [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinal]] such that $
eg \phi \left({y}ight)$, then there exists an ordinal $x \in y$ such that $
eg \phi \left({x}ight)$. The rest follows from the proof of [[Transfinite Induction/Schema 1|Schema 1]]. {{qed}}
rationale:
The corresponding proof:It should be noted that for any two [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]], $x \lt y \iff x \in y$. Let $\phi \left({x}ight)$ be a [[Definition:Property|property]] that satisfies the above conditions. Aiming for [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], let $y$ be an [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinal]] such that $
eg \phi \left({y}ight)$. It is noted that $y 
e \varnothing$. Therefore $y$ must be either a [[Definition:Successor Ordinal|successor ordinal]] or a [[Definition:Limit Ordinal|limit ordinal]]. If $y$ is a [[Definition:Successor Ordinal|successor ordinal]], then let $x$ be the [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinal]] such that $x^+ = y$. By the [[Rule of Transposition]], it is seen that $

statement: There are $3$ ways to represent $1$ as the sum of exactly $3$ [[Definition:Unit Fraction|unit fractions]].
rationale: Let: :$1 = \dfrac 1 a + \dfrac 1 b + \dfrac 1 c$ where: :$0 < a \le b \le c$ and: {{AimForCont}} $a = 1$. Then: :$1 = \dfrac 1 1 + \dfrac 1 b + \dfrac 1 c$ and so: :$\dfrac 1 b + \dfrac 1 c = 0$ which [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the stipulation that $b, c > 0$. So there is no solution possible when $a = 1$. Therefore $a \ge 2$. === $a = 2$ === Let $a = 2$. ==== $b = 2$ ==== Let $b = 2$. Then: :$\dfrac 1 a + \dfrac 1 b = 1$ leaving no room for $c$. Hence there are no solutions where $a = 2$ and $b = 2$. {{qed|lemma}} ==== $b = 3$ ==== Let $b = 3$. {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \dfrac 1 a + \dfrac 1 b       | r = \dfrac 1 2 + \dfrac 1 3       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \dfrac {3 + 2} 6       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \dfrac 5 6       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = \dfrac 1 c       | r = 1 - \dfrac 5 6       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \dfrac 1 6       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = \dfrac 1 c       | r = \dfrac 1 6       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = c       | r = 6       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} Thus we have: :$(1): \quad 1 = \dfrac 1 2 + \dfrac 1 3 + \dfrac 1 6$ {{qed|lemma}} ==== $b = 4$ ==== Let $b = 4$. {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \dfrac 1 a + \dfrac 1 b       | r = \dfrac 1 2 + \dfrac 1 4       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \dfrac {2 + 1} 4       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \dfrac 3 4       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = \dfrac 1 c       | r = 1 - \dfrac 3 4       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \dfrac 1 4       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = c       | r = 4       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} Thus we have: :$(2): \quad 1 = \dfrac 1 2 + \dfrac 1 4 + \dfrac 1 4$ ==== $b > 4$ ==== Let $b > 4$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \dfrac 1 a + \dfrac 1 b + \dfrac 1 c        | o = <       | r = \dfrac 1 2 + \dfrac 1 4 + \dfrac 1 4       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = 1       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} Hence there are no solutions such that $a = 2, b > 4$. {{qed|lemma}} === $a = 3$ === Let $a = 3$. ==== $b = 3$ ==== Let $b = 3$. {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \dfrac 1 a + \dfrac 1 b       | r = \dfrac 1 3 + \dfrac 1 3       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \dfrac 2 3       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = \dfrac 1 c       | r = 1 - \dfrac 2 3       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \dfrac 1 3       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = c       | r = 3       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} Thus we have: :$(3): \quad 1 = \dfrac 1 3 + \dfrac 1 3 + \dfrac 1 3$ {{qed|lemma}} === $a > 3$ === Let $a > 3$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \dfrac 1 a + \dfrac 1 b + \dfrac 1 c       | o = \le       | r = \dfrac 1 a + \dfrac 1 a + \dfrac 1 a       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = <       | r = 1       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} Hence there are no solutions for $a>3$. {{qed|lemma}} === Summary === Hence our $3$ solutions: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | n = 1       | r = \dfrac 1 2 + \dfrac 1 3 + \dfrac 1 6       | o =  }} {{eqn | n = 2       | r = \dfrac 1 2 + \dfrac 1 4 + \dfrac 1 4       | o =  }} {{eqn | n = 3       | r = \dfrac 1 3 + \dfrac 1 3 + \dfrac 1 3       | o =  }} {{end-eqn}} {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \struct {S, \preceq}$ be an [[Definition:Ordered Set|ordered set]]. Let $p \in S$. Then $p$ is [[Definition:Completely Irreducible|completely irreducible]] {{iff}} :$\exists q \in S: p \prec q \land \paren {\forall s \in S: p \prec s \implies q \preceq s} \land p^\succeq = \set p \cup q^\succeq$ where $p^\succeq$ denotes the [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of]] $p$.
rationale:
=== Sufficient Condition === Assume that: :$p$ is [[Definition:Completely Irreducible|completely irreducible]]. By definition of [[Definition:Completely Irreducible|completely irreducible]]: :$p^\succeq \setminus \set p$ admits a [[Definition:Minimum Element|minimum]]. By definitions of [[Definition:Minimum Element|minimum]] and [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]]: :$p^\succeq \setminus \set p$ admits an [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]]. Define $q = \map \inf {p^\succeq \setminus \set p}$ By definition of [[Definition:Minimum Element|minimum]]: :$q \in p^\succeq \setminus \set p$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|difference]]: :$q \in p^\succeq$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of element]]: :$p \preceq q$ By [[Completely Irreducible implies Infimum differs from Element]]: :$q 
e p$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Strictly Precede|strictly precede]]: :$p \prec q$ We will prove that :$\set p \cup q^\succeq \subseteq p^\succeq$ Let $x \in \set p \cup q^\succeq$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Union|union]]: :$x \in \set p$ or $x \in q^\succeq$ In the first case: :$x \in \set p$ By definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$x = p$ By definition of [[Definition:Reflexivity|reflexivity]]: :$p \preceq x$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of element]]: :$x \in p^\succeq$ {{qed|lemma}} In the second case: :$x \in q^\succeq$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of element]]: :$q \preceq x$ By definition of [[Definition:Transitivity|transitivity]]: :$p \preceq x$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of element]]: :$x \in p^\succeq$ {{qed|lemma}} By definition of [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]]: :$q$ is [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]] for $p^\succeq \setminus \set p$ We will prove that: :$ orall s \in S: p \prec s \implies q \preceq s$ Let $s \in S$ such that: :$p \prec s$ By definition of [[Definition:Strictly Precede|strictly precede]]: :$p \preceq s$ and $p 
e s$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of element]]: :$s \in p^\succeq$ By definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$s 
otin \set p$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|difference]]: :$s \in p^\succeq \setminus \set p$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]]: :$q \preceq s$ {{qed|lemma}} We will prove that: :$p^\succeq \subseteq \set p \cup q^\succeq$ Let $x \in p^\succeq$. By definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$x = p$ or $x \in p^\succeq$ and $x 
otin \set p$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|difference]]: :$x = p$ or $x \in p^\succeq \setminus \set p$ By definitions of [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]] and [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]]: :$x = p$ or $q \preceq x$ By definitions of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]] and [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of element]]: :$x \in \set p$ or $x \in q^\succeq$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Set Union|union]]: :$x \in \set p \cup q^\succeq$ {{qed|lemma}} Thus by definition of [[Definition:Set Equality|set equality]]: :$p^\succeq = \set p \cup q^\succeq$ {{qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === Assume that: :$\exists q \in S: p \prec q \land \paren { orall s \in S: p \prec s \implies q \preceq s} \land p^\succeq = \set p \cup q^\succeq$ We will prove that: :$q$ is [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]] for $p^\succeq \setminus \set p$ Let $a \in p^\succeq \setminus \set p$. By definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|difference]]: :$a \in p^\succeq$ and $a 
otin \set p$ By definitions of [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of element]] and [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$p \preceq a$ and $a 
e p$ By definition of [[Definition:Strictly Precede|strictly precede]]: :$p \prec a$ Thus by assumption: :$q \preceq a$ {{qed|lemma}} By definition of [[Definition:Reflexivity|reflexivity]]: :$q \preceq q$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of element]]: :$q \in q^\succeq$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Union|union]]: :$q \in \set p \cup q^\succeq$ By definition of [[Definition:Strictly Precede|strictly precede]]: :$p 
e q$ By definition of [[Definition:Singleton|singleton]]: :$q 
otin \set p$ By definition of [[Definition:Set Difference|difference]]: :$q \in p^\succeq \setminus \set p$ We will prove that: :$ orall b \in S: b$ is [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]] for $p^\succeq \setminus \set p \implies b \preceq q$ Let $b \in S$ such that: :$b$ is [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]] for $p^\succeq \setminus \set p$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]]: :$b \preceq q$ {{qed|lemma}} By definition of [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]]: :$q = \map \inf {p^\succeq \setminus \set p}$ By definition: :$p^\succeq \setminus \set p$ admits a [[Definition:Minimum Element|minimum]]. Thus by definition: :$p$ is [[Definition:Completely Irreducible|completely irreducible]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an [[Definition:Ordered Set|ordered set]]. Let $x \in S$ such that :$x$ is [[Definition:Completely Irreducible|completely irreducible]]. Let $X \subseteq S$ such that :$X$ admits an [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]] and $x = \inf X$ Then $x \in X$
rationale: Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$x \notin X$ By [[Completely Irreducible Element iff Exists Element that Strictly Succeeds First Element]] :$\exists q \in S: x \prec q \land \left({\forall s \in S: x \prec s \implies q \preceq s}\right) \land x^\succeq = \left\{ {x}\right\} \cup q^\succeq$ where $x^\succeq$ denotes the [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of]] $x$. We will prove that :$X \subseteq q^\succeq$ Let $y \in X$. By definitions of [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]] and [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]]: :$x \preceq y$ By definition of [[Definition:Strictly Precede|strictly precede]]: :$x \prec y$ By existence of $q$: :$q \preceq y$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of element]]: :$y \in q^\succeq$ {{qed|lemma}} By [[Infimum of Upper Closure of Element]]: :$\inf\left({q^\succeq}\right) = q$ By [[Infimum of Subset]]: :$q \preceq x$ Thus this contrsdicts $x \prec q$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Complete Lattice|complete lattice]]. Let $X \subseteq S$, $p \in S$ such that :$p$ is [[Definition:Completely Irreducible|completely irreducible]] and $p = \inf X$ Then $p \in X$
rationale:
Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$p 
otin X$ By [[Completely Irreducible Element iff Exists Element that Strictly Succeeds First Element]]: :$\exists q \in S: p \prec q \land \left({ orall s \in S: p \prec s \implies q \preceq s}ight) \land p^\succeq = \left\{ {p}ight\} \cup q^\succeq$ where $p^\succeq$ denotes the [[Definition:Upper Closure of Element|upper closure of]] $p$. We will prove that :$q$ is [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]] for $X$ Let $x \in X$. By definitions of [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]] and [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]] :$p \preceq x$ By assumption: :$x 
e p$ By definition of [[Definition:Strictly Precede|strictly precede]]: :$p \prec x$ Thus by step condition: :$q \preceq x$ {{qed|lemma}} By definition of [[Definition:Strictly Precede|strictly precede]]: :$p \preceq q$ We will prove that :$ orall b \in S: b$ is [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]] for $X \implies b \preceq q$ Let $b \in S$ such that :$b$ is [[Definition:Lower Bound of Set|lower bound]] for $X$. By definition of [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]]: :$b \preceq p$ Thus by definition of [[Definition:Transitivity|transitivity]]: :$b \preceq q$ {{qed|lemma}} By definition of [[Definition:Infimum of Set|infimum]]: :$q = \inf X = p$ Thus this contradicts $p 
e q$ by definition of [[Definition:Strictly Precede|strictly precede]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T_1 = \struct {S_1, \preceq_1, \tau_1}$ and $T_2 = \struct {S_2, \preceq_2, \tau_2}$ be [[Definition:Up-Complete|up-complete]] [[Definition:Topological Lattice|topological lattices]] with [[Definition:Scott Topology|Scott topologies]]. Let $f: S_1 \to S_2$ be a [[Definition:Continuous (Topology)|continuous]] [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]]. Then $f$ is an [[Definition:Increasing Mapping|increasing mapping]].
rationale: Let $x, y \in S_1$ such that :$x \preceq_1 y$ {{AimForCont}} that :$\map f x \npreceq_2 \map f y$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$\map f x \notin \paren {\map f y}^\preceq$ By definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]]: :$\map f x \in \relcomp {S_2} {\paren {\map f y}^\preceq}$ By definition of [[Definition:Reflexivity|reflexivity]]: :$\map f y \preceq_2 \map f y$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$\map f y \in \paren {\map f y}^{\preceq_2}$ By [[Closure of Singleton is Lower Closure of Element in Scott Topological Lattice]]: :$\set {\map f y}^- = \paren {\map f y}^{\preceq_2}$ By definition of [[Definition:Closure (Topology)|closure]]: :$\paren {\map f y}^{\preceq_2}$ is a [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed set]]. By definition of [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed set]]: :$\relcomp {S_2} {\paren {\map f y}^{\preceq_2} }$ is a [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]]. By definition of [[Definition:Continuous (Topology)|continuous]]: :$f^{-1} \sqbrk {\relcomp {S_2} {\paren {\map f y}^{\preceq_2} } }$ is an [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]]. By definition of [[Definition:Scott Topology]]: :$f^{-1} \sqbrk {\relcomp {S_2} {\paren {\map f y}^{\preceq_2} } }$ is an [[Definition:Upper Set|upper set]]. By definition of [[Definition:Preimage of Subset under Mapping|preimage of set]]: :$x \in f^{-1} \sqbrk {\relcomp {S_2} {\paren {\map f y}^{\preceq_2} } }$ By definition of [[Definition:Upper Set|upper set]]: :$y \in f^{-1} \sqbrk {\relcomp {S_2} {\paren {\map f y}^{\preceq_2} } }$ By definition of [[Definition:Preimage of Subset under Mapping|preimage of set]]: :$\map f y \in \relcomp {S_2} {\paren {\map f y}^{\preceq_2} }$ Thus this contradicts $\map f y \in \paren {\map f y}^{\preceq_2}$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $\left({S, \preceq_1, \tau_1}\right)$ and $\left({T, \preceq_2, \tau_2}\right)$ be [[Definition:Complete Lattice|complete]] [[Definition:Topological Lattice|topological lattices]] with [[Definition:Scott Topology|Scott topologies]]. Let $f: S \to T$ be a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]]. Then $f$ is [[Definition:Continuous (Topology)|continuous]] {{iff}} :for all [[Definition:Directed Set|directed set]] $\left({D, \precsim}\right)$ and [[Definition:Moore-Smith Sequence|Moore-Smith sequence]] $N:D \to S$ in $S$: $f\left({\liminf N}\right) \preceq_2 \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right)$
rationale: === Sufficient Condition === Assume that :$f$ is [[Definition:Continuous (Topology)|continuous]]. Let $\left({D, \precsim}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Directed Set|directed set]]. Let $N:D \to S$ be a [[Definition:Moore-Smith Sequence|Moore-Smith sequence]] in $S$. Aiming for a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] suppose that :$f\left({\liminf N}\right) \npreceq_2 \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right)$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$f\left({\liminf N}\right) \notin \left({ \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right) }\right)^{\preceq_2}$ By definition of [[Definition:Relative Complement|relative complement]]: :$f\left({\liminf N}\right) \in \complement_T\left({\left({ \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right) }\right)^{\preceq_2} }\right)$ By [[Lower Closure of Element is Topologically Closed in Scott Topological Ordered Set]]: :$\left({ \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right) }\right)^{\preceq_2}$ is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]]. By definition of [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed set]]: :$\complement_T\left({\left({ \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right) }\right)^{\preceq_2} }\right)$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]. By definition of [[Definition:Continuous (Topology)|continuous]]: :$f^{-1}\left[{\complement_T\left({\left({ \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right) }\right)^{\preceq_2} }\right)}\right]$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]]. By [[Open iff Upper and with Property (S) in Scott Topological Lattice]]: :$f^{-1}\left[{\complement_T\left({\left({ \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right) }\right)^{\preceq_2} }\right)}\right]$ has [[Definition:Property (S)|property (S)]]. By [[Set of Infima for Sequence is Directed]]: :$X := \left\{ {\inf \left({N\left[{\precsim\left({j}\right)}\right]}\right): j \in D}\right\}$ is [[Definition:Directed Subset|directed]]. By definition of [[Definition:Limit Inferior of Moore-Smith Sequence|limit inferior]]: :$\liminf N = \sup X$ By definition of [[Definition:Preimage of Subset under Mapping|preimage of set]]: :$\liminf N \in f^{-1}\left[{\complement_T\left({\left({ \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right) }\right)^{\preceq_2} }\right)}\right]$ By definition of [[Definition:Property (S)|property (S)]]: :$\exists y \in X:\forall x \in X: y \preceq_1 x \implies x \in f^{-1}\left[{\complement_T\left({\left({ \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right) }\right)^{\preceq_2} }\right)}\right]$ We have: :$\exists j \in D: y = \inf \left({N\left[{\precsim\left({j}\right)}\right]}\right)$ By definition of [[Definition:Reflexivity|reflexivity]]: :$y \preceq_1 y$ Then: :$y \in f^{-1}\left[{\complement_T\left({\left({ \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right) }\right)^{\preceq_2} }\right)}\right]$ Define $y' := \inf \left({\left({f \circ N}\right)\left[{\precsim\left({j}\right)}\right]}\right)$ Define $X' := \left\{ {\inf \left({\left({f \circ N}\right)\left[{\precsim\left({j}\right)}\right]}\right): j \in D}\right\}$ By [[Mapping is Increasing implies Mapping at Infimum for Sequence Precedes Infimum for Composition of Mapping and Sequence]]: :$f\left({y}\right) \preceq_2 y'$ By definition of $X'$: :$y' \in X'$ By definitions of [[Definition:Supremum of Set|supremum]] and [[Definition:Upper Bound of Set|upper bound]]: :$y' \preceq_2 \sup X'$ By definition of [[Definition:Limit Inferior of Moore-Smith Sequence|limit inferior]]: :$\liminf \left({f \circ N}\right) = \sup X'$ By definition of [[Definition:Transitivity|transitivity]]: :$f\left({y}\right) \preceq_2 \liminf \left({f \circ N}\right)$ By definition of [[Definition:Lower Closure of Element|lower closure of element]]: :$f\left({y}\right) \in \left({\liminf \left({f \circ N}\right)}\right)^{\preceq_2}$ By definition of [[Definition:Preimage of Subset under Mapping|preimage of set]]: :$y \in f^{-1}\left[{\left({\liminf \left({f \circ N}\right)}\right)^{\preceq_2} }\right]$ By [[Complement of Preimage equals Preimage of Complement]]: :$f^{-1}\left[{\complement_T\left({\left({ \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right) }\right)^{\preceq_2} }\right)}\right] = \complement_S\left({f^{-1}\left[{\left({ \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right) }\right)^{\preceq_2} }\right]}\right)$ Thus this contradicts $y \in \complement_S\left({f^{-1}\left[{\left({ \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right) }\right)^{\preceq_2} }\right]}\right)$ {{qed|lemma}} === Necessary Condition === Assume that :for all [[Definition:Directed Set|directed set]] $\left({D, \precsim}\right)$ and [[Definition:Moore-Smith Sequence|Moore-Smith sequence]] $N:D \to S$ in $S$: $f\left({\liminf N}\right) \preceq_2 \liminf\left({f \circ N}\right)$ By [[Mapping at Limit Inferior Precedes Limit Inferior of Composition Mapping and Sequence implies Mapping Preserves Directed Suprema]]: :$f$ [[Definition:Mapping Preserves Supremum/Directed|preserves directed suprema]]. Thus by [[Mapping Preserves Directed Suprema implies Mapping is Continuous]]: :$f$ is [[Definition:Continuous (Topology)|continuous]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $n$ be a [[Definition:Carmichael Number|Carmichael number]]. Then $n$ has at least $3$ [[Definition:Distinct|distinct]] [[Definition:Odd Prime|odd]] [[Definition:Prime Factor|prime factors]].
rationale: By [[Korselt's Theorem]], $n$ is [[Definition:Odd Integer|odd]]. Therefore $n$ has at least $1$ [[Definition:Odd Prime|odd]] [[Definition:Prime Factor|prime factor]]. By [[Korselt's Theorem]], for each [[Definition:Prime Factor|prime factor]] of $n$: :$p^2 \nmid n$ :$\paren {p - 1} \divides \paren {n - 1}$ Suppose $n = p^k$ for some [[Definition:Odd Prime|odd]] [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] $p$. By [[Korselt's Theorem]], $k = 1$. However by definition of a [[Definition:Carmichael Number|Carmichael Number]], $n$ cannot be [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]]. Therefore $n$ has at least $2$ [[Definition:Distinct|distinct]] [[Definition:Odd Prime|odd]] [[Definition:Prime Factor|prime factors]]. Suppose $n = p^a q^b$ for [[Definition:Distinct|distinct]] [[Definition:Odd Prime|odd]] [[Definition:Prime Number|primes]] $p$ and $q$. By [[Korselt's Theorem]], the following holds: :$a = b = 1$ :$n = p q$ :$\paren {p - 1} \divides \paren {n - 1}$ :$\paren {q - 1} \divides \paren {n - 1}$ Hence: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \paren {p - 1}       | o = \divides       | r = \paren {n - 1 - q \paren {p - 1} } }} {{eqn | r = p q - 1 - p q + q }} {{eqn | r = q - 1 }} {{end-eqn}} Swapping $p$ and $q$ yields $\paren {q - 1} \divides \paren {p - 1}$. Hence $p - 1 = q - 1$ and $p = q$, which is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Therefore $n$ has at least $3$ [[Definition:Distinct|distinct]] [[Definition:Odd Prime|odd]] [[Definition:Prime Factor|prime factors]]. {{qed}}

statement: The number $1091$ has the property that: :$x^6 + 1091$ is [[Definition:Composite Number|composite]] for all [[Definition:Integer|integer]] values of $x$ from $1$ to $3905$.
rationale:
We check the result and show that it cannot be improved further by showing: :$3906$ is the smallest $x$ such that $x^6 + 1091$ is [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]]. Suppose $x^6 + 1091$ is [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]]. Then: :$x$ is a multiple of $42$ :$x$ ends in $0$, $4$ or $6$ in decimal notation :$x 
ot \equiv \pm 1, \pm 3, \pm 4 \pmod {13}$ :$x 
ot \equiv \pm 4, \pm 6, \pm 9 \pmod {19}$ The proof is split into $6$ parts: === $x$ is a multiple of $2$ === Suppose not. Then $x$ is [[Definition:Odd Integer|odd]], and so is $x^6$. Hence $x^6 + 1091$ is [[Definition:Even Integer|even]], and thus [[Definition:Composite Number|composite]]. Thus we must require $x$ to be [[Definition:Even Integer|even]]. {{qed|lemma}} === $x$ is a multiple of $3$ === Suppose not. Write $x = 3 k \pm 1$. Hence: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = x^6 + 1091       | r = \paren {3 k \pm 1}^6 + 1091 }} {{eqn | o = \equiv       | r = \paren {\pm 1}^6 - 1       | rr = \pmod 3       | c = [[Congruence of Powers]] }} {{eqn | o = \equiv       | r = 0       | rr = \pmod 3 }} {{end-eqn}} showing that $x^6 + 1091$ is [[Definition:Composite Number|composite]] ([[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisible]] by $3$). Thus we must require $x$ to be a multiple of $3$. {{qed|lemma}} === $x$ is a multiple of $7$ === Suppose not. Then $x \perp 7$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = n^6 + 1091       | o = \equiv       | r = 1 + 1091       | rr = \pmod 7       | c = [[Fermat's Little Theorem]] }} {{eqn | o = \equiv       | r = 0       | rr = \pmod 7 }} {{end-eqn}} showing that $x^6 + 1091$ is [[Definition:Composite Number|composite]] ([[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisible]] by $7$). Thus we must require $x$ to be a multiple of $7$. {{qed|lemma}} === $x$ ends in $0$, $4$ or $6$ === From the above we require $x$ to be [[Definition:Even Integer|even]]. Suppose $x$ ends in $2$ or $8$. Then $x^6$ ends in $4$. Thus $x^6 + 1091$ ends in $5$, which by [[Divisibility by 5]] is [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisible]] by $5$. Hence we must require $x$ to end in $0$, $4$ or $6$. {{qed|lemma}} === $x 
ot \equiv \pm 1, \pm 3, \pm 4 \pmod {13}$ === Here is a table of $x^6 \pmod {13}$: :$ egin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline  x  mod {13} & 0 & \pm 1 & \pm 2 & \pm 3 & \pm 4 & \pm 5 & \pm 6 \ \hline x^6  mod {13} & 0 & 1 & -1 & 1 & 1 & -1 & -1 \ \hline \end{array}$ For $x \equiv \pm 1, \pm 3, \pm 4 \pmod {13}$: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = x^6 + 1091       | o = \equiv       | r = 1 - 1       | rr = \pmod {13} }} {{eqn | o = \equiv       | r = 0       | rr = \pmod {13} }} {{end-eqn}} showing that $x^6 + 1091$ is [[Definition:Composite Number|composite]] ([[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisible]] by $13$). Thus we must require $x 
ot \equiv \pm 1, \pm 3, \pm 4 \pmod {13}$. {{qed|lemma}} === $x 
ot \equiv \pm 4, \pm 6, \pm 9 \pmod {19}$ === Here is a table of $x^6 \pmod {19}$: :$ egin{array}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline  x  mod {19} & 0 & \pm 1 & \pm 2 & \pm 3 & \pm 4 & \pm 5 & \pm 6 & \pm 7 & \pm 8 & \pm 9 \ \hline x^6  mod {19} & 0 & 1 & 7 & 7 & 11 & 6 & 11 & 1 & 1 & 11\ \hline \end{array}$ For $x \equiv \pm 4, \pm 6, \pm 9 \pmod {19}$: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = x^6 + 1091       | o = \equiv       | r = 11 + 8       | rr = \pmod {19} }} {{eqn | o = \equiv       | r = 0       | rr = \pmod {19} }} {{end-eqn}} showing that $x^6 + 1091$ is [[Definition:Composite Number|composite]] ([[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisible]] by $19$). Thus we must require $x 
ot \equiv \pm 4, \pm 6, \pm 9 \pmod {19}$. {{qed|lemma}} Here is a list of $x^6 + 1091$, where $42 \divides x$ and does not end in $2$ or $8$: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = 84^6 + 1091       | r = 23 	imes 15273827509 }} {{eqn | l = 126       | o = \equiv       | r = -4 \pmod {13} }} {{eqn | l = 210^6 + 1091       | r = 109 	imes 786845146799 }} {{eqn | l = 294       | o = \equiv       | r = +9 \pmod {19} }} {{eqn | l = 336       | o = \equiv       | r = -6 \pmod {19} }} {{eqn | l = 420       | o = \equiv       | r = +4 \pmod {13} }} {{eqn | l = 504       | o = \equiv       | r = -3 \pmod {13} }} {{eqn | l = 546^6 + 1091       | r = 2129 	imes 12444578592403 }} {{eqn | l = 630^6 + 1091       | r = 347 	imes 41957 	imes 4294468229 }} {{eqn | o = etc.}} {{end-eqn}} {{finish|1/8 of the way there. I'll fill it in later}} The above results are obtained using an integer factorization calculator. {{qed}}

statement: Let \(\sequence {x_n}\) be a [[Definition:Real Sequence|sequence in \(\R\)]]. Let \(x_n \to l\) as \(n \to \infty\). Then it is '''not''' the case that: :\((1): \quad \forall n \in \N: x_n > a \implies l > a\) :\((2): \quad \forall n \in \N: x_n < b \implies l < b\)
rationale: Take the examples: :\((1): \quad \sequence {x_n} = \dfrac 1 n\) :\((2): \quad \sequence {y_n} = -\dfrac 1 n\) Then : :\(\forall n \in \N_{>0}: \dfrac 1 n > 0, -\dfrac 1 n < 0\) From [[Sequence of Reciprocals is Null Sequence]], we have :\(x_n \to 0\) :\(y_n \to 0\) as \(n \to \infty\). However, it is clearly '''false''' that \(0 > 0\) and \(0 < 0\). {{qed}}

statement: Let $n$ be a [[Definition:Highly Composite Number|highly composite number]]. Let the [[Definition:Prime Decomposition|prime decomposition]] of $n$ be expressed as: :$n = \displaystyle \prod_{k \mathop \in \N} {p_k}^{r_k}$ where $p_k$ denotes the [[Definition:Prime Number|$k$th prime]]. Then the [[Definition:Integer Sequence|sequence]] $\left\langle{r_k}\right\rangle$ is [[Definition:Decreasing Sequence|decreasing]]. That is: :$\forall k \in \N: r_k \ge r_{k + 1}$
rationale: Let $n = \displaystyle \prod_{k \mathop \in \N} {p_k}^{r_k}$ be [[Definition:Highly Composite Number|highly composite]]. By definition of [[Definition:Tau Function|$\tau$ function]]: :$\tau \left({n}\right) = \displaystyle \prod_{k \mathop \in \N} \left({r_k + 1}\right)$ {{AimForCont}} $r_{l + 1} > r_l$ for some $l \in \N$. Consider $m \in \Z$ whose [[Definition:Prime Decomposition|prime decomposition]] of $n$ is expressed as: :$m = \displaystyle \prod_{k \mathop \in \N} {p_k}^{s_k}$ where: :$\forall j < l: s_j = r_j$ :$\forall j > l + 1: s_j = r_j$ :$s_l = r_{l + 1}$ :$s_{l + 1} = r_l$ We have that: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \tau \left({m}\right)       | r = \prod_{k \mathop \in \N} \left({s_k + 1}\right)       | c = {{Defof|Tau Function}} }} {{eqn | r = \prod_{k \mathop \in \N} \left({r_k + 1}\right)       | c = as all the $s$s are the same as all the $r$s, but in a different order }} {{eqn | r = \tau \left({n}\right)       | c = {{Defof|Tau Function}} }} {{end-eqn}} Thus: : $\tau \left({m}\right) = \tau \left({n}\right)$ Now we have that: :$r_l < r_{l + 1}$ and so: :$s_l > s_{l + 1}$ and so: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \frac { {p_l}^{r_l} {p_{l + 1} }^{r_{l + 1} } } { {p_l}^{s_l} {p_{l + 1} }^{s_{l + 1} } }       | r = \frac { {p_l}^{r_l} {p_{l + 1} }^{r_{l + 1} } } { {p_l}^{r_{l + 1} } {p_{l + 1} }^{r_l} }       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = \frac { {p_l}^c} { {p_{l + 1}^c} }       | c = where $c = r_{l + 1} - r_l$ }} {{end-eqn}} Then: :$p_{l + 1} > p_l$ and so: :${p_{l + 1} }^c > {p_l}^c$ from which it follows that: :$m < n$ while: :$\tau \left({m}\right) = \tau \left({n}\right)$ But $n$ is [[Definition:Highly Composite Number|highly composite]]. This means that if $\tau \left({m}\right) = \tau \left({n}\right)$, then $n \le m$. This is [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicted]] by $n > m$. Thus by [[Proof by Contradiction]]: :$\forall k \in \N: r_k \ge r_{k + 1}$ {{qed}}

statement: Let $n$ be an [[Definition:Integer|integer]] which has at least $3$ [[Definition:Digit|digits]] when expressed in [[Definition:Decimal Notation|decimal notation]]. Let the [[Definition:Digit|digits]] of $n$ be divided into groups of $3$, counting from the right, and those groups added. Then the result is equal to a [[Definition:Multiple of Integer|multiple]] of $999$ {{iff}} $n$ is [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisible]] by $999$.
rationale: The mistake is either ''and conversely'' or ''equal to $999$'', since $999 \, 999$ is an easy counterexample. Here we will show that the result is equal to '''a multiple of''' $999$ {{iff}} $n$ is [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisible]] by $999$. Write $n = \displaystyle \sum_{i \mathop = 0}^k a_i 10^{3 i}$, where $0 \le a_i < 1000$. This divides the [[Definition:Digit|digits]] of $n$ into groups of $3$. Then the statement is equivalent to: :$999 \divides n \iff 999 \divides \displaystyle \sum_{i \mathop = 0}^k a_i$ This statement is true since: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = n       | r = \sum_{i \mathop = 0}^k a_i 10^{3 i} }} {{eqn | r = \sum_{i \mathop = 0}^k a_i 1000^i }} {{eqn | o = \equiv       | r = \sum_{i \mathop = 0}^k a_i 1^i       | rr = \pmod {999}       | c = [[Congruence of Powers]] }} {{eqn | o = \equiv       | r = \sum_{i \mathop = 0}^k a_i       | rr = \pmod {999} }} {{end-eqn}} {{qed}} === [[Integer whose Digits when Grouped in 3s add to Multiple of 999 is Divisible by 999/Examples|Examples]] === {{:Integer whose Digits when Grouped in 3s add to Multiple of 999 is Divisible by 999/Examples}}

statement: The only [[Definition:Factorial|factorials]] which are the product of consecutive [[Definition:Factorial|factorials]] are: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = 0!       | r = 0! \times 1!       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = 1!       | r = 0! \times 1!       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = 2!       | r = 1! \times 2!       | c =  }} {{eqn | r = 0! \times 1! \times 2!       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = 10!       | r = 6! \times 7!       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}}
rationale: Suppose $m, n \in \N$ and $m < n$. Write \map F {n, m} = n! \paren {n + 1}! \cdots m!. Suppose we have \map F {n, m} > r! for some $r \in \N$. Suppose further that there is a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] $p$ where $m < p \le r$. We claim that \map F {n, m} cannot be a [[Definition:Factorial|factorial]] of any number. {{AimForCont}} \map F {n, m} = s! for some $s \in \N$. Since $s! > r!$, we must have $r! \divides s!. Since $p \le r$, we must have $p \divides r!. Thus we have $p \divides s!. However, since $n, n + 1, \dots, m < p, we must have $p \nmid k! for each $n \le k \le m. Thus $p \nmid \map F {n, m} = s!, which is a contradiction. Hence \map F {n, m} cannot be a [[Definition:Factorial|factorial]] of some number. We have the following [[Definition:Lemma|lemmata]]: === [[Factorial as Product of Consecutive Factorials/Lemma 1|Lemma 1]] === {{:Factorial as Product of Consecutive Factorials/Lemma 1}}{{qed|lemma}} === [[Factorial as Product of Consecutive Factorials/Lemma 2|Lemma 2]] === {{:Factorial as Product of Consecutive Factorials/Lemma 2}}{{qed|lemma}} We also have: :$ orall n \in \N: n > 1 \implies \exists p: 2 n < p < 3 n$ {{finish|The result above is shown by M. El Bachraoui in their paper Primes in the Interval [2n, 3n]. I do not have the time to comprehend their proof yet}} === Case $1$: $m$ is an even number larger than $2$ === Write $m = 2 k$, where $k > 1$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \map F {n, m}       | o = \ge       | r = \paren {m - 1}! \, m! }} {{eqn | r = \paren {2 k - 1}! \, \paren {2 k}! }} {{eqn | o = >       | r = \paren {3 k - 1}!       | c = [[Factorial as Product of Consecutive Factorials/Lemma 1|Lemma 1]] }} {{end-eqn}} There is a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] $p$ where $m = 2 k < p \le 3 k - 1$. Therefore \map F {n, m} is not a [[Definition:Factorial|factorial]] of some number. === Case $2$: $m$ is an odd number larger than $11$ === Write $m = 2 k - 1$, where $k \ge 7$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \map F {n, m}       | o = \ge       | r = \paren {m - 1}! \, m! }} {{eqn | r = \paren {2 k - 2}! \, \paren {2 k - 1}! }} {{eqn | o = >       | r = \paren {3 k - 1}!       | c = [[Factorial as Product of Consecutive Factorials/Lemma 2|Lemma 2]] }} {{end-eqn}} There is a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] $p$ where $m = 2 k - 1 < 2 k < p \le 3 k - 1$. Therefore \map F {n, m} is not a [[Definition:Factorial|factorial]] of some number. === Case $3$: Particular values of $m$ === The cases above leaves us with $m = 1, 2, 3, 5, 7, 9, 11$ to check. We have: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = 10! \times 11!       | o = >       | r = 13!       | c = and $13$ is a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] }} {{eqn | l = 8! \times 9!       | o = >       | r = 11!       | c = and $11$ is a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] }} {{eqn | l = 6! \times 7!       | r = 10! }} {{eqn | l = 5! \times 6! \times 7!       | o = >       | r = 11!       | c = and $11$ is a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] }} {{eqn | l = 4! \times 5!       | r = 2880       | c = is not a [[Definition:Factorial|factorial]] of some number }} {{eqn | l = 3! \times 4! \times 5!       | o = >       | r = 7!       | c = and $7$ is a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] }} {{eqn | l = \map F {n, 3}       | r = 12       | c = is not a [[Definition:Factorial|factorial]] of some number }} {{eqn | l = \map F {n, 2}       | r = 2! }} {{eqn | l = \map F {0, 1}       | r = 1! }} {{eqn | r = 0! }} {{end-eqn}} Thus there are no more. {{qed}}

statement: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be an [[Definition:Irreducible Space|irreducible topological space]]. Let $U$ be a [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] of $T$. Then $U$ is [[Definition:Irreducible Space|irreducible]] in its [[Definition:Subspace Topology|induced subspace topology]].
rationale: Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be an [[Definition:Irreducible Space|irreducible topological space]]. Let $U$ be a [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] of $T$. {{AimForCont}} $U$ is not [[Definition:Irreducible Space|irreducible]] in $T$. Then $U = V_1 \cup V_2$ for some [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed sets]] $V_1$ and $V_2$ of $\struct {U, \tau_U}$. By definition of [[Definition:Subspace Topology|subspace topology]]: :$V_1 = U \cap W_1$ and: :$V_2 = U \cap W_2$ for some [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed sets]] $W_1$ and $W_2$ of $T$. Because $W_1 = S \implies V_1 = U \cap W_1 = U$, it follows that: :$W_1 \ne S$ This is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], because $V_1$ is a [[Definition:Proper Subset|proper subset]] of $U$. Now $U \ne \\O$ implies that $S \\setminus U$ is a [[Definition:Proper Subset|proper subset]] of $S$ which is a [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed set]] of $T$. Let $W_3 := W_2 \\cup \\paren {S \\setminus U}$. Then $W_3$ is a [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed set]] of $T$. Also, $W_3 \\ne S$, because otherwise $V_2 = U \\cap W_2 = U \\cap W_3 = U$. Thus $S = W_1 \\cup W_3$ shows that $T$ is not [[Definition:Irreducible Space|irreducible]]. The result follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $S$ be an [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite set]]. Let $T \supseteq S$ be a [[Definition:Superset|superset]] of $S$. Then $T$ is also [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite]].
rationale: Suppose $T$ were [[Definition:Finite Set|finite]]. Then by [[Set Finite iff Injection to Initial Segment of Natural Numbers]], there is an [[Definition:Injection|injection]] $f: T \to \N_{<n}$ for some $n \in \N$. But then by [[Restriction of Injection is Injection]], also the [[Definition:Restriction of Mapping|restriction]] of $f$ to $S$: :$f \restriction_{S}: S \to \N_{<n}$ is an [[Definition:Injection|injection]]. Again by [[Set Finite iff Injection to Initial Segment of Natural Numbers]], this contradicts the assumption that $S$ is [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite]]. Hence $T$ is [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $R_p$ and $R_q$ be [[Definition:Repunit|repunit numbers]] with $p$ and $q$ [[Definition:Digit|digits]] respectively. Then $R_p$ and $R_q$ are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]] {{iff}} $p$ and $q$ are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]].
rationale: === Necessary Condition === Let $R_p$ and $R_q$ be [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. {{AimForCont}} $p$ and $q$ are not [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. Let $p = d m, q = d n$ for some $d > 1$. Then by [[Divisors of Repunit with Composite Index]]: :$R_d \divides R_p$ and: :$R_d \divides R_q$ where \(\divides\) denotes [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisibility]]. That is, $R_d$ is a [[Definition:Common Divisor of Integers|common divisor]] of $R_p$ and $R_q$. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] our hypothesis that $R_p$ and $R_q$ are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. Thus by [[Proof by Contradiction]], $p$ and $q$ are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. {{qed|lemma}} === Sufficient Condition === Let $p$ and $q$ be [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. Let $R_p$ and $R_q$ be [[Definition:Repunit|repunits]] in [[Definition:Number Base|base]] $b$. By [[Integer Combination of Coprime Integers]], there exists [[Definition:Integer|integers]] $m, n$ such that $m p + n q = 1$. One of $m, n$ is [[Definition:Strictly Positive Integer|strictly positive]] while the other is [[Definition:Negative Integer|negative]]. {{WLOG}}, suppose $m > 0$ and $n \le 0$. Then from $m p = 1 - n q$: We have $R_{m p} - b R_{- n q} = 1$. By [[Divisors of Repunit with Composite Index]], $R_p$ is a divisor of $R_{m p}$, while $R_q$ is a divisor of $R_{- n q}$. By definition of [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisibility]], there exists [[Definition:Integer|integers]] $c, d$ such that $R_{m p} = c R_p, R_{- n q} = d R_q$. Therefore $c R_p - b d R_q = 1$. Note that both $c$ and $- b d$ are [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. By [[Integer Combination of Coprime Integers]], $R_p$ and $R_q$ are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $L / K$ be a [[Definition:Field Extension|field extension]]. Let $\alpha \in L$ be [[Definition:Algebraic Element of Field Extension|algebraic]] over $K$. Let $f \in K[x]$ be a [[Definition:Nonzero Polynomial|nonzero polynomial]] of [[Definition:Smallest Natural Number|minimal]] [[Definition:Degree of Polynomial|degree]] such that \(\map f \alpha = 0\). Then $f$ is [[Definition:Irreducible Polynomial|irreducible]] in $K \sqbrk x$.
rationale: {{AimForCont}} that $f$ is not [[Definition:Irreducible Polynomial|irreducible]]. Then there exist non-[[Definition:Constant Polynomial|constant polynomials]] $g, h \in K \sqbrk x$ such that $f = g h$. We have: :$0 = \map f \alpha = \map g \alpha \map h \alpha$ Since $L$ is a [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]], it is an [[Definition:Integral Domain|integral domain]]. Therefore, as $\map g \alpha, \map h \alpha \in L$, either $\map g \alpha = 0$ or $\map h \alpha = 0$. This contradicts the minimality of the [[Definition:Degree of Polynomial|degree]] of $f$. Hence the result, by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: The property of [[Definition:Separable Space|separability]] is not [[Definition:Weakly Hereditary Property|weakly hereditary]].
rationale: It needs to be demonstrated that there exists a [[Definition:Separable Space|separable topological space]] which has a [[Definition:Topological Subspace|subspace]] which is [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] but not [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]]. Consider an [[Definition:Uncountable Particular Point Space|uncountable particular point space]] $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$. From [[Particular Point Space is Separable]], $T$ is [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]]. By definition, the [[Definition:Particular Point Topology|particular point $p$]] is an [[Definition:Open Point|open point]] of $T$. Thus the [[Definition:Subset|subset]] $S \setminus \set p$ is by definition [[Definition:Closed Set (Topology)|closed]] in $T$. But from [[Separability in Uncountable Particular Point Space]], $S \setminus \set p$ is not [[Definition:Separable Space|separable]]. Thus by [[Proof by Counterexample]], [[Definition:Separable Space|separability]] is not [[Definition:Weakly Hereditary Property|weakly hereditary]]. {{qed}}

Thus $\mathcal F \subseteq \mathcal P \left({S}ight)$ is a [[Definition:Filter on Set|filter]] on $S$ which fulfills the condition: :whenever $\mathcal G$ is a [[Definition:Filter on Set|filter]] on $S$ and $\mathcal F \subseteq \mathcal G$ holds, then $\mathcal F = \mathcal G$. otin \mathcal F$ and $\complement_S \left({A}ight)

Let $U \in \mathcal F$. {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \complement_S \left({A}ight)       | o = 
otin       | r = \mathcal F       | c = [[Definition:By Hypothesis|by hypothesis]] }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = U       | o =

otin \mathcal F$ and so: :$\mathcal F \subsetneq \mathcal G$ Thus $\mathcal F$ is not an [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set/Definition 1|ultrafilter by Definition 1]]. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] our initial hypothesis. Hence either: :$A \in \mathcal F$ or: :$\complement_S \left({A}ight) \in \mathcal F$ and so $\mathcal F$ fulfils the conditions to be an [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set/Definition 3|ultrafilter by Definition 3]]. {{qed|lemma}} === [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set/Definition 3|Definition 3]] implies [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set/Definition 1|Definition 1]] === Let $\mathcal F$ be an [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set/Definition 3|ultrafilter on $S$ by definition 3]]. That is, $\mathcal F \subseteq \mathcal P \left({S}ight)$ is a [[Definition:Filter on Set|filter]] on $S$ which fulfills the condition: :for any $A \subseteq S$ either $A \in \mathcal F$ or $\complement_S \left({A}ight) \in \mathcal F$ holds. Let $\mathcal G$ be a [[Definition:Filter on Set|filter]] on $X$ such that $\mathcal F \subseteq \mathcal G$. {{AimForCont}} $\mathcal F \subsetneq \mathcal G$. Then there exists $A \in \mathcal G \setminus \mathcal F$. By definition of [[Definition:Filter on Set|filter]], $\varnothing 
otin \mathcal G$. But from [[Intersection with Relative Complement is Empty]]: :$A \cap \complement_S \left({A}ight)$ and so: :$\complement_S \left({A}ight) 
otin \mathcal G$ By hypothesis: :$\mathcal F \subsetneq \mathcal G$ and so: :$\complement_S \left({A}ight) 
otin \mathcal F$ Therefore neither $A \in \mathcal F$ nor $\complement_S \left({A}ight) \in \mathcal F$. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] our assumption: :for any $A \subseteq S$ either $A \in \mathcal F$ or $\complement_S \left({A}ight) \in \mathcal F$ holds. Thus: : $\mathcal F = \mathcal G$ and so $\mathcal F$ fulfils the conditions to be an [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set/Definition 1|ultrafilter by Definition 1]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $S$ be a [[Definition:Set|set]]. Let $\powerset S$ denote the [[Definition:Power Set|power set]] of $S$. Let $\FF, \FF' \subset \powerset S$ be two [[Definition:Filter on Set|filters]] on $S$. Let $\FF$ have a [[Definition:Filter Basis|basis]] $\BB$. Let $\FF'$ have a [[Definition:Filter Basis|basis]] $\BB'$. $\FF$ is [[Definition:Finer Filter on Set|finer]] than $\FF'$ {{iff}} for every [[Definition:Set|set]] of $\BB'$, there is a [[Definition:Set|set]] of $\BB$ [[Definition:Subset|subset]] to it.
rationale:
=== Necessary Condition === Suppose for every [[Definition:Set|set]] of $\BB'$, there is a [[Definition:Set|set]] of $\BB$ [[Definition:Subset|subset]] to it. Pick any $U \in \FF'$. Then from definition of a [[Definition:Filter Basis|basis]]: :$\exists V' \in \BB': V' \subseteq U$ By our assumption: :$\exists V \in \BB: V \subseteq V' \subseteq U \subseteq S$ By definition of a [[Definition:Filter on Set|filter]]: :$U \in \FF$. Hence we have $\FF' \subseteq \FF$. {{qed|lemma}} === Sufficient Condition === We prove the [[Definition:Contrapositive Statement|contrapositive]]. Suppose there is some [[Definition:Set|set]] of $\BB'$ with no [[Definition:Set|set]] of $\BB$ [[Definition:Subset|subset]] to it. Let $U$ be such a [[Definition:Set|set]]. Then $U \in \BB' \subseteq \FF'$. From our assumption: :$
ot \exists V \in \BB: V \subseteq U$ From the definition of a [[Definition:Filter Basis|basis]]: :$U 
otin \FF$ This gives $\FF' 
ot \subseteq \FF$. {{qed}}

statement: There exists at least one example of a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] for which none of the [[Definition:Tychonoff Separation Axioms|Tychonoff separation axioms]] are satisfied.
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let $T$ be the [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] consisting of the [[Definition:Double Pointed Topology|double pointed topology]] on the [[Definition:Countable Complement Topology|countable complement topology]] on an [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable set]]. From [[Double Pointed Countable Complement Topology fulfils no Separation Axioms]], we have that $T$ satisfies none of the [[Definition:Tychonoff Separation Axioms|Tychonoff separation axioms]]. {{qed}}

statement: There exists at least one example of a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] for which none of the [[Definition:Tychonoff Separation Axioms|Tychonoff separation axioms]] are satisfied except for the [[Definition:T0 Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) axiom]] and [[Definition:T1 Space|$T_1$ (Fréchet) axiom]].
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let $T$ be the [[Definition:Countable Finite Complement Topology|finite complement topology on a countable space]]. From [[Finite Complement Space is T1|Finite Complement Space is $T_1$]], $T$ is a [[Definition:T1 Space|$T_1$ (Fréchet) space]]. Hence from [[T1 Space is T0 Space|$T_1$ Space is $T_0$ Space]], also a [[Definition:T0 Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]]. The rest of the result follows from: :[[Finite Complement Space is not T2|Finite Complement Space is not $T_2$]] and: :[[Finite Complement Space is not T3, T4 or T5|Finite Complement Space is not $T_3$, $T_4$ or $T_5$]] {{qed}}

statement: There exists at least one example of a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] for which none of the [[Definition:Tychonoff Separation Axioms|Tychonoff separation axioms]] are satisfied except for the [[Definition:T3 Space|$T_3$ axiom]].
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let $T$ be the [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] consisting of the [[Definition:Double Pointed Topology|double pointed topology]] on the [[Definition:Tychonoff Corkscrew Topology|Tychonoff corkscrew topology]]. From [[Double Pointed Tychonoff Corkscrew fulfils no Separation Axioms but T3|Double Pointed Tychonoff Corkscrew fulfils no Separation Axioms but $T_3$]], we have that $T$ satisfies none of the [[Definition:Tychonoff Separation Axioms|Tychonoff separation axioms]] except for the [[Definition:T3 Space|$T_3$ axiom]]. {{qed}}

statement: Let $I$ be an [[Definition:Indexing Set|indexing set]] with [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite cardinality]]. Let $\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be a [[Definition:Indexed Family|family]] of [[Definition:Topological Space|topological spaces]] [[Definition:Indexed Family|indexed]] by $I$. Let $\displaystyle \struct {S, \tau} = \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be the [[Definition:Product Space of Topological Spaces|product space]] of $\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$. Let each of $\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be [[Definition:Sigma-Compact Space|\sigma-compact]]. Then it is not necessarily the case that $\struct {S, \tau}$ is also [[Definition:Sigma-Compact Space|\sigma-compact]].
rationale: Let $T = \struct {\Z_{\ge 0}, \tau}$ be the [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] formed by the [[Definition:Discrete Topology|discrete topology]] on the [[Definition:Positive Integer|set of positive integers]]. Let $T' = \struct {\displaystyle \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in \Z_{\ge 0} } \struct {\Z_{\ge 0}, \tau}_\alpha, \tau'}$ be the [[Definition:Countable Cartesian Product|countable Cartesian product]] of $\struct {\Z_{\ge 0}, \tau}$ [[Definition:Indexed Family|indexed]] by $\Z_{\ge 0}$ with the [[Definition:Tychonoff Topology|Tychonoff topology]] $\tau'$. From [[Countable Discrete Space is Sigma-Compact]], $T$ is [[Definition:Sigma-Compact Space|\sigma-compact]]. From [[Countable Product of Countable Discrete Spaces is not Sigma-Compact]], $T'$ is not [[Definition:Sigma-Compact Space|\sigma-compact]]. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $I$ be an [[Definition:Indexing Set|indexing set]] with [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable cardinality]]. Let \(\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}\) be a [[Definition:Indexed Family|family]] of [[Definition:Topological Space|topological spaces]] [[Definition:Indexed Family|indexed]] by \(I\). Let \(\displaystyle \struct {S, \tau} = \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}\) be the [[Definition:Product Space (Topology)|product space]] of \(\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}\). Let each of \(\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}\) be [[Definition:Sequentially Compact Space|sequentially compact]]. Then it is not necessarily the case that \(\struct {S, \tau}\) is also [[Definition:Sequentially Compact Space|sequentially compact]].
rationale: Let \(\mathbb I\) denote the [[Definition:Closed Unit Interval|closed unit interval]]. Let \(T = \struct {\mathbb I, \tau}\) be the [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] consisting of \(\mathbb I\) under the [[Definition:Euclidean Topology on Real Number Line|usual (Euclidean) topology]]. Let \(T' = \mathbb I^{\mathbb I} = \struct {\displaystyle \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in \mathbb I} \struct {\mathbb I, \tau}_\alpha, \tau'}\) be the [[Definition:Uncountable Cartesian Product|uncountable Cartesian product]] of \(\struct{\mathbb I, \tau}\) [[Definition:Indexed Family|indexed]] by \(\mathbb I\) with the [[Definition:Tychonoff Topology|Tychonoff topology]] \(\tau'\). From [[Closed Real Interval is Sequentially Compact]], \(T\) is  [[Definition:Sequentially Compact Space|sequentially compact]]. {{explain|The above has not been proven yet, but I think it is: \(\mathbb I\) is a metric space, and a compact metric space is sequentially compact.}} But from [[Uncountable Cartesian Product of Closed Unit Interval is not Sequentially Compact]], \(T\) is not a [[Definition:Sequentially Compact Space|sequentially compact space]]. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $I$ be an [[Definition:Indexing Set|indexing set]]. Let $\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be a [[Definition:Indexed Family|family]] of [[Definition:Topological Space|topological spaces]] [[Definition:Indexed Family|indexed]] by $I$. Let $\displaystyle \struct {S, \tau} = \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be the [[Definition:Product Space of Topological Spaces|product space]] of $\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$. Let each of $\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact]]. Then it is not necessarily the case that $\struct {S, \tau}$ is also [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact]].
rationale: Let $T$ denote the [[Definition:Novak Space|Novak space]]. Let $T \times T$ denote the [[Definition:Cartesian Product|Cartesian product]] of the [[Definition:Novak Space|Novak space]] with itself under the [[Definition:Product Topology|product topology]]. From [[Novak Space is Countably Compact]], $T$ is a [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact space]]. But from [[Cartesian Product of Novak Spaces is not Countably Compact]], $T \times T$ is not a [[Definition:Countably Compact Space|countably compact space]]. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $I$ be an [[Definition:Indexing Set|indexing set]] with [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite cardinality]]. Let \( \family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \) be a [[Definition:Indexed Family|family]] of [[Definition:Topological Space|topological spaces]] [[Definition:Indexed Family|indexed]] by \( I \). Let \( \displaystyle \struct {S, \tau} = \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} \) be the [[Definition:Product Space of Topological Spaces|product space]] of \( \family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \). Let each of \( \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} \) be [[Definition:Weakly Locally Compact Space|weakly locally compact-compact]]. Then it is not necessarily the case that \( \struct {S, \tau} \) is also [[Definition:Weakly Locally Compact Space|weakly locally compact]].
rationale: Let $T = \struct {\Z_{\ge 0}, \tau}$ be the [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] formed by the [[Definition:Discrete Topology|discrete topology]] on the [[Definition:Positive Integer|set of positive integers]]. Let $T' = \struct {\displaystyle \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in \Z_{\ge 0} } \struct {\Z_{\ge 0}, \tau}_\alpha, \tau'}$ be the [[Definition:Countable Cartesian Product|countable Cartesian product]] of \(\struct {\Z_{\ge 0}, \tau}\) [[Definition:Indexed Family|indexed]] by \(\Z_{\ge 0}\) with the [[Definition:Tychonoff Topology|Tychonoff topology]] \(\tau'\). From [[Discrete Space is Strongly Locally Compact]], $T$ is [[Definition:Strongly Locally Compact Space|strongly locally compact]]. From [[Strongly Locally Compact Space is Weakly Locally Compact]], $T$ is [[Definition:Weakly Locally Compact Space|weakly locally compact]]. From [[Countable Product of Countable Discrete Spaces is not  Weakly Locally Compact]], $T'$ is not [[Definition:Weakly Locally Compact Space|weakly locally compact]]. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $I$ be an [[Definition:Indexing Set|indexing set]]. Let \(\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}\) be a [[Definition:Indexed Family|family]] of [[Definition:Topological Space|topological spaces]] [[Definition:Indexed Family|indexed]] by \(I\). Let \(\displaystyle \struct {S, \tau} = \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}\) be the [[Definition:Product Space of Topological Spaces|product space]] of \(\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}\). Let each of \(\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}\) be a [[Definition:Lindelöf Space|Lindelöf space]]. Then it is not necessarily the case that \(\struct {S, \tau}\) is also [[Definition:Lindelöf Space|Lindelöf space]].
rationale: Let \(T\) be the [[Definition:Sorgenfrey Line|Sorgenfrey line]]. Let \(T' = T \times T\) be [[Definition:Sorgenfrey's Half-Open Square Topology|Sorgenfrey's half-open square topology]]. From [[Sorgenfrey Line is Lindelöf]], \(T\) is a [[Definition:Lindelöf Space|Lindelöf space]]. From [[Sorgenfrey's Half-Open Square Topology is Not Lindelöf]], \(T'\) is not a [[Definition:Lindelöf Space|Lindelöf space]]. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $I$ be an [[Definition:Indexing Set|indexing set]] with [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable cardinality]]. Let \(\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}\) be a [[Definition:Indexed Family|family]] of [[Definition:Topological Space|topological spaces]] [[Definition:Indexed Family|indexed]] by \(I\). Let \(\displaystyle \struct {S, \tau} = \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}\) be the [[Definition:Product Space of Topological Spaces|product space]] of \(\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}\). Let each of \(\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}\) be a [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countable space]]. Then it is not necessarily the case that \(\struct {S, \tau}\) is also a [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countable space]].
rationale: Let \(T = \struct {\Z_{\ge 0}, \tau}\) denote the [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] consisting of the [[Definition:Positive Integer|set of positive integers]] \(\Z_{\ge 0}\) under the [[Definition:Discrete Topology|discrete topology]]. Let \(I\) be an [[Definition:Indexing Set|indexing set]] with [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable cardinality]]. Let \(T' = \struct {\displaystyle \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in \mathbb I} \struct {\Z_{\ge 0}, \tau}_\alpha, \tau'}\) be the [[Definition:Uncountable Cartesian Product|uncountable Cartesian product]] of \(\struct {\Z_{\ge 0}, \tau}\) [[Definition:Indexed Family|indexed]] by \(I\) with the [[Definition:Tychonoff Topology|Tychonoff topology]] \(\tau'\). From [[Discrete Space is First-Countable]], \(T\) is a [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countable space]]. But from [[Uncountable Cartesian Product of Discrete Topology on Positive Integers is not First-Countable]], \(T\) is not a [[Definition:First-Countable Space|first-countable space]]. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: Let $I$ be an [[Definition:Indexing Set|indexing set]] with [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable cardinality]]. Let \(\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}\) be a [[Definition:Indexed Family|family]] of [[Definition:Topological Space|topological spaces]] [[Definition:Indexed Family|indexed]] by \(I\). Let \(\displaystyle \struct {S, \tau} = \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}\) be the [[Definition:Product Space of Topological Spaces|product space]] of \(\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}\). Let each of \(\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}\) be a [[Definition:Second-Countable Space|second-countable space]]. Then it is not necessarily the case that \(\struct {S, \tau}\) is also a [[Definition:Second-Countable Space|second-countable space]].
rationale: Let \(T = \struct {\Z_{\ge 0}, \tau}\) denote the [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]] consisting of the [[Definition:Positive Integer|set of positive integers]] \(\Z_{\ge 0}\) under the [[Definition:Discrete Topology|discrete topology]]. Let \(I\) be an [[Definition:Indexing Set|indexing set]] with [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable cardinality]]. Let \(T' = \struct {\displaystyle \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {\Z_{\ge 0}, \tau}_\alpha, \tau'}\) be the [[Definition:Uncountable Cartesian Product|uncountable Cartesian product]] of \(\struct {\Z_{\ge 0}, \tau}\) [[Definition:Indexed Family|indexed]] by \(I\) with the [[Definition:Tychonoff Topology|Tychonoff topology]] \(\tau'\). From [[Countable Discrete Space is Second-Countable]], \(T\) is a [[Definition:Second-Countable Space|second-countable space]].
