Let $\pi \in R$ be a uniformizer. If $a \in A$ then there exists an $n \geq 0$ and an element $a' \in A$ such that $a = \pi^n a'$ and $a' \not \in \pi A$. This follows from Krull intersection theorem (Algebra, Lemma \\ref{algebra-lemma-intersect-powers-ideal-module-zero}). If $a$ is nilpotent, so is $a'$, because $\pi$ is a nonzerodivisor by flatness of $A$ over $R$. But $a'$ maps to a nonzero element of the reduced ring $A/\pi A = \mathcal{O}_{X_s, x'}$. This is a contradiction unless $A$ is reduced, which is what we wanted to show.

statement: Let $f : X \to Y$ be a flat proper morphism of finite presentation. Then the set $\{y \in Y \mid X_y\text{ is geometrically reduced}\}$ is open in $Y$.
rationale: We may assume $Y$ is affine. Then $Y$ is a cofiltered limit of affine schemes of finite type over $\mathbf{Z}$. Hence we can assume $X \to Y$ is the base change of $X_0 \to Y_0$ where $Y_0$ is the spectrum of a finite type $\mathbf{Z}$-algebra and $X_0 \to Y_0$ is flat and proper. See Limits, Lemma \ref{limits-lemma-descend-finite-presentation}, \ref{limits-lemma-descend-flat-finite-presentation}, and \ref{limits-lemma-eventually-proper}. Since the formation of the set of points where the fibres are geometrically reduced commutes with base change (Lemma \ref{lemma-base-change-fibres-geometrically-reduced}), we may assume the base is Noetherian. \medskip\noindent Assume $Y$ is Noetherian. The set is constructible by Lemma \ref{lemma-geometrically-reduced-constructible}. Hence it suffices to show the set is stable under generalization (Topology, Lemma \ref{topology-lemma-characterize-closed-Noetherian}). By Properties, Lemma \ref{properties-lemma-locally-Noetherian-specialization-dvr} we reduce to the case where $Y = \Spec(R)$, $R$ is a discrete valuation ring, and the closed fibre $X_y$ is geometrically reduced. To show: the generic fibre $X_\eta$ is geometrically reduced. \medskip\noindent If not then there exists a finite extension $L$ of the fraction field of $R$ such that $X_L$ is not reduced, see Varieties, Lemma \ref{varieties-lemma-geometrically-reduced}. There exists a discrete valuation ring $R' \subset L$ with fraction field $L$ dominating $R$, see Algebra, Lemma \ref{algebra-lemma-integral-closure-Dedekind}. After replacing $R$ by $R'$ we reduce to Lemma \ref{lemma-proper-flat-over-dvr-reduced-fibre}.

statement: A flat degeneration of a disconnected scheme is either disconnected or nonreduced.
rationale: Write $S = \Spec(R)$ and let \pi \in R$ be a uniformizer. To get a contradiction assume that $X_\eta$ is disconnected. This means there exists a nontrivial idempotent $e \in \Gamma(X_\eta, \mathcal{O}_{X_\eta})$. Let $U = \Spec(A)$ be any affine open in $X$. Note that $\pi$ is a nonzerodivisor on $A$ as $A$ is flat over $R$, see More on Algebra, Lemma \ref{more-algebra-lemma-flat-torsion-free} for example. Then $e|_{U_\eta}$ corresponds to an element $e \in A[1/\pi]$. Let $z \in A$ be an element such that $e = z/\pi^n$ with $n \geq 0$ minimal. Note that $z^2 = \pi^nz$. This means that $z \bmod \pi A$ is nilpotent if $n > 0$. By assumption $A/\pi A$ is reduced, and hence minimality of $n$ implies $n = 0$. Thus we conclude that $e \in A$! In other words $e \in \Gamma(X, \mathcal{O}_X)$. As $X$ is connected it follows that $e$ is a trivial idempotent which is a contradiction.

statement: Let $f : X \to S$ be a morphism of schemes. Let $s \in S$. Then $X_s$ is geometrically connected, if and only if for every \'etale neighbourhood $(U, u) \to (S, s)$ the base change $X_U \to U$ has connected fibre $X_u$.
rationale: If $X_s$ is geometrically connected, then any base change of it is connected. On the other hand, suppose that $X_s$ is not geometrically connected. Then by Varieties, Lemma \\ref{varieties-lemma-characterize-geometrically-disconnected} we see that $X_s \\times_{\\Spec(\\kappa(s)} \\Spec(k)$ is disconnected for some finite separable field extension $\\kappa(s) \\subset k$. By Lemma \\ref{lemma-realize-prescribed-residue-field-extension-etale} there exists an affine \'etale neighbourhood $(U, u) \\to (S, s)$ such that $\\kappa(s) \\subset \\kappa(u)$ is identified with $\\kappa(s) \\subset k$. In this case $X_u$ is disconnected.

It is clear that (1) implies (2) and (2) implies (3). Let us prove that (3) implies (1). Suppose that the base change $X_T \to T$ is not open for some morphism of schemes $g : T \to S$. Then we can find some affine opens $V \subset S$, $U \subset X$, $W \subset T$ with $f(U) \subset V$ and $g(W) \subset V$ such that $U \times_V W \to W$ is not open. If we can show that this implies $\mathbf{A}^n \times U \to \mathbf{A}^n \times V$ is not open, then $\mathbf{A}^n \times X \to \mathbf{A}^n \times S$ is not open and the proof is complete. This reduces us to the result proved in the next paragraph. \medskip\noindent Let $A \to B$ be a ring map such that $A' \to B' = A' \otimes_A B$ does not induce an open map of spectra for some $A$-algebra $A'$. As the principal opens give a basis for the topology of $\Spec(B')$ we conclude that the image of $D(g)$ in $\Spec(A')$ is not open for some $g \in B'$. Write $g = \sum_{i = 1, \ldots, n} a'_i \otimes b_i$ for some $n$, $a'_i \in A'$, and $b_i \in B$. Consider the element $h = \sum_{i = 1, \ldots, n} x_i b_i$ in $B[x_1, \ldots, x_n]$. Assume that $D(h)$ maps to an open subset under the morphism $$ \Spec(B[x_1, \ldots, x_n]) \longrightarrow \Spec(A[x_1, \ldots, x_n]) $$ in order to get a contradiction. Then $D(h)$ would map surjectively onto a quasi-compact open $U \subset \Spec(A[x_1, \ldots, x_n])$. Let $A[x_1, \ldots, x_n] \to A'$ be the $A$-algebra homomorphism sending $x_i$ to $a'_i$. This also induces a $B$-algebra homomorphism $B[x_1, \ldots, x_n] \to B'$ sending $h$ to $g$. Since $$ \xymatrix{ \Spec(B[x_1, \ldots, x_n]) \ar[d] & \Spec(B') \ar[l] \ar[d] \\ \Spec(A[x_1, \ldots, x_n]) & \Spec(A') \ar[l] } $$ is cartesian the image of $D(g)$ in $\Spec(A')$ is equal to the inverse image of $U$ in $\Spec(A')$ and hence open which is the desired contradiction.

statement: Let $(\Sh(\mathcal{C}), \mathcal{O})$ be a ringed topos. Let $p$ be a point of the topos $\Sh(\mathcal{C})$. \begin{enumerate} \item The functor $p_* : \textit{Mod}(\mathcal{O}_p) \to \textit{Mod}(\mathcal{O})$, $M \mapsto p_*M$ is exact. \item The canonical surjection $p^{-1}p_*M \to M$ is $\mathcal{O}_p$-linear. \item The functorial direct sum decomposition $p^{-1}p_*M = M \oplus I(M)$ of Lemma \ref{lemma-skyscraper-exact} is {\bf not} $\mathcal{O}_p$-linear in general. \end{enumerate}
rationale: Part (1) and surjectivity in (2) follow immediately from the corresponding result for abelian sheaves in Lemma \ref{lemma-skyscraper-exact}. Since $p^{-1}\mathcal{O} = \mathcal{O}_p$ we have $p^{-1} = p^*$ and hence $p^{-1}p_*M \to M$ is the same as the counit $p^*p_*M \to M$ of the adjunction for modules, whence linear. \medskip\noindent Proof of (3). Suppose that $G$ is a group. Consider the topos $G\textit{-Sets} = \Sh(\mathcal{T}_G)$ and the point $p : \textit{Sets} \to G\textit{-Sets}$. See Sites, Section \ref{sites-section-example-sheaf-G-sets} and Example \ref{sites-example-point-G-sets}. Here $p^{-1}$ is the functor forgetting about the $G$-action. And $p_*$ is the right adjoint of the forgetful functor, sending $M$ to \text{Map}(G, M). The maps in the direct sum decomposition are the maps $$ M \to \text{Map}(G, M) \to M $$ where the first sends $m \in M$ to the constant map with value $m$ and where the second map is evaluation at the identity element $1$ of $G$. Next, suppose that $R$ is a ring endowed with an action of $G$. This determines a sheaf of rings $\mathcal{O}$ on $\mathcal{T}_G$. The category of $\mathcal{O}$-modules is the category of $R$-modules $M$ endowed with an action of $G$ compatible with the action on $R$. The $R$-module structure on \text{Map}(G, M) is given by $$ ( r f ) (\sigma) = \sigma(r) f(\sigma) $$ for $r \in R$ and $f \in \text{Map}(G, M)$. This is true because it is the unique $G$-invariant $R$-module strucure compatible with evaluation at $1$. The reader observes that in general the image of $M \to \text{Map}(G, M)$ is not an $R$-submodule (for example take $M = R$ and assume the $G$-action is nontrivial), which concludes the proof.

statement: The following conditions are equivalent. \begin{enumerate} \item[(a)] The morphism $f$ is a descent morphism for modules. \item[(b)] The morphism $f$ is an effective descent morphism for modules. \item[(c)] The morphism $f$ is universally injective. \end{enumerate}
rationale: It is clear that (b) implies (a). We now check that (a) implies (c). If $f$ is  not universally injective, we can find $M \in \text{Mod}_R$ such that the map $1_M \otimes f: M \to M \otimes_R S$ has nontrivial kernel $N$. The natural projection $M \to M/N$ is not an isomorphism, but its image in  $DD_{S/R}$ is an isomorphism. Hence $f^*$ is not fully faithful. \medskip\noindent We finally check that (c) implies (b). By Lemma \ref{lemma-descent-lemma}, for $(M, \theta) \in DD_{S/R}$, the natural map $f^* f_*(M,\theta) \to M$ is an isomorphism of $S$-modules. On  the other hand, for $M_0 \in \text{Mod}_R$, we may tensor (\ref{equation-equalizer-S}) with $M_0$ over $R$ to obtain an  equalizer sequence, so $M_0 \to f_* f^* M$ is an isomorphism. Consequently, $f_*$ and $f^*$ are  quasi-inverse functors, proving the claim.

statement: 13. Let f be an increasing function on [a, b], with its range being [f(a), f(b)]. Prove that f is continuous on [a, b].
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose otherwise, i.e., there exists a point x₀ ∈ [a, b] where f is not continuous. Since f is increasing on [a, b], x₀ must be a jump discontinuity of f. Therefore, at least one of f(x₀) - f(x₀ - 0) and f(x₀ + 0) - f(x₀) is greater than zero. For example, suppose f(x₀) - f(x₀ - 0) > 0. Then, by the monotonicity of f, f cannot attain any value between f(x₀ - 0) and f(x₀), which contradicts the assumption. Thus, f must be continuous on [a, b].

statement: 15. Let {fₙ} be a sequence of continuous functions on the interval [a, b]. For every point x ∈ [a, b], {fₙ(x)} is bounded; that is, there exists a constant Mₓ depending on x such that |fₙ(x)| ≤ Mₓ for all n = 1, 2, … Prove that {fₙ} is uniformly bounded on some subinterval of [a, b]; that is, there exists a constant M such that |fₙ(x)| ≤ M for all x ∈ [a, b] and all n = 1, 2, …
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose otherwise. Then, there exist n₁ and x₁ ∈ [a, b] such that |fₙ₁(x₁)| > 1. Because fₙ₁ is continuous, there exists a subinterval [a₁, b₁] ⊂ [a, b] containing x₁ (assume without loss of generality that b₁ - a₁ < 1/2) such that |fₙ₁(x)| > 1 for all x ∈ [a₁, b₁]. Since {fₙ : n ≠ n₁} is not uniformly bounded on [a₁, b₁], there exist n₂ and x₂ ∈ [a₁, b₁] such that |fₙ₂(x₂)| > 2. As fₙ₂ is continuous, there exists a subinterval [a₂, b₂] ⊂ [a₁, b₁] containing x₂ such that b₂ - a₂ < 1/2² and |fₙ₂(x)| > 2 for all x ∈ [a₂, b₂]. Continuing this process, we obtain a strictly increasing sequence {nₖ} and a decreasing sequence of closed intervals {[aₖ, bₖ]} such that for each k, |fₙₖ(x)| > k for all x ∈ [aₖ, bₖ], with aₖ < aₖ₊₁, bₖ > bₖ₊₁, and bₖ - aₖ → 0 as k → ∞. By the Nested Interval Theorem, there exists x₀ ∈ [aₖ, bₖ] for all k = 1, 2, … Thus, for every k, |fₙₖ(x₀)| > k, contradicting the assumption that {fₙₖ(x₀)} is bounded.

statement: 16. Let f be a real-valued function defined on (-∞, +∞) with the Intermediate Value Property; that is, if f(a) < c < f(b), then there exists some x between a and b such that f(x) = c. Additionally, suppose that for each rational number r, the set {x : f(x) = r} is closed. Prove that f is continuous.
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose there exists x₀ ∈ (-∞, +∞) such that f is discontinuous at x₀. Then, there exists ε₀ > 0 and a sequence {xₙ} converging to x₀ such that |f(xₙ) - f(x₀)| ≥ ε₀ for all n = 1, 2, … First, assume there are infinitely many points xₙₖ such that f(xₙₖ) < f(x₀) - ε₀. Choose a rational number r such that f(xₙₖ) < r < f(x₀). By the Intermediate Value Property, there exists ξₖ between x₀ and xₙₖ such that f(ξₖ) = r. The set F = {ξ : f(ξ) = r} is closed by assumption, so limₖ→∞ ξₖ = x₀ implies x₀ ∈ F, and hence f(x₀) = r, which contradicts our earlier inequality. Next, if only finitely many points satisfy f(xₙ) < f(x₀) - ε₀, then there exists an infinite subsequence {xₙⱼ} such that f(xₙⱼ) ≥ f(x₀) - ε₀. A similar argument leads to a contradiction. Hence, f must be continuous on (-∞, +∞).

statement: Lemma: If C is a complete cover of [a, b], then C contains a partition of [a, b]; that is, there exist points a = x₀ ≤ x₁ ≤ ... ≤ xₙ = b such that each interval [xₖ₋₁, xₖ] (k = 1, 2, ..., n) belongs to C.
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose C does not contain any partition of [a, b]. Repeatedly bisecting [a, b], we obtain a sequence of nested closed subintervals {Jₙ} of [a, b] such that Jₙ ⊃ Jₙ₊₁ for all n = 1, 2, ..., and |Jₙ| → 0 as n → ∞, where |Jₙ| denotes the length of Jₙ. By the Nested Interval Theorem, there exists a unique point x₀ ∈ ⋂ₙ=1^∞ Jₙ. This contradicts the assumption that C does not contain a partition of [a, b]. Therefore, C must contain a partition of [a, b].

statement: 29. Let f be a continuous function on [a, b] with a unique minimum at x₀ ∈ [a, b]. Prove that if xₙ ∈ [a, b] and limₙ→∞ f(xₙ) = f(x₀), then limₙ→∞ xₙ = x₀.
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose otherwise. Then, there exists ε₀ > 0 and a subsequence {xₙₖ} such that |xₙₖ - x₀| ≥ ε₀. Since {xₙₖ} ⊂ [a, b], it has a convergent subsequence. Assume without loss of generality that {xₙₖ} itself converges to some x₀' ∈ [a, b], with x₀' ≠ x₀. By continuity of f, f(x₀') = limₖ→∞ f(xₙₖ) = f(x₀), which contradicts the uniqueness of the minimum at x₀. Hence, limₙ→∞ xₙ = x₀.

statement: 32. Let f be an upper semicontinuous function on [a, b]. Prove that f is bounded above on [a, b].
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose f is upper semicontinuous but unbounded on [a, b]. Then, there exists a sequence {xₙ} ⊂ [a, b] such that f(xₙ) > n for all n = 1, 2, …. Since {xₙ} is bounded, it has a convergent subsequence {xₙₖ}, say converging to α ∈ [a, b]. Because f is upper semicontinuous at α, for any ε₀ = 1, there exists δ > 0 such that f(x) < f(α) + 1 whenever |x - α| < δ and x ∈ [a, b]. However, since {xₙₖ} converges to α, there exists K such that for all k > K, |xₙₖ - α| < δ, implying f(xₙₖ) < f(α) + 1. But f(xₙₖ) > nₖ, leading to the contradiction nₖ < f(α) + 1 for all large k. Therefore, f must be bounded above on [a, b].

statement: 28. Let aₙ ≥ 0 (n = 1, 2, …), and suppose that lim_{n→∞} aₙ / (aₙ₊₁ + aₙ₊₂) = 0. Prove that the sequence {aₙ} is unbounded.
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose {aₙ} is bounded, and let lim_{n→∞} aₙ = M < +∞. Since aₙ ≥ 0 (n = 1, 2, …), we have M ≥ 0. From (1), there exists a positive integer n₀ such that for all n ≥ n₀, aₙ / (aₙ₊₁ + aₙ₊₂) < 1/2, which implies aₙ < (aₙ₊₁ + aₙ₊₂)/2. Thus, aₙ < max{aₙ₊₁, aₙ₊₂} for n ≥ n₀. By iteration of (2), for any positive integer k, we have a_{n₀} < max{a_{n₀ + k}, a_{n₀ + k + 1}}. Since a_{n₀} > 0, it follows from (3) that M > 0, i.e., lim_{n→∞} aₙ = M > 0. Therefore, for ε = M/2, there exists a positive integer m and an increasing sequence of positive integers nᵢ satisfying: m < nᵢ and nᵢ → ∞ as i → ∞, such that aₙ < 3M/2 when n > m, and a_{nᵢ} ≥ M/2 (i = 1, 2, …). Then, we have a_{nᵢ}/(a_{nᵢ + 1} + a_{nᵢ + 2}) > (M/2)/(3M/2 + 3M/2) = 1/6 (i = 1, 2, …), which contradicts condition (1). Hence, the sequence {aₙ} is unbounded.

statement: 33. Let f be an upper semicontinuous function on [a, b]. Prove that there exists x₀ ∈ [a, b] such that f(x₀) = sup_{a ≤ x ≤ b} f(x).
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): From Problem 32 in this chapter, we know that f is bounded above on [a, b]. Let A = sup_{a ≤ x ≤ b} f(x). Suppose f does not attain its supremum A on [a, b], so for all x ∈ [a, b], A - f(x) > 0. Define F(x) = 1/(A - f(x)) for a ≤ x ≤ b. For any x ∈ [a, b], we have lim_{t→x} F(t) = 1/(A - lim_{t→x} f(t)) ≤ 1/(A - f(x)) = F(x), so F is upper semicontinuous on [a, b], hence F is bounded above. Let B be an upper bound for F, i.e., 0 < F(x) = 1/(A - f(x)) < B. Then f(x) < A - 1/B for all x ∈ [a, b], contradicting A = sup_{a ≤ x ≤ b} f(x).

statement: 41. Let f, g be continuous functions on (a, b), and assume that either f or g is decreasing. Suppose that some sequence {xₙ} satisfies f(xₙ) = g(xₙ₋₁) and has a limit point in (a, b). Prove that the equation f(x) = g(x) has a solution in (a, b).
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Assume that f(x) ≠ g(x) for all x ∈ (a, b). Without loss of generality, suppose f(x) > g(x) for all a < x ≤ b. Let x₀ be a limit point of {xₙ}, with x₀ ∈ (a, b), and let {x_{n_k}} be a subsequence such that lim_{k→∞} x_{n_k} = x₀. Since g(x₀) < f(x₀), there exists a positive integer p such that for all k₁, k₂ ≥ p, we have g(x_{n_{k₁}}) < f(x_{n_{k₂}}) — (1). On the other hand, for some positive integer m, n_{p+1} = n_p + m, we have f(x_{n_{p+1}}) = g(x_{n_{p+1}-1}) < f(x_{n_{p+1}-1}) = g(x_{n_{p+1}-2}) < … < g(x_{n_p}), contradicting (1). Therefore, the equation f(x) = g(x) must have a solution in (a, b).

statement: 42. Prove that there is no continuous function from ℝ to ℝ that is one-to-one on the irrationals but not one-to-one everywhere.
rationale: One can construct a continuous function from ℝ to ℝ that is one-to-one on the rationals but not one-to-one everywhere (see [79], p. 59). It is natural to ask: Can the role of the rationals be replaced by the irrationals? White [78] showed that this is impossible. Proof (by contradiction): Suppose such a continuous function f exists. Since f is not one-to-one everywhere, there exist rational numbers a < b such that f(a) = f(b) = h. The set A = {x ∈ [a, b] : f(x) = h} is not dense in [a, b], otherwise f would be constant on [a, b]. So there exist points a' < b' in A such that no other point of A lies in (a', b'). By the Intermediate Value Theorem, f((a', b')) consists entirely of values greater than h or less than h. Suppose the former (the latter case is similar), then f([a', b']) = [h, f(m)] where h < f(m), m ∈ (a', b'). Therefore, f([a', m]) = f([m, b']) = [h, f(m)]. Since f is one-to-one on the irrationals, f must map the irrationals in [a', m] onto the rationals in [m, b'], which is impossible because an uncountable set cannot be mapped injectively into a countable set.

statement: 43. Let f be a continuous function on the interval [a, b]. Prove that if f attains a local extremum at every point of [a, b], then f must be constant.
7. Let f be differentiable on the bounded interval (a, b). Prove that if f is unbounded on (a, b), then f′ is also unbounded on (a, b); the converse is not true.
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose there exists a constant M such that |f′(x)| ≤ M for all x ∈ (a, b). Choose c ∈ (a, b). Then for any x ∈ (a, b), |f(x) - f(c)| = |f′(ξ)||x - c| ≤ M(b - a), where ξ lies between c and x. Since |f(x) - f(c)| ≥ |f(x)| - |f(c)|, we get |f(x)| ≤ |f(c)| + M(b - a), contradicting the assumption that f is unbounded on (a, b). Therefore, f′ must also be unbounded on (a, b).

statement: 15. Let f be continuous on the closed bounded interval [a, b], and let g be differentiable with g(a) = 0 and λ ≠ 0 a constant. Prove that if |g(x)f(x) + λg'(x)| ≤ |g(x)|, then g ≡ 0 ([22], 1968, pp. 417–418).
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose g ≠ 0. Then there exists a subinterval (c, d) ⊂ (a, b) where g ≠ 0 and g(c) = 0. On (c, d), we have |f(x) + λg'(x)/g(x)| ≤ 1. Let h(x) = ln|g(x)|, then |f(x) + λh'(x)| ≤ 1. However, lim_{x→c} h(x) = -∞, and since (c, d) is bounded, h' must be unbounded on (c, d) (see Problem 7 in this chapter), which contradicts the fact that f is continuous on [a, b], hence bounded on (c, d). Taking a sufficiently large positive integer n₀ such that -2n₀π + π/4 < ln ξ(ε/2), and noting that lim_{x→0+} ln ξ(x) = -∞, we find δ ∈ (0, ε/2) such that ln ξ(δ) < -2n₀π + π/4. Since ln ξ(x) is continuous on [δ, ε/2], there exists x₀ ∈ (δ, ε/2) such that ln ξ(x₀) = -2n₀π + π/4. Then sin(ln x₀) = √2 sin(-2n₀π + π/4 + ln ξ(x₀)) = √2, which is impossible. Hence, ξ(x) is not continuous on (0, ε).

statement: 24. Let f be twice differentiable on [a, b], with f'(x) ≥ 0 and f''(x) ≥ 0 for all x ∈ [a, b], and suppose that f is not identically zero on any subinterval of [a, b]. Prove that the equation f'(x) = 0 has at most one root in [a, b].
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose there exist x₁, x₂ ∈ [a, b] with x₁ < x₂ such that f'(x₁) = f'(x₂) = 0. By Rolle's Theorem, there exists c ∈ (x₁, x₂) such that f''(c) = 0. But f''(x) ≥ 0 on [a, b], so f' is non-decreasing. If f'(x) = 0 on [x₁, c], then f is constant on [x₁, c], contradicting the assumption. Otherwise, there exists c₁ ∈ (x₁, c) such that f'(c₁) < 0, implying that f is strictly decreasing on [x₁, c₁], contradicting f'(x) ≥ 0. Therefore, the equation f'(x) = 0 has at most one root in [a, b].

statement: 29. Let f be continuous on [a, b] and differentiable in (a, b), with f(x) > 0 for a < x < b. Prove that there does not exist a constant M ≥ 0 such that |f'(x)/f(x)| ≤ M for all a < x < b.
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose there exists M ≥ 0 such that |f'(x)/f(x)| ≤ M for all a < x < b. Define g(x) = ln f(x) for a < x < b. For any x ∈ (a, b), by the Mean Value Theorem, there exists ξ between x₀ and x such that g(x) - g(x₀) = g'(ξ)(x - x₀). Thus, |g(x)| ≤ |g(x₀)| + M(b - a), so g is bounded on (a, b). However, since f is continuous on [a, b], f(a) = 0, and f(x) > 0 for a < x < b, we have lim_{x→a+0} g(x) = -∞, which implies g is unbounded on (a, b), a contradiction.

statement: 11. Let f be integrable on [a, b] and suppose ∫_a^b f(x) dx > 0. Prove that there exists an interval [α, β] ⊂ [a, b] such that f(x) > 0 for all x ∈ [α, β].
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose otherwise. Then for every subinterval [α, β] ⊂ [a, b], there exists a point ξ such that f(ξ) ≤ 0. For any partition T of [a, b], we can choose points ξ_i in each subinterval such that f(ξ_i) ≤ 0. By the integrability of f, ∫_a^b f(x) dx = lim_{max Δx_i → 0} ∑ f(ξ_i)Δx_i ≤ 0, contradicting the assumption that the integral is positive.

statement: 24. Let f be continuous on [a, b], and suppose that for every continuous function φ on [a, b] satisfying ∫_a^b φ(x) dx = 0, it holds that ∫_a^b f(x)φ(x) dx = 0. Prove that f must be constant.
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose f is not constant. Then there exist x₀, x₁ ∈ (a, b) such that f(x₀) > f(x₁). By continuity, there exists δ > 0 such that inf_{x ∈ (x₀ - δ, x₀ + δ)} f(x) > sup_{x ∈ (x₁ - δ, x₁ + δ)} f(x). Define φ₀(x) and φ₁(x) as piecewise quadratic functions supported on these intervals. Set φ(x) = φ₀(x) - φ₁(x). Then ∫_a^b φ(x) dx = 0, but ∫_a^b f(x)φ(x) dx > 0, a contradiction.

statement: 31. Let f be continuous on [a, b], and suppose that for every subinterval [α, β] ⊂ [a, b], ∫_α^β |f(x)| dx ≤ M(β - α)^{1+δ} (M > 0, δ > 0). Prove that f(x) ≡ 0.
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose there exists ξ ∈ [a, b] such that f(ξ) ≠ 0. Assume without loss of generality that f(ξ) > 0. Since f is continuous, there exists an interval [α, β] containing ξ such that f(x) > 0 on [α, β]. Using the Integral Mean Value Theorem and the given inequality, we obtain f(ξₙ) ≤ M(2εₙ)^δ. Taking limits yields f(ξ) ≤ 0, a contradiction.

statement: 1. Let {a_n} be a sequence of positive numbers. Prove that lim_{n→∞} n((1 + a_{n+1})/a_n - 1) ≥ 1. Moreover, the number 1 on the right-hand side cannot be replaced by any larger number.
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose the inequality fails. Then there exists n₀ such that for all n ≥ n₀, n((1 + a_{n+1})/a_n - 1) < 1. This implies 1/(n + 1) < a_n/n - a_{n+1}/(n + 1). Summing over n₀ to n₀ + k - 1 gives a contradiction with the divergence of the harmonic series. To show 1 cannot be improved, take a_n = kn or a_n = n ln n and verify that the limit approaches 1.

statement: 5. Let f_n (n = 1, 2, ...) be continuously differentiable on [a, b], with max_{a ≤ x ≤ b} |f'_n(x)| ≤ M. Suppose {f_n} converges at every point in [a, b]. Prove that {f_n} converges uniformly on [a, b].
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose {f_n} does not converge uniformly to f. Then there exists ε₀ > 0 and sequences {x_n}, {n_k} such that |f_{n_k}(x_n) - f(x_n)| ≥ ε₀. Assume x_n → x₀. Use the Mean Value Theorem and bounded derivatives to bound |f_{n_k}(x_n) - f_{n_k}(x₀)| and |f(x_n) - f(x₀)|, leading to a contradiction with convergence at x₀.

statement: 11. (Dini's Theorem) Let {f_n} be a sequence of continuous functions on [a, b] such that f_n(x) ≤ f_{n+1}(x) for all x ∈ [a, b]. If {f_n} converges to a continuous function f, then the convergence is uniform.
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose {f_n} does not converge uniformly to f. Then there exists ε₀ > 0 and a sequence {x_n} in [a, b] such that |f_n(x_n) - f(x_n)| ≥ ε₀. Extract a convergent subsequence {x_n} → x₀. Use monotonicity and continuity to derive a contradiction.

statement: 13. Suppose each u_n(x) (n = 1, 2, ...) is continuous at x = c, but ∑_{n=1}^{∞} u_n(c) diverges. Prove that for any δ > 0, the series ∑_{n=1}^{∞} u_n(x) does not converge uniformly on (c, c + δ).
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose ∑ u_n(x) converges uniformly on (c, c + δ). Then for any ε > 0, there exists n₀ such that for all n > n₀ and p ≥ 1, |∑_{k=n+1}^{n+p} u_k(x)| < ε for all x ∈ (c, c + δ). Letting x → c gives uniform convergence at c, contradicting divergence at c.

statement: 5. Let z = f(x, y) be defined on D = {(x, y): 0 ≤ x ≤ 1, 0 ≤ y ≤ 1}, and suppose f(x, y) is continuous at (x₀, 0) for every x₀ ∈ [0, 1]. Prove that there exists δ > 0 such that f is bounded on D* = {(x, y): 0 ≤ x ≤ 1, 0 ≤ y ≤ δ}.
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose no such δ exists. Then for each n, there exists (x_n, y_n) ∈ D_n = {(x, y): 0 ≤ x ≤ 1, 0 ≤ y ≤ 1/n} such that |f(x_n, y_n)| > n. Extract a convergent subsequence (x_{n_k}, y_{n_k}) → (x₀, 0). Then f(x_{n_k}, y_{n_k}) → f(x₀, 0), contradicting |f(x_{n_k}, y_{n_k})| > n_k.

statement: 6. Let the bounded sequence z_n = (x_n, y_n) (n = 1, 2, ...) satisfy lim_{n→∞} ||z_n|| = l, limsup_{n→∞} ||z_n|| = L, and lim_{n→∞} ||z_{n+1} - z_n|| = 0. Prove that for any μ with l < μ < L, the circle x² + y² = μ² contains at least one cluster point of {z_n}.
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose there exists μ₀ ∈ (l, L) such that the circle x² + y² = μ₀² contains no cluster points of {z_n}. Then there exists δ > 0 such that the annulus (μ₀ - δ)² < x² + y² < μ₀² contains no points of {z_n}. But then we can construct infinitely many n such that ||z_n|| < μ₀ - δ and ||z_{n+1}|| > μ₀, implying ||z_{n+1} - z_n|| > δ, contradicting the assumption.

statement: 6. Prove that the functional equation f(x, y) = 1 + ∫₀^x ∫₀^y f(u, v) dudv has at most one continuous solution on 0 ≤ x ≤ 1, 0 ≤ y ≤ 1.
rationale: Proof (by contradiction): Suppose there are two continuous solutions h₁ and h₂. Let h = h₁ - h₂. Then h satisfies h(x, y) = ∫₀^x ∫₀^y h(u, v) dudv. Let M_p = max_{0 ≤ x,y ≤ p} |h(x, y)|. Then M_p ≤ M_p p², implying M_p ≤ 0. Hence h(x, y) ≤ 0. A symmetric argument gives h(x, y) ≥ 0, so h(x, y) = 0, proving uniqueness.

statement: Two circles that touch each other at a single point cannot have the same center if one circle is inside the other.
rationale: If the two [[Definition:Circle|circles]] are outside one another, the result is trivial. This proof will focus on the situation where one [[Definition:Circle|circle]] is inside the other one. Let $ABC$ and $CDE$ be [[Definition:Circle|circles]] which touch one another at $C$, such that $CDE$ is inside $ABC$. Assume they had the same [[Definition:Center of Circle|center]] $F$. Join $FC$ and let $FB$ be drawn at random through $E$. As $F$ is the [[Definition:Center of Circle|center]] of $ABC$, by {{EuclidDefLink|I|15|Circle}}, we have that $FB = FC$. Similarly, as $F$ is also the [[Definition:Center of Circle|center]] of $CDE$, we have that $FC = FE$. But they are clearly unequal by the method of construction. So from this [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]], the two [[Definition:Circle|circles]] can not have the same [[Definition:Center of Circle|center]]. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|6|III}}

statement: The square root of 2 is irrational.
rationale: First we note that, from [[Parity of Integer equals Parity of its Square]], if an [[Definition:Integer|integer]] is [[Definition:Even Integer|even]], its [[Definition:Square Root|square root]], if an [[Definition:Integer|integer]], is also [[Definition:Even Integer|even]]. Thus it follows that: :$(1): \quad 2 \divides p^2 \implies 2 \divides p$ where $2 \divides p$ indicates that $2$ is a [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisor]] of $p$. Assume that $\sqrt 2$ is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]]. So: :$\sqrt 2 = \dfrac p q$ for some $p, q \in \Z$, and: :$\gcd \set {p, q} = 1$ where $\gcd$ denotes the [[Definition:Greatest Common Divisor|greatest common divisor]]. Squaring both sides yields: :$2 = \dfrac {p^2} {q^2} \iff p^2 = 2 q^2$ Therefore from $(1)$: :$2 \divides p^2 \implies 2 \divides p$ That is, $p$ is an [[Definition:Even Integer|even integer]]. So $p = 2 k$ for some $k \in \Z$. Thus: :$2 q^2 = p^2 = \paren {2 k}^2 = 4 k^2 \implies q^2 = 2 k^2$ so by the same reasoning: :$2 \divides q^2 \implies 2 \divides q$ This contradicts our assumption that $\gcd \set {p, q} = 1$, since $2 \divides p, q$. Therefore, from [[Proof by Contradiction]], $\sqrt 2$ cannot be [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]]. {{qed}}

statement: Given a strict ordering $\prec$, its reflexive closure $\preceq$ defines an ordering where elements $a$ and $b$ are incomparable, the transitive closure of a relation $\prec'$, denoted as $\prec'^+$, is a strict ordering.
rationale:
First, note that since $\prec$ is a [[Definition:Strict Ordering|strict ordering]], $\preceq$ is an [[Definition:Ordering|ordering]] by [[Reflexive Closure of Strict Ordering is Ordering]]. === $a$ and $b$ are $\preceq$-incomparable === Suppose that $a \preceq b$. By the definition of [[Definition:Reflexive Closure|reflexive closure]], either $a \prec b$ or $a = b$. Each possibility contradicts one of the premises, so $a 
ot \preceq b$. For the same reasons, $b 
ot \preceq a$. {{qed|lemma}} === $\prec'^+$ is antireflexive === Let $p \in S$. Then by the definition of [[Definition:Strict Ordering|strict ordering]]: $p 
ot\prec p$. Suppose that $p \preceq a$ and $b \preceq p$. Then since $\preceq$ is [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]], $b \preceq a$, contradicting the fact that $a$ and $b$ are [[Definition:Non-Comparable|$\preceq$-incomparable]]. Since neither $p \prec p$ nor $\paren {p \preceq a \land \paren {b \preceq p}$ holds: :$p 
ot \prec'^+ p$. Since this is the case for all $p \in S$, $\prec'^+$ is [[Definition:Antireflexive Relation|antireflexive]]. {{qed|lemma}} === $\prec'^+$ is transitive === Let $p \prec'^+ q$ and $q \prec'^+ r$. Then there are three possibilities: $(1): \quad p \prec q$ and $p \prec r$ Because $\prec$ is [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]]: :$p \prec r$ Thus: :$p \prec'^+ r$ $(2): \quad p \prec q$, $q \preceq a$, and $b \preceq r$ By [[Extended Transitivity]], $p \prec a$. Since $p \prec a$ and $b \prec r$: :$p \prec'^+ r$ $(3): \quad p \preceq a$, $b \preceq q$, and $q \prec r$ By [[Extended Transitivity]]: :$b \prec r$ Therefore: :$b \preceq r$ Since $p \preceq a$ and $b \preceq r$: : $p \prec'^+ r$ Note that it is impossible to have $p \preceq a$, $b \preceq q$, $q \preceq a$ and $b \preceq r$. If that were so, $b \preceq q$ and $q \preceq a$ together would imply by transitivity that $b \preceq a$. But this contradicts the fact that $a$ and $b$ are [[Definition:Non-Comparable|$\preceq$-incomparable]]. Thus in all cases, $p \prec'^+ q$ and $q \prec'^+ r$ imply $p \prec'^+ r$, so $\prec'^+$ is [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]]. {{qed|lemma}} Since $\prec'^+$ is [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive]] and [[Definition:Antireflexive Relation|antireflexive]], it is by definition a [[Definition:Strict Ordering|strict ordering]]. === $\prec'^+$ is the transitive closure of $\prec'$ === First note that $\prec'$ is a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $\prec'^+$: If $p \prec' q$ then either :$p \prec q$ or :$p = a$ and $q = b$ If $p \prec q$ then $p \prec'^+ q$ by definition. If $p = a$ and $q = b$, then $p \preceq a$ and $q \preceq b$ by the definition of $\preceq$. Thus $p \prec'^+ q$ by the definition of $\preceq'^+$. Let $\mathcal R$ be a [[Definition:Transitive Relation|transitive relation]] [[Definition:Subset|containing]] $\prec'$. Let $p, q \in S$ and let $p \prec'^+ q$. Then either: :$p \prec q$ or :$p \preceq a$ and $b \preceq q$ If $p \prec q$, then by the definition of [[Definition:Subset|subset]], $p \mathrel {\mathcal R} q$. Suppose instead that $p \preceq a$ and $b \preceq q$. By the definition of $\preceq'$, $a \preceq' b$. Since [[Reflexive Closure is Closure Operator]], it is [[Definition:Increasing Mapping|increasing]], so $\preceq \subseteq \mathcal R^=$. Thus $p \mathrel {\mathcal R}^= a$, $a \mathrel {\mathcal R}^= b$, and $b \mathrel {\mathcal R}^= q$. Since $\mathcal R$ is transitive, $\mathcal R^=$ is as well, by [[Reflexive Closure of Transitive Relation is Transitive]]. Thus $p \mathrel {\mathcal R}^= q$. Since $\preceq'^+$ is [[Definition:Antireflexive Relation|antireflexive]] and we assumed $p \preceq'^+ q$, we conclude that $p 
e q$. Thus by the definition of [[Definition:Reflexive Closure|reflexive closure]]: :$p \mathrel {\mathcal R} q$ Thus we have shown that $\preceq'^+$ is a subset of $\mathcal R$. Since this holds when $\mathcal R$ is any transitive superset of $\preceq'$, $\preceq'^+$ is the [[Definition:Transitive Closure (Relation Theory)/Smallest Transitive Superset|transitive closure]] of $\preceq'$. {{qed}}

statement: The product of two primitive polynomials over the integers is also a primitive polynomial.
rationale: Let $f$ and $g$ be as follows: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = f | r = \sum_{k \mathop \in \Z} a_k X^k }} {{eqn | l = g | r = \sum_{k \mathop \in \Z} b_k X^k }} {{end-eqn}} From the definition of [[Definition:Primitive Polynomial (Ring Theory)|primitive polynomial]], the [[Definition:Polynomial Coefficient|coefficients]] of $f$ and $g$ are all [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. From the definition of [[Definition:Multiplication of Polynomial Forms|polynomial product]]: :$\displaystyle f g = \sum_{k \mathop \in \Z} c_k \mathbf X^k$ where: :$\displaystyle c_k = \sum_{\substack {p \mathop + q \mathop = k \\ p, q \mathop \in \Z}} a_p b_q$ it is clear that the [[Definition:Polynomial Coefficient|coefficients]] of $f g$ are also all [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. {{AimForCont}} $f g$ is not [[Definition:Primitive Polynomial (Ring Theory)|primitive]]. Then its [[Definition:Polynomial Coefficient|coefficients]] must have a [[Definition:Greatest Common Divisor of Integers|GCD]] greater than $1$. Therefore there exists some [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] $p$ which [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divides]] all the [[Definition:Polynomial Coefficient|coefficients]] of $fg$. Now $p$ can not [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divides]] all the [[Definition:Polynomial Coefficient|coefficients]] of either $f$ or $g$, because they are [[Definition:Primitive Polynomial (Ring Theory)|primitive polynomials]]. So: :Let $i$ be the smallest [[Definition:Integer|integer]] such that $p$ does not [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divide]] $a_i$ :Let $j$ be the smallest [[Definition:Integer|integer]] such that $p$ does not [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divide]] $b_j$. Consider the [[Definition:Polynomial Coefficient|coefficient]] $c_{i+j}$ of $f g$: :$\displaystyle c_{i + j} = \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^{i + j} a_k b_{i + j - k} = a_0 b_{i + j} + a_1 b_{i + j - 1} + \cdots + a_i b_j + \cdots + a_{i + j - 1} b_1 + a_{i + j} b_0$ From the assumption, it follows that $p \divides c_{i + j}$, and so: :$\displaystyle p \divides \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^{i + j} a_k b_{i + j - k}$ where $\divides$ denotes [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisibility]]. Also, from the choice of $i$ and $j$, we have: :$p \divides a_m$ whenever $m < i$ :$p \divides b_n$ whenever $n < j$. Now all the terms of $\displaystyle \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^{i + j} a_k b_{i + j - k}$, except for $a_i b_j$, contain a [[Definition:Divisor of Ring Element|factor]] from either $\set {a_0, a_1, \ldots, a_{i - 1} }$ or $\set {b_0, b_1, \ldots, b_{j - 1} }$. It follows that we have: :$p \divides \paren {\displaystyle \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^{i - 1} a_k b_{i + j - k} + \sum_{k \mathop = i + 1}^{i + j} a_k b_{i + j - k} }$ But then, as also $p \divides c_{i + j}$, it follows that $p \divides a_i b_j$ as well. From [[Euclid's Lemma for Prime Divisors]], $p$ has to [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divide]] one or the other. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the definition of $i$ and $j$. So $i$ and $j$ cannot both exist. It follows that $p$ [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divides]] at least one of $f$ and $g$, one of which is therefore not [[Definition:Primitive Polynomial (Ring Theory)|primitive]]. From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], we conclude that $f g$ must be [[Definition:Primitive Polynomial (Ring Theory)|primitive]]. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: If set $S$ is a subset of set $T$, then the complement of $T$ is a subset of the complement of $S$.
rationale: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = S       | o = \subseteq       | r = T       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadstoandfrom       | l = (x \in S        | o = \implies       | r = x \in T)       | c = {{Defof|Subset}} }} {{eqn | ll= \leadstoandfrom       | l = (x \notin T       | o = \implies       | r = x \notin S)       | c = [[Rule of Transposition]] }} {{eqn | ll= \leadstoandfrom       | l = (x \in \map \complement T       | o = \implies       | r = x \in \map \complement S)       | c = {{Defof|Set Complement}} }} {{eqn | l = \map \complement T       | o = \subseteq       | r = \map \complement S       | c = {{Defof|Subset}} }} {{end-eqn}} {{qed}}

statement: If $x$ is an element of $y$, and both $x$ and $y$ are ordinals, then the successor of $x$, $x^+$, is an element of the successor of $y$, $y^+$. In other words, if $x \in y$ where $x$ and $y$ are ordinals, then $x^+ \in y^+$.
rationale:
First note that by [[Successor Set of Ordinal is Ordinal]], $x^+$ and $y^+$ are [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]]. By [[Ordinal Membership is Trichotomy]], one of the following must be true: : $x^+ = y^+$ : $y^+ \in x^+$ : $x^+ \in y^+$ We will show that the first two are both false, so that the third must hold. Two preliminary facts: {{begin-axiom}} {{axiom |n = 1         |t = $x 
e y$         |rc = $x \in y$ and [[Ordinal is not Element of Itself]] }} {{axiom |n = 2         |t = $y 
otin x$         |rc = $x \in y$ and [[Ordinal Membership is Asymmetric]] }} {{end-axiom}} By $(1)$ and [[Equality of Successors]]: : $x^+ ≠ y^+$ Thus the first of the three possibilities is false. Suppose [[Proof by Contradiction|for the sake of contradiction]] that $y^+ \in x^+$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn |o =       |r = y \in y^+       |c = Definition of [[Definition:Successor Set|successor set]] }} {{eqn |o = \implies       |r = y \in x^+       |c = $y^+ \in x^+$ and $x^+$ is an [[Definition:Ordinal/Definition 1|ordinal]] and therefore [[Definition:Transitive Set|transitive]]. }} {{eqn |o = \implies       |r = y \in x \lor y = x       |c = Definition of [[Definition:Successor Set|successor set]] }} {{end-eqn}} But we already know that $y 
otin x$ by $(2)$ and $y 
e x$ by $(1)$, so this is a contradiction, and we conclude that $y^+ 
otin x^+$. Thus we have shown that the second possibility is false. Thus the third and final one must hold: $x^+ \in y^+$. {{qed}}

statement: If $x \in y$ where $x$ and $y$ are ordinals, then the successor of $x$, denoted as $x^+$, is an element of the successor of $y$, denoted as $y^+$.
rationale:
First note that by [[Successor Set of Ordinal is Ordinal]], $x^+$ and $y^+$ are [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]]. By [[Ordinal Membership is Trichotomy]], one of the following must be true: : $x^+ = y^+$ : $y^+ \in x^+$ : $x^+ \in y^+$ We will show that the first two are both false, so that the third must hold. Two preliminary facts: {{begin-axiom}} {{axiom |n = 1         |t = $x 
e y$         |rc = $x \in y$ and [[Ordinal is not Element of Itself]] }} {{axiom |n = 2         |t = $y 
otin x$         |rc = $x \in y$ and [[Ordinal Membership is Asymmetric]] }} {{end-axiom}} By $(1)$ and [[Equality of Successors]]: : $x^+ ≠ y^+$ Thus the first of the three possibilities is false. Suppose [[Proof by Contradiction|for the sake of contradiction]] that $y^+ \in x^+$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn |o =       |r = y \in y^+       |c = Definition of [[Definition:Successor Set|successor set]] }} {{eqn |o = \implies       |r = y \in x^+       |c = $y^+ \in x^+$ and $x^+$ is an [[Definition:Ordinal/Definition 1|ordinal]] and therefore [[Definition:Transitive Set|transitive]]. }} {{eqn |o = \implies       |r = y \in x \lor y = x       |c = Definition of [[Definition:Successor Set|successor set]] }} {{end-eqn}} But we already know that $y 
otin x$ by $(2)$ and $y 
e x$ by $(1)$, so this is a contradiction, and we conclude that $y^+ 
otin x^+$. Thus we have shown that the second possibility is false. Thus the third and final one must hold: $x^+ \in y^+$. {{qed}}

statement: For any set $S$, there does not exist a surjective function from $S$ to its power set $\mathcal{P}(S)$.
rationale:
Let $S$ be a [[Definition:Set|set]]. Let $\mathcal P \left({S}ight)$ be the [[Definition:Power Set|power set]] of $S$. Let $f: S 	o \mathcal P \left({S}ight)$ be a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]]. Let $T = \left\{{x \in S: 
eg \left({x \in f \left({x}ight)}ight)}ight\}$. Then $T \subseteq S$, so $T \in \mathcal P \left({S}ight)$ by the definition of [[Definition:Power Set|power set]]. We will show that $T$ is not in the [[Definition:Image of Mapping|image]] of $f$ and therefore $f$ is not [[Definition:Surjection|surjective]]. Aiming for a [[Proof by Contradiction|contradiction]], suppose that: : $\exists a \in S: T = f \left({a}ight)$ Suppose that: : $a \in f \left({a}ight)$ Then by the definition of $T$: : $
eg \left({a \in T}ight)$ Thus since $T = f \left({a}ight)$: : $
eg \left({a \in f \left({a}ight) }ight)$ By [[Rule of Implication]]: : $(1) \quad a \in f \left({a}ight) \implies 
eg \left({ a \in f \left({a}ight) }ight)$ Suppose instead that: : $
eg \left({a \in f \left({a}ight)}ight)$ Then by the definition of $T$: : $a \in T$ Thus since $T = f \left({a}ight)$: : $a \in f \left({a}ight)$ By [[Rule of Implication]]: : $(2) \quad 
eg \left({ a \in f \left({a}ight) }ight) \implies a \in f \left({a}ight)$ By [[Non-Equivalence of Proposition and Negation/Formulation 1|Non-Equivalence of Proposition and Negation]], applied to $(1)$ and $(2)$, this is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. As the specific choice of $a$ did not matter, we derive a contradiction by [[Existential Instantiation]]. Thus by [[Proof by Contradiction]], the supposition that $\exists a \in S: T = f \left({a}ight)$ must be false. It follows that $f$ is not a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]]. {{qed}}

statement: The quotient and remainder obtained from dividing integer $a$ by positive integer $b$ are unique.
rationale: Suppose $q_1, r_1$ and $q_2, r_2$ are two pairs of $q, r$ that satisfy $a = q b + r, 0 \le r < b$. That is: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = a       | r = q_1 b + r_1, 0 \le r_1 < b       | c =  }} {{eqn | l = a       | r = q_2 b + r_2, 0 \le r_2 < b       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} This gives: :$0 = b \paren {q_1 - q_2} + \paren {r_1 - r_2}$ {{AimForCont}} that $q_1 \ne q_2$. {{WLOG}}, suppose that $q_1 > q_2$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = q_1 - q_2       | o = \ge       | r = 1       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = r_2 - r_1       | r = b \left({q_1 - q_2}\right)       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = \ge       | r = b \times 1       | c = as $b > 0$ }} {{eqn | r = b       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = r_2       | o = \ge       | r = r_1 + b       | c =  }} {{eqn | o = \ge       | r = b       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} This [[Proof by Contradiction|contradicts]] the assumption that $r_2 < b$. A similar contradiction follows from the assumption that $q_1 < q_2$. Therefore $q_1 = q_2$ and so $r_1 = r_2$. Thus it follows that $q$ and $r$ are [[Definition:Unique|unique]]. {{qed}}

statement: An element belongs to the limit superior of a sequence of sets if and only if it belongs to infinitely many terms of the sequence.
rationale: The corresponding proof:Begin by defining: :$\ds B_n := \bigcup_{j \mathop = n}^\infty E_j$ Then by [[Definition:Limit Superior of Sequence of Sets/Definition 1|definition 1]]: :$\ds \limsup_{n \to \infty} E_n = \bigcap_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty B_n$ === First Direction === Let $x$ belong to $E_i$ for [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinitely]] many $i \in \N$. Let $\map \phi n$ be the [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] consisting of these [[Definition:Natural Number|numbers]] in increasing order. Then for any [[Definition:Natural Number|number]] $k$, there exists a [[Definition:Natural Number|number]] $a$ such that $\map \phi a \ge k$. Hence: :$\ds x \in E_{\map \phi a} \subseteq \bigcup_{j \mathop = k}^\infty E_j = B_k$ Since $k$ was arbitrary, it follows that $x \in B_n$ for each $n$. So: :$\ds x \in \limsup_{n \mathop \to \infty} E_n$ === Second Direction === Let: :$\ds x \in \bigcap_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty B_n$ {{AimForCont}} $x$ occurs in only [[Definition:Finite Set|finitely]] many $E_i$. Then there is a largest value of $i$ (call it $i_0$) for which the membership holds. Hence: :$x \notin \paren {E_{i_0 + 1} \cup E_{i_0 + 2} \cup \ldots} = B_{i_0 + 1}$ Therefore: :$\ds x \notin \bigcap_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty B_n$ This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] our assumption about $x$. Hence $x$ belongs to [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinitely]] many [[Definition:Term of Sequence|terms]] of the [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]]. {{qed}}

statement: The number $\pi$ is irrational.
rationale: {{AimForCont}} $\pi$ is [[Definition:Rational Number|rational]]. Then from [[Existence of Canonical Form of Rational Number]]: :$\exists a \in \Z, b \in \Z_{>0}: \pi = \dfrac a b$ Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$. We define the [[Definition:Real Polynomial Function|polynomial function]]: :$\forall x \in \R: \map f x = \dfrac {x^n \paren {a - b x}^n} {n!}$ We [[Definition:Differentiation|differentiate]] this $2 n$ times, and then we build: :$\displaystyle \map F x = \sum_{j \mathop = 0}^n \paren {-1}^j \map {f^{\paren {2 j} } } x = \map f x + \cdots + \paren {-1}^j \map {f^{\paren {2 j} } } x + \cdots + \paren {-1}^n \map {f^{\paren {2 n} } } x$ That is, $\map F x$ is the alternating sum of $f$ and its first $n$ [[Definition:Even Integer|even]] [[Definition:Derivative|derivatives]]. First we show that: :$(1): \quad \map F 0 = \map F \pi$ From the definition of $\map f x$, and our supposition that $\pi = \dfrac a b$, we have that: :$\forall x \in \R: \map f x = b^n \dfrac {x^n \paren {\pi - x}^n} {n!} = \map f {\pi - x}$ Using the [[Chain Rule for Derivatives]], we can apply the [[Principle of Mathematical Induction]] to show that, for all the above [[Definition:Derivative|derivatives]]: :$\forall x \in \R: \map {f^{\paren j} } x = \paren {-1}^j \map {f^{\paren j} } {\pi - x}$ In particular, we have: :$\forall j \in \set {1, 2, \ldots, n}: \map {f^{\paren {2 j} } } 0 = \map {f^{\paren {2 j} } } \pi$ From the definition of $F$, it follows that: :$\map F 0 = \map F \pi$ Next we show that: :$(2): \quad \map F 0$ is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]. We use the [[Binomial Theorem]] to expand $\paren {a - b x}^n$: :$\displaystyle \paren {a - b x}^n = \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^n \binom n k a^{n - k} \paren {-b}^k x^k$ By substituting $j = k + n$, we obtain the following expression for $f$: :$\displaystyle \map f x = \frac 1 {n!} \sum_{j \mathop = n}^{2 n} \binom n {j - n} a^{2 n - j} \paren {-b}^{j - n} x^j$ Note the following: :The coefficients of $x^0, x^1, \ldots, x^{n - 1}$ are all zero :The [[Definition:Degree (Polynomial)|degree]] of the polynomial $f$ is at most $2 n$. So we have: :$\forall j < n: \map {f^{\paren j} } 0 = 0$ :$\forall j > 2 n: \map {f^{\paren j} } 0 = 0$ But for $n \le j \le 2 n$, we have: :$\map {f^{\paren j} } 0 = \dfrac {j!} {n!} \dbinom n {j - n} a^{2 n - j} \paren {-b}^{j - n}$ Because $j \ge n$, it follows that $\dfrac {j!} {n!}$ is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]. So is the [[Definition:Binomial Coefficient|binomial coefficient]] $\dbinom n {j - n}$ by its very nature. As $a$ and $b$ are both [[Definition:Integer|integers]], then so are $a^{2 n - j}$ and $\paren {-b}^{j - n}$. So $\map {f^{\paren j} } 0$ is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]] for all $j$, and hence so is $\map F 0$. Next we show that: :$(3): \quad \displaystyle \dfrac 1 2 \int_0^\pi \map f x \sin x \rd x = \map F 0$ As $\map f x$ is a [[Definition:Real Polynomial Function|polynomial function]] of [[Definition:Degree (Polynomial)|degree]] $n$, it follows that $f^{\paren {2 n + 2} }$ is the [[Definition:Null Polynomial over Ring|null polynomial]]. This means: :$F'' + F = f$ Using the [[Product Rule]] and the derivatives of [[Derivative of Sine Function|sine]] and [[Derivative of Cosine Function|cosine]], we get: :$\paren {\map {F'} x \sin x - \map F x \cos x}' = \map f x \sin x$ By the [[Fundamental Theorem of Calculus]], this leads us to: :$\displaystyle \frac 1 2 \int_0^\pi \map f x \sin x \rd x = \frac 1 2 \bigintlimits {\paren {\map {F'} x \sin x - \map F x \cos x} } {x \mathop = 0} {x \mathop = \pi}$ From [[Sine and Cosine are Periodic on Reals]], we have that $\sin 0 = \sin \pi = 0$ and $\cos 0 = - \cos \pi = 1$. So, from $F \left({0}\right) = F \left({\pi}\right)$ (see $(1)$ above), we have: :$\displaystyle \frac 1 2 \int_0^\pi \map f x \sin x \rd x = \map F 0$ The final step: On the [[Definition:Open Real Interval|interval]] $\openint 0 \pi$, we have from [[Sine and Cosine are Periodic on Reals]] that $\sin x > 0$. So from $(2)$ and $(3)$ above, we have that $\map F 0$ is a [[Definition:Positive Integer|positive integer]]. Now, we have that: :$\paren {x - \dfrac \pi 2}^2 = x^2 - \pi x + \paren {\dfrac \pi 2}^2$ and so: :$x \paren {\pi - x} = \paren {\dfrac \pi 2}^2 - \paren {x - \dfrac \pi 2}^2$ Hence: :$\forall x \in \R: x \paren {\pi - x} \le \paren {\dfrac \pi 2}^2$ Also, from [[Real Sine Function is Bounded]], $0 \le \sin x \le 1$ on the interval $\openint 0 \pi$. So, by the definition of $f$: :$\displaystyle \frac 1 2 \int_0^\pi \map f x \sin x \rd x \le \frac {b^n} {n!} \paren {\frac \pi 2}^{2 n + 1}$ But this is smaller than $1$ for large $n$, from [[Radius of Convergence of Power Series over Factorial]]. Hence, for these large $n$, we have $\map F 0 < 1$, by $(3)$. This is impossible for the [[Definition:Strictly Positive Integer|(strictly) positive integer]] $\map F 0$. So our assumption that $\pi$ is rational must have been false. {{qed}}

statement: The sum of the reciprocals of all prime numbers diverges.
rationale: {{AimForCont}} the contrary. If the prime reciprocal series converges then there must exist some $k \in \N$ such that: :$\displaystyle \sum_{n \mathop = k \mathop + 1}^{\infty} \frac 1 {p_n} < \frac 1 2$ Let: :$\displaystyle Q = \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^k {p_i}$ and: :$\displaystyle \map S r = \sum_{i \mathop = 1}^r \frac 1 {1 + i Q}$ Let $\map S {r, j}$ be the sum of all of the terms from $\map S r$ for which $1 + i Q$ has exactly $j$ prime factors. Notice that $1 + i Q$ is coprime with every prime factor in $Q$. Thus every prime factor of $1 + i Q$ where $i = 1, \ldots, r$ falls into some finite sequence of consecutive primes: :$\map P r = \set {p_{k + 1}, p_{k + 2}, \ldots, p_{\map m r} }$ {{explain|What exactly is $\map m r$?}} Notice again that each term of $\map S {r, j}$ occurs at least once in the expansion of: :$\displaystyle \paren {\sum_{n \mathop = k \mathop + 1}^{\map m r} \frac 1 {p_n} }^j < \paren {\sum_{n \mathop = k \mathop + 1}^\infty \frac 1 {p_n} }^j < \paren {\frac 1 2}^j$ and also by [[Sum of Infinite Geometric Sequence]]: :$\displaystyle \map S r = \sum_{j \mathop = 1}^r \map S {r, j} < \sum_{j \mathop = 1}^r \paren {\frac 1 2}^j < 1$ for every $r$. Finally notice that: :$\displaystyle \map S r = \sum_{i \mathop = 1}^r \frac 1 {1 + i Q} > \frac 1 {1 + Q} \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^r \frac 1 n$ which implies that $\map S r$ diverges towards $+\infty$ by [[Harmonic Series is Divergent]], a contradiction. {{qed}}

statement: If for every subset A of S, A equals the preimage under f of its image, then f is an injection.
rationale: Suppose that $f$ is not an [[Definition:Injection|injection]]. Then two [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $S$ map to the same one [[Definition:Element|element]] of $T$. That is: :$\exists a_1, a_2 \in S, b \in T: \map f {a_1} = \map f {a_2} = b$ Let $A = \set {a_1}$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \map {f^\to} A       | r = \set b       | c =  }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = \map {f^\gets} {\map {f^\to} A}       | o = \supseteq       | r = \set {a_1, a_2}       | c = {{Defof|Preimage of Subset under Mapping}} }} {{eqn | ll= \leadsto       | l = \map {f^\gets} {\map {f^\to} A}       | o = \supsetneqq       | r = A       | c = as $A = \set {a_1}$ }} {{end-eqn}} So by the [[Rule of Transposition]]: :$\forall A \in \powerset S: A = \map {\paren {f^\gets \circ f^\to} } A$ implies that $f$ is an [[Definition:Injection|injection]]. {{qed}}

statement: If a straight line is perpendicular to two planes, then the two planes are parallel.
rationale: Let $AB$ be a straight line which is perpendicular to each of the planes $CD$ and $EF$. To prove this, assume the contrary that $CD$ and $EF$ are not parallel. Then, if extended, they will meet at some point. According to Euclid's Proposition XI.3, let the common section of these planes be the straight line $GH$. Let $K$ be any point on $GH$, and join $AK$ and $BK$. Since $AB$ is perpendicular to plane $EF$, by definition it is also perpendicular to the straight line $BK$ within the plane $EF$. Therefore, $\angle ABK$ is a right angle. Similarly, $\angle BAK$ is also a right angle. This means that in triangle $ABK$, there are two angles which are right angles. By Euclid's Proposition I.17, it is impossible for a triangle to have two right angles. Hence, the initial assumption that $CD$ and $EF$ are not parallel leads to a contradiction. Therefore, $CD$ and $EF$ do not meet when produced and are thus parallel according to the definition of parallel planes. {{qed}}

statement: The ratio of the bases of two tetrahedra with the same height is equal to the ratio of the tetrahedra themselves.
rationale: [[File:Euclid-XII-5.png|700px]] Let there be two [[Definition:Tetrahedron|tetrahedra]] of the same [[Definition:Height of Pyramid|height]] whose [[Definition:Base of Pyramid|bases]] are $ABC, DEF$ and whose [[Definition:Apex of Pyramid|apices]] are $G$ and $H$. It is to be demonstrated that the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $\triangle ABC$ to $\triangle DEF$ equals the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of [[Definition:Tetrahedron|tetrahedron]] $ABCG$ to [[Definition:Tetrahedron|tetrahedron]] $DEFH$. Suppose the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $ABCG$ to $DEFH$ is not equal to the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $\triangle ABC$ to $\triangle DEF$. Then the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $\triangle ABC$ to $\triangle DEF$ equals the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $ABCG$ to some [[Definition:Solid Figure|solid figure]] $W$ which is either smaller than $DEFH$ or larger than $DEFH$. First suppose that $W$ is smaller than $DEFH$. From {{EuclidPropLink|book = XII|prop = 3|title = Tetrahedron divided into Two Similar Tetrahedra and Two Equal Prisms}}: :let $DEFH$ be divided into two equal [[Definition:Tetrahedron|tetrahedra]] which are [[Definition:Similar Solid Figures|similar]] to $DEFH$ and two equal [[Definition:Prism|prisms]]. Then the two [[Definition:Prism|prisms]] are greater than half of $DEFH$. Again, let those [[Definition:Tetrahedron|tetrahedra]] be similarly divided. {{EuclidPropLink|book = X|prop = 1|title = Existence of Fraction of Number Smaller than Given}}: :Let this be done continually until there are left over from $DEFH$ some [[Definition:Tetrahedron|tetrahedra]] which are less than the excess by which $DEFH$ is greater than $W$. Let these, for the sake of argument, be $DQRS$ and $STUH$. Therefore their remainders, the [[Definition:Prism|prisms]] in $DEFH$, are greater than $W$. Let $ABCG$ be divided similarly and the same number of times as $DEFH$. From {{EuclidPropLink|book = XII|prop = 4|title = Proportion of Sizes of Tetrahedra divided into Two Similar Tetrahedra and Two Equal Prisms}}: :the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $\triangle ABC$ to $\triangle DEF$ equals the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of the [[Definition:Prism|prisms]] in $ABCG$ to the [[Definition:Prism|prisms]] in $DEFH$. But: :$\triangle ABC : \triangle DEF = ABCG : W$ So from {{EuclidPropLink|book = V|prop = 11|title = Equality of Ratios is Transitive}}: :the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $ABCG$ to $W$ equals the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of the [[Definition:Prism|prisms]] in $ABCG$ to the [[Definition:Prism|prisms]] in $DEFH$. So from {{EuclidPropLink|book = V|prop = 16|title = Proportional Magnitudes are Proportional Alternately}}: :the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $ABCG$ to the [[Definition:Prism|prisms]] in it is equal to the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $W$ to the [[Definition:Prism|prisms]] in $DEFH$. But $ABCG$ is greater than the [[Definition:Prism|prisms]] in it. Therefore $W > DEFG$. But [[Definition:By Hypothesis|by hypothesis]] $W < DEFG$. Therefore it is not the case that the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $\triangle ABC$ to $\triangle DEF$ equals the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $ABCG$ to some [[Definition:Solid Figure|solid figure]] smaller than $DEFH$. Now suppose that the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $\triangle ABC$ to $\triangle DEF$ equals the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $ABCG$ to some [[Definition:Solid Figure|solid figure]] $W$ greater than $DEFH$. Thus: :$\triangle DEF : \triangle ABC = W : ABCG$ But using the same technique as {{EuclidPropLink|book = XII|prop = 2|qual=Lemma|title = Areas of Circles are as Squares on Diameters}}: :$W : ABCG = DEFH : X$ where $X$ is some [[Definition:Solid Figure|solid figure]] less than $ABCG$. Therefore from {{EuclidPropLink|book = V|prop = 11|title = Equality of Ratios is Transitive}}: :$\triangle DEF : \triangle ABC = DEFG : X$ But this has been demonstrated to be absurd. Therefore it is not the case that the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $\triangle ABC$ to $\triangle DEF$ equals the [[Definition:Ratio|ratio]] of $ABCG$ to some [[Definition:Solid Figure|solid figure]] greater than $DEFH$. Hence the result. {{qed}} {{Euclid Note|5|XII}}

statement: The formula $(2mn, m^2 - n^2, m^2 + n^2)$ generates all primitive Pythagorean triples.
rationale: First we show that $\tuple {2 m n, m^2 - n^2, m^2 + n^2}$ is a [[Definition:Pythagorean Triple|Pythagorean triple]]: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = \paren {2 m n}^2 + \paren {m^2 - n^2}^2       | r = 4 m^2 n^2 + m^4 - 2 m^2 n^2 + n^4       | c = }} {{eqn | r = m^4 + 2 m^2 n^2 + n^4       | c = }} {{eqn | r = \paren {m^2 + n^2}^2       | c = }} {{end-eqn}} So $\tuple {2 m n, m^2 - n^2, m^2 + n^2}$ is indeed a [[Definition:Pythagorean Triple|Pythagorean triple]]. Now we establish that $\tuple {2 m n, m^2 - n^2, m^2 + n^2}$ is [[Definition:Primitive Pythagorean Triple|primitive]]: {{AimForCont}} to the contrary, that $\tuple {2 m n, m^2 - n^2, m^2 + n^2}$ is not [[Definition:Primitive Pythagorean Triple|primitive]]. So there is a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime]] [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisor]] $p$ of both $2 m n$ and $m^2 - n^2$. That is: :$p \in \mathbb P: p \divides \paren {2 m n}, p \divides \paren {m^2 - n^2}$ Then from [[Prime Divides Power]]: :$p \divides \paren {2 m n}^2$ and $p \divides \paren {m^2 - n^2}^2$ Hence from [[Common Divisor Divides Integer Combination]]: :$p \divides \paren {m^2 + n^2}^2$ and from [[Prime Divides Power]] again: :$p \divides \paren {m^2 + n^2}$ So from [[Common Divisor Divides Integer Combination]]: :$p \divides \paren {m^2 + n^2} + \paren {m^2 - n^2} = 2 m^2$ :$p \divides \paren {m^2 + n^2} - \paren {m^2 - n^2} = 2 n^2$ But $p \ne 2$ as, because $m$ and $n$ are of [[Definition:Parity of Integer|opposite parity]], $m^2 - n^2$ must be [[Definition:Odd Integer|odd]]. So $p \divides n^2$ and $p \divides m^2$ and so from [[Prime Divides Power]], $p \divides n$ and $p \divides m$. But as we specified that $m \perp n$, this is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. Therefore $\paren {2 m n, m^2 - n^2, m^2 + n^2}$ is [[Definition:Primitive Pythagorean Triple|primitive]]. {{qed|lemma}} Now we need to show that every [[Definition:Primitive Pythagorean Triple|primitive Pythagorean triple]] is of this form: So, suppose that $\tuple {x, y, z}$ is ''any'' [[Definition:Primitive Pythagorean Triple|primitive Pythagorean triple]] given in [[Definition:Pythagorean Triple/Primitive/Canonical Form|canonical form]]. From [[Parity of Smaller Elements of Primitive Pythagorean Triple]], $x$ and $y$ are of opposite [[Definition:Parity of Integer|parity]]. By definition of [[Definition:Pythagorean Triple/Primitive/Canonical Form|canonical form]] $x$ is [[Definition:Even Integer|even]] and $y$ and $z$ are both [[Definition:Odd Integer|odd]]. As $y$ and $z$ are both [[Definition:Odd Integer|odd]], their sum and difference are both [[Definition:Even Integer|even]]. Hence we can define: :$s, t \in Z: s = \dfrac {z + y} 2, t = \dfrac {z - y} 2$. Note that $s \perp t$ as any [[Definition:Common Divisor of Integers|common divisor]] would also divide $s + t = z$ and $s - t = y$, and we know that $z \perp y$ from [[Elements of Primitive Pythagorean Triple are Pairwise Coprime]]. Then from the [[Definition:Pythagorean Equation|Pythagorean equation]]: :$x^2 = z^2 - y^2 = \paren {z + y} \paren {z - y} = 4 s t$ Hence: :$\paren {\dfrac x 2}^2 = s t$ As $x$ is [[Definition:Even Integer|even]], $\dfrac x 2$ is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]] and so $s t$ is a [[Definition:Square Number|square]]. So each of $s$ and $t$ must be square as they are [[Definition:Coprime Integers|coprime]]. Now, we write $s = m^2$ and $t = n^2$ and substitute back: :$x^2 = 4 s t = 4 m^2 n^2$ and so $x = 2 m n$ :$y = s - t = m^2 - n^2$ :$z = m^2 + n^2$ Finally, note that: :$m \perp n$ from $s \perp t$ and [[Prime Divides Power]] :$m$ and $n$ have [[Definition:Parity of Integer|opposite parity]] otherwise $y$ and $z$ would be [[Definition:Even Integer|even]]. Thus, our [[Definition:Primitive Pythagorean Triple|primitive Pythagorean triple]] is of the form $\tuple {2 m n, m^2 - n^2, m^2 + n^2}$. {{qed}}

statement: There are infinitely many prime numbers.
rationale: {{AimForCont}} that there are only $N$ [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]]. Let the [[Definition:Set|set]] of all [[Definition:Prime Number|primes]] be: :$\Bbb P = \set {p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_N}$ By the [[Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic]], every [[Definition:Integer|integer]] $k > 1$ can be expressed in the form: :$k = {p_1}^{a_1} {p_2}^{a_2} \dotsm {p_N}^{a_N}$ Let $n > 1$ be fixed. Let $a$ be the largest [[Definition:Exponent|exponent]] occurring in the [[Definition:Prime Decomposition|prime decomposition]] of all [[Definition:Positive Integer|positive integers]] $k \le n$. Then: :$\displaystyle \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n \frac 1 k \le \prod_{j \mathop = 1}^N \paren {\sum_{k \mathop = 0}^a \frac 1 { {p_j}^k} }$ is expressible in the form: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | n = 1       | l = 1 + \frac 1 2 + \frac 1 3 + \dotsb + \frac 1 n       | o = \le       | r = \paren {1 + \frac 1 {p_1} + \frac 1 { {p_1}^2} + \dotsb + \frac 1 { {p_1}^a} }       | c =  }} {{eqn | o =       | ro= \times       | r = \paren {1 + \frac 1 {p_2} + \frac 1 { {p_2}^2} + \dotsb + \frac 1 { {p_2}^a} }       | c =  }} {{eqn | o =       | ro= \times       | r = \ \dotsb       | c =  }} {{eqn | o =       | ro= \times       | r = \paren {1 + \frac 1 {p_N} + \frac 1 { {p_N}^2} + \dotsb + \frac 1 { {p_N}^a} }       | c =  }} {{end-eqn}} which can be seen by multiplying out the factors on the {{RHS}}. But from [[Sum of Infinite Geometric Sequence]]: :$1 + x + x^2 + \dotsb = \dfrac 1 {1 - x}$ for all $x$ such that $\size x < 1$. Thus the factors in $(1)$ are less than the numbers: :$\dfrac 1 {1 - 1 / p_1}, \dfrac 1 {1 - 1 / p_2}, \dotsb, \dfrac 1 {1 - 1 / p_N}$ and so: :$1 + \dfrac 1 2 + \dfrac 1 3 + \dotsb + \dfrac 1 n < \dfrac {p_1} {p_1 - 1} \dfrac {p_2} {p_2 - 1} \dotsm \dfrac {p_N} {p_N - 1}$ We have chosen $n > 1$ arbitrarily, so this holds for every $n > 1$. This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] the result [[Harmonic Series is Divergent]]. Hence the result, by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: The sum of the reciprocals of the primes diverges.
rationale: {{AimForCont}} the contrary. If the prime reciprocal series converges then there must exist some $k \in \N$ such that: :"$\displaystyle \sum_{n \mathop = k + 1}^\infty \frac 1 {p_n} < \frac 1 2$" Let: :"$\displaystyle M_x = \set {n \in \N: 1 \le n \le x \text { and } n \text { is not divisible by any primes greater than } p_k}$". Notice that: :"$\size {M_x} \le {2^k} \sqrt x$" because if: :"$n = m^2r$" then :"$m \le \sqrt x$" and there are at most $2^k$ distinct non-square prime compositions using primes less than $p_k$. Now let: :"$N_{i, x} = \set {n \in \N: 1 \le n \le x \text{ and } n \text { is divisible by } p_i}$" Notice: :"$\displaystyle \size {\set {1, \dots, x} \setminus M_x} \le \sum_{i \mathop = k + 1}^\infty \size {N_{i, x} } < \sum_{i \mathop = k + 1}^\infty \dfrac x {p_i} \implies \dfrac x 2 < \size {M_x}$" Finally notice that whenever: :"$x \ge 2^{2 k + 2}$" then it cannot be的 case that both: :"$\dfrac x 2 < \size {M_x} \le {2^k} \sqrt x$

statement: If a straight line is perpendicular to two planes, then the two planes are parallel.
rationale: Let $AB$ be a straight line which is perpendicular to each of the planes $CD$ and $EF$. To prove this, assume the contrary that $CD$ and $EF$ are not parallel. Then, if extended, they will meet at some point. According to Euclid's Proposition XI.3, let the common section of these planes be the straight line $GH$. Let $K$ be any point on $GH$, and join $AK$ and $BK$. Since $AB$ is perpendicular to plane $EF$, by definition it is also perpendicular to the straight line $BK$ within the plane $EF$. Therefore, $\angle ABK$ is a right angle. Similarly, $\angle BAK$ is also a right angle. This means that in triangle $ABK$, there are two angles which are right angles. By Euclid's Proposition I.17, it is impossible for a triangle to have two right angles. Hence, the initial assumption that $CD$ and $EF$ are not parallel leads to a contradiction. Therefore, $CD$ and $EF$ do not meet when produced and are thus parallel according to the definition of parallel planes. {{qed}}

statement: There cannot exist integers $j > 0, k, m$ such that $j = \floor {k \cdot r} = \floor {m \cdot s}$ for irrational numbers $r$ and $s$.
rationale: === Collisions === {{AimForCont}} there exist [[Definition:Integer|integers]] $j > 0, k, m$ such that: :$j = \floor {k \cdot r} = \floor {m \cdot s}$ This is equivalent to the inequalities: :$j \le k \cdot r < j + 1$ and: :$j \le m \cdot s < j + 1$ As $r$ and $s$ are [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational]], equality cannot happen. So: :$j < k \cdot r < j + 1$ and: :$j < m \cdot s < j + 1$ which leads to: :$\dfrac j r < k < \dfrac {j + 1} r$ and: :$\dfrac j s < m < \dfrac {j + 1} s$ Adding these together and using the [[Definition:By Hypothesis|by hypothesis]]: :$j < k + m < j + 1$ Thus there is an [[Definition:Integer|integer]] strictly between two adjacent [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. This is impossible. Thus the supposition must be false. {{qed|lemma}}

statement: There cannot exist integers $j > 0, k, m$ satisfying both $k \cdot r < j < (k + 1) \cdot r$ and $m \cdot s < j < (m + 1) \cdot s$ for irrational numbers $r$ and $s$.
rationale: === Anti-collisions === {{AimForCont}} that there exist [[Definition:Integer|integers]] $j > 0, k, m$ such that: :$k \cdot r < j$ and: :$j + 1 \le \paren {k + 1} \cdot r$ and: :$m \cdot s < j$ and: :$j + 1 \le \paren {m + 1} \cdot s$ Since $j + 1 \ne 0$, and $r$ and $s$ are [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational]], equality cannot happen. So: :$k \cdot r < j$ and: :$j + 1 < \paren {k + 1} \cdot r$ and: :$m \cdot s < j$ and: :$j + 1 < \paren {m + 1} \cdot s$ Then: :$k < \dfrac j r$: and: :$\dfrac {j + 1} r < k + 1$ and: :$m < \dfrac j s$ and: :$\dfrac {j + 1} s < m + 1$ Adding corresponding inequalities: :$k + m < j$ and: :$j + 1 < k + m + 2$ :$k + m < j < k + m + 1$ which is also impossible. Thus the supposition is false. {{qed}}

statement: There can be no total order relation on the complex numbers that is compatible with their ring structure.
rationale:
{{AimForCont}} there exists a [[Definition:Endorelation|relation]] $\preceq$ on $\C$ which is [[Definition:Ordering Compatible with Ring Structure|ordering compatible with the ring structure of $\C$]]. That is: :$(1): \quad z 
e 0 \implies 0 \prec z \lor z \prec 0$, but not both :$(2): \quad 0 \prec z_1, z_2 \implies 0 \prec z_1 z_2 \land 0 \prec z_1 + z_2$ By [[Totally Ordered Ring Zero Precedes Element or its Inverse]], $(1)$ can be replaced with: :$(1'): \quad z 
e 0 \implies 0 \prec z \lor 0 \prec -z$, but not both. As $i 
e 0$, it follows that: :$0 \prec i$ or $0 \prec -i$ Suppose $0 \prec i$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = 0 | o = \prec | r = i 	imes i | c = from $(2)$ }} {{eqn | r = -1 | c = {{Defof|Complex Number|index = 1}} }} {{end-eqn}} Otherwise, suppose $0 \prec \paren {-i}$. Then: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = 0 | o = \prec | r = \paren {-i} 	imes \paren {-i} | c = from $(2)$ }} {{eqn | r = -1 | c = {{Defof|Complex Number|index = 1}} }} {{end-eqn}} Thus by [[Proof by Cases]]: :$0 \prec -1$ Thus it follows that: {{begin-eqn}} {{eqn | l = 0 | o = \prec | r = \paren {-1} 	imes \paren {-1} | c = from $(2)$ }} {{eqn | r = 1 | c = }} {{end-eqn}} Thus both: :$0 \prec -1$ and: :$0 \prec 1$ This [[Definition:Contradiction|contradicts]] hypothesis $(1')$: :$(1): \quad z 
e 0 \implies 0 \prec z \lor 0 \prec -z$, but not both Hence, by [[Proof by Contradiction]], there can be no such ordering. {{qed}}

statement: The Russell class cannot be a small class (set).
rationale: Assume that $\mathrm U$ is [[Definition:Small Class|small]]. Note that $\operatorname{Ru} \subseteq \mathrm U$ where $\operatorname{Ru}$ denotes the [[Definition:Russell Class|Russell class]]. By [[Axiom of Subsets Equivalents]], $\operatorname{Ru}$ is also [[Definition:Small Class|small]]. This contradicts [[Russell's Paradox]]. {{qed}}

statement: An absolutely convergent infinite product of terms $(1 + a_n)$ cannot diverge to $0$.
rationale:
By [[Factors in Absolutely Convergent Product Converge to One]], $
orm {a_n} < 1$ for $n \ge n_0$. Let $n_1 \ge n_0$. {{AimForCont}} the product [[Definition:Divergent Product|diverges]] to $0$. Then: :$\displaystyle \prod_{n \mathop = n_1}^\infty \paren {1 + a_n} = 0$ By [[Norm of Limit]]: :$\displaystyle \prod_{n \mathop = n_1}^\infty 
orm {1 + a_n} = 0$ By the [[Triangle Inequality]] and [[Squeeze Theorem]]: :$\displaystyle \prod_{n \mathop = n_1}^\infty \paren {1 - 
orm {a_n} } = 0$ By the [[Weierstrass Product Inequality]], we have for $N \ge n_1$: :$\displaystyle \prod_{n \mathop = n_1}^N \paren {1 - 
orm {a_n} } \ge 1 - \sum_{n \mathop = n_1}^N 
orm{a_n}$ Taking limits: :$0 \ge 1 - \displaystyle \sum_{n \mathop = n_1}^\infty 
orm {a_n}$ Because $\displaystyle \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \paren  {1 + a_n}$ is [[Definition:Absolute Convergence of Product|absolutely convergent]]: :$\displaystyle \sum_{n \mathop = n_1}^\infty 
orm {a_n} < 1$ for $n_1$ [[Definition:Sufficiently Large|sufficiently large]]. This is a [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: If a property $P(x)$ satisfies certain conditions for ordinals, then it holds for all ordinals.
rationale:
It should be noted that for any two [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]], $x \lt y \iff x \in y$. Let $P \left({x}ight)$ be a [[Definition:Propositional Function|property]] that satisfies the above conditions. Aiming for [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]], let $y$ be an [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinal]] such that 
eg P \left({y}ight)$. Let $S$ be the [[Definition:Set|set]] defined as: :$S = \left\{{x \in y^+: 
eg P \left({x}ight)}ight\}$ It is seen that this set is [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] because by [[Set is Element of Successor]]: :$y \in y^+$ $y^+$ is an [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinal]] because of [[Successor Set of Ordinal is Ordinal]]. By [[Element of Ordinal is Ordinal]], $S$ is a set of [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]]. By the [[Rule of Transposition]], it follows that for every $x \in S$, there exists an ordinal $\alpha \lt x \iff \alpha \in x$ such that 
eg P \left({\alpha}ight)$. But by [[Definition:Transitive Class|transitivity]]: :$\alpha \in x \land x \in y^+ \implies \alpha \in y^+$ So the [[Definition:Epsilon Restriction|epsilon restriction]] \in_S is a [[Definition:Right-Total Relation|right-total relation]] on $S$. Therefore by the [[Axiom:Axiom of Dependent Choice|Axiom of Dependent Choice]] there exists a [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] \left\langle{x_n}ightangle_{n \in \N}$ in $S$ such that: :$ orall n \in \N: x_{n+1} \in x_n$ But this contradicts [[No Infinitely Descending Membership Chains]]. And thus $P \left({x}ight)$ holds for all [[Definition:Ordinal|ordinals]]. Hence the result. {{qed}}

statement: The three definitions of an ultrafilter on a set are equivalent.
rationale:
The corresponding proof is divided into three parts showing the equivalence between each pair of definitions. === Definition 1 implies Definition 2 === Let $\mathcal F$ be an [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set/Definition 1|ultrafilter on $S$ by definition 1]]. Thus $\mathcal F \subseteq \mathcal P \left({S}ight)$ is a [[Definition:Filter on Set|filter]] on $S$ which fulfills the condition: :whenever $\mathcal G$ is a [[Definition:Filter on Set|filter]] on $S$ and $\mathcal F \subseteq \mathcal G$ holds, then $\mathcal F = \mathcal G$. Let $A \subseteq S$ and $B \subseteq S$ such that: :$A \cap B = \varnothing$ :$A \cup B \in \mathcal F$ {{AimForCont}} $A 
otin \mathcal F$ and $B 
otin \mathcal F$. Consider the set $\mathcal B := \left\{{V \cap A: V \in \mathcal F}ight\} \cup \left\{{V \cap B: V \in \mathcal F}ight\}$. This is a [[Definition:Filter Basis|basis]] of a [[Definition:Filter on Set|filter]] $\mathcal G$ on $S$, for which $\mathcal F \subseteq \mathcal G$ holds. Let $U \in \mathcal F$. Through a series of logical deductions, it is shown that assuming $A 
otin \mathcal F$ and $B 
otin \mathcal F$ leads to a contradiction, thus either $A \in \mathcal F$ or $B \in \mathcal F$, and so $\mathcal F$ fulfils the conditions to be an [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set/Definition 2|ultrafilter by Definition 2]]. === Definition 2 implies Definition 3 === Let $\mathcal F$ be an [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set/Definition 2|ultrafilter on $S$ by definition 2]]. That is, $\mathcal F \subseteq \mathcal P \left({S}ight)$ is a [[Definition:Filter on Set|filter]] on $S$ which fulfills the condition: : for every $A \subseteq S$ and $B \subseteq S$ such that $A \cap B = \varnothing$ and $A \cup B \in \mathcal F$, either $A \in \mathcal F$ or $B \in \mathcal F$. Using logical steps, it is demonstrated that if $A \subseteq S$, then either $A \in \mathcal F$ or its complement $\complement_S(A) \in \mathcal F$, fulfilling the requirements for an [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set/Definition 3|ultrafilter by Definition 3]]. === Definition 3 implies Definition 1 === Let $\mathcal F$ be an [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set/Definition 3|ultrafilter on $S$ by definition 3]]. Assuming there is a filter $\mathcal G$ containing $\mathcal F$ with an element not in $\mathcal F$ leads to a contradiction, showing that no such $\mathcal G$ can exist and therefore $\mathcal F$ must be maximal, satisfying [[Definition:Ultrafilter on Set/Definition 1|Definition 1]]. {{qed|lemma}}

statement: A particular point space is not meager.
rationale: By definition of [[Definition:Particular Point Topology|particular point space]], any [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$ which contains $p$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] in $T$. {{AimForCont}} $T$ is [[Definition:Meager Space|meager]]. By definition, $T$ is [[Definition:Meager Space|meager]] {{iff}} it is a [[Definition:Countable Union|countable union]] of [[Definition:Subset|subsets]] of $S$ which are [[Definition:Nowhere Dense|nowhere dense]] in $T$. At least one such [[Definition:Nowhere Dense|nowhere dense]] [[Definition:Subset|subset]] $U$ of $S$ must contain $p$. By definition, $U$ is [[Definition:Nowhere Dense|nowhere dense]] in $T$ {{iff}}: :$U^-$ contains no [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open set]] of $T$ which is [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]] where $U^-$ denotes the [[Definition:Closure (Topology)|closure]] of $U$. By definition of [[Definition:Particular Point Topology|particular point space]], $U$ is [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] in $T$. By [[Closure of Open Set of Particular Point Space]], $U^- = S$. But $S$ is itself [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open]] in $T$ and [[Definition:Non-Empty Set|non-empty]], and so $U$ is not [[Definition:Nowhere Dense|nowhere dense]]. From this [[Definition:Contradiction|contradiction]] it follows that $T$ is [[Definition:Non-Meager Space|non-meager]]. {{qed}}

statement: The double pointed topology on an indiscrete space is not a $T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space.
rationale: By definition, the [[Definition:Double Pointed Topology|double pointed topology]] $	au$ on $T_1$ is the [[Definition:Product Topology|product topology]] on $T_1 	imes D$. By definition, $D$ is the [[Definition:Indiscrete Topology|indiscrete space]] on a [[Definition:Doubleton|doubleton]]. {{AimForCont}} $T$ is a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]]. Then from [[Product Space is T0 iff Factor Spaces are T0|Product Space is $T_0$ iff Factor Spaces are $T_0$]] it follows that $D$ is also a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]]. But from [[Indiscrete Non-Singleton Space is not T0|Indiscrete Non-Singleton Space is not $T_0$]], $D$ is not a [[Definition:Kolmogorov Space|$T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space]]. The result follows by [[Proof by Contradiction]]. {{qed}}

statement: A mapping $f: S \to T$ is a surjection if and only if for all $t \in T$, the preimage $f^{-1}(t)$ is non-empty.
rationale:
=== Necessary Condition === We use a [[Proof by Contraposition]]. To that end, suppose: :$\exists t \in T: f^{-1} \paren t = \O$ That is: :$
eg \paren { orall t \in T: \exists s \in S: f \paren s = t}$ So, by definition, $f: S 	o T$ is not a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]]. From [[Rule of Transposition]] it follows that if $f$ is a surjection: $
eg \exists t \in T: f^{-1} \paren t = \O$ {{qed|lemma}} === Sufficient Condition === We again use a [[Proof by Contraposition]]. To that end, suppose $f$ is not a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]]. Then by definition: :$\exists t \in T: 
eg \paren {\exists s \in S: f \paren s = t}$ That is: :$\exists t \in T: f^{-1} \paren t = \O$ From [[Rule of Transposition]] it follows that if $
eg \exists t \in T: f^{-1} \paren t = \O$, then $f$ is a [[Definition:Surjection|surjection]]. {{Qed}}

statement: A relation can be reflexive and symmetric but not transitive.
rationale: [[Proof by Counterexample]]: Let $S = \Z$ be the set of [[Definition:Integer|integers]]. Let $n \in \Z$ such that $n > 1$.
